DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 1, or the 20th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1650: Rene Descartes, French mathematician and philosopher known as the "father of French philosophy," dies at the age of 54. His philosophy is based on the rationalistic premise: "I think, therefore I am."
1893: Thomas Edison, the American inventor who patented more than a thousand inventions, opens the first film studio in West Orange, New Jersey.
1901: Clark Gable, American film actor who became an international heart throb, is born. He played Rhett Butler in "Gone With the Wind."
1902: The Ching dynasty orders the lifting of a ban on marriages between the Manchus and the Chinese.
1913: The first Far Eastern Games are held in Manila, the Philippines, with athletes from the Republic of China, Japan and the host country attending.
1924: Britain recognizes the Communist government of the Soviet Union.
1948: The Bank of Taiwan issues a new edition of the 100-dollar bill.
1950: Deputies of the National Assembly respectfully invite Chiang Kai-shek to succeed acting President Lee Tsung-jen as the president of the Republic of China. Lee remained in the United States following the Nationalist government's retreat to Taiwan after being defeated by the Communists in China's civil war.
1951: The U.N. General Assembly condemns the Chinese Communists as aggressors in Korea.
1952: The U.N. General Assembly finds the Soviet Union guilty of violating the 1945 Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1958: The first U.S. satellite, the Vanguard-1, is successfully launched into orbit.
1963: Taiwan's `king of iron and steel' Tang Jung dies at the age of 83.
1967: President Chiang Kai-shek establishes the National Security Council. Vice Premier Huang Shao-ku is named secretary-general of the organization and Ku Shu-tung is named deputy secretary-general.
1973: One hundred and four members of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan, 20 mayors and magistrates and the 73 members of the fifth Taiwan Provincial Assembly are sworn in.
1974: An economic mission headed by Economic Affairs Vice Minister Chang Kwang-shih leaves for Saudi Arabia for a five-day visit.
1978: The Central Daily News, the oldest newspaper in the country, marks its 50th anniversary.
1979: Iranian religious leader the Ayatollah Khomeini ends 16 years of exile, returning from Paris to a frenzied welcome at Tehran airport.
1980: Taiwan's North Link (Suao-Hualien) Railway is opened with ceremonies in Nanshenghu, near Ilan, and Hualien. The project cost the government NT$7.3 billion and took six years to complete.
1982: Alfred Britain III, chairman of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, opens the bank's branch office in Taipei.
1990: South African President F.W. de Klerk announces the legitimacy of the African National Congress and other political organizations. He also promises the unconditional release of jailed ANC leader Nelson Mandela within two weeks.
1991: An earthquake rocks Pakistan and Afghanistan, killing more than 1,200 people.
1992: U.S. President George Bush and Russian President Boris Yeltsin sign the Camp David declaration stating that their two countries no longer regard each other as adversaries.
1995: Communist Vietnam and the United States begin a new chapter in their relationship by opening liaison offices in each others' capitals.
1995: The World Trade Organization passes a resolution to accept the Republic of China as an observer country.
2000: Premier Vincent Siew presides over a ceremony to unveil the name plaque of the newly established Coast Guard Administration and swear in CGA Director-General Yao Kao-chiao.
2001: Nobel laureate Gao Xingjian, at the invitation of the Taipei City Government's Cultural Affairs Bureau, arrives in Taiwan from Hong Kong.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In my method of teaching, I always wait for my student to make an effort himself to find his way through a difficulty, before I show him the way myself. I also make him find his own illustrations before I give him one of my own. When I have pointed out the bearing of a subject in one direction and found that my student cannot himself see its bearings into other directions, I do not then repeat my lesson."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS LONG-RANGE MISSILES TO DETER PLA ATTACKS: U.S. EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 31 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Washington should seriously consider selling Taiwan long-range attack missiles so it can better deter the growing missile, air and naval forces of mainland China's People's Liberation Army (PLA), a U.S. military strategist said Thursday.

To sustain a sufficient level of deterrence in the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan requires the greater air defense and antisubmarine capabilities of the Kidd class destroyer, as well as the even greater anti-aircraft and potential antimissile capabilities of the Aegis class destroyer, said Richard Fisher Jr., a senior fellow with the private nonprofit Jamestown Foundation.

In his latest article carried in China Brief, a publication of the Jamestown Foundation, Fisher said the purchase by mainland China of two Russian Project 956EM Sovremenny class destroyers, with the contract being signed this Jan. 3 for delivery by 2006, highlights the continuing growth in the PLA's capability of putting military pressure on Taiwan.

It is increasingly apparent that the "center" of the PLA's counter-Taiwan strategy will be its space-missile-air power combine, Fisher noted, pointing out that this might include support from airborne troops, which can decide the outcome of a conflict in a short period of time.

The mainland Chinese naval forces, and especially its growing submarine forces, would be critical in a combined forces effort to stop the U.S. Navy from helping Taiwan. But if Beijing were to try subduing Taiwan by a naval blockade, then ships like the Sovremenny would assume a greater importance, wrote Fisher, the managing editor of China Brief.

For general operations against Taiwan, Fisher analyzed, the PLA's goal would be to first strike Republic of China Navy at its ports with missiles, aircraft and special forces units. Surviving warships would then face a superior number of mainland Chinese submarines, strike aircraft, combat ships as well as numerous naval mines.

The Sovremennys, with their 130mm naval guns, could either provide fire support for amphibious invasion forces or act as the leading edge in a blockade operation, said Fisher, who is a noted military strategist, particularly on the PLA.

Concern in both Taipei and Washington about mainland China's first purchase of two Russian Project 956E Sovremenny class destroyers in 1996 is justified by the fact that Taiwan and perhaps even the U.S. Navy lack an effective defense against the ship's SS-N-22 Sunburn (3M-80E Moskit) supersonic anti-ship missile, Fisher said, adding that both of these Sovremennys are now assigned to mainland China's East Sea Fleet which faces Taiwan and Japan.

For Taipei and Washington, mainland China's recent purchase of even more advanced models of the Russian-made Sovremenny serves to validate the Bush administration's decision last year to sell Taiwan U.S. Kidd class destroyers and eight new conventional submarines, Kidd said, noting that there is an even greater requirement for the submarines now to counter the new Sovremennys.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES HELICOPTER TO PANAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Jan. 31 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China donated a helicopter to Panama in a ceremony held at the Ministry of the Interior in Panama City Thursday.
David Hu, the ROC ambassador to Panama, donated the helicopter on behalf of the ROC government, with Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso accepting it on behalf of the Central American nation.

More than 100 Panamanian officials, including Foreign Affairs Minister Jose Miguel Aleman, Interior and Justice Minister Anibal Salas, and Minister of the Presidency Ivonne Young, also attended the ceremony.

Ambassador Hu said the donation signifies the long-standing friendship between the two nations. He also expressed his admiration for President Moscoso for her dedication to the improvement of the life of the general public, adding that he hopes the helicopter will enhance the airborne patrol and emergency rescue capacity of Panama.

Minister Young read a speech for President Moscoso, who was suffering from a sore throat, in appreciation of the donation, which she said will benefit patients in remote areas who need emergency medical treatment.

She also said that people living in 70 percent of the nation's territory depend on helicopters for medical emergency transportation, adding that Panama's air force performed 254 missions and carried 454 patients to hospitals over the past year.
She also inspected the Bell-407 helicopter, which has seats for a pilot and co-pilot, as well as space for doctors, nurses and stretchers in the cabin.
Eles Cardenas, who flew the helicopter back from the United States, said the helicopter has good performance, adding that he believes it will be able to take on multiple-purpose missions.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC `COMBATIVE' CABINET ASSUMES OFFICE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun formally took office Friday after being sworn in by President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.
Yu then led his new Cabinet in a joint swearing-in ceremony.

Key members of Yu's Cabinet include Vice Premier Lin Hsin-yi, who also doubles as chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, Interior Minister Yu Cheng-hsien, Foreign Affairs Minister Eugene Chien, Defense Minister Tang Yao-ming, Finance Minister Lee Yung-san, Education Minister Huang Jung-tsun, Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan, Economic Affairs Minister Christine Tsung and Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Ling-san.

Also included in the new Cabinet lineup are Hsu Chih-hsiung, chairman of the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission; Chang Fu-mei, minister of overseas Chinese affairs; Kuo Yao-chi, chairwoman of the Public Construction Commission; Lee Chieh, chief of the General Staff of the ROC Armed Forces; Lee Ying-yuan, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan; Tchen Yu-chiou, chairwoman of the Council for Cultural Affairs; Wei Che-ho, chairman of the National Science Council; Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council; and Fan Chen-tsung, chairman of the Council of Agriculture.

Other Cabinet-level officials also sworn in Friday are Yang Teh-chih, chairman of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen; Lin Chuan, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics; Chen Chu, chairwoman of the Council of Labor Affairs; Lin Chia-cheng, chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission; Ou Yang Min-sheng, chairman of the Atomic Energy Council; Yeh Kuo-hsing, director-general of the Government Information Office; Lee Ming-liang, director-general of the Department of Health; and Hao Lung-bin, administrator of the Environmental Protection Administration.

Other officials who were sworn in are: Lee Yi-yang, director-general of the Central Personnel Administration; Lin Fang-mei, chairwoman of the National Youth Commission; Tu Cheng-sheng, director of the National Palace Museum; Chen Chien-nien, chairman of the Council of Aboriginal Affairs; Lin Teh-fu, chairman of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports; Yeh Chu-lan, chairwoman of the Council for Hakka Affairs; Wang Chun, administrator of the National Coast Guard Administration; Fan Kuang-chun, Taiwan provincial governor; Yen Chung-cheng, Fujian provincial governor; and ministers-without-portfolio Chiou I-jen, Tsai Ching-yen, Hu Sheng-cheng, Chen Chi-nan, Huang Hui-chen and Lin Feng-sheng.
The swearing-in ceremony was witnessed by Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh, Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien and National Security Council Chairman Ting Yu-chou.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCUMBENT LEGISLATIVE YUAN PRESIDENT WINS RE-ELECTION

TEXT.P: Incumbent Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng won his re-election bid overwhelmingly Friday, the first day of the fifth legislature.
Wang, who served as president of the fourth legislature, vice president of the third and is concurrently a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, won 218 votes from the 225 legislators.
Wang, who as a nine-term legislator has a great deal of experience of Taiwan's lawmaking organ, said after his victory that he wishes to create an "efficient and high-quality" legislature.

He had been favored from the start to win the election because he had secured general support from all four major political parties. Even the ruling Democratic Progressive Party endorsed him in a goodwill gesture in exchange for the KMT's support for its candidate -- Hong Chi-chang -- for the vice presidency.
The DPP has become the largest party in the new legislature with 87 seats, the KMT has 68 seats, the People First Party (PFP) has 46 seats and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) 13 seats.

However, the KMT and the PFP joined forces to recommend P.K. Chiang of the KMT for the vice presidency, which seemed to give the situation an uncertain factor, but Wang was able to win after receiving support from the DPP and the TSU.

Wang's 218 votes was the highest number of votes to be garnered in any legislative presidency election. However, some dissenting legislators used the voting to express their preferred choices, resulting in one vote each for legislators Lu Po-chi, Hong Chi-chang, Shen Fu-hsiung and Wang Hsing-nan of the DPP and one for P.K. Chiang.

Wang won only 134 votes in the previous legislature, when the KMT was the dominant force in the legislature and the PFP had yet to appear. The DPP's candidate for the speaker on that occasion was Chang Chun-hsiung, who received only 72 votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN INTERCHANGE ASSOCIATION NAMES NEW REPRESENTATIVE TO TAIPEI
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 1 (CNA) (By C.C. Huang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The quasi-official Japan Interchange Association announced Friday the appointment of former Ambassador to Canada Katsuhisa Uchida as its new representative to Taipei, replacing Shintaro Yamashita.
Uchida, 63, will assume his duties as director of the Interchange Association's Taipei Office Feb. 15.

The new representative, who graduated from Tokyo University and joined the Foreign Ministry in 1961, retired from foreign service last year. His past career posts include Japanese ambassador to Israel, Singapore and Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LIKELY TO SUSPEND NEW DEFENSE MINISTER'S PARTY RIGHTS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is likely to suspend newly sworn-in Defense Minister Tang Yao-ming's rights as a member of the opposition party, a KMT official said Friday.

Tang, who replaces Wu Shih-wen as minister of national defense under the new Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-ruled Cabinet led by Premier Yu Shyi-kun, assumed his duties that day, despite a recent decision by the KMT Central Standing Committee to ban KMT members from serving in the new Cabinet.
The ban was imposed to uphold the party's determination to force the DPP to take sole responsibility for the administration.

The suspension of Tang's party rights is more lenient than outright expulsion from the party, because Tang gave his word to the KMT decision-makers on a four-point guarantee that he will remain patriotic to the nation and people and will keep the Republic of China Armed Forces neutral and nationalized.

The four-point guarantee also stipulates that he will try to bolster national security, will not help promote Taiwan independence, will not stump for any DPP candidates in any elections, and will not participate in any party political activities.
The KMT Evaluation and Discipline Committee is expected to make a final decision within days on Tang's punishment.

Meanwhile, the committee is also considering measures to discipline KMT member Yang Teh-chih, who was also sworn in Friday as chairman of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen, a Cabinet-level position.

DOC.HEADLINE: EIGHT BANKS TO BE ALLOWED TO OPEN OFFICES IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Lee Yung-san, who was sworn in along with the rest of the new Cabinet Friday, said that eight leading Taiwan-based banks will be allowed to open offices in mainland China in the preliminary stage of a new government policy.

The former chairman of the International Commercial Bank of China said it is necessary for Taiwan-based banks to venture into the mainland China because so many Taiwan companies have already moved or expanded their operations there.
Opening offices in the mainland is the first step for banks that wish to eventually open branch offices there.

As regulator of the country's banks, Lee said, the Finance Ministry would prefer to let local banks go to the mainland in phases. He added that more banks might be allowed to follow the eight pioneers if the first phase proves successful.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER STRESSES IMPORTANCE OF `HUMAN RIGHTS DIPLOMACY'

TEXT.P: New Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien stressed Friday the importance of promoting what he called "human rights diplomacy" as a way for the country to take part in international activities.
Speaking after assuming office, Chien said that the top priority of the country's diplomatic work in the future will be on democracy and human rights, economic co-prosperity, peace and security.
He noted that Taiwan has attained laudable achievements in democratization over the past decade, as displayed by the peaceful transfer of power following the March 18, 2000 presidential election.
"It constitutes an invisible protection for Taiwan's security and survival," Chien said.

The new foreign minister stated that the ROC shares with other democratic countries the common values of freedom, democracy and human rights and added that further efforts will be made to enlist the private sector to help the country take part in international activities.

As Taiwan has become a member of the World Trade Organization, Chien went on, his ministry will cooperate with related government agencies to promote economic and trade relations, which he said will also help the promotion of diplomatic work.
In the face of threats from mainland China, the minister said, his ministry will urge peace-loving people around the world to pay attention to peace and security.
Chien added that the appeal for peace in the international community "will help build a protective net for the ROC's peace and security."

At this time of globalization, he continued, everyone should contribute to the promotion of the country's foreign relations because "diplomatic work is not only the work of his ministry but also the work of everyone."
Chien was a deputy presidential secretary-general before his appointment as foreign minister, replacing Tien Hung-mao, who has been appointed as Taiwan's representative to London.

DOC.HEADLINE: 9TH TAIWAN-BRITAIN TRADE CONSULTATION UNDER WAY IN LONDON

TEXT.P: The ninth Taiwan-Britain economic and trade consultation is under way in London, with both sides exchanging views on subjects for a new round of World Trade Organization (WTO) talks and other trade issues, Board of Foreign Trade officials said Friday.
This is the first such meeting between the two sides since Taiwan entered the WTO at the beginning of this year, the BOFT officials pointed out.

Britain is an important trade partner for Taiwan, and the officials claimed that with its economic strength, high quality manpower resources and geographic position, Taiwan is British businessmen's first choice when picking cooperative ventures in expanding Asia-Pacific markets.

The BOFT attaches great importance to the current meeting because it is Taiwan's first with a WTO member economy since it entered the organization and because the agenda has this year expanded to industrial cooperation and policy, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT NOMINATES ROC WTO REPRESENTATIVE

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian Friday nominated former Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang as Taiwan's representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Taiwan became the 144th member of the WTO Jan. 1, 2002 after 12 years of effort.
Chen also nominated former Education Minister Ovid Tzeng as vice president of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest research institution.
He also nominated Yu Ling-ya as president of the Taiwan Provincial Consultative Assembly.

DOC.HEADLINE: 23 IMPORT-EXPORT APPLICATIONS CLEARED BY KINMEN, MATSU CUSTOMS IN 2002

TEXT.P: Customs officials in Kinmen and Matsu cleared a total of 23 export and import applications in the cross-Taiwan Strait "mini links" during January, according to statistics released Friday by the Directorate General of Customs.

Kinmen customs, under the control of the Kaohsiung Customs Office, cleared nine import applications and eight export applications, while handling 425 inbound and 577 outbound passengers, as well as 4,816 postal packages.
Matsu customs, under the control of the Keelung Customs Office, cleared six import applications, 35 inbound and 95 outbound passengers and 1,605 postal packages during the same period.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR TASKS AWAITING NEW ECONOMIC AFFAIRS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Major tasks are awaiting Economic Affairs Minister Christine Tsung with the swearing in of the new "combative Cabinet" Friday, at a time when Taiwan's economy is still mired in a recession, according to local analysts.

Major issues of national concern, such as whether the government should lift a ban on the relocation of eight-inch wafer plants to mainland China and the reform of state-run enterprises, remain high on the agenda of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), which analysts said will see a tremendous transformation of Taiwan's economy in the coming years.

Although the non-partisan Economic Development Advisory Conference reached consensus in August last year to ease restrictions on mainland-bound investment by Taiwan firms, the MOEA has not yet made a final decision on whether to lift the ban after the Mainland Affairs Council and some scholars voiced opposition to the opening late last year out of fear of a capital flight to the mainland.

But Vice Premier Lin Hsin-yi, who was Tsung's predecessor, dismissed a widely assumed belief shortly after deciding to take over the new post that he is opposed to the relocation of eight-inch wafer plants to the mainland, saying that it is "a misunderstanding" and that he will address the issue in greater detail in the future."
Lin's remarks provoked suspicion among observers as to whether the remarks are an indication that the MOEA will soon remove the ban in response to keen demand from the local semiconductor industry.

At the same time, incoming personnel arrangements in various state-run enterprises, including Taiwan Power Company, Taiwan Sugar Cooperation and Taiwan Salt Industrial Corporation, will also test Tsung's wisdom amid high public expectations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER TO BALANCE GOVERNMENT BOOKS IN 5-10 YEARS

TEXT.P: Newly sworn in Finance Minister Lee Yung-san said Friday that his ministry will endeavor to balance the country's income and expenditure in between five to 10 years and resolve the problems related to budget allocations to local governments.
Lee said implementing the consensus reached at the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) and other financial reforms will be his top priorities in the coming years.

As a respected economist and former chairman of the International Commercial Bank of China, Lee went on to say that his ministry will also maintain strict control of corporate finances and will address the serious problem of non-performing loans among local banks.

Also on his list of tasks are an examination of the income tax system, helping with the establishment of financial holding companies and agricultural banks, assisting grassroots financial institutions to become commercial banks, creating an environment favorable to corporate mergers and attracting more foreign investment in the stock market.
The new minister emphasized that as companies play an extraordinary role in the country's economic development, his future financial policies will give first priority to corporate needs.

"Any obstacle that impedes the competitiveness of enterprises should be examined quickly," Lee said, adding that the ministry will streamline administrative procedures and make them transparent and more efficient, especially as regards taxes, customs, finance and insurance affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2000 NOBEL PRIZE WINNER FOR CHEMISTRY TO LECTURE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Heeger and two other scientists were awarded the prize for their discovery and development of a plastic that conducts electricity like a metal.
Research on these conductive polymers is closely related to molecular electronics, which scientists expect will dramatically increase the speed and decrease the size of computers.
The lecture session will be presided over by NTU Vice President Peng Hsu-ming. The public is also welcome to attend the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WINS ELECTION FOR VICE PRESIDENT IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: KMT candidate P. K. Chiang was voted vice president of the Legislative Yuan Friday in the second round of balloting.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO OFFERS COMMUNICATION FOR TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA: U.S. TRADE REP
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 1 (CNA) (By W. H. Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The World Trade Organization (WTO) can offer a channel for negotiations and communications for Taiwan and mainland China, as both sides have recently joined the world trade regulatory body, U.S. Trade Representative Robert Zoellick said Thursday.

Speaking at a lunch banquet at the invitation of the U. S.-China Business Council in Washington, D. C., Zoellick said, "Now, if China and Taiwan choose, they can employ the WTO as a channel for communication and negotiation, mutually observe its rules, and use its disciplines to accelerate the course upon which they have already embarked."

"It is not a given that either or both will do so..., but opportunities of this kind are rarely easy to grasp, and both will need to apply the courage and wisdom of their ancestors to prosper from this modern millennium," Zoellick stressed.
As the Taiwan Strait remains one of the world's most dangerous flash points, differences between the United States and PRC have required the most sensitive management, Zoellick said.
At a time of political and military stalemate, and occasionally confrontation across the Taiwan Strait, he said, "We have witnessed extraordinary growth of economic ties."

"Indeed, Taiwan is emerging as the largest investor in the PRC, with trade growing from zero to over US$30 billion in a decade, hundreds of thousands of people from Taiwan living in the Shanghai area alone, and millions of visitors from Taiwan going to the mainland," he said.
Although economic interdependence does not guarantee peace, Zoellick expressed the hope that "cross-strait economic integration could offer possibilities to mute differences."
"Give each side a stake in peace and stability, and challenge stereotypes as Taiwan's democracy thrives and China's politics changes," he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMUGGLING CASES IN TAIWAN REACHED 7,170 LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's law enforcement agencies and customs uncovered 7,170 smuggling cases last year, with cigarettes, mushrooms, garlic and drugs being the bulk of the goods, the value of which was NT$489 million (US$14.9 million).

According to statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Customs, customs uncovered 6,305 smuggling cases last year, accounting for 87.94 percent of the total, while law enforcement agencies found 865 cases, representing 12.06 percent of the total.

Major inbound smuggled goods were mainly cigarette, vegetables, organic chemical products, heroin and amphetamines, while toys, game products, sporting goods, fishing products and shoes were major outbound smuggling articles.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PREMIER VOWS TO BUILD TAIWAN WHILE SETTING SIGHTS ON WORLD

TEXT.P: New Premier Yu Syi-kun said the top priority of his Cabinet is to create a administration with global competitiveness on the basis of a stable society and accomplish the goal of "building Taiwan strenuously while setting our sights on venturing into the world."
Yu made the remarks after taking the official seal from his predecessor Chang Chun-hsiung in a ceremony presided over by Senior Adviser to the President Peng Min-ming.

Yu vowed to accomplish "the historical task" mandated by the position after taking over as premier Friday from Chang. Yu, the former top aid to President Chen Shui-bian, lauded Chang for laying the groundwork for the country's transformation into a modern country and helping its further development.

Peng gave a pep talk to Yu and his team at the ceremony, encouraging them to live up to the high expectations of the public. Peng, who also presided over the transitional ceremony between Chang and his predecessor, Tang Fei, more than one year ago, praised Chang's job performance over the last 483 days, saying that he took over the reins of the Executive Yuan when the government was mired in the hardships due to the international economic slowdown and the country's first change of political power in history.

However, Peng said, Chang leaves his post as the country is beginning to pull out of its economic doldrums, and the victory of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the Dec.1 elections of lawmakers is proof of his success in office.

In his farewell speech at the ceremony, Chang expressed his thanks to President Chen for his full trust and support of his administration. He also thanked his Cabinet team, saying that many of them found working in the Cabinet was more demanding than in their previous postings.
Chang, who was appointed a senior adviser to the president, capped his speech by wishing the country, the people and the government well.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.024 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at NT$35.004.
The local currency opened Friday at NT$35.032 and was traded between NT$34.998 and NT$35.060. Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$449 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC MINISTER OF INTERIOR STRESSES DECENTRALIZATION OF POWER

TEXT.P: Newly sworn in Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien of the Republic of China stressed Friday that he will push for further decentralization of power by amending relevant regulations.

Speaking at the ceremony officially giving Yu the new post, Yu said that he will push for the implementation of policies under the principle that national interests and people's welfare are always top priorities.

Yu said that he comes from the grassroots level and can comprehend intuitively the importance of power decentralization, adding that he will push for the realization of the goal in a bid to vitalize the partnership between the central government and local governments.

He hopes that all the Ministry of the Interior staff will adjust their service attitudes along with the changes in the Cabinet and will promote administrative efficiency through "four management principles: objective management, growth management, action management and crisis management."

Yu also lauded former Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya for several of her achievements during her tenure, including the practice of an alternative military service system, the setting up of the women and children protection hotline "113," and the settlement of the compensation for the collection of land used to construct the Tseng Wen Reservoir in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CELLIST YO YO MA TO PLAY TAIWAN IN MARCH

TEXT.P: The world's leading cellist, Yo Yo Ma, will perform in Taiwan in March, organizers for the event said Friday.

Ma is slated to hold a concert March 5 at the National Concert Hall in cooperation with Spanish conductor David Gimenez and a local orchestra. He will play the music of Haydn, Tchaikovsky, and Mozart for the Taipei audience.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO CONSIDER PUNISHMENT FOR PARTY MEMBERS JOINING DPP CABINET

TEXT.P: The Party Disciplinary Committee of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will convene a meeting Feb. 4 to discuss how to punish the party members who joined the Cabinet of Premier Yu Shyi-kun Friday.

Four new Cabinet ministers are KMT members -- Minister of National Defense Tang Yao-ming, Veterans Affairs Commission Chairman Yang Te-chih, Coast Guard Administration Director-General Wang Chun and Minister without Portfolio Tsay Ching-yen.

Council of Aboriginal Affairs Chairman Chen Chien-nien quit the KMT before accepting the offer. The KMT Central Standing Committee recently passed a resolution to prohibit party members from joining the Cabinet, otherwise they will face punishment.

A KMT official said that the party intends to suspend party rights, the slightest punishment, for defense minister Tang as he has issued a statement which the KMT considers complying with four conditions -- that he will do his best to protect the nation's security, will not push forward independence for Taiwan, will not campaign for Democratic Progressive Party candidates and will not participate in political activities.
Punishment for three others will be discussed by the disciplinary committee next Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVERAGE DOMESTIC OVERNIGHT INTERBANK RATE FALLS TO 2.28 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The average domestic overnight interbank rate of Taipei fell 0.009 percentage points to 2.28 percent Friday, despite the issuance amount of the central bank's time deposit certificates Friday far exceeded the amount of time deposit certificates expired on the day, the Central Bank of China (CBC) said.

The fall of the average domestic overnight interbank rate was due mainly to the loosening of capital on the market, the CBC said. The amount of CBC's time deposit certificates expired Friday totaled NT$33 billion (US$942 million). The CBC also issued a batch of time deposit certificates on an average rate of 2.275 percent, with a total amount of NT$74.1 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AUTHORITIES WILLING TO MEET BEIJING LEADERSHIP IN MAINLAND: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan is considering sending key individuals to mainland China to exchange views with the leadership in Beijing, Premier Yu Shyi-kun of the Republic of China said Friday. Yu, who was just sworn in Friday also said that Taiwan would facilitate visits by Beijing leaders should they wish to come to the ROC.

At his first news conference after taking office, Yu said that there are several issues that could be discussed, including negotiations on the protection of cross-strait investments, the so-called "mini three links" between two of Taiwan's frontline islands and mainland China, and the dispute stemming from the 1992 controversy over whether a consensus was reached by the two sides regarding the "one China" issue.
"We would welcome official visits to Taiwan by Beijing leaders -- should they wish to make such trips -- and would make all necessary arrangement for them," Yu said.

Premier Yu said that peace, safety and stability are the basis of any development between Taiwan and mainland China, and he regretted that Beijing has turned a blind eye to the goodwill gestures Taiwan has made over the past year and a half.
However, Yu said, his government is glad to see signs that the Beijing authorities are coming to terms with the fact that the DPP has the mandate to rule Taiwan.

However, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen was quick to clarify the premier's remarks, saying that there is no official policy yet in place regarding sending individuals to mainalnd China.

She said that Yu's comments were simply a response to the remarks made by Chinese Deputy Premier Qian Qichen Jan. 24, when he said that Beijing welcomed visits to mainland China by all Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) members of Taiwan except those who advocate Taiwan independence. Qian is in charge of Taiwan affairs for mainland China.
Tsai said that official contacts may be planned in the future when the chemistry across the Taiwan Strait is better.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA TO CHALLENGE TAIWAN AS SEMICONDUCTOR PRODUCTION HUB
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 31 (CNA) (By W. H. Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Mainland China will challenge Taiwan as a semiconductor production center, U. S. Trade Representative Robert Zoellick said Thursday here while giving a speech at a lunch banquet held by the U.S.-China Business Council.

As mainland China is expected to become the world's-largest supplier of information technology hardware in 10 years, mainland China's recent announcement of its intention to seek free trade agreements with Southeast Asia and Hong Kong is a natural evolution of this trend, Zoellick said. He also claimed that the mainland will soon become the world's second-largest market for personal computers. Zoellick said that Taiwan companies, the IT powerhouse of the region, have invested about US$9 billion in assembly and production plants in the mainland, and added that one-quarter of the world's desktop computers are already manufactured there along with half of the world's CD-ROMs.

The U. S. Trade Representative official attributed the mainland's spectacular growth in the last 25 years to its progress toward freer markets, greater openness to foreign competition, investment and tariff reduction.
He called on mainland China to share its developmental experience with other countries, a move which he said will benefit the mainland itself and the rest of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CABINET WILL STRIVE FOR COUNTRY'S DEVELOPMENT: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun Friday chaired his first Cabinet meeting in which he said that his "Cabinet in battle" will meet new challenges and strive for Taiwan's development, not for election wins.
Yu said that all Cabinet ministers should have confidence in the future and he expressed his hope that they will do their best to carry out administrative plans.

The new premier, who was sworn in Feb. 1, noted that the common expectation of the people is to stimulate the sluggish economy. In order to revitalize the economy, he said that more effort must be given to the improvement of the industrial structure and the resolution of the problem of high unemployment.

Regarding "government reorganization," Yu said that the target is to improve the country's global competitiveness, with the basic concepts for reorganization being providing better service, partnership, flexible renovation, clean government and responsible politics.
The premier instructed related government agencies to address the problems concerning social security, the investment environment and traffic congestion during the Chinese New Year holiday.

Earlier, Yu told a news conference that his Cabinet will employ a devoted, pragmatic spirit to create new situations for the country. He said that more administrative emphasis will be placed on the development of a knowledge-based economy to improve Taiwan's global competitiveness, the implementation of government reorganization and utilization of the power of the private sector, as well as strengthening humanist concerns.
Meanwhile, the premier said that he will take advantage of weekends to visit various government agencies to have a better understanding about their operations.

Accompanied by Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i, Yu will visit Nantou City Saturday morning to listen to a report on the progress of post-earthquake reconstruction projects in areas heavily damaged by the Sept. 21, 1999 temblor.
He will visit the Ministry of Transportation and Communications Saturday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI AIMS TO BE VANGUARD OF TAIWAN'S KNOWLEDGE-BASED ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Taiwan should endeavor to be a center of innovation and research and the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) should be the pioneer of the knowledge-based economy in the country, the institute's president Shih Chin-tai said Feb. 1.

In a news conference that coincided with the inauguration of Republic of China's new Cabinet, Shih said that while the Executive Yuan will focus on the economy, his institute will work toward a significant leap forward in high-tech development by the year 2008.

Lin Yu-huan, an ITRI official, said the institute has done much to attract high-tech talent during recent years, with researchers with master-degrees accounting for 56 percent of the staff, and those with doctorates 13 percent.

The institute has also solicited internationally well-known experts to serve as advisers at the institute, Lin added. As the cradle of Taiwan's high technology, the ITRI established the country's first nanotechnology center last month that involves the creation and utilization of materials, devices and systems through the control and manipulation of matter at the nanometer scale, that is, at the size of atoms, molecules and supramolecular structures.

A nanometer is one-billionth of a meter -- about 10,000 times narrower than a human hair and four times wider than an atom. Besides, Lin added, ITRI will set up a talent-cultivation center in the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park in October, and will have 300 researchers by the year 2004 in ITRI's branch in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT NARROWLY WINS ELECTION FOR VICE PRESIDENT IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) candidate P. K. Chiang was voted vice president of the Legislative Yuan Friday after two nail-biting rounds of balloting.

Chiang's win, with 115 votes against 106 for his Democrative Progressive Party (DPP) rival Hong Chi-chang, gave his party a much-needed boost after it suffered a disastrous defeat in the Dec. 1 elections for lawmakers.

The KMT saw its seats trimmed in that election from 115 to 68 in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan. Chiang led Hong in the first round of balloting, 111 to 108, but was two ballots shy of the 113 majority which was needed to win in the first round.

In the second round, whoever got the most votes won. The showdown between Chiang and Hong for the mainly ceremonial post has divided the legislature into two groups, with the KMT and its political ally, the People First Party on one side, and the ruling DPP and the minor Taiwan Solidarity Union on the other side. The almost evenly divided legislature into two political blocs augurs a bumpy future for the new lawmaking body, according to political analysts. Friday was the first meeting of the new legislature.
Chiang was sworn in along with the president-elect, KMT legislator Wang Jin-pyng, who won the presidency in an uncontested election earlier in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW DEFENSE MINISTER TO SPEAK ON NATIONAL DEFENSE POLICY FEB. 2

TEXT.P: The new minister of national defense, Tang Yao-ming, said Friday that he will to speak on the goals of the ministry and his expectations Saturday.
Tang, formerly the chief of the general staff, received the official seals at a ceremony officiated over by Minister without Portfolio Chiou I-jen.
Outgoing defense minister Wu Shih-wen told reporters afterwards that he felt relieved now that his 40-year military career has come to an end.

He said that the implementation of national defense policy and war preparedness should be a consistent work, and added that he believed the new defense minister will be outstanding in national defense affairs.
Tang will speak to the media at the Armed Forces Officers' Club Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO TAIWAN CITIES HOPE TO SPONSOR 2007 WORLD UNIVERSITY GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Feb. 1 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Officials of two cities in southern Taiwan announced Friday that the two cities intend to jointly sponsor the 2007 World University Games.

Deputy Mayor Lin Yung-chien of Kaohsiung City and Mayor Hsu Tien-tsai of Tainan City made the announcement at a news conference. Lin said that Kaohsiung City has been actively striving for the sponsorship of large-scale international sporting events to raise the profile of sports and map out a far-reaching blueprint for the development of the city.

Hsu said he was confident that by joining forces, the two cities could enhance their chances to sponsor international sporting events. The World University Games are held every two years. Taegu of South Korea will sponsor the 2003 World University Games, Turkey will organize the 2005 Games.
Kaohsiung and Tainan are expected to face challenges in sponsoring the 2007 Games from Melbourne, Vancouver and Bangkok.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 2, or the 21st day of the 12th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1535: The Argentine city of Buenos Aires is founded by Spanish explorer Pedro de Mendoz.
1556: An earthquake rocks the provinces of Shensi, Henan and Shansi in mainland China, killing an estimated 830,000 people.
1665: A British fleet captures New Amsterdam, the center of the Dutch colony in North America and the flourishing trading settlement on the island of Manhattan, renaming it New York in honor of the Duke of York.
1848: Mexico, according to a treaty signed after the U.S.-Mexico War, cedes Texas, New Mexico and California to the United States.
1878: Greece declares war on Turkey.
1913: The world's biggest railroad station, New York's Grand Central Station, is formally opened.
1915: Germany begins U-boat blockades of British waters, while the United States warns Germany against attacking American ships.
1926: Valery Giscard d'Estaing, French president from 1974 to 1981, is born.
1943: German troops surrender to the Soviet Union in Stalingrad.
1946: Taipei's Yuanshan Zoo is opened.
1953: The U.S. government announces it will no longer block Chinese Nationalist troops in their raids against mainland Chinese troops stationed along the mainland coastline during the period of the Nationalist-Communist struggle.
1967: Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle is elected president of Nicaragua.
1970: China Airlines launches ROC-U.S. flight services with its inaugural flight, by a Boeing 707, to San Francisco.
1970: British philosopher and Nobel Prize-winner Bertrand Russel dies at the age of 98.
1972: Protesters in Dublin burn down the British Embassy in an act of revenge for the "Bloody Sunday" shooting in Londonderry the previous weekend in which British troops killed 13 Catholic youths and wounded another 17.
1975: Gen. Gamad Shumaimari, chief of the general staff of the armed forces of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a 10-day visit.
1979: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini returns from 14 years in exile in Paris to rule Iran. He succeeded the Shah of Iran who fled to Egypt 15 days prior to Khomeini's return after failing to resist mounting opposition masterminded by Khomeini.
1986: Oscar Arias Sanchez is elected president of Costa Rica.
1989: A coup in Paraguay topples President Alfredo Stroessner who ruled the South American country for 35 years.
1989: The last of the Soviet troops withdraw from Afghanistan, ending a nine-year occupation of the country by Communist forces.
1994: Rafael Caldera is sworn in as president of Venezuela.
1994: The Republic of China and Burkina Faso announce the restoration of diplomatic relations, which were suspended for 21 years.
1998: A Cebu Pacific Air DC-9 crashes into a mountainside 65 kilometers northeast of Cagayan de Oro airport in the Philippines, killing all 104 people on board.
2000: The U.S. House of Representatives passes the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, a bill aimed at strengthening military ties with Taiwan, despite warnings from Beijing and the White House.
2001: Exiled mainland Chinese-born Nobel laureate writer Gao Xingjiang meets with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If there were a sure way of getting rich, even though one had to be a groom and keep horses, I would be willing to pursue it. But as there is really no sure way of getting rich, I prefer to follow the pursuits congenial to me."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times:
Opposition KMT candidate P. K. Chiang wins legislative deputy speakership.
The United Daily News:
P. K. Chiang wins legislative vice speaker post after nail-biting runoff.
The Liberty Times:
The opposition KMT commands the two top legislative posts.
The Taiwan Daily:
The pan-blue camp's Chiang defeats the pan-green camp's Hong.
The Central Daily News:
The Wang-Chiang ticket wins the legislative speaker-deputy speaker race.
The China Post:
Wang, Chiang command speakerships.
The Taiwan News:
New Premier Yu outlines goals for 'combat Cabinet.'
The Taipei Times:
Anger greets KMT's clean sweep.

DOC.HEADLINE: CATHOLIC BISHOPS FROM TAIWAN COMPLETE ROUTINE REPORT TO POPE
DOC.DATELINE: Vatican City, Feb. 1 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A delegation of bishops from the Republic of China on Friday completed a comprehensive report to Pope John Paul II and various Vatican offices on the current state of Catholic affairs in the Taiwan region.

Led by Cardinal Paul S.J. Suan of the Archdiocese of Kaohsiung, nine bishops from dioceses around the island arrived in Vatican City on Jan. 22 to deliver the report, which is customarily done so once every five years. The group also attended the multi-faith prayer gathering in Assisi hosted by the Pope on Jan. 24.

They briefed the pontiff on the development of each diocese in Taiwan over the past five years and were told by the Pope in regard to relations with mainland China that their efforts have promoted mutual understanding and greater opportunities for dialogue for the entire Chinese Catholic population.
Beijing sanctions an official state Catholic Church that does not answer to the Vatican, even as an "underground Church" remains loyal to the Pope.
The delegation from Taiwan is scheduled to return to the island Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MERCHANTS ON M'LAND CAN HEAD HOME FOR HOLIDAYS VIA KINMEN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government approved a tentative arrangement Friday allowing mainland China-based Taiwan business people to travel directly from the mainland's Xiamen port to the ROC-held Kinmen island from where they can fly back to Taiwan for the Chinese New Year holidays.

Approval was granted by the Bureau of Immigration to a total of 300 Taiwan investors and their relatives to sail aboard a ferry from Fujian Province's Xiamen port to Kinmen in two groups on Feb. 9 and 10 to return to Taiwan for the holidays.

The same travelers are scheduled to return to Fujian Province later in the month by taking similar ferries from Kinmen on Feb. 16, 17 and 24, respectively, allowing them to return to work on the mainland after the holiday break.

This marks the first time the ROC government has approved direct travel of people, rather than goods, across the Taiwan Strait, following its initiation of the "mini three links" on Jan. 2, 2001 allowing for direct trade, postal and shipping links between the ROC's outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the mainland port cities of Xiamen and Fuzhou in Fujian Province.

Bureau of Immigration officials, however, said this is only a tentative move taken to meet needs during "special periods" of the year and is not yet a set-in-stone ROC policy pertaining to cross-strait relations.

The Xiamen-Kinmen-Taiwan trip formula will tentatively be applied during the Chinese New Year period, as well as during the three other major traditional Chinese holidays, namely Tomb Sweeping Day, the Dragon-Boat Festival and the Mid-Autumn Festival, Bureau of Immigration officials said.

According to officials from the Taiwan Traders' Association in Fujian, which is sponsoring the first "direct trip" of people across the Taiwan Strait, the Xiamen-Kinmen-Taiwan sea and air trip will save roughly NT$10,000 (US$286) for each person per trip. In the past, a traveler had to spend about NT$16,000 for a one-way trip to Fujian Province from Taiwan via a "third place," namely Hong Kong or Macau.
Sailing from Xiamen port to Kinmen takes about 90 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER AFFIRMS CONTRIBUTIONS BY POST-921 QUAKE RELIEF WORK STAFF
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun on Saturday affirmed the contributions made by the staff of the 921 Earthquake Post-Disaster Recovery Commission and encouraged them to continue pushing forward in their reconstruction work efforts.
The Cabinet-level commission was set up after the devastating magnitude 7.3 temblor on Sept. 21, 1999 that killed more than 2,400 people and injured more than 6,000 others in Taiwan.
Yu affirmed the efforts of the post-quake relief work staff at a ceremony officially giving Chen Chin-huang the post of chief executive officer of the recovery commission.

Chen, incumbent vice chairman of the Taiwan Provincial Government, succeeded Huang Jung-tsun who Friday assumed his new post as minister of education. Chen concurrently acts as vice chairman of the Taiwan Provincial Government.

DOC.HEADLINE: UMC TO BUILD 12-INCH WAFER FAB IN SINGAPORE WITH AMD
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) announced Friday that it will establish a joint venture with U.S.-based Advanced Micro Devices Inc. (AMD) to own and operate a 12-inch wafer fabrication facility in Singapore.

The joint venture will be known as AU Partnership Ltd. and is expected to begin commercial production on 65-nanometer technology in mid-2005, according to UMC, Taiwan's second-largest wafer fabrication company.

"This is the first agreement under which a premier foundry company joins forces in a broadly unified partnership with a leading integrated device manufacturer," said Robert Tsao, chairman and CEO of UMC.

"Our respective customers around the world will benefit as we join forces to develop leading-edge technology and drive down manufacturing costs through rapid, cost-effective implementation of the most advanced process technologies and manufacturing practices," he added.

The agreement marks UMC's second joint venture with another leading global company to build a 12-inch wafer plant in Singapore. Last year, UMC began constructing the plant as part of the joint venture UMCi Partnership Ltd., which is 30 percent owned by Germany's Infineon Technologies AG and 15 percent owned by Singapore's Economic Development Board.
Both UMCi and AU will be located next to each other at Singapore's Pasir Ris Wafer Fab Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE PEOPLE SHARE TAIWAN LOTTO'S TOP PRIZE OF US$ 5.37 MILLION

TEXT.P: Three people will share NT$188 million (US$5.37 million) in prize money after winning the top prize Friday in the fourth drawing of Taiwan's lottery, sources with TAIPEIBANK, which issued tickets for the lottery, said Saturday.
Nineteen people won the second prize by correctly selecting five of the six numbers drawn plus the special number drawn. Each of the second-prize winners will receive NT$3.14 million in prize money.
Meanwhile, 446 people won the third prize by correctly picking five of the six numbers drawn, with each winner to receive NT$167,000.
The fourth prize went to 24,000 people who will each get NT$7,228 in prize money after correctly selecting four of the six numbers.
A total of 391,000 people won the fifth prize (minimum prize), with each to receive NT$200 in prize money.
The numbers 13, 39, 28, 30, 25, and 29, and the special number 21 were drawn from the lottery wheel in that order Friday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIRCULATION OF NT$ 2000-DENOMINATION BILLS WON'T CAUSE INFLATION: CBC

TEXT.P: The circulation of NT$2000-denomination bank notes, slated to begin this July, will not cause inflation nor result in any abnormalities in Taiwan's financial sector, Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Perng Fai-nan said Saturday.

The CBC is scheduled to formally begin issuing the NT$2000-denomination bills July 1 to help adjust the structure of Taiwan's currency. The new bank notes will represent the largest-denomination bills that the Republic of China government has ever issued in the Taiwan area.

Perng said that Taiwan's currency has been controlled well in the able hands of the CBC and that the island's well-balanced commodity prices will not be affected by the circulation of the NT$2000-denomination bills.

He said Taiwan's per capita income has increased fivefold since the CBC began issuing NT$1000-denomination bank notes in 1980. According to the standard of the ratio between a nation's largest-denomination bill and its per capita gross domestic product (GDP), the NT$1,000 bank note is too low in value to be the largest-denomination bill in circulation, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP VICTORY TO IMPACT TAIPEI MAYOR ELECTION: KMT LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator John Chang said Saturday that the successful collaboration between the KMT and the opposition People First Party (PFP) in the just-concluded race for Legislative Yuan president and vice president will have a direct impact on the year-end Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections.

Speaking at a seminar on the power structure of the newly sworn-in Legislative Yuan, the former vice premier said that Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, a KMT stalwart, is favorably placed to seek re-election with the PFP's support because the two parties were able to agree on fielding common candidates in Friday's legislative leadership elections.

He added that there might also be more room for flexibility in collaborating to field a common candidate to contest the Kaohsiung mayorship, a popularly elected post currently held by ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh.

However, both Chang and PFP Legislator Pang Chien-kuo said it remains to be seen whether the "pan-blue alliance" -- referring to the loose alliance between the KMT and its splinter parties, namely the PFP and the New Party -- will be able to follow the same model to work together in the Legislative Yuan.

Pang said that he believes the results of Friday's elections have strengthened the mutual confidence between KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong, while President Chen Shui-bian of the DPP and former President Lee Teng-hui -- the "spiritual leader" of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) -- might now have difficulty forming a pan-partisan "national stabilization alliance."

KMT Vice Chairman Wang Jyn-ping won a landslide victory Friday to be re-elected Legislative Yuan president, and former top government economic planner P.K. Chiang of the KMT won the vice legislative presidency by a narrow margin after a hotly contested race against Hong Chi-chang, a DPP candidate also backed by the TSU.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER ANNOUNCES TROOPS REDUCTION PLAN

TEXT.P: Newly sworn-in Minister of Defense Tang Yao-ming announced Saturday that the military will further trim its work force from 2004 in line with the government's policy of building an elite deterrent force.
Speaking at his first news conference since assuming office Friday, Tang said the military plans to cut 15,000 troops annually between 2004 and 2006.

The three-year troops reduction plan is the second phase of a military downsizing and modernization package. Former Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen shelved the plan during his term in office. Tang announced his decision to revive the plan a day after he succeeded Wu as the defense chief.

Tang, who served as chief of the General Staff until Thursday, said the downsizing package will enter a new stage in 2003, with the restructuring of military units. "And the Army, Navy and Air Force general headquarters will complete restructuring in accordance with the new defense organization law by the end of 2004."

The three-year troops reduction plan will also get underway that year, Tang said, adding that the number of Taiwan's armed forces personnel will be slashed to about 350,000 by 2006 from the current 400,000.

In implementing the downsizing plan, Tang said, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) will conduct regular reviews of its possible impact and make necessary adjustments in terms of mainland China's military threat, regional security strategy and national defense resources.
Tang said cutting the number of service members and upgrading their combat capabilities as well as modernizing weaponry systems is the "road that the military must take."

As for the proposal to replace the current conscription system with a voluntary military service system, Tang said, the MND has formed a special task force to study the issue and come up with a blueprint.

Turning to his own party membership issue, Tang said he will never voluntarily renounce his Kuomintang (KMT) membership as he has deep feelings for the party and defense affairs have little to do with partisan concerns.
The opposition KMT has banned its members from joining the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led Cabinet. KMT sources said the party may suspend Tang's party rights as a penalty.

Noting that he has been a member of the KMT for more than 40 years, Tang said he is unlikely to willingly withdraw from the party. "But I would accept any form of punishment handed down by the party," he said, adding that as a matter of fact, partisan considerations have no role in military-related work.
With Taiwan's democratization, Tang said, its armed forces have been nationalized. "And neutrality is a basic principle in handling military affairs," he added.

According to the ROC Constitution, Tang said, military service members can freely join any political party or group. Nevertheless, he said, the constitution also demands that military service members transcend any regional or partisan concerns in performing their duties.
"Therefore, I think that any individual service member's party affiliation should not be a topic of discussion in the barracks," Tang said.
Touching on the recent large-scale military reshuffle, Tang said impartiality and transparency have been the top guidelines for military personnel administration and adjustment.

In line with the integration of military command and administration in March, Tang said the military structure will be adjusted and personnel reshuffled. He made the assurance that any personnel adjustments will abide by the principles of impartiality and transparency. "We'll protect the legitimate rights of those whose jobs will be reassigned," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRMS TO TIE-UP WITH LI KA SHING GROUP FOR E-HUB

TEXT.P: Taiwan's computer maker Elitegroup Computer System and Pou Chen Industrial are entering a partnership with Hong Kong's business giant Li Ka Shing Group to jointly establish a regional distribution system of information technology products which will be called the E-Hub.
The three are expected to make a formal announcement together on the business tie-up next week.

Elitegroup Computer System, a veteran PC maker in Taiwan, has demonstrated invincible ambition in recent years by crossing over to other fields of production, including motherboards, connectors, printed circuits and system devices, by entering joint ventures with other Taiwan companies. Pou Chen, one of the largest shoe makers in Taiwan, which makes big-name sneakers and footwear for international companies on an OEM basis, is one of them.

Elitegroup further expanded its operations last year by buying out two other notebook computer OEM makers in Taiwan, enabling it to cross over to the production of notebook computers and become an OEM supplier to Apple Computer's NBs.

Over a year of talks, Elitegroup, Pou Chen and Li Ka Shing Group came to an agreement recently on establishing the E-Hub, which is envisaged as a regional distribution system supplying IT products and related services in the Asian-Pacific region.

The E-Hub, to be headquartered in Hong Kong with exclusive port facilities, will be able to operate the distribution of IT products worth over NT$100 billion (US$2.86 billion) a year, and it is expected to help globalize Elitegroup products, according to an Elitegroup spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN VICE PRESIDENT SAYS HE WILL MAINTAIN NEUTRALITY

TEXT.P: New Legislative Yuan Vice President P.K. Chiang said Saturday that he will take a neutral stand to help promote legislative reforms and stimulate the country's economy.

Chiang, an economics expert and a member of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), was elected to his new post Friday after a bitter battle with Hung Chi-chang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Both Chiang and Hung failed to gain more than half of the votes in the first round of voting, with Chiang collecting 111 votes and Hung gaining 108 votes.

In the second round of voting, Chiang received 115 votes against Hung's 106. Chiang's support mainly came from the KMT and the People First Party, while Hung was supported by the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

Chiang said that he will perform his duties as a neutral vice president to help Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng handle legislative affairs. Wang, who won reelection with 218 votes, is a KMT vice chairman.
Chiang stressed that he will do his best to help promote legislative reforms and improve the efficiency of the legislature.

Despite the heated competition with the ruling party's candidate for the post of Legislative Yuan vice president, Chiang said that there is no need to be concerned about an escalation in confrontation between the ruling party and the opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIANG'S VICTORY SAID TO SPARE KMT CRISIS OF FURTHER SPLIT

TEXT.P: The victory of P. K. Chiang in the hotly contested legislative deputy speakership election will spare the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) the crisis of further split in the foreseeable future, local scholars said Saturday.
Chiang, a veteran former economics official and a freshman KMT legislator-at large, beat ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Hong Chi-chang in a runoff vote Friday evening.

The race was seen the first showdown in the new legislature between the "pan-blue" camp, which comprises the KMT and its splinter group -- the People First Party (PFP) -- and the "pan-green" camp, which refers to the DPP and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

Emile Sheng, a political political Shen Chih-jen, a political scientist from Soochow University, said Chiang's victory will help revive the KMT's confidence and morale after the party suffered embarrassing setbacks in the 2000 presidential election and last year's legislative elections.
Moreover, Sheng said, the race has enabled the KMT to consolidate its ranks and weed out the influence of former President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui in the party.

Before the deputy speaker election, Lee had openly thrown support behind DPP's Hong in an attempt to sway "pro-localization" KMT lawmakers. But the voting results indicated that almost no KMT legislators "defected" to vote for Hong.
In his view, Sheng said, Chiang's win marked an end of Lee's influence in the KMT.

Sheng further said the KMT has succeeded in using the race to "screen out" disloyal members. "And following Chiang's victory, the KMT has defused the crisis of further split in its ranks," Sheng noted.

Yang Tai-shun, chairman of Chinese Culture University's Political Science Department, echoed Sheng's view, saying that the deputy speaker election marks a significant victory for the KMT in its struggle for reviving its past glory and political clout.

The KMT lost its decades-old control of the legislature in last December's elections. It commands only 68 seats in the 225-member Fifth Legislative Yuan inaugurated Friday. With the support of the PFP, which controls 45 seats, and several independent lawmakers, Chiang managed to claim the deputy speaker post.

Although the DPP controls 87 seats in the new legislature, it still lacks a clear majority. Both Sheng and Yang said they believe that the "pan-blue" and the "pan-green" standoff will continue in Taiwan's political arenas in the run-up to the next presidential election.
Sheng and Yang also said that the KMT and the PFP should be able to draw inspiration from the victory of Friday's deputy speaker election.

"And whether the two opposition parties can cooperate in the year-end mayoral elections for Taiwan's two largest municipalities -- Taipei and Kaohsiung -- will be a litmus test for the possibility of their cooperation in the 2004 presidential election," Sheng predicted.
Meanwhile, Sheng attributed the DDP's defeat in the deputy speakership election mainly to its excessive self-confidence and misjudgment of the domestic political situation.

The DPP didn't field its own candidate for the speaker election and lent full support for the re-election bid of incumbent speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT vice chairman. As a result, Wang won re-election with a landslide.
The DPP originally expected that its support for Wang would prompt "pro-localization" KMT lawmakers' support for Hong in the deputy speaker election. However, such a scenario didn't materialize.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC CHAIRWOMAN CRITICIZES MAINLAND CHINESE VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) Chairwoman Chang Fu-mei Saturday criticized mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen for attempting to "sow discord" among members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Qian recently stated that the vast majority of DPP members are welcome to visit mainland China, except for the small number of diehards who insist on Taiwan independence.
Chang said on a local radio program that Beijing was apparently trying to intentionally create an ambiguous situation to serve its own ends.
Nevertheless, she admitted that Beijing has progressed a little by allowing DPP members to visit the mainland since in the past it had consistently refused to have contact with the DPP.
The OCAC chief went on to say that over the past few years, mainland China has stepped up its work in opposing Taiwan independence, while promoting unification between the mainland and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP TO COOPERATE IN TAIPEI, KAOHSIUNG MAYORAL ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng said Saturday that Friday's legislative deputy speaker election indicates that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) remains a minority force in the new legislature.
With the cooperation of the KMT and its splinter group -- the People First Party (PFP) --, KMT candidate P. K. Chiang managed to defeat his DPP rival Hong Chi-chang to win the deputy speaker post.

Lin said Chiang's victory betrays that the KMT and the PFP, which jointly control 113 seats in the 225-member Fifth Legislative Yuan, which was sworn in Friday, remain dominating force in the legislature.

"We hope that the DPP will respect the majority force in the legislature and increase communication and consultation with the opposition parties in formulating major policies in order to ensure the chamber's smooth operation," Lin said. "The DPP should not adopt any high-handed tactics in pushing through major bills."

The DPP managed to emerge as the largest party in the legislature elected Dec. 1, 2001 by winning 87 seats. Even with the support of its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union which controls 13 seats -- the DPP still lacks a clear majority. As a result, its candidate Hong lost to Chiang, a veteran trade and economic technocrat and freshman legislator-at large, with a vote of 106-115.
Encouraged by the latest electoral victory, Lin said the KMT and the PFP will continue pooling their resources to cope with the year-end Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections.

PFP Secretary-General Chung Jung-chi echoed Lin's view, saying that Friday's election indicates that the two parties will stand a good chance to win a major political election so long as they can cooperate closely.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VISITS NANTOU TO VIEW POST-921 QUAKE RECONSTRUCTION EFFORTS
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun visited the area of Nantou County struck by the massive Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake to gain a better understanding of the progress in reconstruction work there.
The magnitude 7.3 temblor that shook Taiwan killed more than 2,400 people, injured more than 6,000 others and caused heavy property losses. The central part of the island was the most seriously hit.

After listening to a briefing by Huang Jung-tsun, former chief executive officer of the Cabinet-level 921 Earthquake Post-Disaster Recovery Commission, on the results over the past year of reconstruction work and the focal points of the work that lies ahead, Yu toured the quake-stricken area and pledged the Cabinet's continuing support in reconstructing the area.

Huang assumed his new post of minister of education Friday, with Chen Chin-huang succeeding Huang as the CEO of the recovery commission. Chen concurrently acts as vice chairman of Taiwan Provincial Government.
Yu proposed a seven-point set of instructions on the reconstruction work, including progress management and effective use of reconstruction funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH URGED TO GAIN ASSURANCES OF ADDRESSING CHINESE PEOPLE DIRECTLY

TEXT.P: The U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom has urged the U.S. president to gain assurances from Beijing that he will have the chance during his upcoming visit to deliver a speech on human rights and freedoms directly to the Chinese people via a live and uncensored broadcast.

In a letter Thursday to President George W. Bush, Michael K. Young, chair of the commission, also recommended that Bush continue to raise concerns about religious freedom in mainland China directly with President Jiang Zemin, "as you began during your discussions in Shanghai last October."

Young pointed out that serious violations of the right to freedom of religion and belief in mainland China have been well documented by his commission, the U.S. State Department, as well as by religious and other non-governmental organizations.

He noted that in October 2001, the U.S. Secretary of State for the third straight year concluded that the Beijing regime severely and systematically violates freedom of religion and belief, and named mainland China as a "country of particular concern" under the International Religious Freedom Act.

"An important aspect of promoting religious freedom in China, along with other human rights, is for representatives of the United States to inform the Chinese people why the U.S. government is concerned about human rights practices in their country," he wrote.

President Ronald Reagan gave an address to Russian students at Moscow State University during his state visit to the former Soviet Union in 1988 in which he described in detail the commitment of Americans to democracy, economic freedom, and the freedoms of assembly, speech, the press and religion.

"The commission urges you to follow this precedent and address the Chinese people directly in a similar fashion to express why the U.S. government, on behalf of the American people, is concerned with violations of internationally recognized human rights, including religious freedom, and why it is U.S. policy to oppose such violations anywhere in the world, and not just in China," Young wrote to Bush.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG HAS NO PLANS TO CHANGE LINKED EXCHANGE RATE

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong government has no plans of changing the exchange rate mechanism whereby the Hong Kong dollar is linked to the U.S. dollar, Financial Secretary Antony Leuang reiterated in a government announcement released Saturday.
Leung, who is now in New York attending the World Economic Forum, said changing the present exchange rate system is not an option for Hong Kong.

Speaking at a dinner held by the forum in New York on the evening of Feb. 1, Leung noted that some people have suggested that the link be abolished to solve the problem of deflation, which has been part of the painful process of economic restructuring, now affecting Hong Kong, saying that these individuals even cited Argentina as an example to support their argument.

He reportedly countered these suggestions by saying that "as the chief executive and I have said many times before, the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government has no plan, nor does it intend, to change the linked exchange rate."

"The basic point here is that our financial and economic systems would not be able to withstand the tremendous shock created by the possible massive outflow of capital if the linked exchange rate were to go," he added.
"Hong Kong is markedly different from Argentina. We do not have any external debt. We have a sizable foreign exchange reserve of over US$100 billion," he pointed out.
However, he noted that Hong Kong should learn a lesson from Argentina and not perpetuate the problem of fiscal deficits.

Leung pointed out that Hong Kong has been facing the problem of ongoing deficits for several years and that as financial secretary, he has had the responsibility of bringing the budget back into balance within a reasonable period of time.
He added that he has currently been focusing on controlling government expenditures. (Stanley Cheung)

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 3, or the 22nd day of the 12th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1468: Johann Gutenberg, a German goldsmith who developed the letterpress printing method and oil-based inks, dies in obscurity. His "Mazarin Bible" (1455) is believed to be the first book printed with such type.
1488: Portuguese explorer Bartolomeu Diaz, after rounding the Cape of Good Hope, lands on Africa's eastern coast. He is the first European to land on African soil.
1830: Greece is declared independent under the protection of Britain, France, and Russia at a London conference.
1867: Prince Mutsuhito becomes Emperor Meiji at the age of 14. His reign in Japan lasted until 1912.
1913: The 16th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution is ratified, giving the government the power to impose and collect taxes on income.
1919: The League of Nations holds its first meeting in Paris with U.S. President Woodrow Wilson presiding.
1924: Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1919, dies at the age of 67.
1930: Ho Chi Minh establishes the Vietnamese Communist Party in Hong Kong.
1931: An earthquake jolts Hawks Bay in New Zealand, killing 256 people.
1943: British bombers pound the German city of Hamburg.
1945: U.S. troops recover Manila in the Philippines from Japanese forces during World War II.
1960: British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan tells the astonished white politicians in the Cape Town parliament that they should accept racial equality.
1966: The unmanned Soviet spaceship Luna IX lands on the moon and sends signals back to Earth.
1969: Yasser Arafat is elected as the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1973: Fighting in Vietnam comes to a halt when a cease-fire goes into effect.
