1974: Dr. Arthur A. Kimball, director of the International Training Section of the U.S. Agency for International Development, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The Indian Ocean satellite communications ground station in Taiwan begins operations, providing improved telephone service to Europe and Africa.
1974: The ROC's agricultural technical cooperation with Honduras is extended for two years.
1977: China Steel Corp.'s Kaohsiung mill begins operations.
1978: The European Economic Community and Communist China initial their first trade agreement.
1989: P.W. Botha resigns as chief of South Africa's ruling party.
1989: A military coup topples strongman Alfredo Stroessner in Paraguay, ending his eight successive presidential terms and 35 years of rule.
1992: A fight breaks out in a camp for Vietnamese boat refugees in Hong Kong, resulting in 18 deaths.
1994: U.S. President Bill Clinton announces the lifting of the United States' trade embargo against Vietnam.
1996: An earthquake rocks Lijiang in southwestern China, killing more than 302 people.
2000: An A300-600R airbus of China Airlines, carrying 225 passengers, departs Taipei for Manila, formally resuming direct air links between Taiwan and the Philippines after they had been suspended for four months.
2001: A group of Taiwan students studying in mainland China forms an association in Taipei, the first of its kind, to promote their legitimate rights and interests.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Living upon the poorest fare with cold water for drink and with my bent arms for a pillow, I could yet find pleasure in such a life, whereas riches and honors acquired through the sacrifice of what is right would be to me as unreal as a mirage."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times:
Former lawmaker released by court on grounds that he was illegal taken custody by prosecutors.
The United Daily News:
Court rejects prosecutors' appeal for detention of former lawmaker.
The Liberty Times:
Prosecutors look into alleged irregularities in elections of president and vice president of legislature.
The Taiwan Daily:
Court releases former lawmaker, saying his detention is illegal.
The Central Daily News:
The first new standard university entrance examination conclude successfully.
The China Post:
Prosecutors seek detention for Lo in scandal case.
The Taiwan News:
Premier Yu encourages renewed efforts for post-earthquake relief.
The Taipei Times:
Tang details armed forces restructuring.

DOC.HEADLINE: SLAIN TAIWAN FEMALE BACKPACKER BURIED IN EASTERN TURKEY
DOC.DATELINE: Ankara, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By Kuo Chuan-hsin and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan female backpacker who was suspected of being raped and murdered in Sanliurfa, eastern Turkey five days ago, was buried Saturday in Adana where her body was kept for autopsy after being found.

At Liu Chieh-ying's funeral were her father, Liu Chun-shung, and mother from Taiwan, officials from the Taiwan representative office to Turkey, Turkish officials, and workers of the Taiwan charity Tzu Chi Foundation.

Although Liu's father said she was a Buddhist, the funeral financed by the local government was held in the Islamic style as most Turks are Moslems. The local government also provided a place for internment and promised to do their best to help bring her remains back to Taiwan.

Liu's parents, who flew in from Taiwan Saturday afternoon, resigned themselves to laying their daughter to rest in a country thousands of miles away from her homeland after learning that there is no crematorium in Adana and to airlift Liu's body back to Taiwan would entail enormous red tape and cost.
Liu Chun-shung and his wife are scheduled to fly back to Taiwan on Feb. 4.

Liu Chieh-ying, 27, arrived in Turkey alone for a trip in the middle of January. She lodged in a cheap hotel in Sanliurfa Jan. 27. Her landlord called police Jan. 29 to force their way into her room after she was reported to have not left her room for two days.
The police found her scantily-clad body on the bed with her limbs tied to the four legs of the bed.
A waiter at the hotel confessed that he killed Liu to steal her belongings but police suspected that Liu was sexual assaulted before being killed and more accomplices were involved in the case.
Located about 1,000 kilometers southeast of Ankara, Sanliurfa is a small town of Kurds and foreigners are rarely seen there.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS TO OPEN OFFICE IN MACAU
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Feb. 3 (CNA) (By Jen Chung-hung and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), the mainland Chinese organization responsible for negotiations with Taiwan, is set to open an office in Macau, a Beijing official in Macau said Sunday.

Liu Gangqi, the official in charge of Taiwan Affairs in Beijing's liaison office to Macau said ARATS staff assigned to the office are already in Macau and are expected to make an announcement about their new office on Monday.

Liu said the imminent opening of the Macau office is evidence of the former Portuguese colony's importance as a bridge between mainland China and Taiwan, adding that his office will work closely together with the main ARATS office in facilitating exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FALUN GONG FOLLOWERS DEMONSTRATE IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By David Wang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: More than a hundred Taiwan Falun Gong practitioners, joined about 1,500 U.S. followers of the spiritual movement in a demonstration Feb. 2 near the venue of the World Economic Forum in New York.
They braved chilly, drizzling rain to gather for a one-day meditation session at a hotel several blocks away from the plush Waldorf Astoria Hotel, where the World Economic Forum is being held.

One participant said that the demonstration was timed to coincide with the World Economic Forum not to disturb the high-powered forum but to draw the public's attention to the plight of the sect's mainland Chinese practitioners.
Many protesters, not least the opponents to economic globalization, have gathered in New York since the forum opened Feb. 2 and have demonstrated to seek publicity for their various causes.
The forum, organized annually by the Geneva-based foundation, World Economic Forum, has brought together about 2,700 world leaders to chart a path for the future of the world's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF MASTERCARD HOLDERS GROWS

TEXT.P: The number of people owning a MasterCard grew by nearly 40 percent in 2001 from the previous year, and total consumption also increased by 14 percent, an official of from the company said Sunday.
Tina Chiang, Taiwan regional president of MasterCard, said that 95 percent of the transactions made by Taiwan cardholders were made domestically.

The ratio of cash borrowing accounted for 13.39 percent of consumption conducted through MasterCards last year, up from 11.56 percent of the total consumption from the previous year, showing that more and more card holders have used the credit cards to borrow cash.
She predicted the ratio would rise further this year with the active promotion of issuing banks.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLEDGES TECHNOLOGY ADVANCES AND CULTURAL ENHANCEMENT

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun reaffirmed Sunday that his new Cabinet would focus on enhancing technological development, but not at the expense of enriching the cultural heritage of those on Taiwan.
Yu made the remarks while visiting Taiho village, Tungshan township, Ilan County, Sunday to pay his respects to his ancestor's family shrine and stop at nearby temples.

Yu mentioned President Chen Shui-bian's ideal of turning Taiwan into a "green silicon island" and said that his Cabinet will focus on technology development, but also stressed the importance of cultural preservation.
Yu, a self-made man whose reputation was built around his two terms as county magistrate of Ilan County, has prided himself on promoting cultural activities during his stint as the county chief.
He said that only through technology and cultural enhancement can the nation retain its competitive edge and effectively upgrade the quality of life.

Asked about whether the Cabinet will reconsider a revised law governing the allocation of government revenues, which was railroaded through the last legislature in mid-January, Yu said that the matter is now being handled by Lin Chuang, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, and the Executive Yuan will make its decision soon.
The revision, initiated by the Kuomintang (KMT) and supported by the People First Party (PFP), will force the central government to give a larger portion of its revenue to local governments.

Prior to the revision, the central government was required to give 40 percent of the government's transaction tax revenue, 10 percent of the income tax revenue and 10 percent of the excise duty to the nation's local governments, including the two special municipalities of Taipei and Kaohsiung.
Under the revised law, the percentage of revenues to be earmarked for local governments will increase to 50 percent of the transaction tax, 30 percent of the income tax and 30 percent of excise duty.

According to the government's forecast, this could see the money disbursed to the local governments increase by between NT$150 billion and NT$310 billion, which would make an enormous dent in the central government's coffers.

The revised law also advocates changes to the way the money is split among the local governments, with 15.5 percent going to Taipei City, 10 percent going to Kaohsiung City, 61.5 percent going to other counties and 7 percent going to townships.

The KMT initiated the changes at the request of Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who has seen the city's share of the central government's revenue decrease year by year, especially after the inauguration of President Chen, who was ousted from Taipei City Hall by Ma in the 1998 mayoral election.

Although the Executive Yuan said the reduction is necessary to reverse the long-standing financial imbalance between Taipei City and other countries in Taiwan, the opposition said it is a political reprisal against Ma, who is the highest-ranking elected official in the KMT and who holds promise to be the party's hope for winning back the presidency in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL PRIZE LAUREATE TO GIVE SPEECH IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Nobel prize winner Alan Heeger will arrive in Taiwan this week to talk about material technology.

Heeger, at the invitation of the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI), will give a speech on "Semiconducting and Metallic Polymers: Opportunities for Science and Technology" in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan Saturday.

Heeger, currently a physics professor at the University of California at Santa Barbara, was awarded the Nobel prize in chemistry together with Hideki Shirakawa, professor of the University of Tsukuba, and Professor Alan MacDiarmid of the University of Pennsylvania in 2000, and their research has shown that plastics could be converted to a conductor of electricity, ITRI officials said.
The officials said that Heeger's visit will give a chance to academic and industrial fields to better understand material technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PRESIDES OVER OPENING OF WIND BELL FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Sunday presided over the opening of the "2002 Kenting Wind Bell Festival" in southern Pingtung County, where he wished the people of Taiwan a prosperous Chinese New Year of the Horse, which will fall on Feb. 12 this year.

Taking advantage of Pintung's strong winds in winter and spring to promote local tourism, the Bureau of Cultural Affairs of the Pingtung County Government organized the first wind bell festival. More than 200 wind bells from Australia, Chile, India, Indonesia, Japan, South Africa, Taiwan, Europe and United States are being displayed at a local park through Feb. 17.
The event is the first of its kind in the world.

The heaviest article on display is a piece weighing 15 kilograms from Arizona of the United States, while the largest one is a three-meter work from the United States. The smallest of all is a tiny wind bell from Japan, which is about the size of a thumb.

At the same time, the bureau also erected a 13-meter landmark figure featuring a horse and a wind bell in a Kenting street. The bureau also set up a theme park at Kenting Elementary School, where visitors can take part in a series of interesting activities, such as a wind bell spa and a wind bell maze.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GEESE-WATCHING SEASON OPENS

TEXT.P: The annual Huachiang geese-watching season in Taipei formally opened Sunday with thousands of bird-watchers gathered under the Huachiang Bridge in Taipei.
With the aid of members of the Wild Bird Society in Taipei City, people used binoculars and tried to identified the different species according to illustrated guidebooks.

Most the geese that descended Sunday on banks of the Tamsui River, which runs through Taipei City, are small geese, numbered at about 5,000, a few sponge-billed geese and geese of other species could also be seen.
The geese stop in Taiwan on their migration north in the spring, and will keep flying to the island's marshes until late April -- marking the end of the Huachiang geese-watching season.
Before then, the Wild Bird Society of Taipei City will sent members to the river banks under the Huachiang Bridge every weekend to give guidance to those wanting to learn more about the birds.

The society said in a statement that the number of geese living in the geese sanctuary on the Tamsui River banks between Youngfu Bridge and Chunghsing Bridge has leveled off to between 4,700 to 7,000, thanks to the government's conservation policy.
However, the number of migratory geese stopping in Taiwan on their way north or south fell by almost half this year, possibly because of global warming, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MASTER SHENG YEN SPEAKS AT WORLD ECONOMIC FORUM
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Buddhist Master Sheng Yen delivered a speech Friday at the 32nd annual meeting of the World Economic Forum (WEF) in New York and urged tolerance and respect in a multicultural, pluralistic world to achieve true peace and lasting security.

Addressing a dinner banquet, Sheng Yen said the notion of "sacred" varies according to different people, geographic environments and eras. He stressed, however, that there is only one supreme truth -- that people should seek "common ground" to mend their differences.

"Today, in order to resolve the dangers of conflicts and avoid annihilation, we need to preserve and respect the values of different races; other than our own self-centered values, we need to be tolerant of the values held dear by others too," Sheng Yen said.

Maintaining that technology research and progress is far more than just an adventure of mankind's curiosity, Sheng Yen said the development of the biotechnology sector must take into account human ethics. He also called for the establishment of a global mechanism to monitor, supervise and assist the development of biotechnology related to cloning of human organs or human beings.

Speaking at a meeting of religious leaders earlier the same day, the Buddhist master called for a spiritual, ritual and environmental-friendly life. He stressed that a poor heart is the root problem of modern society.

"We should understand that poverty and ignorance are often interrelated. Because of poverty, it becomes difficult to access modern, pluralistic and global information. This may then lead to the isolation of cultures and ways of thinking, and result in discrimination against, belittling and rejecting whoever is different," he said.

As poverty may lead to crime, Sheng Yen said, "We should upgrade moral and religious education ... and we should make donations to poor people and exercise the power of love in the world" to help wipe out poverty.

Sheng Yen also called for providing economic aid, cultural exchanges and improving educational facilities for the so-called "fundamentalists" to give them access as a means of eradicating any forms of "fundamentalism."
"Military retaliation might have a temporary deterrent effect, but if a lasting peace is hoped for, we must follow these steps with love and patience," he suggested.

Sheng Yen, the founder and chief of the Taipei-based Dharma Drum Mountain Buddhist Association, was the first Buddhist religious leader ever invited to attend the WEF annual conference. More than 3,000 business, academic and religious leaders from across the world are taking part in this year's gathering, which opened Jan. 31 and will run through Feb. 4.

It was also the first time that the WEF annual conference is being held outside the organization's founding city -- Davos, Switzerland. The choice of New York was made as a gesture of support for the city, which was attacked by suicide terrorists Sept. 11 last year.
Sheng Yen left New York Feb. 2 and is slated to return to Taipei Feb. 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: 48 MEMBERS SELECTED TO JOIN TRAINING FOR NATIONAL TAEKWONDO TEAM

TEXT.P: A total of 48 men and women were selected Sunday to join the training courses for the Republic of China National Taekwondo Team after two days of fierce competition.

The 48 athletes -- 24 men and 24 women who cover all categories -- together with 48 others chosen last year by the Chinese Taipei Amateur Taekwondo Association, will make up this year's national team.

These 96 athletes are qualified to take part in the final selection of the national team which will participate in the Asian Championships in April, the World Cup in Tokyo in July and the Asian Games slated for September in Pusan, South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO BUILD TAIWAN INTO A TOURIST GREEN SILICON ISLAND
DOC.DATELINE: Kenting, southern tip of Taiwan, Feb. 3 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Sunday vowed to build Taiwan into a tourist "green silicon island."
The president made the promise while presiding over the world's first 2002 Kenting Wind Bell Festival held at the Kenting Primary School in Pingtung County.
President Chen stressed that a joyful and warm tourist "green silicon island" is a lofty goal for the government.

President Chen, accompanied by Deputy Secretary-General to the President Chen Che-nan, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san and Pingtung County Magistrate Su Chia-chuan, arrived at the Kenting Primary School at 10:30 am and crowds extended a warm welcome to the president.

Chen looked at all the wind bells from foreign countries displayed at the exhibition hall and he also swung one of the wind bells displayed at the exhibition to pray for peace and prosperity for the people.
He pointed out that the Kenting peninsula, which is surrounded by seas, is famous for its picturesque landscape and mountainous winds and migratory birds.
The president hoped that the festival, the first of the 12 serial of festivals to be held in Taiwan, will upgrade Taiwan's image in the international community.
More than 200 wind bells from Australia, Chile, India, Indonesia, Japan, South Africa, Europe, the United States and host Republic of China are being displayed at a local park through Feb. 17.
The festival was jointly sponsored by the Tourism Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and the Bureau of the Cultural Affairs of the Pingtung County Government.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2002 SPRING FESTIVAL COMPUTER AND MULTIMEDIA EXPO TO OPEN WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: The 2002 Spring Festival Computer and Multimedia Exposition will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center Feb. 6-10, the Taipei Computer Association announced Sunday.
The exposition will feature a national computer games hall, newly-developed computer and video games, personal computers, and notebook and palm-sized computers.
More than 200 local computer, games and software manufacturers will be on hand in 1,000 stalls in seven different areas over the five-day exhibition.

The exposition will be divided into the games software area, the educational software area, the applied software area, the multimedia computer area, the hardware and peripherals area, the online area and the professional media area.

In conjunction with the government's declaration that the year 2002 will be a digital year, a national main theme hall will be set up during the exhibiting period. The main contents will include a 2002 game contest, the first 4C creation contest and a software creation contest.
Several world famous software games manufacturers including Aqi Twp Corp., Gamemania, Q.A. Gamer and others will also be at the exposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT RELEASES EX-LEGISLATOR LO FU-CHU

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court has decided to immediately release former Legislator Lo Fu-chu after finding that the detention by the prosecutor's office of Lo by force did not follow legal procedures, a court official said Sunday.

Lo, who lost his legislative protection last Friday, was detained by force by law enforcement officials Friday afternoon due to his alleged involvement in fraud, destroying evidence and since officers felt that he was a flight risk.
Lo did not reply to questions since he felt that he had been wrongly detained. Prosecutors appealed to the court to formally detain Lo.
A joint court comprising three judges decided to release Lo immediately after a two-hour debate.

Lo told local media after his release that he appreciated the court judges decision which permitted him to explain his side of the story. He stressed that he still has faith in the judicial system and promised that he was willing to attend any court investigation.
Lo refused to answer any direct questions, but only said that he was under a great deal of pressure.
A prosecutor at the prosecutor's office of the Taiwan High Court said further appeals will be made to bring Lo into custody.
The prosecutor said his office is also worried about the safety of the informant who told authorities of Lo's unlawful acts.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALAN VICE FOREIGN MINISTER TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Guatemala Vice Foreign Minister Ramiro Ordonez Jonama will arrive in Taipei Monday for a five-day visit.
While in Taiwan, Ordonez will call on Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien and his counterpart C. M. Lan, in addition to visiting economic and cultural establishments.
On behalf of the Guatemalan government, Ordonez will confer the medal of "Orden del Quetzal en el Grado de Gran Cruz" upon Lan in recognition of his outstanding contribution to bilateral ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER SHOWS WILLINGNESS TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Sunday he is willing to visit mainland China in his capacity as the head of Taiwan's highest representative body of public opinion if permitted by President Chen Shui-bian and four preconditions can be guaranteed.
Wang, who was re-elected recently the speaker of the Legislative Yuan, made the announcement while giving a keynote speech on parliamentary reform and improved Taiwan-mainland ties.

Wang said he is willing to travel to mainland China for discussions on issues of mutual concern for people in both Taiwan and mainland China should President Chen allow him to do so and the four prerequisites -- national needs, public consent, parliamentary approval and reciprocity -- be respected.

According to Wang, he will also form a new and non-partisan cross-Taiwan Strait task force at the fifth legislature, which opened Feb. 1, to help the government's executive branch forge better ties with mainland China.

As communication channels between Taiwan and mainland China through the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) remained deadlocked, Wang said the resumption of cross-strait dialogue is vital to improved bilateral relations.

Systemic SEF-ARATS negotiations were unilaterally suspend by Beijing in 1996 after former President Lee Teng-hui paid an unofficial visit to the United States in 1995, which Beijing viewed as a covert move to promote Taiwan independence.
The semi-official SEF and ARATS are authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to deal with two-way exchanges in the absence of government-to-government contacts between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN YAO CHIA-WEN MEETS WITH TAIWANESE IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Yao Chia-wen, an advisor to President Chen Shui-bian, said here Sunday that he has decided to run for the chairmanship of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in May.

Yao, who was DPP chairman in 1987-88, made the disclosure when he delivered a speech on the current political situations of Taiwan at a luncheon meeting attended by some 300 overseas Taiwanese living in Japan. Among the dignitaries welcoming Yao at the meeting was Lo Fu-chen, representative of the Republic of China in Japan.
Yao said he has to win the support of most DPP leaders before he can formally announce his candidacy for DPP chairmanship.
He arrived in Japan on Saturday for a brief visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 4, or the 23rd day of the 12th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1789: George Washington is elected as the first president of the United States.
1793: France abolishes slavery in all its territories.
1810: Tsar Alexander I of Russia refuses to grant Napoleon his sister Anna's hand in marriage. The Russian tsar's plans to liberalize the government were forestalled by wars with Napoleon.
1899: Fighting breaks out in the newest U.S. protectorate, the Philippines, which declared itself a republic the previous month.
1902: Charles Lindbergh, the American aviator who made the first solo flight over the Atlantic Ocean, is born.
1904: The Russo-Japanese war breaks out.
1906: The New York Police Department adopts fingerprint-lifting methods for the collection of evidence in criminal cases.
1922: China signs an agreement with Japan in Washington, D.C., to settle the Shantung dispute.
1938: Joachim von Ribbentrop becomes foreign minister of Germany while Hitler assumes the office of war minister.
1945: Leaders of the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union meet in Yalta, USSR and reach the so-called "Yalta secret agreement." According to the pact, Soviet troops are to enter the war against Japan on the condition that its former land rights in China, taken by Japan in 1904, are to be restored later.
1948: Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) gains independence from Britain.
1949: Taiwan Provincial Governor Chen Cheng publicizes the practice of the Farm Rental Reduction Program, which was put into force on April 12 of the same year.
1966: An All Nippon Airway plane crashes at Tokyo's Haneda Airport, killing all 133 people aboard.
1969: Liao Ho-shu, Communist China's charge d'affaires in the Netherlands, arrives in the United States and requests political asylum.
1973: The Asian Relations Association opens its Japan office in Tokyo.
1976: A disastrous earthquake measuring 7.5 on the Richter scale jolts Guatemala, claiming more than 22,000 lives.
1976: Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs H.K. Yang decorates Dr. Tare Takemi, president of the Japan Medical Association, with the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Cordon.
1978: Junius Jayawardene becomes the first president of Sri Lanka.
1978: Fan Yuan-yen, the defecting Communist Chinese pilot who flew a MiG-19 to Taiwan the previous July, writes an open letter to the United Nations condemning human rights violations by the Beijing regime.
1980: Abolhassan Bani-Sadr becomes the first elected president of Iran. He is expected to follow the line of the country's de facto ruler, religious leader Ayatollah Khomeini.
1986: Twelve political dissidents jailed in Taiwan for the Formosa magazine incident are released on parole. The incident occurred in 1979 when political dissidents clashed with police while celebrating the anniversary of the publication of the magazine.
1992: The Republic of China's Fair Trade Law goes into effect.
1997: Two military helicopters collide in mid-air in a storm in northern Israel, killing 73 Israeli soldiers.
1998: A strong earthquake measuring 6.1 on the Richter scale hits northern Afghanistan, killing 4,000 and leaving more than 15,000 homeless.
2000: Three Indonesian workers at the sixth naphtha cracking plant owned by Taiwan Plastic Corp. are killed in an accident while cleaning gas pipelines.
2001: The opposition Kuomintang's spokesman Jason Hu urges President Chen Shui-bian to resume construction of the controversial fourth nuclear power plant which was halted by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's announcement last Oct. 27.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I am not the one born with understanding. I am only the one who has given himself to the study of antiquity and is diligent in seeking for understanding in such studies."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Monday are as follows:
The China Times:
Bereaved families of laborers who had not joined labor insurance program and had died from workplace disasters will receive compensation.
The United Daily News:
Police refuse to remand Lo; prosecutors to file protest.
The Liberty Times:
The Cabinet will decide whether to ask the legislature to review the revenues and expenditures allocation law.
The Taiwan Daily:
Prosecutors and controversial former independent lawmaker Lo Fu-chu accuse each other of intimidation.
The Central Daily News:
The Cabinet is mulling whether to seek legislative review of the revenues and expenditures allocation law.
The China Post:
The opposition Kuomintang set for showdown over local government budgets.
The Taiwan News:
U.S. draws fire at World Economic Forum.
The Taipei Times:
U.S. says it's ready for further strikes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR LEAVES FOR VISITS TO LONDON, AMSTERDAM
DOC.DATELINE: Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Feb. 4 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou departed Taipei late Sunday night for a five-day visit to Britain and the Netherlands.
Ma is mainly scheduled to deliver a speech at Oxford University and to try to become better acquainted with the tourism industries of the two countries.

The Taipei mayor will first call at several government offices and public-run establishments in London Monday, including the Tourist Board and the Tate Modern Gallery, to hear briefings on Britain's tourism development and culture-related activities.
On Monday afternoon, Ma will attend a colloquium on the education of overseas Chinese in Europe to be hosted by the Overseas Chinese Education Center in London.

Ma is then scheduled to deliver a keynote speech Tuesday at the Taiwan Research Chair of Oxford University's Center of Asian Studies on the topic of The Challenges of Cross-Taiwan Strait Relations in the 21st Century.

Before delivering the speech Tuesday, Ma will continue his whirlwind visit in London, including a stop at the headquarters of the National Trust to gain an understanding of the revitalization and rescue of cultural legacies in Britain, as well as a stop at the Thames River to view waterway transportation planning and operations of the most celebrated river in Britain.

The mayor is then scheduled to fly across the English Channel to Amsterdam for a two-day visit Wednesday and Thursday. In Amsterdam, Ma will be joined by four officials of the Taipei City government, including Huang Jung-fung, director of the Bureau of Business Management.
Ma and the Taipei officials will call at Dutch agencies in charge of canal management and tourism business, in addition to touring flower auction markets and related facilities.

They will also attempt to gain an understanding during their visit of how the Dutch people preserve their cultural legacies, including vintage houses and architecture, and related renaissance technologies and skills.
Ma and his group are scheduled to return to Taipei Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 8.08 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 8.08 points to close at 5,849.85.
Market turnover amounted to NT$87.76 billion (US$2.51 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: MANY FOREIGN WORKERS IN TAIPEI TEST POSITIVE FOR PARASITIC DISEASES

TEXT.P: Nearly 1,400 foreign laborers in Taipei were found during 2001 to be carriers of parasitic diseases and thus potential threats in terms of spreading their disease in their place of employment, according to the Taipei City Government's Bureau of Health.

According to the bureau, a total of 1,370 foreign helpers, most of whom work as domestic helpers in private households or at nursing homes, tested positive during health checks last year as carriers of intestinal parasitic diseases -- a threat to household sanitation and people's health.

The bureau conducted health checks on more than 50,000 foreign laborers in Taipei during 2001. Of the total, more than 1,400 people, or 2.76 percent, were found to not meet the standards in terms of health and medical considerations.

A high of 92.6 percent of those who did not meet the standards, or a total of 1,370 helpers, tested positive for intestinal parasitic diseases, bureau officials said, adding that this signifies that 1,370 households or nursing homes are under the threat of being infected by related diseases through the presence of these helpers.
Lu Hui-chen, director of the Bureau of Health, called for private households which employ foreign domestic helpers to pay special attention to their employees.

She emphasized that the foreign helpers should be encouraged to stringently maintain a high level of personal sanitation, including the habits of frequently washing their hands and of being extra careful when preparing food.

According to Lu, all foreign laborers from overseas receive regular health checks in Taipei -- once every six months -- to help monitor their health condition. If any are found to be carriers of serious contagious diseases or fatal diseases, such as AIDS, they are forcefully repatriated.

Intestinal parasitic disease patients, however, are not forced to leave the country as the disease is not an internationally declared disease, Lu said, adding that carriers can continue to work in Taiwan as long as they continue to receive medical treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 8.08 points to close at 5,849.85.
The bourse opened at 5,867.45 and fluctuated between 5,909.46 and 5,834.5 during trading.
A total of 2.94 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$87.76 billion (US$2.51 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile issues moving up the most at 3 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 1.2 percent, and cement stocks at 0.2 percent.

The other major categories posted losses, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 2 percent, followed by construction stocks and foodstuff shares, both at 0.6 percent, and bank and insurance stocks and electrical shares, both at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 423 to 185, with 72 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Monday as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for February moved down 20 points to close at 5,838, with 10,370 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March lost 12 points to close at 5,818, with 99 contract transactions, while September futures fell 100 points to close at 5,850, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,858 for February, 5,830 for March, 5,900 for June, 5,950 for September, and 5,988 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
February TE futures moved down 2.6 points to close at 308, with 2,001 contract transactions, while March TE futures decreased 3.4 points to finish at 305.2, with 28 contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
February TF futures moved up 1.6 points to finish at 726.4, with 692 contract transactions, while March TF futures rose 3.2 points to close at 726.2, with seven contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTHORITIES PONDERING CONSCRIPT ALTERNATIVES FOR SPORTS TALENT

TEXT.P: Officials from the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) are pondering special alternative conscript programs to allow talented athletes approaching the age of 20 not to discontinue their sports training because of Taiwan's compulsory two-year military service.

MOI officials are now discussing with their counterparts from the Ministry of National Defense and the Cabinet-level National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports (NCPFS) about the feasibility of allowing the young gifted athletes to perform their compulsory military service as replacements who are only required to serve for 35 days, or possibly allowing them to serve two-year alternative programs in non-military fields, such as serving as sports instructors in schools or community centers.

As of today, the only athletes approaching the age of 20 who have been allowed to perform the 35-day "replacement" service have been those who are athletes on national teams or who have won medals at international meets. So far, approval to perform the "replacement" service has only been granted to 14 such athletes.

As the great majority of athletes in Taiwan are unable to meet this standard, they are forced at the age of 20 to perform the regular compulsory military service -- thus resulting in the discontinuation of their sports training for at least two years.

Since the new Interior Minister Yu Cheng-hsien, who previously served as Kaohsiung County magistrate and was known for his love of sports and his fervent support for athletic activities, took office Feb. 1, the MOI has begun pushing for the implementation of the alternative military service policy for gifted athletes to allow them to continue their training uninterrupted and maintain their high level of performance even while they perform their mandatory military service duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRIALISTS DISCUSS CHALLENGES AND CHANGES FACING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Industrialists attending a symposium Monday on challenges and changes facing Taiwan's hi-tech industries stressed the importance of the government setting up a certification standard applicable to locally-made as well as imported products.

Shen Yen-shih, chairman of the Apex Biotechnology Corp., said that Taiwan manufacturers will face fiercer competition from international corporations since Taiwan has become a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO).

While intellectual property and patent rights will be of great importance to competitiveness, Shen suggested that local manufacturers should have long-term research plans and develop their own patent products.
Hu Ting-hua, chairman of the chipset supplier Macronix International Co., said that local manufacturers in general were weak in acquiring intellectual property rights and developing their own brands.

Foreseeing that mainland China will eventually become a low-cost manufacturing hub of the semiconductor sector, Hu said that Taiwan needs to find new niches based on the existing advantages of strong design capabilities and its ability to raise capital.

In the telecommunications sector, Liu Chao-kai, general manager of Tecom Co., said that telecommunications technologies have advanced remarkably in the past five years. On the other hand, profit margins of the manufacturers have been declining.
To maintain competitiveness, Liu said that a manufacturer should keep operations economical and emphasize research and development as well as marketing.

Liu Yung-sheng, director of the Industrial Technology Research Institute's Opto-electronics and Systems Laboratories, said that Taiwan has become an important supplier of such opto-electronic products as optical storage equipment and panels, with the production value amounting to NT$400 billion a year.
He said that innovation and patent rights are vital for local manufacturers to improve their international competitiveness. Liu called on local manufacturers to form an alliance on patent rights.
Meanwhile, the China External Trade Development Council may help Taiwan manufacturers to promote the image of Taiwan products in the international market, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE MUM ON OPENING OF ARATS OFFICE IN MACAU
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Feb. 4 (CNA) (By Stanley Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Representative to Macau Tsai Chih-chung kept mum Monday on the opening of an office in Macau by Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), a quasi-official body authorized to handle talks with Taiwan.

"We have heard of the ARATS plan to open an office in Macau. As we remain unaware of its purposes, we should refrain from making any speculative comments on the ARATS move," said Tsai, head of the Taipei Trade and Tourism Office in Macau.

According to customary practices, Tsai said, the ARATS' Taiwan counterpart is the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF). "If the new ARATS' Macau office intends to deal with Taiwan-related affairs in the future, it will have to contact the SEF headquarters in Taipei.
Liu Gangqi, the mainland Chinese official in charge of Taiwan affairs at Beijing's liaison office in Macau, announced Sunday that ARATS would open an office in Macau Monday.

In his announcement, Liu said, the opening of an ARATS office in Macau signifies the former Portuguese colony's importance as a conduit for exchanges across the Taiwan Strait. Liu further said the new office will work closely with ARATS headquarters in facilitating cross-strait interchanges.
Local sources said the Beijing liaison office in Macau didn't send any invitation to the Taipei representative office to attend the opening ceremony for the new ARATS office.
Beijing has unilaterally suspended regular cross-strait dialogue for more than three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20TH WORKING MEETING OF ROC DIPLOMATS IN AFRICA TO BE HELD FEB. 7-8

TEXT.P: The 20th working meeting of the Republic of China diplomats in Africa is scheduled to be held Feb. 7-8 in Mbabane, Swaziland, sources with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Monday.

The meeting will be presided over by Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Chiou Jong-nan, with ROC ambassadors and representatives stationed in the African region, as well as officials at the Board of Foreign Trade, Government Information Office and International Cooperation and Development Fund taking part.
The main purpose of the annual working meeting is to review the results of the ROC's diplomatic work in the African region and map out a guideline for future work.

Participants will propose reports on the carrying out of bilateral and multilateral cooperative agreements between the ROC and African nations as well as exchange views on developments in politics, economics and society in the African region and relevant issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST MAINALND CHINESE TOUR GROUP ARRIVING TUESDAY

TEXT.P: A 15-member tour group of mainland Chinese nationals residing in Japan is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Tuesday for a four-day sightseeing trip, a spokesman for International Tour Operations (ITO) said Tuesday.

It will be the first mainland tour group to visit Taiwan since the Republic of China government opened the door for overseas mainland citizens to make group tours of the island at the beginning of this year.
ITO Vice President Lee Ta-wen said most of the members of the group are leaders of major mainland Chinese organizations in the Osaka and Kobe areas and that some of them operate travel agencies.
"All of the members are male and mostly in their 60s or 70s," the spokesman said," Lee said. "In addition to sightseeing, some of the members intend to survey the tourist market here."

During their stay, the group will visit popular northern Taiwan tourist attractions, including the National Palace Museum, the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, Keelung, Wulai and Chiufen as well as major tourist hotels and restaurants in the region.

ITO, the local travel agency which organizes the tour package for the mainland group, said the group has demanded high-quality room and catering services. The group will stay at the five-star Taipei Westin Hotel.

Among the members is Lin Tung-chun, a 77-year-old mainland Chinese resident in Kobe. He was quoted as having told Taiwan journalists stationed in Japan that he was very excited to be able to visit Taiwan.

"Taiwan is so close to Kobe, but I have waited for nearly 50 years to enter the island," Lin said. He moved from mainland China's Fujian province to the southwestern Japanese port city of Kobe when he was nine years old. In 1959, he made a transit stop at a Taiwan international airport on his way to Europe. As he held a mainland passport, he was banned from enter Taiwan at that time.
Lin, who is now honorary chairman of the largest mainland Chinese association in Kobe, said he most yearns to visit Taipei's Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall during his stay in Taiwan.
As overseas mainland Chinese people are only allowed to make group tours of Taiwan, ITO executives said they don't leave any free time for individual members.

As part of its efforts to boost exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan began Jan. 1 to allow mainland Chinese citizens with permanent foreign residency or mainland students studying abroad to make pleasure trips to the island.
Meanwhile, the Taipei Association of Travel Agents (TATA) said the second mainland tour group may arrive after the Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 12 this year.
Tourist sources said scores of mainland Chinese residents in San Francisco have expressed interest in joining a Taiwan-mainland China tour package organized by a travel agency there.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MAY USE `TAIWAN' IN FUTURE FREE TRADE AGREEMENTS: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Christine Tsung said Monday that the Republic of China might use the name "Taiwan" in future signings of free trade agreements with other countries instead of using its designated name for use in the World Trade Organization (WTO).
"As long as the other side agrees, why not?" Tsung said while inspecting the Board of Foreign Affairs (BOFT) under her ministry.
Taiwan formally became the 144th WTO member Jan. 1 under the name "The Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu."

According to the BOFT, almost all countries and economies in the world have signed at least one regional free trade agreement, with the exception of mainland China, Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT BESTOWS MEDAL ON FORMER PREMIER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian decorated former Premier Chang Chun-hsiung Monday with the Medal of Propitious Clouds of First Grade for his contribution to the country during his one-plus years in office.

Similar honors were also given to former Vice Premier Lai In-jaw and former Secretary-General of the Executive Yuan Chiou I-jen who received Medals of Brilliant Star of First Grade and Second Grade, respectively.
Chang said at the ceremony that the medal he received is not only his honor but also that of his entire Cabinet.

He noted that during the last 483 days when he was in office, Taiwan experienced the first transfer of power between different political parties. The result left the nation with an administration with the ruling party as the minority in the legislature. Taiwan has also been weathering a global economic recession.

Now, Chang said, the domestic political situation is stabilizing, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has become the biggest party in the Legislative Yuan, and the economy is recovering. This all means that he has completed his phase of the country's mission.
Chang attributed this to the support from the president and the people of the country, as well as the efforts of his Cabinet team.
Meanwhile, Lai said the medal represents the highest honor in his life, while Chiou expressed gratitude to Chang and Lai for assisting him to grow and learn.

Also present at the ceremony were Premier Yu Shyi-kun; Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng; Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng; Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh; Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien and other high-ranking government officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI'S UNEMPLOYMENT THIRD-LOWEST IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taipei's unemployment averaged 3.95 percent last year, the third-lowest level among Taiwan's 23 cities and counties, according to statistics released recently by the Taipei City Government.

The statistics made public by the municipal Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics showed that the ratio was up by 1.24 percentage points over its 2000 level but was lower than the country's average of 4.57 percent, a 20-year high.

Despite the fact that the country's economy has weathered a recession due to a global economic slump and a massive relocation of Taiwan businesses to other countries, the department said it found Taipei's unemployment has been lower than that of other regions in the recent two years. It said that it is an indication that firms based in Taipei have stronger demand for workers.
The department added that 73.9 percent of job seekers in Taipei will find a job through executive research advertisements in newspapers or small red notes posted on street notice boards.

In terms of educational backgrounds of the jobless people in Taipei, the department said the unemployment of the job seekers with a higher-education degree in Taipei was 3.06 percent last year, well below the average 5.06 percent among junior high school graduates.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SUSPENDS PARTY RIGHTS FOR FOUR NEW CABINET MEMBERS

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) announced Monday it has decided to suspend all "party rights" to four of its members who have joined the new Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led Cabinet.

Chen Keng-chin, head of the KMT's party disciplinary committee, said the four members to have their party rights suspended are Minister of National Defense Tang Yao-ming, Veteran Affairs Commission Chairman Yang Teh-chih, National Coast Guard Administration Administrator Wang Chun and Minister without Portfolio Tsai Ching-yen.

Chen said the four members have violated the party mandate which says that its members cannot serve in the new DPP Cabinet. This, the party elders have said, is to enhance political accountability and strengthen party politics in Taiwan's young democracy.

"As the four members have expressed their deep feelings for the KMT and promised to abide by the principles of administrative neutrality in their work and to refrain from doing anything harmful to the KMT, we have decided to give them a more lenient penalty," Chen explained.
Instead of expelling them from the party, Chen said, the KMT will only suspend their rights as members during their terms of office as punishment.
Chen stressed that the KMT ban was mainly aimed at promoting healthy development of Taiwan's fledgling democracy through upgrading political accountability.
Chen said the party will decide how to discipline its members serving as vice ministers or deputy agency heads in the new Cabinet after the Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 12 this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW GOVERNOR OF TAIWAN PROVINCE SWORN IN

TEXT.P: Fang Kuang-chun took over the post of governor of Taiwan Province Monday from his predecessor Chang Po-ya, with Minister without Portfolio Lin Sheng-feng presiding over the ceremony.
Fang, former chairman of the Council for Hakka Affairs, was the head of the second streamlined Taiwan Provincial Government.

Stressing that he will seek to make the Taiwan Provincial Government an efficient team by injecting it with a new lease on life and creativity, Fang encouraged all staff workers to use new thinking and work vigorously at future tasks.

Meanwhile, Yu Lin-ya was sworn in as the speaker of the Taiwan Provincial Consultative Council, taking the post from Fan Chen-tsung, chairman of the Council of Agriculture in the new Cabinet which was installed Feb. 1.
Yu vowed to build a new culture in the provincial government in line with the central government's pledges of political reform and economic prosperity.
Governor Fang and Minister Lin witnessed the event.
The consultative body provides the Taiwan Provincial Government with business information and references.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO CONTRIBUTING TO WORLD PROSPERITY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday the Republic of China is more than willing to pay back to the international community for the assistance it received in the past.

"As a member of the international community, we are willing to share our developmental experience and results with other countries in return for the assistance we received in our development process," Chen said while meeting with foreign delegates who are here to attend the 2002 World Freedom Day celebration activities.
Chen further said the ROC will also do its utmost to contribute to international cooperation and prosperity in the new century.

The World Freedom Day activities are organized by the ROC Chapter of the World League for Freedom and Democracy (WLFD). Chen met with the representatives from South Korea, Senegal, Poland, the Philippines and other countries at the Presidential Office.

Chen said the organization and working agenda of the WLFD have evolved along with the general world trends. "Its focus has evolved from anti-totalitarianism to strive for freedom, democracy and human rights," he noted.

Over the years, Chen said, the WLFD has achieved many remarkable accomplishments and won world recognition. With the end the Cold War, he went on, the international community is now pursuing closer cooperation and strategic alliance on the principles of reciprocity and equality.
Chen said the terrorist attacks in the United States Sept. 21, 2001 has further betrayed the importance of international cooperation in safeguarding world peace and security.
As a member of the world society, Chen said, the ROC will work even closer with other countries in promoting world peace, cooperation and prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO REINFORCE ITS SERVICES TO HI-TECH MANUFACTURERS

TEXT.P: The China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will reinforce its services to hi-tech manufacturers in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in terms of marketing research, products promotion, and training of management personnel, CETRA Chairman Shea Jia-dong said Monday.

Presiding over the inauguration of CETRA's service center in the industrial park, Shea said that the trade promotion organization set up an office in Hsinchu two years ago. In order to reinforce its services to the hi-tech manufacturers, CETRA decided to move the office close to its clients.

In the past two years, the Hsinchu office sponsored 111 seminars on trade opportunities and market analysis which were attended by 4,200 business people. CETRA marketing experts also visited 350 factories in Hsinchu and the neighboring area to provide on-site consultations, according to Shea.

Shea said that the electronics, information, opto-electronics, semiconductors, biotechnology as well as aviation manufacturers in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park were important foreign exchange earners. The CETRA service center will help the manufacturers acquire updated market information and coordinate their sales promotion efforts.

The trade official said that Taiwan's manufacturing industries are facing fiercer international competition since Taiwan has become a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO). The CETRA service center in Hsinchu will cooperate with local governments and trade associations to help the manufacturers improve their product competitiveness.

There are around 300 hi-tech companies in the Hsinchu industrial park, mostly concerned with integrated circuits, computer and peripherals, telecommunications, opto-electronics, precision machinery and materials, and biotechnology sectors.

CETRA, a non-profit organization founded in 1970, now has four local branch offices in Hsinchu, Taichung, Tainan, Kaohsiung, and 38 overseas branch offices worldwide. In addition to the global marketing information network, CETRA's functions include exhibitions, design promotion, trade education and convention services.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CSE FREIGHTER CHRISTENED, DELIVERED
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Feb. 4 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A new bulk cargo freighter ordered by the China Steel Express Corp. (CSE) and built by the China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSC) was christened and delivered Monday.
The christening and delivery ceremony for the "China Steel Excellency" was held at the CSC dock in Kaohsiung and attended by some 100 dignitaries from the shipbuilding and shipping sectors.

The "China Steel Excellency," measuring 289 meters in length, 45 meters in width and 24.1 meters in height, is the first of an order of four of the ships ordered by the CSE. Construction of the other three vessels is still under way.
With a draught of 17.78 meters and a dead weight of 175,600 metric tons, the freighter has a maximum speed of 18 knots.
CSE is affiliated with the China Steel Enterprise Group.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAREASTONE ACQUIRES SYNDICATED LOAN OF NT$ 4.3 BILLION

TEXT.P: Nine foreign and domestic banks signed an agreement Friday to grant a syndicated bank loan of NT$4.3 billion (US$122.2 million) to Fareastone Telecommunications Co.

In addition to Citibank, N.A., which was commissioned by Fareastone to forge the loan, the eight domestic banks involved are Bank of Taiwan, Taiwan Cooperative Bank, First Commercial Bank, Hua Nan Commercial Bank, Chang Hwa Commercial Bank, Taipei Bank, E. Sun Bank, and Asia Pacific Bank.

Fareastone, one of Taiwan's leading wireless service providers, said the approval of the five-year loan is a reflection of the confidence customers have in the company due to its good credibility and bright business prospects.
The loan carries an interest rate of 3.4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER HEARS ECONOMIC PLANNING COUNCIL'S WORK PLANS

TEXT.P: New Vice Premier Lin Hsin-yi, who is concurrently chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), heard a report Monday on the CEPD's work plans for this year.

Major work plans for 2002 will include establishing an information center on real estate transactions, blueprints for an IC design park, a bio-technology park, a national flower park, a free trade harbor, development of a knowledge-based economy and employment of foreign personnel with scientific and technological backgrounds.
According to CEPD Vice Chairwoman Ho Mei-yueh, Lin chaired the first working meeting of the CEPD after he assumed the new post Feb. 1.
He instructed officials and researchers of the council to try to present their research with easily understandable language and to step up communications with the public and lawmakers, Ho said.
Lin said that CEPD officials will be given more say in their responsible sectors in the future so that they can participate in the policymaking process.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEXTILE BODY RECOMMENDS LABOR DIVISION BETWEEN TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Textile Federation called Monday for a division of labor between the textile industries of Taiwan and mainland China as a way for local industry to survive the impact of the country's access to the World Trade Organization (WTO).
In a report to the Board of Foreign Trade under he Economics Ministry, the federation noted that Taiwan's WTO access entails the opening of its market to foreign textile manufacturers.

That means the country will no longer be able to prohibit the import of mainland textiles, while the protective measure that stipulates that textiles aimed for the domestic market must be made with home-supplied materials will be done away with.

As a result, textile manufacturers catering to the domestic market may turn to mainland suppliers for their materials, dealing a hard blow to local producers of yarn, cloth and other fibers, which constitute a market of NT$4.94 billion (US$141.14 million) per year.

To cushion the impact, the federation recommended that the government help local manufacturers to develop overseas markets more aggressively, and that the textile manufacturing process be divided between the mainland and Taiwan to make best use of each side's advantages, such as Taiwan's well-developed synthetic fiber manufacturing industry and the mainland's cheap labor that is suited to garment processing.
The report admitted, however, that such a division of labor would be impossible without direct trade and transportation links across the Taiwan Strait.

Taiwan's labor-intensive dyeing and finishing industry is most vulnerable to mainland competition and will therefore urgently need to transfer some of its operations to the mainland unless the government allows manufacturers to hire more foreign laborers or lets conscripts work in the industry as an alternative to military service, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIGH-TECH INDUSTRY SHOULD VALUE INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY: EXPERTS
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Feb. 4 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's high-tech industry should place greater importance on developing its own ideas rather than relying on foreign technology, experts and industry leaders said Monday.

At a seminar on the new challenges and opportunities for the local high-tech industry with the island's World Trade Organization accession, Macronix International Chairman Hu Ding-hua said that Taiwan remains weak in marketing its own brand-name products and accumulating its own intellectual property.

Hu said that Taiwan could take the path of establishing design centers for new and value-added high-tech products, as mainland China is expected to replace the island as a low-cost manufacturing center for such products in the future.

Meanwhile, Apex Biotechnology Corp. Chairman Thomas Y. Shen urged biotechnology research institutions to value local talent and local patents, adding that Taiwan biotech companies must establish their own design teams instead of just buying available technology.

Liu Jung-sheng, head of the Opto-Electronics and Systems Laboratories under the Industrial Technology Research Institute, pointed out that although Taiwan's global CD-R market share is over 80 percent, the island receives only approximately 30 percent of the global share of related patent licensing fees.

Liu recommended that Taiwan companies should consider establishing a "patent strategic alliance" and should attach higher value to patents if they want to avoid becoming victims of global competition.
The seminar, organized by the China External Trade Development Council, took place at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, which is home to approximately 300 local high-tech companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLANS FOR SEF OFFICE IN MACAU: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An official of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday that the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) has no plans to set up an office in Macau.
However, the official stressed that the MAC is willing to exchange views with the Beijing authorities over the setting up of such an office.

The MAC official made the remarks on the same day that a Macau Office of the Association for Relations Across Taiwan Strait (ARATS) became operational Monday. The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official bodies set up by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties between the two sides.
The MAC, the nation's policy-making body on mainland Chinese affairs, said that while the opening of the ARATS office in Macau is important, it is a mainland internal affair.
The official pointed out that Taiwan has an office in Macau to deal with issues related to Taiwan-Macau exchanges and that its functions are being expanded.
He said Beijing set up the Macau ARATS office to strengthen its work toward Taiwan and is part of a new policy toward Taiwan announced recently by mainland Vice Premier Qian Qichen.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC PLANS TO RELEASE 66% OF SHARES WITHIN A YEAR

TEXT.P: The Chinese Petroleum Corporation (CPC) is planning to release 66 percent of its shares within a year, in conjunction with the program to privatize state-run enterprises, a senior CPC official said Monday.
CPC Board Chairman Chen Chao-wei pointed out, however, that the CPC privatization project has still to be approved by the Legislative Yuan.

Lin Wen-yen, vice chairman of the Commission of National Corporations under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said CPC has worked out the selection guidelines for financial consultants for bidding on CPC shares and has submitted them to the commission.
He added that the commission will also evaluate CPC's assets before submitting its findings to the Legislative Yuan for deliberation.

At present, several renowned financial consulting companies, including Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch and Kao Sheng Securities Co., have expressed interests in brokering CPC shares, Lin went on, adding that the decision will be made in the first half of this year.
Lin said it is hoped that CPC share buyers will include international oil companies and that petroleum-producing countries in the Middle East will become CPC overseas strategic investors.
Asked whether the Formosa Plastics Group could become a CPC stockholder, Lin said this might be a possibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF ISSUES REINSURANCE REGULATIONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) has issued a set of regulations, effective April 1, for insurance companies involved in the reinsurance business, an MOF official said Monday.

According to the official, financial reinsurance is a one-year contract signed between the insurer and the insured under the terms of which, the insured pays reinsurance fees to the insurer in return for a financial loan.

According to the regulations, insurance companies that want to offer reinsurance must meet qualification requirements set by either the Chinese Crediting Corp., Standard & Poor's, Moody's Investors Service, A.M. Best Corp., or Fitch IBCA Ltd.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTION FOR RECONSIDERATION OF REVENUE LAW IS LAST RESORT: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will ask the legislature to reconsider the newly revised Law Governing the Allocation of Government Revenues and Expenditures only as a last resort, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Monday.

Fielding questions from journalists while inspecting the Ministry of the Interior, the premier, who was only sworn in on Friday, said he will leave no stone unturned in his efforts to solve the problems caused by the revised law. He added that a motion for the legislature to reconsider the revision is the last thing he wants to see.
Any motion for reconsideration of any measures should be put forward within seven days of legislative approval, which in this case means Wednesday.
Yu said his administration would prefer to sort out its differences with the opposition through amicable communications.

The revised law railroaded through the opposition-controlled legislature on the final day of the last legislature obliges the administration to hand over a larger proportion of central government revenues to local governments, which the central government says will cause a financial gap of NT$150 billion (US$4.28 billion) in its budget.
Besides, the premier went on, the revised rules will deprive his administration of the power to ensure that revenue distributed to local government is used for the purposes for which it is allocated.
Instead of "giving a bigger slice of the pie" to local government, as claimed by its sponsors, Yu said, the revised law is "robbing Peter to pay Paul."
Yu said he is weighing various options available to his administration and will try to find a way around the problem without causing a confrontation between the executive and legislative branches.

Meanwhile, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -- which mastermind the revision -- stuck to its guns Monday, with KMT Chairman Lien Chan saying that the revision is a result of "careful studies by his party" that has won the support of the majority in the legislature and that there is no question of the KMT backing down on the issue.

KMT Legislative Whip Lin Yi-shih urged the Executive Yuan to drop the option of reconsideration, saying it will pit the ruling party against the opposition again in the legislature and therefore stir up political unrest.
The legislature will be forced to act on the motion for reconsideration within seven days if it is put forward by the Executive Yuan, or the revision will automatically lapse.

However, if the legislature upholds the revision with a simple majority vote, the Executive Yuan will be pushed to the brink of either accepting the setback or asking the president to dissolve the legislature and order a snap election.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO HELP RELIGIOUS MENTAL THERAPY CENTER TO BE LEGALIZED

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has agreed that the controversial mental sanitarium Lung Fa Temple can be legalized and allowed to receive "less seriously" mentally challenged patients, DOH officials said Monday.
The Lung Fa Temple, established 31 years ago in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, has aroused controversy over the years with its so-called religious and folk therapies for the mentally ill.

For many years, patients and their families have complained about the temple's inhumane treatment that includes shackling patients and forcing them to work outside bareheaded in conditions more reminiscent of a labor camp.
However, temple officials claim that "some patients" have completely recovered after the "treatment" offered, which they said uses no medicine and is free of charge.

According to the officials, the "miracles" achieved by the temple have drawn much attention around the world and many invitations have been issued to the founder of the temple, Master Shih Kai-feng, inviting him to introduce another so-called "Taiwan experience."

In 1997, Stanford University of the United States invited Shih to give a lecture about the psychological rehabilitation of the chronically mentally challenged and to visit some psychiatric and psychological sanitariums nearby to meet various experts.
A band made up of temple patients has visited many Asian countries, including mainland China, during recent years and their performances have been highly acclaimed.
However, the temple had no links with sanitary or medical institutions until 2000, when Shih finally agreed to let qualified doctors offer treatment at the temple.

Tan Kai-yuan, the director of the DOH Bureau of Medical Affairs, said that since the DOH has agreed to allow the temple to receive only less seriously ill patients, the government and social welfare agencies must take over the treatment of the temple's seriously ill patients.
The temple has more than 600 patients.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASTROPHYSICIST STEPS INTO FATHER'S SHOES AT LOCAL UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: Frank H. Shu, a world-renowned astrophysicist stepped into his father's shoes Monday when he took over as president of National Tsinghua University of the Republic of China.

Shu's father, Shu Hsien-shiu, served as president of the prestigious university three decades ago. Another coincidence is that both of them were 58 years old when they took their positions at the prestigious school.

Shu, took over the seal from retiring President Liu Chung-lang, in a ceremony held at the university in northern Taiwan. Witnessing the ceremony were various education officials, former Tsinghua University President Liu Chao-shiuan and National Chiao Tung University President Chang Chu-yen.

Shu, who was born in the mainland Chinese city of Kunming, stayed in Taiwan for only one year before emigrating to the United States at the age of six. Accordingly, he had to read a romanized version of his acceptance vow before changing to English to deliver his acceptance speech.

Shu recalled that "when his father was in Taiwan, the biggest problem was the brain drain to the United States." Nowadays, he went on, young students are less inclined to go abroad for advanced degrees.
Envisioning Tsinghua as a first-class research university, Shu said the university wishes "to attract the best scholars from overseas to Taiwan, as well as growing them at home."

Shu admitted that he grew up mainly in the United States and had limited knowledge of Chinese. Although he has often returned to Taiwan for academic activities, he had rarely thought about settling here.

When Tsinghua started its selection process a year ago, he said, one of his friends suggested that he take the post. However, his father did not approve of the idea and questioned how he could take the post of president when he couldn't speak fluent Chinese.

Shu said that when his father died late last year, he thought about many things. His father, he said, made a great contribution to Taiwan, which made him feel he had a worthy life and that his contribution to Taiwan was one of his greatest achievements.
Shu said that although he felt the environment in the United States is good, he also wanted to make some contribution to his "hometown," and to have a worthwhile life.

In addition, he went on, bringing Taiwan's universities to a par with world-class universities is also a challenging job. He added that he heard about Tsinghua so much during his childhood, he could not believe he would one day be head of the university, with the additional magic connection with his father.

Saying that he still had some unfinished work at the University of California at Berkeley, he said that he may have to shuttle back and forth between the United States and Taiwan for some months before settling down.
He also described "teaching and research" as his two loves and said he plans to open a course on astrophysics at Tsinghua.
Two prestigious journals -- Nature and Science -- have recently reported Shu's selection as president of Tsinghua, highlighting his stature in world academic circles.
Shu, who helped establish the Institute of Astronomy & Astrophysics of Academia Sinica, the highest research institute in Taiwan, in 1993, has pioneered astronomical studies on the island.

He has a B.S. in physics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a Ph.D. in Astronomy from Harvard University. He is best known for his works on the dynamics of spiral galaxies and their interstellar media, the mechanisms of mass, energy, and angular momentum transfer in interacting binary stars, and the structure and dynamics of planetary rings.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE MISSION TO VISIT VIETNAM, THAILAND
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Feb. 4 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Export Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Kaohsiung city government will jointly organize a trade mission to Vietnam and Thailand, EPZA sources said Monday.
Local manufacturers are being invited to take part in the mission that is scheduled to leave in early March, the sources said.
The EPZA organized a trade mission to Vietnam in early December last year, which resulted in tremendous trade opportunities, the sources added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH'S BEIJING TRIP WILL NOT SACRIFICE TAIWAN: ROC MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said Monday that U.S. President George Bush's visit to Beijing later this month will not sacrifice Taiwan's interests.
Chien told reporters that as Taipei and Washington maintain a "tacit agreement," he sees no unexpected situation developing over the Taiwan issue.
Bush will arrive in Beijing Feb. 21 for a two-day official visit. Mainland Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing is presently in Washington to discuss Bush's itinerary.

Chien, who assumed office Feb. 1, said that the United States will not sacrifice Taiwan to favor the mainland because Taiwan and the United States share a common interest, while the top priority of U.S. foreign policy is the war against terrorism.

Regarding the government's plan to add "Issued in Taiwan" to ROC passports and the Government Information Office's move to add "ROC on Taiwan" to the GIO's Web site, Chien said only that "the name of our country is the Republic of China."
The minister reiterated that the guidelines on future diplomatic work are "democracy and human rights, economic co-prosperity, and peace and security."

He also stressed the importance of "keeping secrets" in conducting diplomacy, and expressed the hope that reporters "will not ask about and will not reveal" government plan's to establish formal ties with foreign countries.
Chien said that his ministry will also work out a plan for President Chen Shui-bian to make a foreign trip later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE FILM TO BE SHOWCASED AT BERLIN INTERNATIONAL FILM FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: "The Rule of the Game," a new film by Taiwanese director Ho Ping, will be showcased at the upcoming 52nd Berlin International Film Festival to be held Feb. 6-17.
Ho said Monday at a news conference that he will leave for Berlin Wednesday, and that he will arrive there without giving any thought as to whether he will win any prizes.
"`The Rule of the Game' tells a story of several downbeat characters who are willing to die for money," he said. "This movie is about the destiny and irony of my generation in Taiwan."
He described his Mandarin-language film, also called "Wa Dong Ren" -- literally "the hole-digger" -- as a black comedy.
"The Rule of the Game" was entered in the International Forum of New Cinema, an independent section of the Berlinale dedicated to innovative and experimental cinema.
It will be shown at the festival four times -- on Feb. 8 at the Delphi cinema, Feb. 9 at the Arsenal 1 and CinemaxX 3, and Feb. 10 at the Babylon.
In the film, the leading character, Turtle, enlists the help of his enthusiastic friend Chewy to knock out a sly business partner, but Turtle does not know that Chewy might have another plan in mind.
Chewy has a rule about killing: "Killing is easy. Burying is difficult."
Ho said: "Chewy is the least greedy one, but he has the most serious problem. He is not pursuing money, sex or even a better future. He has lost all hope and desire.
"When the hole is filled, it becomes a grave. Perhaps Chewy should dig a hole for himself, a well-planned hole where he can lie down and rest with comfort and dignity," Ho said.

Last year, Taiwan's "Betelnut Beauty" and "Beijing Bicycle" each claimed a Silver Bear and a new talent award at the Berlinale, which ranks with Cannes and Venice among the leading film festivals of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALAN VICE FOREIGN MINISTER ARRIVES FOR FIVE-DAY VISIT
