TEXT.P: Guatemalan Vice Foreign Minister Ramiro Ordonez Jonama arrived in Taipei Monday for a five-day visit.
On hand at the airport to greet Ordonez were officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) and staff members of the Guatemalan Embassy in Taipei.
While in Taiwan, the Guatemalan diplomat will call on Republic of China Foreign Minister Eugene Chien and visit economic establishments in Taiwan.
According to MOFA, Ordonez will confer the "Orden del Quetzal en el Grado de Gran Cruz" on his ROC counterpart Lan Chih-min for his contributions to promoting relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR IN LONDON TO STUDY TOURISM
DOC.DATELINE: London, Feb. 4 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou arrived in London Monday on the first leg of a tour of two European countries in which he will focus on Britain and the Netherlands' tourism industries.
After Ma's arrival, he proceeded to the Tourist Board and the Tate Gallery to hear briefings on Britain's tourism development and culture-related activities.
He was also scheduled to meet overseas Chinese residents in Britain.
Ma's last visit to the United Kingdom was in 2000, when he concentrated his attention on Britain's sewerage systems, waste disposal and urban renewal plans.
During his stay in Britain, Ma will also give a speech at the Oxford University's Center of Asian Studies about cross-Taiwan Strait Relations in the 21st Century.
He will visit the River Thames Tuesday to view waterway tourist activities on Britain's most celebrated river.
The mayor is then scheduled to fly across the English Channel to Amsterdam for a two-day visit.
In Amsterdam, Ma and various Taipei city officials will call at Dutch agencies in charge of canal management and tourism business, in addition to touring flower auctions and related facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTRY ASKED TO LET LOCAL GOVERNMENTS NAME OWN POLICE CHIEFS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun asked the Ministry of the Interior Monday to come up with measures to give local governments the power to name their own police chiefs.

Interior minister Yu Cheng-hsien quoted the premier as saying after inspecting the ministry for the first time Monday that the right to appoint police heads is frequently a bone of contention between the central and local governments.

Since his administration is pushing for the revamp of the government's structure, the premier asked the ministry to come up with measures within three months to let local governments choose their own police chiefs and weed out the cause of the dispute once and for all, Yu Cheng-hsien said.

He added that the premier also asked his ministry to work out a proposal to reform the current electoral system, a proposal to re-draw county boundaries, a draft bill regulating political donations and a draft bill governing the activities of political parties.
All these should be ready in three months, according to the premier's instruction, Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 29 HECTARES OF LAND IN INDUSTRIAL ZONES LEASED BY JANUARY

TEXT.P: A total of 29 hectares of land in five industrial zones of Taiwan had been leased out to 31 investors as of the end of January, according to the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs of the Republic of China.

Citing its own statistics, the bureau said Monday that its plan to put the land in its industrial zones up for lease rather than for sale in order to ease investors' financial burdens has been very successful.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-LEGISLATOR FILES SUIT AGAINST PROSECUTOR

TEXT.P: Former Legislator Lo Fu-chu filed a lawsuit Monday against a prosecutor who asked a judge to detain him last week.

Accompanied by his lawyers, Lo went to the Taipei District Court to file suit against Sheng Ming-lun, a prosecutor of the Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court, for "interfering with his freedom."

Sheng asked the judge for permission to detain Lo, who is in hot water for his involvement in fraud and breach of trust, last week but the request was later denied, although Lo was forced to appear in court briefly.
Lo claimed that Sheng threatened and intimidated him during the arraignment, trying to hurt his family, friends and staff.

Lo said he is seeking a "fair" trial and expressed hope that the prosecutor will not try to trump up any accusations against him, although he admitted that he had committed offenses that could carry sentences of not more than five years. He also vented his dissatisfaction that the "black gold" task force of the Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court was used against him, claiming that its a "waste of taxpayers' money."
Sheng said that he would take the suit "in his stride," and added that he will "do what he has to do." He made no further comment on the matter.

Lo was briefly detained Friday afternoon and did not reply to questions, since he felt he had been wrongly detained. A joint court comprising of three judges decided to release Lo immediately after a two-hour debate.

Lo told local media after his release that he appreciated the judges' decision, which allowed him to explain his side of the story. He stressed that he still has faith in the judicial system and said he would be willing to attend any court investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY WILL STEP UP ALERT DURING CHINESE NEW YEAR HOLIDAY

TEXT.P: The military will go on heightened alert during the Chinese New Year holiday, which starts Feb. 12, the spokesman for the Republic of China Ministry of National Defense said Monday.

Gen. Huang Hui-sheng told reporters that various units of the armed forces have completed their preparations for heightened alert to ensure a tranquil New Year holiday for the people of Taiwan and its islands.
Huang escorted a group of reporters to observe a demonstration of F-16 jet fighters and S-70C rescue helicopters at Chiayi airbase.
They also inspected the training of a tank brigade in Alan Township, Kaohsiung County to demonstrate the army's capability against enemy paratroopers.

Gen. Chen Chin-sheng, commander of the 8th Army Crops, who is in charge of the combat mission for southern Taiwan, said that the army has made sound preparations to meet natural disasters and abrupt military attacks so that the people can enjoy a happy New Year.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERALL CREDIT RATINGS OF TAIWAN ENTERPRISES DECLINED IN 2001

TEXT.P: The overall credit rating of Taiwan's enterprises, especially the traditional manufacturing sector, showed signs of decline last year, the Taiwan Ratings Corp. (TRC) said Monday.
The TRC lowered the credit ratings of three of Taiwan's traditional industries in 2001, with outlook negative, due mainly to the tough operating climate.
These industries faced oversupply and weak prices in 2001, the TRC said.

According to the TRC, the number of entities rated by the corporation in 2001 soared compared with 2000 and 1999. In 1999, only seven companies ratings published. The number increased to nine in 2000 and 21 in 2001, it said.

As a result of the limited pool of rated entities in 1999 and 2000, gauging annual rating trends is difficult. Nevertheless, a sector review with the information available is still indicative of current industry trends, the TRC said.

The number of rated entities whose credit ratings were listed with outlook negative in 2001 was three, accounting for 14.3 percent of the total number of rated entities. The number surpassed that in the previous two years, according to the TRC statistics.
However, there was one rated entity whose credit rating was listed with outlook as positive in December last year, the TRC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 5, or the 24th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1596: Japanese Shogun Hideyoshi Toyotomi puts 26 Catholic converts to death in Nagasaki after he banned Christianity earlier in the year.
1792: Tippo of Mysore, India is defeated and cedes half of Mysore to the British.
1900: Adlai Stevenson, American statesman and ambassador whose liberal views caused him trouble during the McCarthy witch hunts, is born.
1917: Mexico becomes a federal republic of 28 states.
1922: The first issue of the U.S. magazine Reader's Digest rolls off the presses.
1924: French automaker Renault launches an epoch-marking car safari in the Sahara.
1929: The Nationalist government changes the name of Fengtien Province to Liaoning Province.
1945: Gen. Douglas MacArthur and U.S. troops enter Manila. On Oct. 20, 1944, MacArthur and his forces landed on the Philippine island of Leyte, fulfilling his pledge to return to the Philippines.
1955: U.S. President Dwight Einsenhower instructs the Seventh Fleet to assist Nationalist troops in withdrawing from the island of Tachen, opposite mainland China's Chechiang Province.
1959: The Republic of China's Executive Yuan adopts a resolution to open Hualien port in eastern Taiwan as an international port.
1959: The Ilan branch of Taiwan's East-West Highway is formally opened to traffic.
1962: A total solar eclipse occurs in the morning.
1962: President Charles de Gaulle of France calls for independence for Algeria.
1971: U.S. Apollo 14 astronauts land on the moon.
1974: Thirteen-year-old Mats Wermelin of Sweden scores all 272 points in a basketball game.
1976: A major earthquake rocks Guatemala, killing nearly 23,000 people.
1977: Brazilian soccer star Pele arrives in Taiwan for a three-day visit.
1990: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev indicates that the Communist Party must abandon its monopoly on power.
1990: Rafael Calderon Fournier wins the presidential election in Costa Rica.
1996: Rene Preval succeeds Jean-Bertrand Aristide in a peaceful transfer of power in Haiti.
1997: Switzerland's three banking giants announce the creation of a Holocaust memorial fund worth 100 million Swiss francs.
1999: Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua and his wife Hiromi Kabua arrive in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1999: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou awards a plaque to popular movie star Andy Lau in honor of his appointment as "Taipei Rapid Transit Ambassador," which includes the right to travel on the Taipei MRT for free for the rest of his life.
2001: New Philippine President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo praises Chinese businessmen and industrialists for their efforts in helping her government to stabilize the country.
2001: The United States reaffirms its commitment to assisting Taiwan in meeting the island's legitimate defense needs in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act and the three Washington-Beijing joint communiques.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When three men meet together, one of them who is anxious to learn can always learn something from the other two. He can profit by the good example of the one and avoid the bad example of the other."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The China Times:
Evergreen Marine Corp. will shift focus of business to Europe.
The United Daily News:
Taitung chief prosecutor gets job transfer due to defying the Ministry of Justice's order regarding office building expansion.
The Liberty Times:
The Cabinet plans to have the controversial allocation amendment overturned.
The Taiwan Daily:
Budget chief warns against perils of the new allocation law.
The Central Daily News:
The Cabinet, opposition at odds over the budget allocation law.
The China Post:
The government rushes to decide on controversial allocation law.
The Taiwan News:
Foreign ministry mulls opening up secret documents
The Taipei Times:
Premier Yu mulls options in funding battle.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CENTRAL BANK OFFICIALS MUM ON EXCHANGE RATE SPECULATIONS

TEXT.P: Officials of Taiwan's Central Bank of China refused to comment Tuesday on the remarks made a day earlier by Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Yung-fa that the New Taiwan dollar should depreciate from NT$35 to NT$38 against the greenback.
Chang said in Japan Monday that the devaluation would increase the competitiveness of Taiwanese products and lead the local economy into a recovery.

Also on Monday, the central bank urged the local media to clarify a report that claimed the NT dollar will continue to stay at NT$35 against the greenback well into 2003. The bank released a Goldman Sachs report speculating that the NT dollar will instead appreciate to NT$34.5 this year and to NT$34 in 2003.
Chang is an adviser to the presidents of the Republic of China, Panama and the Philippines. His empire includes EVA Airways and Evergreen Marine Corp., one of the world's largest container operators.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 5.6 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 5.6 points to close at 5,844.25.
Market turnover amounted to NT$82.54 billion (US$2.36 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and then fluctuated on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 5.6 points to close at 5,844.25.
Affected by a plunge in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,812.7 and fluctuated between 5,849.02 and 5,773.07 during trading.

A total of 2.71 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$82.54 billion (US$2.36 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.94 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$87.76 billion (US$2.51 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up 0.5 percent.

The other major categories posted losses, with textile issues moving down the most at 3.2 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 2.8 percent, construction stocks at 2.4 percent, pulp and paper issues at 2 percent, cement stocks at 1.3 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.2 percent, and bank and insurance stocks at 0.8 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 427 to 170, with 84 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were generally higher on Tuesday as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for February moved up 46 points to close at 5,884, with 8,991 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March rose 62 points to close at 5,880, with 259 contract transactions, while December futures lost 118 points to finish at 5,850, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,838 for February, 5,818 for March, 5,880 for June, 5,850 for September, and 5,968 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
February TE futures moved up 4.5 points to close at 312.5, with 2,211 contract transactions, while March TE futures increased 5.8 points to finish at 311, with 36 contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
February TF futures moved down 4.4 points to finish at 722, with 695 contract transactions, while March TF futures fell 0.6 points to close at 724, with 18 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER INSTRUCTS JUSTICE MINISTRY TO CONTINUE JUDICIAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun on Tuesday instructed the Ministry of Justice to continue cracking down on vote-buying, improving prison management and promoting other judicial reforms.
Yu said after a briefing by the ministry's top officials on his fifth day on the job that the government pledges to eliminate illegal financial influence in politics and stamp out vote-buying.

Being the government agency in charge of making good on that pledge, the justice ministry must follow every lead by informers, plan ahead in carrying out anti-corruption operations and supervise local prosecutorial offices in promoting clean elections, he said.

At the same time, Yu continued, the ministry must strengthen its education and training for public prosecutors, who were charged with even greater responsibility to investigate crimes and secure convictions when amendments to the Code of Criminal Procedure were ratified by the Legislative Yuan last month without a grace period for the ministry to prepare for the necessary changes.
Yu also instructed the justice ministry to speed up the drafting of bills related to the establishment of a national human rights committee, which would have limited powers of investigation.
He added that the ministry should improve its prison management to prevent further jailbreaks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR URGES BEIJING TO RESPOND TO PRESIDENT CHEN'S GOODWILL
DOC.DATELINE: London, Feb. 4 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said in London Monday that mainland China should respond to all the goodwill messages expressed by ROC President Chen Shui-bian.

"Chen is by no means a pro-independence diehard as claimed by mainland China," Ma said in a speech delivered to Chinese residents in the London area. "My observation is that President Chen is flexible and willing to change to suit different circumstances."

Ma said President Chen announced in his inaugural speech that so long as mainland China does not invade Taiwan, he would never declare Taiwan independence. In addition, he said, Chen has on many occasions extended olive branches to Beijing since assuming office in May 2000.

"Although Chen is unmistakably supportive of Taiwan independence, he is absolutely not a fundamentalist," Ma noted, adding that mainland China should recognize Chen's flexibility and make a positive response to his goodwill.

"In view of Chen's previous stance, it's not easy for him to deliver so many goodwill messages and gestures regarding relations across the Taiwan Strait," Ma said. "Mainland China should not continue ignoring Chen's goodwill appeals and should instead give him acclaim."
In his view, Ma said, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should acknowledge each other's goodwill to forge mutual trust and improve bilateral relations.
Ma further said mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen's recent softened rhetoric on cross-strait relations marked a shift in mainland China's tactics toward Taiwan.

"Qian's statement that members of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), except for a few pro-independence diehards, are welcome to visit the mainland in an 'appropriate status' seems to be conveying a certain message," Ma said. "We can take it as the start of new stage of cross-strait engagements."

The Republic of China government has made an appropriate response to Qian's rare message. But Ma said as the time is not on Taipei's side in the development of cross-strait ties, the ROC government should take even more active, concrete measures to break the current impasse.
Ma's speech was organized by the Sun Yat-sen Association in Britain. Despite the chilly rainy weather, many Chinese residents in the London area attended the meeting.
Ma arrived in London earlier in the day for a three-day visit aimed at studying British experiences in promoting cultural and tourist development.
"We hope to learn from British experience in order to make Taipei a more interesting, more tasteful city," Ma said after visiting the London Tourist Board.

During his talks with London tourist officials, Ma exchanged views with them on management and marketing strategies as well as budget planning. Ma said Taipei must improve its marketing strategy to attract more foreign tourists.
Later in the day, Ma toured the popular Tate Modern Gallery. Besides browsing through its exhibits, Ma also expressed interest in the gallery's budget planning and management system.

Ma is scheduled to visit Britain's cultural relics preservation authority Tuesday and will then deliver an address on the challenges in cross-strait relations in the 21st century at the Taiwan Research Chair of Oxford University's Center of Asian Studies.

After winding up his London trip, Ma will travel to Amsterdam for a two-day visit. While there, Ma will call at Dutch authorities in charge of canal management and tourist services. Ma said he will also take advantage of the tour to learn from Dutch experiences in cultural heritage preservation and relevant renovation expertise and technologies.
Ma is accompanied by several Taipei city councilors and municipal officials on his current European tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE CAUCUSES MEET OVER REVISED GOVERNMENT REVENUE ALLOCATION

TEXT.P: The ruling and opposition caucuses in the legislature held its first coordination meeting Tuesday to discuss the controversy over the newly revised Law Governing the Allocation of Government Revenues and Expenditures.

The revised law, which was hurriedly pushed through on the last day of the previous legislature last month, was initiated by the Kuomintang and supported by the People First Party. The law will force the central government to give a bigger portion of its revenues to local governments.

Legislative President Wang Jin-pyng, reading the conclusion reached at the meeting, said the first session of the fifth legislature will open Feb. 26, but if the Executive Yuan deems the revised law hard to execute and asks the legislature to reconsider the law, the session will open Feb. 19.

Meanwhile, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said the Executive Yuan will decide in two days whether to ask the legislature to reconsider the revised law, stressing that the Cabinet hopes to solve the problem through communication.
Yu reiterated that asking the legislature to reconsider the law will be a last resort, adding that he hopes the issue will not turn into rivalry between the ruling and opposition parties.

While inspecting the Ministry of Justice, the premier, who was only sworn in Feb. 1, said that the entire nation is looking forward to a stable political environment for the sake of economic development.

Yu said that if the revised allocation law is executed, it will be counter to regulations governing the current account balance under the Budget Law, and a shortage of current accounts of NT$50 billion (US$1.42 billion) would likely result.
Though some have suggested revising the ceiling of the Public Debt Law to fill the financial gap, Yu said that he fears it may become a normal practice each year to finance the shortage.
Tsai Huang-liang, legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said that the revised law will cause huge financial shortages for the government.

Tsai said that if the DPP caucus tries to revise the law, it will be a time-consuming process and that the chances of seeing the opposition party boycotting it will also increase, adding that the stance of the caucus is "to favor the option of reconsidering the law."

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFIDENCE NEEDED TO PROMOTE TAIPEI-MOSCOW TRADE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Chang Hung-kuang and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Mutual confidence is needed in addition to interest in investment if bilateral trade between Russia and Taiwan is to improve, the Republic of China's representative to Moscow said Tuesday.

Charles S.C. King said that several trade delegations from Taiwan will visit Moscow in the next few months, demonstrating sufficient interest in bilateral cooperation, but Russia's 18 percent inflation rate and its laws governing foreign investments have contributed to a lack of mutual confidence.

King said that the 45 percent year-on-year drop in bilateral trade last year was mainly due to the global economic slump, but Russia continued to enjoy a US$340 million trade surplus with Taiwan, with the island exporting only US$260 million in goods to Russia in 2001.

In regard to the issue of direct flights between Taipei and Moscow, King said that both governments have already completed all necessary paperwork after eight years of negotiations, but the airlines appointed to operate the route are still working on tax-related details.
The Russian government views the tax issue with a great deal of importance because the two governments do not have an agreement in place to avoid double taxation, King added.

DOC.HEADLINE: RICE PLANTING AREAS DOWN TO LOWEST POINT SINCE RETROCESSION

TEXT.P: In anticipation of rice imports after Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) this year, land used for cultivation of rice fell last years to their lowest level since 1947, the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported Tuesday.
COA officials said rice planting areas were cut to 332,183 hectares in 2001, down 7,766 hectares from the previous year -- the smallest paddy acreage since Taiwan was retroceded from Japan in 1947.
It is estimated that rice planting areas will be further cut to around 300,000 hectares this year, the officials said.

They noted that after WTO entry in January, Taiwan will be required to allow imports of 144,720 tons of rice this year. To cope with this situation, the agriculture council will continue to promote its voluntary fallow program and rotational planting of indigenous crops.
The officials also said that from 2002 to 2004, the government will continue to promote a regional rotation fallow system.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC AIRLINES NOT THINKING OF MERGER DESPITE HEAVY LOSSES

TEXT.P: Times have been tough for ROC domestic airlines over the last two years, but this is not pushing all the companies to consider mergers because of possible complications, an official of the Civil Aeronautics Administration said Tuesday.
Although the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has encouraged the airlines to merge, three of the four domestic carriers have said that they will wait to make any decision.

Taiwan's domestic air carriers -- UNI Airways Corp., Mandarin Airlines, Far East Air Transport Corp. and TransAsia Airways -- have all suffered heavy losses due to the sluggish aviation market and rising fuel prices.

Eva Air Group Chairman Chang Jung-fa Monday suggested that the four domestic airlines should merge into two to reduce their operational costs and avoid cut-throat competition. Domestic airlines have experienced two waves of mergers in the past few years.

The EVA Air Group in 1995 bought a small domestic airline and converted it into UNI Airways to serve domestic air routes. Competing with a dozen other domestic airlines while the market scale was limited, UNI Airways, like most of its competitors, was constantly operating in the red.

The government lifted its restrictions on the domestic aviation market in 1987, and many new airlines were set up in the early 1990s. While the domestic market was limited, the airlines were gambling on the possibility of tapping the lucrative market for direct flights across the Taiwan Strait.

Three years ago, several domestic airlines on the brink of bankruptcy decided to merge. UNI Airways merged with Great China Airlines and the China Airlines-affiliated Mandarin Airlines merged with Formosa Airlines. By 2001, there were only four airlines operating 28 domestic routes in Taiwan. Still, none of them was making profit.

Chang said that the completion of the north-south high-speed railway by 2006 will affect the aviation business. He suggested that the four domestic airlines should take stock of the economic reality now.
Except for the EVA group-affiliated UNI Airways, executives of the other three domestic airlines have said that they are not interested in merger proposals, at least for the time being.

An executive of Mandarin Airlines said that different corporate cultures could become serious problems during and after the process of merging. Mandarin Airline's financial status was adversely affected after merging with airlines with huge deficits, he added.

Far East Air Transport Corp. and TransAsia Airways, which have long cooperated on airport services, are not planning to merge because of their differing management styles, according to company executives.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST MAINLAND TOUR GROUP ARRIVES FROM JAPAN

TEXT.P: A 13-member tour group of mainland Chinese nationals residing in Japan arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a four-day sightseeing trip.

It was the first mainland tour group to visit Taiwan since the Republic of China opened the door for overseas mainland Chinese citizens to make group tours of the island at the beginning of this year.
"I'm excited to set feet on Taiwan after a 60-year wait," said Jin Hui, leader of the tour group, upon his arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway.
Jin said he moved to Japan from Beijing with his parents when he was six years old. Due to complicated political factors, he has been unable to come to Taiwan for sightseeing.
"It takes only two hours to fly from Osaka to Taiwan, but I had to wait six decades to realize my dream to tour the island," said the 64-year-old Osaka resident of Chinese descent.
Jin said he would take advantage of this rare trip to visit noted Taiwan cultural and historical relics as well as taste all sorts of delicious Taiwanese-style snacks.

He also cited the National Palace Museum in suburban Taipei as the place he most yearns to visit during his current trip. "I like Chinese culture very much. Therefore, I went to mainland China to receive my college education. I have paid numerous visits to Beijing's National Palace Museum. Although its architecture is magnificent, its exhibits are not very impressive."

Jin said he has long heard of the massive collection of exquisite Chinese art objects at Taipei's National Palace Museum. "Seeing is believing. I want to take a close look at the Chinese cultural and artistic treasures there," an emotional Jin said.

None of Jin's group have ever been allowed to enter Taiwan. All of them appeared to be delighted to become the first group of mainland Chinese tourists to visit the island. They were all smiles while being greeted by a throng of local journalists.

International Tour Operation (ITO), which organized the tour package for the group, said most of the visiting mainland tourists are residing in Japan's Kobe and Osaka areas and engaging in the travel service business. "In addition to sightseeing, many members also intend to survey the local tourist market," said an ITO executive.
The group will visit major tourist attractions in northern Taiwan as well as visit famous tourist hotels and restaurants in the region.

As part of its efforts to boost exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan began Jan. 1 to allow mainland Chinese citizens with permanent foreign residency or mainland students studying abroad to make pleasure trips to the island.
Meanwhile, the Taipei Association of Travel Agents (TATA) said the second mainland tour group may arrive after the Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 12 this year.
Tourist sources said scores of mainland Chinese residents in San Francisco have expressed interest in joining a Taiwan-mainland China tour package organized by a travel agency there.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO ENTRY MAY AFFECT 'CLANDESTINE ECONOMY': REPORT

TEXT.P: The livelihood of some 500,000 people on Taiwan will be affected because of the island's opening to foreign products and services following its Jan. 1 entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), according to a recent government analysis.

As foreign goods and services are expected to flow into the domestic market in the near future -- bringing down product prices amid fiercer competition -- the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported that the livelihood of 500,000 people, including market vendors, elderly and middle-aged farmers, and ranking executives, may be affected.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development had forecast earlier that Taiwan's unemployment rate would rise by 0.22 percentage points following its WTO admission. Taiwan's jobless rate stood at 5.22 percent at the end of last year.

According to a DGBAS investigation on street vendors, business in the so-called "clandestine economy" will be particularly hard hit, despite the fact that the sector may absorb a large number of jobless workers during recession.

The investigation also discovered that there are more younger vendors at traditional markets over the past year. DGBAS officials said this is an indication that older vendors are being edged out and added that the number of floating street vendors has gradually grown in the last 10 years because of the difficulties of shifting professions.
According to DGBAS tallies, there were about 256,000 street vendor stands in 1993, with the number rising to 263,000 in 1998 involving 390,000 people.
DGBAS officials estimated that the number of street vendor stands may hit around 300,000 absorbing 500,000 people at present, with 40,000 of the stands located in northern Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE VP TO FORM TAIWAN-JAPAN LEGISLATIVE ALLIANCE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The newly elected vice president of the ROC Legislative Yuan, P. K. Chiang, plans to form a non-partisan legislative alliance between lawmakers of Taiwan and Japan to boost bilateral ties, according to a Japanese despatch from Taipei.
In a meeting with Japanese reporters stationed in Taipei Monday, Chiang expressed the desire to establish the alliance to further reinforce legislative exchanges between the two countries.

Chiang, who is already the highest-level adviser of a civil interchange association between Taiwanese and Japanese enterprises, said the move is also aimed at stabilizing the local political situation at a time when the new Cabinet will be turning its attention to stimulating the economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE CORP. GAINS ORDER FROM TAIWAN TO BUILD 2 TRASH INCINERATORS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Huang Ching-ching and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Japanese Ebara Corp. has jointly gained an order with a Taiwan manufacturer to build two trash incinerators in northern Taiwan, the Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported Tuesday.

Ebara Corp. will jointly build the two trash incinerators with the Taiwan manufacturer in Keelung with each incinerator disposing of 300 tons of trash daily, the newspaper said, adding that the construction project will be completed in May, 2004.
Ebara Corp.'s Taiwan branch will be responsible for the construction work, while Ebara Corp.'s headquarters will be in charge of engineering design and management, the newspaper said.
Founded in 1912, Ebara Corp. is a listed company doing such businesses as environmental protection, sewage disposal and resource regeneration.

DOC.HEADLINE: PURCHASES WITH VISA CARDS TOPPED NT $ 572 BILLION IN ROC LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: Purchases with VISA credit cards in the Taiwan area last year totaled NT$572.2 billion (US$16.34 billion), up NT$51.4 billion over the preceding year, according to VISA International statistics released recently.
It represents a 67 percent share of credit card use in Taiwan for 2001.

Transactions through VISA cards registered a considerable decline in Taiwan last September following the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington and the floods brought by Typhoon Nari in the second half of last September.
However, transactions began to return to the normal levels in October and the figure amounted to NT$51.5 billion in December alone.
VISA International said that more Asian people have begun using credit cards for purchases.

Purchases with VISA cards in Taiwan over the past five years were listed as NT$270.7 billion in 1997, NT$362.7 billion in 1998, NT$437.2 billion in 1999, NT$520.8 billion in 2000 and NT$572.2 billion in 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S POPULATION IN SERVICE SECTOR SMALL

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwan's workers in the service sector as a percentage of its total workforce is small compared to that of developed countries, according to a recent government investigation report.

The report by the Council of Labor Affairs on labor force structure in the world's major countries indicated that around 60 percent to 80 percent of the workers in European countries and the Untied States are employed in the service sector, while the ratio in Southeast Asian countries is lower than 50 percent.

At the same time, around 10 percent to 16 percent of the employed population in Australia, Europe, New Zealand and the United States are in the financial and real estate sectors, while the percentage in Taiwan is only 4.3 percent, according to the report. It pointed out that 27.7 percent of Taiwan's workforce is in the manufacturing sector.

The report also discovered that 80 percent to 90 percent of the workforce in European countries and the United States are employed as workers, while self-employed workers in Taiwan, South Korea and Italy account for more than 20 percent, the world's largest ratio.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NATIONAL TEAM LEAVES FOR WINTER OLYMPIC GAMES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China national team left Tuesday for Salt Lake City to take part in the Winter Olympic Games which will open Feb. 8. in the United States city in central Utah.

The new chairman of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, Lin Teh-fu, presented a flag of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) to CTOC Chairman Huang Ta-chou and team leader C. W. Tsai.
Wishing good luck and success to the team members, Lin said Chinese Taipei has participated in every Winter Olympic Games since 1972 when the 11th games were held in Sapporo, Japan.
Huang stressed that participation is more important than winning and encouraged the ROC national team to learn from other athletes and make good friends with them.
The athletes from Taiwan will compete in snowmobiling and toboggan races.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD TO STUDY AIRPORT DEVELOPMENT PLAN OVER THE NEXT FIVE YEARS

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Tuesday invited related agencies to discuss the development of Taiwan's international airports in the coming five years amid expected changes in air traffic.
Officials of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said once the country's first north-south high-speed railway is completed, the local air traffic industry will suffer greatly.
At that time, the officials added, Taiwan's aeronautic industry should focus on air passenger traffic across the east and west of Taiwan, as well as some of its remote islands.

Officials of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the MOTC suggested that Taiwan should focus only on the northern CKS International Airport in order to accelerate the development of becoming an international marketing and production center, and they think there will be no need to construct new international airports in central and southern Taiwan before 2021.
As opinions are divided on whether the country should focus on one or two international airports, the CEPD decided to have further discussions on the matter in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER MUM ON EVERGREEN'S SHIFT OF STRATEGY

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Christine Chung declined to comment Tuesday on a major local shipping company's decision to change the country of registration of half of its vessels to facilitate its investment projects in mainland China.

Evergreen Marine Corp. Chairman Chang Jung-fa said in the southwestern Japanese port city of Kobe Monday that his company has decided to change the registration of half of its 148 container vessels from either Panama or the Republic of China to Britain or Italy.
"The change is aimed at facilitating the company's expansion of shipping services in Europe and its investment in mainland China," Chang was quoted as saying.
Meanwhile, Chang also said he plans to resign as senior adviser to the ROC president. His announcement was widely seen as a major shift in Evergreen's business strategy.
Responding to Chang's announcement, the newly sworn-in minister said only that it is a "choice of the entrepreneur himself" and a "business activity."

Chung, who served as president and CEO of Taiwan's largest carrier -- China Airlines -- until last Thursday, said that if she were still a corporate executive, she would not put personal business interests above the nation's overall interests.

Nevertheless, she added that she is willing to give her "best wishes" to Evergreen Group, which operates one of the world's largest container shipping fleets, as well as Taiwan's second-largest air carrier, EVA Airways.

In her first news conference following her nomination late last month as the ROC's first female minister of economic affairs, an elated Chung said the "worst moments" for recession-hit Taiwan are over and that she will make Taiwan's economy "fly again within two years."

However, Chang told local reporters covering his Kobe trip that Taiwan's economic problems cannot be separated from its political issues. "In the past, the mainland Chinese economy relied on investment from Taiwan, but in the future, Taiwan's economy will rely on the vast mainland market. Against this backdrop, if political issues between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait cannot be resolved, Taiwan's economic prospects will remain gloomy," he predicted.

In response, Chung said Taiwan's economy is presently at rock bottom. "It won't get worse any more," she forecast, adding that if an enterprise faces difficulties, the first step the company should take is to review its internal management.

Chang is known to maintain close ties with ROC President Chen Shui-bian, a stalwart of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). Although Chen and his DPP have mellowed their pro-independence stance, Beijing remains reluctant to resume long-stalled cross-strait dialogue.
Amid the lingering political impasse, the mainland has banned Taiwan's shipping companies and their subsidiaries from setting up footholds on its shores.

Political analysts said Chang's decisions to change the registration of Evergreen ships and resign from the presidential advisory post are expected to pave the way for his company's smooth entry into the mainland market.

DOC.HEADLINE: CTOC EXECUTIVE ATTENDS IOC GENERAL ASSEMBLY IN SALT LAKE CITY
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Feb. 4 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Wu Ching-kuo, a member of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and executive member of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC), has arrived in Salt Lake City to attend the 2002 IOC general assembly that opened Monday.

The IOC general assembly, with new IOC President Jacques Rogge at the helm, will focus its discussions mainly on security during the Games -- slated to open Friday in Salt Lake City -- as they will be the biggest sporting spectacle since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States.
Rogge's predecessor, Juan Antonio Samaranch, is also attending the general assembly.
Wu, who has taken part in every Olympic Summer and Winter Games since 1984, said he has noticed that security is particularly reinforced.
Meanwhile, the first three athletes from Taiwan (Chinese Taipei) have arrived in the athletes' village to familiarize themselves with the competition environment.
Lee Chia-hsun, one of the three Chinese Taipei competitors, said security in the village can be described as "airtight."

DOC.HEADLINE: VIENNA CHOIR BOYS TO TOUR TAIWAN IN MARCH

TEXT.P: The Vienna Choir Boys will tour Taiwan in March, presenting six performances around the island.
A local organizer said the choir will give two concerts in Taipei March 22-23, one concert in Taichung City March 16, one in Hualien City March 17, and two in Hsinchu City March 19-20.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN CURRENCY RESERVES TOTAL US$ 123.629 B. AS OF JANUARY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign currency reserves totaled US$123.629 billion at the end of January, 2002, an increase of US$1,419 million over that of last December, setting a record high but maintaining the third-largest reserves in Asia, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Central Bank of China.

In related news, Chi Schive, director of the Taiwan Financial and Monetary Institute, said that there was no country in the world to enervate its economy through the parity between its local currency and foreign currency.
Any suggestion on the rate between new Taiwan dollar and the U.S. dollar made by the industry itself was inappropriate, Schive said.

Schive made the remarks while commenting on local media reports that Chang Jung-fa, president of the Evergreen Group, suggested that the new Taiwan dollar should depreciate to NT$38 against one U.S. dollar as a way to boost Taiwan's competitiveness and to revive the stagnated economy.

Schieve pointed out that Chang is engaged in the shipping industry and from his viewpoint, the new Taiwan dollar should depreciate and said that the government will face difficulties if another industry suggests that the new Taiwan dollar should appreciate to NT$30 against one U.S. dollar based on his stance.
He cited Japan as saying that Japan continued to depreciate the Japanese yen, thus causing hyperinflation. "The issue was worth considering," Schive said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN, ROC TO JOINTLY TAP ONLINE CELLULAR TECHNOLOGY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By C.C. Huang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: A Japanese company and Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) have agreed to jointly tap into online cellular technology, according to the Nihon Keizai Shinbum, a Japanese newspaper.

Japan's Access, in addition to providing Taiwan's communications and monitor manufacturers with online software to be used in cellular applications, will enter into a cooperation agreement with the MOEA to tap into a new online software system for use in cellular phones.

The online software system developed by Access has been exported to the United States and European countries and has been widely adopted by Japan's NTT DoCoMo, the largest computer server in Japan. More than 53 million cellular phones use the system.
According to the news report, Access last November authorized some Taiwan enterprises to use its software system.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO RESPECT CIVIL RIGHTS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The China Independent PEN called for the mainland authorities Monday to put an end to the Cultural Revolution-style political struggle against opponents and forsake the tradition of the "feudalism of literary inquisition," which often ends in the writers' imprisonment or execution.
The Boston-based association of independent Chinese literary writers confirmed Monday that Shanghai-based dissident writer Wang Yiliang has been released from a mainland Chinese prison.
The China Independent PEN urged the Beijing authorities to respect their civilians' "freedom of speech" and their political rights.

According to Liu Bingyen, a noted Chinese writer now living in the United States in self-imposed exile and chairman of the China Independent PEN, Wang, who insisted on freedom of writing and who participated in the Chinese Culture Renaissance Movement, was jailed in February 2000 for two years' of labor and "soul searching" and was released Jan. 30 this year. Wang has now returned to his home in Shanghai.
In a long-distance telephone conversation with members of the China Independent PEN, Wang said he now needs rest and time for rehabilitation and that he will soon begin writing again.

Wang, who won the 2000 Freedom of Speech Award from the New York-based Human Rights Watch, took part in underground literary circle activities in Shanghai during the 80s and established the "Tientien Cultural Society" jointly with Chinese poet Meng Lang before being arrested.

China Independent PEN members said the association is cooperating with International PEN and PEN American Center to closely monitor the human rights condition of mainland writers in the hope that human rights issues there as a whole will improve if more people in the rest of the world show concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHERY EXECUTIVES DIVIDED OVER IMPACT OF MAINLAND LABOR EXPORT BAN

TEXT.P: Fishing ship owners in Nanfangao, a fishing port in the northeastern county of Ilan, are divided over the possible impact of mainland China's recent alleged decision to prohibit mainland fishery workers from working in Taiwan, sources said Tuesday.
Lin Yueh-ying, secretary-general of the Nanfangao Fishery Association, said some local owners believe the ban, if true, would have a positive effect on the protection of Taiwan's fishery resources.

"In the past, mainland fishermen working aboard Taiwan fishing ships had directed mainland fishing boats to major Taiwan fishing grounds after ending their contracts with local fishing firms," Lin claimed.
Some local ship owners thus believe that the supposed mainland labor export ban will help stem the recurrence of such scenarios and facilitate the protection of Taiwan's fishery resources, Lin said.

Meanwhile, he went on, several other owners have pointed out that as mainland fishery workers are banned from landing on Taiwan's shores, local owners have to hire other laborers to assist in unloading their catches, which actually increases their operational costs.

"The mainland export ban may force local ship owners to employ foreign fishery workers who can land in Taiwan," Lin continued. "Against this background, hiring foreign workers may be more cost-efficient."
However, Lin said, many other ship owners in the Nanfangao area are worried about the aggravation of the present manpower shortage following the mainland labor export ban.

"In the future, local ship owners may have to hire fishermen from Vietnam, the Philippines, Indonesia and Thailand to work aboard their fishing boats," Lin said. "Language barriers will be the biggest headache in employing Southeast Asian fishery laborers."
The fishing industry in the Nanfangao area presently employs about 1,300 mainland workers and Lin pointed out that "It will be no easy task to fill all the vacancies left by mainland fishermen."

With the approach of the Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 12 this year, many Nanfangao-based vessels have returned to port in preparation for the traditional Chinese festival. As a result, the demand for mainland fishery workers has yet to reach a peak.

Nevertheless, some ship owners said it has become more difficult to hire mainland fishery workers since they received an internal mainland document purporting to bear official seals of the mainland Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Agriculture, which declares the mainland's decision to suspend the export of fishery workers to Taiwan. The documents have not yet been verified and several reports have described them as a hoax.

The Nanfangao Fishery Association urged the ROC government to work out measures to help local ship owners resolve the manpower shortage problem, which it said will become very serious after the Lunar New Year holidays.

It remains unclear why mainland China would abruptly suspend exports of its fishery laborers. Some sources have said the move may be aimed at pushing local ship owners to improve living and working conditions for mainland fishermen.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER TO LEAVE HOSPITAL WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: Former Premier Chang Chun-hsiung has recovered from hernia surgery and will be discharged from hospital Wednesday, sources from National Taiwan University Hospital said Tuesday.
Chang had been suffering from his hernia since before he left office Feb. 1, but his heavy workload left him no time to undergo surgery at that time.
The NTUH sources said Chang refused visitors and flower baskets, as a nod to the new Cabinet's economizing policy, but he expressed thanks for the concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT WANTS TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said Tuesday he would like to visit mainland China if invited.

Lee said during a tea party held in a lighthearted atmosphere in the southern port city of Kaohsiung that he would like to visit the mainland mainly to "teach the younger generation what freedom and democracy are all about."
"I reckon nobody on the mainland would dare to invite me," Lee added.

Lee was in Kaohsiung to take part in a series of gala activities being hosted by the Association of Lee Teng-hui's Friends. He received a warm welcome from Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, who is also chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Lee disclosed that he is scheduled to visit the United States in May for a lecture tour at the invitation of the Overseas Taiwanese Association. The itinerary of his forthcoming tour might include visits to Los Angeles, San Francisco, New York and Washington, D.C., he said.
He added that he has no plans to visit Japan shortly for medical treatment, as he is in good health.

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN DAFA DAY MARKED IN 18 MAINLAND CHINESE PROVINCES
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 4 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Falun Gong followers in some 18 mainland Chinese provinces have marked their Falun Dafa Day over the past 45 days since the first such day was celebrated in Changchun city in northeastern Jilin Province Dec. 22, 2001.

According to the New York-based Falun Dafa Information Center, Falun Gong practitioners in cities in the 18 provinces, including Shandong, Heilongjiang, Jilin and Liaoning, have followed Changchun's suit since the end of last year by declaring their respective Falun Dafa Days.

Many of them chose Feb. 4 -- the day of the arrival of spring according to the Chinese lunar calender -- as their Falun Dafa Day, the center said. Most Falun Gong members practiced calligraphy, breathing exercises and prayer to mark the day with the aim of encouraging people living under persecution to continue seeking truth, beauty and prudence.

Falun Gong followers in Changchun said in a declaration that their decision to choose Dec. 22 last year -- the day of the arrival of winter according to the Chinese lunar calender -- carried a symbolic meaning as the beginning of "a new life, a new year and the end of all sin."
According to the center, the world's first Falun Dafa Day was observed May 13, 2000. Since then, towns and cities in Canada and the United States have respectively set up their own Falun Dafa Days.

A Web site belonging to the Falun Gong said that over the past 13 months, more than 54,700 mainland Chinese people have linked to the Web site and have declared that they have re-started practicing the breathing exercises and meditation that is viewed by the Chinese communists as a sect. Beijing has launched repeated and brutal crackdowns on its followers across the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW DIPLOMATS SWORN IN

TEXT.P: Three new ambassadors and representatives of the Republic of China were sworn in Tuesday in a ceremony presided over by Foreign Minister Eugene Chien.

The three new diplomats are the representative to Mexico, Andrew J.S. Wu, who is a former ambassador to Guatemala; Ambassador to Guatemala Francisco L.Y. Hwang, who is a former representative to Chile; and Representative to Chile Adolfo Sun, who is a former ambassador to the Dominican Republic.
Chien urged the new diplomats to gain a better understanding of the countries in which they are stationed, coordinate with the ROC government and to use more innovative ideas in their work.

DOC.HEADLINE: JANUARY CPI UP 0.4 PERCENT FROM DECEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) in January was up a slight 0.4 percent from the previous month and down 1.67 percent from the year-earlier level, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

Hikes in tobacco and liquor prices in January following World Trade Organization entry were partially offset by lower prices for fresh vegetables and fruit, together with sales promotions for winter clothing, the DGBAS statistics show.
The food-excluded CPI registered a year-on-year decrease of 2.23 percent in January, and the service sector CPI fell 3.38 percent from a year earlier, the largest decline since 1982.
The island's wholesale price index (WPI) in January grew by 0.57 percent from December but fell 3.45 percent from a year ago, according to the statistics.

Compared with the same month of last year, the prices of Taiwan-produced cigarettes and imported cigarettes in January increased 38.02 percent and 19.55 percent respectively, pushing the CPI up 0.42 percent.
The prices of Taiwan-made liquor and imported liquor in January grew by 81.89 percent and 2.45 percent respectively, pushing the CPI up 0.51 percent.

The DGBAS attributed the year-on-year CPI and WPI declines mainly to the progress of technology and the relaxation of foreign exchange control. It said that decline is continuing and added that it remains to be seen whether the current loosened monetary policy of the Central Bank of China will result in a currency deflation.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPEED UP PRIVATIZATION OF STATE-RUN FIRMS: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Christine Tsung instructed the Commission of National Corporations (CNC) under the Ministry of Economics Affairs (MOEA) Tuesday to speed up the privatization of state-run enterprises.
Tsung issued the instruction while inspecting the CNC, where she heard a briefing on the commission's operations.
Tsung also heard working reports by the MOEA's Energy Commission, Commerce Department and Industrial Technology Department.
She also said that all state-run enterprises should strictly control overtime pay for employees so as to reduce costs.
However, she did not mention personnel reshuffles at Taiwan Power Co., the Aerospace Industrial Development Corp., Taiwan Sugar Corp. and Taiwan Salt Works.
Tsung, who assumed her duties five days ago, is inspecting the institutes under MOEA control to familiarize herself with their functions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES PARTISAN RECONCILIATION FOR STABILITY AND PROSPERITY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday he hopes the opposition parties and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will reconcile and interact on a basis that will be conducive to Taiwan's political stability.
Chen called for all the parties concerned to "reach out their hands" to each other to allow Taiwan -- "our common home" -- to shine on the world stage.

Over the past year, Chen said, Taiwan has overcome crises and impacts of all kinds, both domestic and international, "enabling us to perceive how vital it is that all of us, regardless of our different political affiliations and varied cultural and ethnic backgrounds, should live together on the island as a community."

Chen said he is glad that after the December legislative elections, Taiwan's politics have become more stable than before and that a consensus between the opposition parties and the DPP on striving for economic growth and political reforms has been made possible -- developments that made him more confident in the country's future.
The president made the remarks at a year-end luncheon party held to entertain the media from home and abroad.

Chen said he was particularly pleased to hear the latest report by the Switzerland-based World Economic Forum that Taiwan's international competitiveness climbed three notches from 2000 to reach seventh in the world in 2001.

He added that he owes former Premier Chang Chun-hsiung a salute for his performance during his 480-day tenure that ended Feb. 1, and that he has great expectations for Chang's successor -- Yu Shyi-kun -- who he said will definitely help lead Taiwan's economy to a brighter future.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO DEVELOP TAIWAN INTO `GREEN SILICON ISLAND'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vowed to develop Taiwan, which was named by Dutch sailors Ilha Formosa or "beautiful island," into a "green silicon island" cherishing humanitarianism and setting its sights on sustained development.

In a meeting with visiting Nobel laureate Alan Heeger, the president said the island will harness technology to transform itself into a "green silicon island" and he praised Heeger's research in converting plastics into conductors of electricity, which earned him the 2000 Nobel Chemistry Prize. Chen said Heeger's work will change the traditional method of information transfer and has thereby altered people's vision of the future.

Heeger said that although it is difficult to make scientific discoveries, the process of applying scientific research results to commercial production is more difficult, not least in the high-tech area.
Heeger, a physics professor at the University of California at Santa Barbara, arrived in Taiwan Monday at the invitation of the Industrial Technology Research Institute.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA TO COOPERATE IN EXPLOITING UNDERSEA OIL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will sign an agreement with the China National Offshore Oil Corp. (CNOOC) of mainland China in March or April to exploit undersea oil in the Chaoshan area, a CPC official said Tuesday.
CPC Vice President Tsai San-lang told reporters that the agreement will be signed soon after the cooperation deal is approved by the Executive Yuan (Cabinet).

He noted that working-level officials from CNOOC arrived in Taipei a few days ago to discuss details of the projects, and added that CNOOC President Wei Liucheng will come to Taipei to sign the agreement in person.
According to Tsai, undersea wells will be drilled in an area covering 15,400 square meters near the median line of the Taiwan Strait centered around a point 118 degrees east, 21 degrees north.
He said that both sides have agreed to prospect for oil on an equal and mutually beneficial principle without touching on sovereignty.
They will establish a joint venture company, called "Tainan Chaoshan Oil Corp.," with capital of US$50,000, and will set up branch offices in Taipei and Shenzhen.
The two sides will share the cost of drilling the undersea wells, estimated at NT$30 million per well, while sharing the results, Tsai went on.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PLANNING TO ESTABLISH THREE FREE TRADE PORTS

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development is planning to establish three free trade ports in northern, central and southern Taiwan in view of the expected easing of the country's restrictive policy toward investment in mainland China.
In a briefing to Premier Yu Shyi-kun Tuesday, officials of the Cabinet-level CEPD said the plan is part of a project aimed at increasing Taiwan's competitiveness.

The project calls for the future work of the CEPD to include the promotion of a knowledge-based economy, e-commerce, planning of global positioning, setting up of free trade ports and improving infrastructure.

In the initial plan to establish free trade ports, the CEPD has targeted Taipei Port to cover the northern Taiwan area, working in conjunction with Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to create a channel of maximum economic efficiency for the flow of goods.

As for the two other free trade ports for central and southern Taiwan, the CEPD is still working on the details and will promote the plan from July once related regulations and laws have been completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEXICO CONTACTED BY ROC REGARDING APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Contact with Mexico, which will host the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum summit this year, have been started to ensure that Taiwan will not be shut out, Foreign Minister Eugene Chien said Tuesday.

The minister told journalists after administering the swearing-in of Taipei's new representative to Mexico Wu Jen-hsiu, that Taipei is contacting the Mexican authorities, as well as the APEC secretariat, to preempt possible opposition to ROC leader's access to the summit.
The minister would not reveal who will be appointed to attend the summit on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.

The unofficial summit has been off-limits to the ROC president ever since it was launched in 1993 at Beijing's insistence. Instead, the ROC sends an economic official to the gatherings designed for heads of APEC member states.

Chen named former Vice President Li Yuan-zu as his representative to the 2001 summit in Shanghai. The decision raised eyebrows in Beijing, which denied Taipei an invitation to the gathering on the grounds that it was inconsistent with the custom of Taiwan being represented by a non-economic official.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREENBACK DIPS ON TAIWAN FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped on the Taipei Foreign Exchange market Tuesday, closing at NT$34.993, or 0.005 down from Monday's close.
A total of US$541 million changed hands in the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$34.917 and was traded between NT$34.909 and NT$34.999.

DOC.HEADLINE: UMC TO TURN PROFIT THIS YEAR: CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) Chairman Robert H.C. Tsao said Tuesday that his company will turn a profit from the second quarter of this year.
Because of the global recession, UMC's revenues for 2001 were registered at NT$64.49 billion, representing a net loss of NT$3.15 billion.

Tsao noted that his company's revenues for the first quarter of 2002 are expected to decrease 10 percent from the fourth quarter of 2001, with the utilization rate of its production capability ranging between 55 percent-60 percent.
The firm's revenues for the fourth quarter of last year totaled NT$13.94 billion, representing a net loss of NT$3.75 billion.
Meanwhile, another UMC official said that the company's capital expenditure this year had been revised downward to US$800 million from an originally estimated US$1.1 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF WELCOMES ARATS MACAU OFFICE

TEXT.P: An official of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Tuesday that Beijing's setting up of an Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) office in Macau is "a good thing" and that Taipei is glad to see its establishment.
Shi Huei-you, vice chairman and secretary-general of the quasi-official SEF, made the remarks while meeting the press at the SEF's Taipei office.

Asked whether the SEF plans to set up an office in Macau, Shi said that under SEF regulations, branches can be set up in areas outside Taiwan and that if necessary, it could prepare to set up such an office immediately.
Shi said that the SEF suggested to ARATS in 1991 that the AFATS should set up an office in Hong Kong, but the suggestion was rebuffed.
The SEF and the ARATS are quasi-official organizations set up by Taipei and Beijing respectively, to deal with cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official relations between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 6, or the 25th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1643: Abel Janszoon Tasman, Dutch mariner and explorer who was the first European to discover Tasmania and New Zealand in 1642, discovers the Fiji Islands in the Pacific.
1778: Britain declares war on France.
1788: Massachusetts becomes the sixth state in the Union of American States.
1804: Joseph Priestley, British chemist noted for his work on the isolation of gases and his discovery of oxygen (1774), dies at the age of 71.
1819: The East India Company, represented by Stamford Raffles, sets up its settlement at Singapore.
1840: Britain annexes New Zealand.
1895: Babe Ruth (George Herman), American baseball player with a tremendous batting record, is born.
1899: The Treaty of Paris is ratified, whereby Spain cedes Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines to the United States for US$20 million.
1911: Ronald Reagan, an actor turned politician and the 40th president of the United States, is born.
1917: British women over 30 obtain the right to vote.
1922: The Washington Conference ends with the United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan agreeing on restricting the use of poison gas and submarine warfare.
1932: Japanese troops capture Harbin in northeastern China.
1932: The Republic of China National Military Council is established.
1938: The ROC National Military Council sets up a Political Department, with Chen Cheng serving as director and Chou En-lai (Zhou Enlai) and Huang Chi-hsiang serving as deputy directors.
1941: Erwin Rommel, the German general known as "the Desert Fox" who committed suicide after his implication in the July Plot to assassinate Hitler in 1944, becomes the supreme commander of German forces in Africa.
1945: U.S. Gen. Douglas MacArthur announces the retaining of Manila and the rescuing of more than 5,000 prisoners of war.
1952: King George VI of Britain dies peacefully at Sandringham. He was succeeded by his eldest daughter Princess Elizabeth.
1957: Taiwan's textile industry enters the age of chemical fibers, as a man-made fiber company's plant in Toufen begins production.
1958: Britain's Manchester soccer team, one of the best teams in Europe, is virtually wiped out in an airplane crash in Munich.
1983: Klaus Barbie, known as "the Butcher of Lyon" during World War II, is charged in Lyon, France with crimes against humanity.
1983: Lee Mei-hsu, noted Taiwanese painter, dies at the age of 82.
1999: The Taipei District Court sentences Hong Kong business tycoon Lin Por-yen to three years and two months in prison for his role in a bribery scandal.
1999: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski says that despite pressure from mainland China, his government will not change its decision to establish diplomatic ties with the Republic of China.
2000: Tarja Halonen becomes the first woman president of Finland.
2001: A mainland Chinese ferry, with 91 passengers and crew members on board, arrives at the ROC's frontline island of Kinmen, marking the first legal direct voyage from the mainland to Kinmen in more than 50 years.
2001: The opposition Kuomintang issues a statement calling for the immediate resumption of construction of the partially completed fourth nuclear power plant.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Holy, sainted men I do not expect to see; if I could only meet with wise and good men I would be satisfied."
