DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLANDERS FIND NEW WAY TO SNEAK INTO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Mainlanders have apparently devised a new way of sneaking into Taiwan by using forged birth certificates and identification cards issued by the government of Matsu, an outlying Republic of China-controlled island, according to Taoyuan district prosecutors.

The prosecutors said they believe that more than 100 mainland Chinese have successfully sneaked into Taiwan over the past year via Matsu, located close to the mainland in the Taiwan Strait, by using falsified documents.

Prosecutor Hsu Ping-wen said that after months of investigations and fact-finding trips to Matsu, the Taoyuan District Prosecutors Office has come to the conclusion that an organized crime ring has been behind the Matsu-Taiwan illegal immigration operations.
It was found that former People's Liberation Army soldiers and public security officers from mainland China have entered Taiwan under this formula over the past year.

Mindful of the potential threat to Taiwan's national security of the Matsu-Taiwan "human cargo" smuggling, the ROC's military intelligence authorities have also pitched in with related investigations, fearing that former mainland PLA and public security members might conduct intelligence-gathering operations in Taiwan once they enter the island.

The newly-arrived "Matsu" people began to raise suspicions among Taoyuan prosecutors last year after the prosecutors discovered that the "Matsu" people "got lost" immediately after entering Taiwan, had no relatives in Taiwan and were unable to be tracked down by local police. In addition, the prosecutors found that the guardians who endorsed the guarantee certificates for the newly-arrived "Matsu" people did not know them personally at all.

Hsu, who made several fact-finding trips to Matsu to gain a further understanding of the situation, said he found out that Taoyuan citizens Liu Tseng-tung and Liu Chien-wen were part of a crime ring that began to smuggle illegal immigrants from mainland China into Taiwan via Matsu in May 2000 after the ROC government initiated a policy making it more convenient for Matsu residents to move to Taiwan for permanent settlement.

Under the policy, all Matsu residents are allowed to emigrate to Taiwan as long as they can produce their birth certificates, identification cards and a guarantee document carrying the names of three Matsu "neighbors" who can prove the applicants are native to Matsu.

The two Lius and the human smuggling ring they belong to were found to have sponsored more than 100 people to move from Matsu to Taiwan, charging each applicant NT$120,000 to NT$160,000 for providing them with fake IDs, birth documents and guarantee papers carrying the names of the required three Matsu residents. In his interviews with the "Matsu" residents whose names were used for the guarantee papers, most of whom are local elders, Hsu found that none personally knew the people they had endorsed. The guarantors were usually paid NT$5,000 to NT$10,000 for their signatures, he added.

The prosecutors also discovered during their investigations that these "Matsu" immigrants to Taiwan from the mainland are not subject to the regulations under the existing Statutes Governing Relations Between People from Across the Taiwan Strait and are therefore not restricted in terms of the number of times they can enter and exit Taiwan, according to Hsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 81.83 points to close at 5,926.08.

Despite a decline in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,887.31 and continued to go up due to a rebound by both electronics and financial shares. The index fluctuated between 5,978.89 and 5,887.31 during trading.

A total of 3.89 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$138.88 billion (US$3.97 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 2.71 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$82.54 billion (US$2.36 billion).

All the eight major stock categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up the most at 1.7 percent, followed by bank and insurance stocks at 1.3 percent, foodstuff shares, pulp and paper issues and plastics and chemical shares, all at 0.8 percent, construction stocks at 0.6 percent, and textile issues and cement stocks, both at 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 428 to 171, with 85 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Wednesday as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for February moved up 85 points to close at 5,969, with 12,373 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March rose 71 points to close at 5,951, with 885 contract transactions, while June futures gained 4 points to finish at 5,930, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,884 for February, 5,880 for March, 5,926 for June, 5,896 for September, and 5,850 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

February TE futures moved up 4 points to close at 316.5, with 2,958 contract transactions, while March TE futures increased 5 points to finish at 316, with 81 contracts changing hands. No transactions were recorded for other months.
February TF futures moved up 2 points to finish at 724, with 976 contract transactions, while March TF futures gained 1 point to close at 725, with 28 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN MAKES PUBLIC ROC FIRST COUPLE'S ASSETS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian reportedly owns eight pieces of land, six houses and apartments, bank savings totaling about NT$6.6 million, and stocks, bonds and securities worth nearly NT$40 million.

President Chen, who shares his assets with his wife, the first lady Wu Shu-chen, has formally registered his assets with the Department of Assets Disclosure for Public Functionaries Under the Control Yuan, which on Wednesday made public a list of the related public officials and their assets.

According to the department's reports, one of the eight pieces of land that President Chen and his wife own is located in Chen's hometown of Kuantien in Tainan County, while the other seven pieces of land are in Taipei City.
Of the six houses and apartments the couple owns, one is located in Kuantien and the other five are in Taipei City, according to the report.

The first couple has NT$6.65 million in bank accounts, none of which is in a foreign currency. The first lady owns all of the couple's stocks, bonds and securities, which together are worth about NT$40 million if calculated at NT$10 per share, the department report indicated.

There are no cars, ships or aircraft in Chen's name. In an appendix to his assets report to the Control Yuan, Chen said he also has NT$520,000 that was part of the NT$34 million in subsidies that he received from the government for the 2000 presidential election. This money, currently in a First Bank savings account, has been put aside for charity and other activities for public interest purposes, according to Chen.

In accordance with Article 4 of the Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law, assets disclosure reports must be submitted to the Control Yuan by the ROC president and vice president, the presidents and vice presidents of the five Yuan, political appointees, paid advisors to the president, elected officials at the level of township magistrate or above, and elected representatives of counties and cities under provincial jurisdiction and higher administrative units.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN, XIAMEN TO JOINTLY OBSERVE LANTERN FESTIVAL WITH FIREWORKS

TEXT.P: People from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will for the first time jointly observe the annual Lantern Festival by setting off fireworks simultaneously on either side of the narrow stretch of water separating the island of Kinmen from mainland China.

Kinmen county government officials said Wednesday that the fireworks displays will be staged simultaneously on the coast of the ROC-controlled island and on the coast near the mainland port city of Xiamen, which is located opposite Kinmen, on the evening of Feb. 26. The idea for the displays was initiated by the Xiamen city government and received enthusiastically by Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng.

The Xiamen officials originally proposed that the two places set off fireworks simultaneously on the eve of the Lunar Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 11, but their Kinmen counterparts suggested instead that the event be postponed to the Lantern Festival in order to allow plenty of time for the requisite arrangements to be made. On the night of the Lantern Festival, a total of 1,120 fireworks are expected to be set off on Kinmen, while an even more magnificent display will be sent up in Xiamen.

In addition to the fireworks displays, the Kinmen county government will also sponsor a lantern exhibition in Kinmen and a traditional Chinese puppet show, which is expected to be performed by the troupe of mainland classic puppet master Huang Yi-chueh, according to Kinmen officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM TO ASK LEGISLATURE TO REVIEW REVISED ALLOCATION LAW (I)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan decided Wednesday to propose a motion to ask the legislature to reconsider a revised law governing the allocation of government revenues and expenditures, the first possible conflict between the ruling and opposition camps in the new legislature.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun said the move is "a last resort," necessary because the Cabinet finds it "hard to implement" the revised law, which was rammed through the legislature the last day of the previous legislature.

In anticipation of a strong reaction from the opposition, Yu urged "calm and rationality," saying that the national construction and financial systems are at stake and that his decision had nothing to do with parties or party factions.

The revised law, initiated by the opposition Kuomintang and supported by the People First Party, will force the central government to give a larger portion of its revenues to local governments. The executive branch blasted the revision as "hard to implement" at the time and Wednesday was the last day for the Exceutive Yuan to ask the legislature to reconsider the law. Yu said at a press conference held at the Government Information Office that the revised law was hastily passed without full and comprehensive communication among all sides.

He said that the revision would result in a serious imbalance of the central and local governments in the future, which he said runs counter to the regulations of the Budget Law. The revision, he claimed, also fails to provide measures that would allow local governments to follow the ideals of self-rule.

He noted that the current subsidy system exercised by the central government addresses the financial situation of local governments, replenishing and balancing their accounts, which he said has borne fruit, citing local governments' shouldering of national health insurance fees as an example.

Yu said that the local governments paid up to 98 percent of the insurance fees, up sharply from 40 percent in the past. The ruling Democratic Progressive Party said it supports Yu's motion and urged that the matter be viewed rationally and apolitically.

Tsai Huang-liang, the DPP legislative whip, said the party will communicate with the opposition in the hope that the motion can be passed, so that the revised law will not "result in squeezing the subsidies for local governments and therefore the budgets for social and welfare groups."

Tsai also urged the Cabinet to present a convincing formula for the allocation of revenues and subsidies, and to allow all local governments, as well as the municipalities of Taipei and Kaohsiung, to participate in discussion of the formula to stem fights over the allocation issue each year.
Wu Nai-jen, DPP secretary-general, echoed the premier's remarks that the motion is a last resort.

Although there have been suggestions that implementation of the revised law should be put off for one year in order to allow for further revision, Wu said that this would not address the immediate problem, as the Cabinet will soon have to work out next year's budget.

Meanwhile, the KMT accused the DPP of acting "conspiratorially," saying that the DPP should shoulder the responsibility if its actions result in a confrontation between the ruling and opposition camps that affects political stability and economic development. After the exceutive branch presents the motion to be reconsidered, a majority vote will be needed if the original law is to be upheld.

Even if the motion fails, the revised Constitution stipulates that the Cabinet will not have to step down but will have to accept the failure or seek other options, which the opposition camp claimed is the reason the Cabinet made the decision to press the motion, since it "cannot lose."

DOC.HEADLINE: PM TO ASK LEGISLATURE TO REVIEW REVISED ALLOCATION LAW (II)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 6 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu) (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The KMT Central Standing Committee noted that the Executive Yuan claimed that the revised allocation law will result in a financial shortfall of NT$50 billion (US$1.42 billion), but said this could be resolved by raising the ceiling of the Public Debt Law, "improving the stock market" and increasing the revenue raised by lotteries, according to Wu Ching-ki, a KMT spokesman.

Wu said that the DPP made the decision because it hopes to "create political instability," which it could then use as an excuse to bring in the National Security Alliance mechanism touted by President Chen Shui-bian.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who had promoted the revised law, was said to be so worried about the latest development that he might cut short a trip to Europe and return to Taiwan.
The revision would give a large share of government revenues to local governments and the special municipality of Kaohsiung, while Taipei would make little gains.

PFP Chairman James Soong said that the allocation of government revenues requires full discussion by all involved and urged Chen to call for coordination between the ruling and opposition camps so that the choice is not limited to only two options.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar Wednesday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange market, gaining NT$0.023 to close at NT$35.016.
A total of US$341 million changed hands during the trading session. The greenback opened at NT$35.043 and was traded between NT$35.005 and NT$35.043.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES BUSINESSES TO ADOPT `TAIWAN INSIDE' CONCEPT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian traveled to Nantou County Wednesday, where he urged businesses to adapt Intel's world-famous "Intel Inside" slogan and tout "Taiwan Inside" in the face of robust competition in the global market.

Chen made the trip to the central county to gain a better understanding of industrial development in the region that was devastated by the earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999, the worst temblor to hit Taiwan in a century. He visited a 30-year-old local factory that has expanded its operations following the killer quake.

Chen praised the company's efforts to retain its roots in Taiwan despite a mainland China investment rush among many Taiwan enterprises. In light of the huge tasks ahead in the knowledge-based era, Chen said Taiwan industries are being challenged by the need to transform following the country's Jan. 1 entry into the World Trade Organization.

The president encouraged Taiwan-based businesses to adopt the "Taiwan Inside" slogan wherever they go and make the island a base of "spiritual support" for Taiwan businessmen overseas. He also called for a "second Taiwan economic miracle" through all-out cooperation between the government and the private sector.

Stressing that the goal to build Taiwan into a "green silicon island" is high on the government's agenda, he urged Taiwan-based firms not to underestimate their own abilities and pointed out that the World Economic Forum recently rated Taiwan as the world's seventh-most competitive country, ahead of Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea and mainland China, and an advance from last year's 10th spot. Chen also visited a local center where he wished a happy Lunar New Year to elderly people and children and gave away more than 40 "red envelopes."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TRAFFIC SCOFFLAW RECEIVED 462 TICKETS LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: A Taipei man was handed a total of 462 tickets in 2001 for traffic violations including speeding, running red lights, illegal parking and other traffic irregularities, making him country's biggest traffic scofflaw last year in terms of tickets issued.

The man has unpaid tickets worth NT$296,500 that he will have to clear soon after the Lunar Chinese New Year, according to the Traffic Adjudication Office under the Taipei city government. However, in terms of fines, another Taipei man was the biggest offender last year, as he received a total of 205 tickets worth NT$465,900.

The Taipei Traffic Adjudication Office published a list Wednesday of the top 100 traffic violators in 2001 in terms of number of tickets as well as the amount of fines. The 100th violator on the list received 146 tickets last year, for a combined fine of NT$181,800.
The "record holder" over the past four years was one particularly antisocial individual who received 1,244 tickets worth NT$803,100 in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: BREAKTHROUGH IN CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS `POSSIBLE': TAIPEI MAYOR
DOC.DATELINE: London, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that a breakthrough between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is possible in the long term, although it will probably be in the form of verbal exchanges rather than substantial progress in the short term.
Ma made the remarks in a speech he delivered at Oxford University.
Ma said that judging from the resilience shown by President Chen Shui-bian so far, it is possible that there will be some breakthrough during his term.
He said that the president has shown strength when facing sticky issues, and warned that Chen's resilience and ability to initiate change should not be underestimated.
Ma cited as an example the scrapping and subsequent resumption of the semi-finished fourth nuclear plant in late October 2000, a move that cost long delays and huge financial losses.
Ma said that this shows Chen is not a fundamentalist and that while the president may be an anti-nuclear sympathizer, he was pragmatic enough to support the resumption of the plant's construction.

On cross-strait relations, the popular Taipei mayor said that the mainland should not be suspicious of Taiwan declaring independence, while Taiwan does not need to worry that it will be swallowed by the mainland.

He appealed for a shelving of disputes and focus on the building of mutual trust so as to seek common ground for a breakthrough, saying that the return to the so-called "1992 consensus" on "one China, different interpretations" could serve as a good start.

DOC.HEADLINE: IFPI, LOCAL POP SINGERS CALL FOR ANTI-PIRACY ACTION IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Executives of the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI) and several local pop singers called Wednesday on the public in Taiwan to reject music piracy and help "save the music industry from collapse."

IFPI Chairman and CEO Jason Berman said at a meeting in Taipei that rampant music piracy has damaged the recording industry in every region of the world and that the IFPI hopes to call public attention to what he described as "an endangered industry."

Statistics released by the IFPI Members Foundation in Taiwan indicate that sales revenues of Taiwan's recording industry dropped to NT$5.3 billion in 2001, less than half of the total of NT$12.3 billion five years ago. Pirate music CDs accounted for 48 percent of the music market.

While music downloads in MP3 format has been extremely popular among youngsters in Taiwan, the recording industry is being backed into a corner, according to IFPI Taiwan Secretary-general Robin Lee. Accompanied by representatives of Taiwan's recording industry, Berman and Asia/Pacific regional office Board Chairman Lachie Rutherford called on Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan, Interior Minister Yu Cheng-hsien and Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng to ask the government to find effective measures to fight piracy.

According to an IFPI global anti-piracy watch report, a series of raids upon warehouses and packaging centers engaged in producing pirate music CDs have had significant impact on the piracy market in Taiwan, although the piracy problem remains serious.

The IFPI Taiwan executive said that his office has been coordinating with the authorities to fight piracy. In the past year, he went on, a total of 2,235 cases of piracy were indicted. However, arrest and the confiscation of pirated products does not stem the flow because most of the offenders caught are juveniles who are often treated with leniency by the courts.

Fighting music piracy remains one of the IFPI's priorities. The organization, which represents the international recording industry in 46 countries, reported recently that massive proliferation of CD-burning and increasing availability of unauthorized Internet downloads have had a strong impact around the globe. CD album sales in the first half of 2001 dropped by 4.6 percent from the year-earlier level.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP REPORTS FINANCIAL ASSETS OF NT $ 26.6 MILLION

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu has registered her assets with the Control Yuan, reporting NT$26.6 million in bank accounts, six plots of land and five houses, according to a report published Wednesday by the ROC's highest control organ.
According to the report by the Control Yuan's Department of Assets Disclosure for Public Functionaries, Lu's assets include some U.S. dollar accounts but no securities.
Of her six land lots, five are located in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan and the other is in Taipei City, while four of her five houses are located in Taoyuan County and the other is in Taipei City.
According to the report, Lu has no debts and is not owed any money.
She has neither cars, ships or aircraft, but has registered 12 publications, which she claimed as "price incalculable."

In accordance with Article 4 of the Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law, the Control Yuan receives assets disclosure reports from the president and vice president, the presidents and vice presidents of the five yuans, political appointees, paid advisors to the president, elected officials at the level of township magistrates or above and elected representatives of counties and cities under provincial jurisdiction and higher administrative units.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TAP DANCE GROUP TO PERFORM IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Theatrical Arts International from the United States will perform in Taipei from Thursday through Sunday at the National Theater.

Allen Evenson, director of the tap dance troupe, said the performances will feature a live band, adding greater entertainment value to the shows, which he said are very different from traditional tap dance performances.

According to Evenson, his dancers will present a new type of tap dance to the Taipei audiences, combining elements of stomp, heavy metal, rock and techno music. He said that the energy, rhythm and speed of the dancers will be a brand new experience for local audiences.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUMMER CAMP IN TAIWAN PLANNED FOR TAIWAN CHILDREN IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Two mainland-based schools for Taiwan businessmen's children have decided to organize an annual summer camp in Taiwan for their students, starting this year, an official with the Ministry of Education said Wednesday.

The decision was made in a coordination meeting attended by representatives from the schools for Taiwan businessmen's children in Dongwan and Shanghai, the official said, adding that the Education Ministry may grant financial support for the activities.

With an increasing number of Taiwan businessmen settling down in mainland China, the Dongwan Taiwan Businessmen's School and the Huadong Taiwan Businessmen's School in Shanghai were set up in 2000 and 2001, respectively, to meet the educational needs of Taiwanese children.

Although the textbooks to be used and the sites for the summer camp have not yet been decided, it is understood that a total of 173 elementary and junior high school students from the two schools will return to Taiwan to take part in the planned summer courses.

In a bid to help Taiwanese children studying in the mainland to proceed with their studies here, mainland-based schools for Taiwan businessmen's children usually use Taiwan textbooks that are first screened by the mainland authorities in order to censor those parts of the books considered "sensitive" by the communist regime.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI DEVELOPS COMMAND CHIPSET FOR MULTIFUNCTION PRINTERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) has developed a command chipset that is expected to help embattled local optical scanner makers to design and produce more profitable and price-competitive multifunction printers (MFPs). According to the ITRI's Opto-Electronics and Systems Laboratories printer technologies division chief, the lab owns several patents on the new command chipset, which is based on the popular ARM7, a low-voltage RISC microprocessor architecture made up of a core CPU and a range of system peripherals that provide a complete system on a chip.

Ying Tai-fa said that the lab, which researches, develops and transfers to Taiwan industry new opto-electronics technologies that increase competitiveness and create new market opportunities, also provides its clients with related firmware and system integration design services, as well as relevant information on merge color printing and other image processing technologies.

Ying said that the recent market saturation and price wars for traditional computer peripherals have gradually reduced their profitability, with traditional optical scanner makers facing the greatest pressure.

Taiwan's optical scanner makers, which dominate the world's scanner market with an approximately 90 percent market share, have been looking for new products based on their existing technologies, and the MFP has piqued their interest because of its market potential, Ying said.
An MFP is an office tool for paper management that is connected to a personal computer or network and combines the functions of printing, scanning, photocopying and faxing.
The ITRI is a national-level non-profit research and development organization that carries out projects entrusted by the government and private companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: IPO EXECUTIVE SUGGESTS R&D CAPABILITY IS TAIWAN'S ADVANTAGE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's information industry maintains the advantage of research and development capability, even though many electronics manufacturers have moved their production facilities to mainland China, according to an international purchasing office (IPO) executive in Taipei.

Chen Chiou-ming, general manager of the Hewlett-Packard Greater China Region IPO, said his office will continue to boost its purchases from Taiwan, although the deliveries might be made in mainland China.

Last year, HP purchases from Taiwan's information industry were valued at US$5.7 billion, up 14 percent from the preceding year, according to Chen. Taiwan's original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) are major suppliers of notebooks, desktop computers, servers, work stations, printers, scanners, monitors and digital cameras to the international corporation.

He said that many IPOs prefer to place orders with the head offices of the Taiwan manufacturers because the business and industry in Taiwan are more advanced in logistics than their mainland counterparts.

While it will take time for mainland China to improve its basic infrastructure and simplify customs clearance procedures, IPOs may continue to place orders with manufacturers in Taiwan in the next one or two years, Chen said, adding, however, that it is an unavoidable trend that the IPOs will begin placing orders directly with mainland manufacturing plants in the coming years.

Chen said that for long-term development, business and industry in Taiwan should stress R&D. As a matter of fact, HP is studying the feasibility of setting up an R&D center in Taiwan, he disclosed. He suggested that Taiwan also has the advantage of having the potential to develop into an international operational center with capital flow and cargo flow functions.

Last year, the more than 100 IPOs in Taiwan purchased US$37.8 billion-worth of industrial products, mostly information industry hardware. The amount is expected to increase to US$41 billion this year, according to the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Purchases by the top 10 IPOs in Taiwan -- Compaq, HP, Dell, IBM, Apple, Intel, Gateway, Radioshack, Ingram Micro and Solectron -- were worth US$27.9 billion in 2001, an increase of 2 percent from the year-earlier level.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION VALUE OF TAIWAN'S NETWORK PRODUCTS REACH US $ 3.04 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's major computer network products reached a production value of US$3.04 billion last year, 0.9 percent higher than the year before, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) announced Wednesday.

According to the DGBAS, the annual production value of broadband modems and ISDN-related wide area network (WAN) products dropped 7.7 percent, or US$1.55 billion, from 2000, amid slumping market demand and a lackluster global economy.

OEM products comprised 77 percent of Taiwan's WAN products last year, with only 14 percent marketed under a local brand name. The four major makers of WAN products increased their total market share from 68 percent to 90 percent last year.
Broadband modems made up 60 percent of the total production value of local WAN products in 2001, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE FOREIGN MINISTER TO PRESIDE MEETING OF DIPLOMATS IN AFRICA
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Chang Jer-shong and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Chiou Jong-nan will arrive in Swaziland from South Africa Wednesday to preside over an annual meeting of ROC's diplomats stationed in Africa.

The meeting will be held Feb. 7 at Mbabane, capital of Swaziland, with the participation of ROC's ambassadors, representatives, officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Government Information Office and other government agencies.

The meeting will review the works of ROC diplomats in Africa during the past year and plan for the future. The participants are expected to exchange opinions about regional development in Africa and relations of ROC with African countries.

During his stay in Swaziland, Chiou will meet Swazi King Mswati III, the premier and foreign minister, and will inspect the work of major technological cooperation projects between the two countries. Before arriving in South Africa, Chiou visited Liberia, Senegal, Cote d'ivoire and Malawi. He jointly presided with Liberian Foreign Minister Monie Captan over the fourth meeting of the ROC-Liberia Mixed Commission in Monrovia Jan. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO VISIT FRANCE, ITALY

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan was to leave for a 12-day trip to France and Italy Wednesday evening.
KMT spokesman Wu Ching-chi told reporters that the trip is a private Chinese New Year vacation for Lien and his family and that no official activities have been arranged for him.

Despite the fact that Legislative Yuan will be convened Feb. 19 to discuss the Cabinet's request for overturning amendments to the law governing the allocation of revenues to local governments, Wu said that Lien has no plans to cut short his trip.
He noted that Lien instructed related bodies to be fully prepared to veto the Cabinet's move by consolidating the opposition in the Legislative Yuan.
While abroad, the KMT chief will be kept informed about developments regarding the issue, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO PROMOTE TAIWAN AGRICULTURAL GOODS IN INTERNATIONAL FOOD FAIRS

TEXT.P: In an effort to seek outlets overseas for Taiwan agricultural products, the Council of Agriculture (COA) has worked out a series of plans for domestic produce to increase their presence in the international market.

The COA's International Cooperation Department said it has decided to organize delegations to take part in food fairs to be held in Chicago, Singapore, Taipei and Tokyo, starting in March through August, as a means of offsetting the impact of Taiwan's Jan. 1 entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Taiwan's agricultural industry is expected to be hard hit following the island's WTO admission amid inflows of foreign imports from Southeast Asian countries and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER DISCHARGED FROM HOSPITAL AFTER HERNIA OPERATION

TEXT.P: Former Premier Chang Chun-hsiung left National Taiwan University Hospital Wednesday after undergoing hernia surgery, sources from the hospital said.

Chang had been suffering from a hernia since before he left office Feb. 1. He suffered through the pain during lengthy legislative sessions which often lasted seven or eight hours. However, because of his heavy workload, he was unable to schedule the corrective surgery.
Chang went to hospital directly after he received a medal bestowed by President Chen Shui-bian the day he left office.
Hospital spokesman Chen Ming-feng said the hernia surgery is routine and if Chang does not feel uncomfortable, he will not have to go back to hospital for further checkup.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2002 SPRING COMPUTER, MULTIMEDIA EXPO KICKS OFF IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2002 Spring Computer and Multimedia Expo kicked off Wednesday at the Taipei World Trade Center, attracting over 50,000 spectators, bargain hunters and game players eager to see the season's newest software and hardware products.

Organized by the Taipei Computer Association, the five-day trade show was attended by about 200 computer game companies, broadband service providers, and desktop and laptop computer makers manning 1,000 booths, each going all out to dazzle show-goers with pop bands, prize drawings, discounts and give-aways.

This year's Spring Computer and Multimedia Expo goes by the theme "Taipei Game Show," with gaming software companies -- many of which did surprisingly well last year despite the overall economic slump -- stealing the spotlight.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPANIES TO SET STANDARDS FOR MOBILE APPLICATION PLATFORMS

TEXT.P: An alliance of high-tech companies, research centers and government agencies announced Wednesday that it will work to establish common standards for mobile terminal application platforms, a move that is expected to pave the way for greater growth for Taiwan's telecommunications industry.

According to the Mobile Terminal Application Development Platform R&D Alliance, its members plan to lay down the development standards for cellular phones, PDAs and other wireless communication terminals for Chinese-speaking regions over the next two years so that all involved companies can use the cross-platform standards to develop application software and services.

Ministry of Economic Affairs Industrial Technology Department Director-General Hwang Jung-chiou said that his department was charged with promoting the alliance, which includes such high-tech leaders as Acer, Inventec and Asustek.

Hwang said that a common standard will stimulate the growth of the wireless communications industry. Taiwan is especially well-suited as a testing ground for such a standard because of the prevalence of cellular phones, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD TO SET UP NATIONAL DESIGN CENTER NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) will include the establishment of a national design center as one of its priorities next year, said CEPD Vice Chairwoman Ho Mei-yueh Wednesday.
Ho said the center is aimed at assisting traditional industries to make more innovative designs to enhance the value of the products.

She noted that since Taiwan's traditional industries had focused a great deal of energy on production, they are easily undercut by countries that supply cheap labor, now the government is going to assist them to develop a "knowledge-based economy" and inject into these industries a new energy.

Ho emphasized that the government has done much in the development of nanotechnology, which she said will become the most important technology in the future -- one that will overshadow even IC design and its related technologies.

Nanotechnology involves the creation and utilization of materials, devices and systems through the control and manipulation of matter at the nanometer scale, that is, at the level of atoms, molecules and supramolecular structures. A nanometer is one-billionth of a meter - about 10,000 times narrower than a human hair and four times wider than an atom.
Using nanotechnology, Ho added, traditional industries can make more innovative and high-value products.

Ho said that some European countries do not consider products of traditional industries as low-end articles; for instance, France deems the perfume industry one of its most important national industries.
She also thinks that Taiwan's traditional industries should strengthen their marketing and try some OEM designs for other trademarks.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING CRITICIZED FOR OPPRESSING FALUN GONG MEMBERS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The latest report of the Human Rights Watch said that the Beijing authorities continue to oppress Falun Gong members through new laws or new interpretations of existing laws.

The report, to be made public Wednesday, said that the Falun Gong is listed by Beijing as an unlawful religious group and its members, like the Tibetans and the Uigurs, are treated as "separatists" and constitute a threat to the communist party.
Mainland Chinese official documents were quoted as describing the Falun Gong as a "terrorist" organization.

A Human Rights Watch official said that it was "extremely absurd" for Beijing to treat Falun Gong members as terrorists because most members are "peace-loving and law-abiding" citizens whose acts have never violated human rights.
The report said that the Falun Gong now has several million members around the world, adding that Beijing began oppressing the Falun Gong in July 1999.
Over the past year, it noted, Beijing prohibited Falun Gong members from doing meditating exercises on public occasions and destroyed tens of thousands of Falun Gong publications.
The report said that Beijing has also forced some other countries not to tolerate the Falun Gong to suppress any people who may consider joining the discipline.
The official said Beijing's accusation that the Falun Gong threatens the social stability of mainland China is inaccurate.
The Human Rights Watch urged Beijing to amend related laws designed to deal with so-called "secret organizations" and "vicious religious groups."

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TRIES TO LIMIT CITIZENS NOT BORN IN TAIWAN TO RUN FOR PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) is to propose banning citizens not born in Taiwan from running for president or vice president of the nation, a TSU spokesman said Wednesday.

Legislator Chen Chien-min, deputy secretary-general of the TSU's legislative caucus, said that members of the party's legislative caucus have discussed the idea and added that the TSU plans to propose to amend the Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law by inserting a clause that "those who were not born in the free area of the Republic of China" cannot run for the post of president or vice president.
He added that because the proposal would involve a constitutional amendment, the TSU caucus will first have to put the idea before the TSU's policy-making center for further study.

Many of Taiwan's most prominent politicians and office-bearers were born in mainland China or Hong Kong and the TSU proposal will almost certainly be interpreted by the other parties as a clause to exclude opposition Chairman Lien Chan, People First Party Chairman James Soong and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou in future elections.
However, Chen claimed at a press conference that the proposal is "based on considerations of national security" and is "not aimed at any specific people."
Chen added that if the TSU's proposal were to be approved, non-Taiwan born residents could still run for legislative and local government seats.
The proposal drew immediate criticism and ridicule from both the ruling and the opposition parties.

Lin Yi-shih, secretary of the KMT legislative caucus, said that KMT will strongly oppose the proposal and said that the imposition of this restriction would violate the Constitution, as well as further provoke the independence-reunification dispute.

Tsai Huang-lang, outgoing secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's legislative caucus, also said that the proposal would violate the Constitution, which protects the right of every citizen to take part in elections.

Lee Ching-an, convener of the People First Party legislative caucus, ridiculed the proposal and pointed out that it would not only inflame the independence versus reunification dispute but would also violate the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL PRIZE WINNER IN CHEMISTRY DELIVERS SPEECH AT ITRI

TEXT.P: The winner of the Nobel Prize in chemistry, Alan Heeger, Wednesday delivered a speech on "semiconducting and metallic polymers: opportunities for science and technology" at the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan.

Prior to delivering the speech, Heeger met with Chintay Shih, president of ITRI; Liu Jung-sheng, director of the Optoelectronics and System Laboratories; Liu Chung-ming, director of the materials Research Laboratories; Cheng Wu-hsun, director of the Union Chemical Laboratories and others to exchange views on technology exchanges.

Heeger, 66, currently a physics professor at the University of California at Santa Barbara, was awarded the Nobel Prize in chemistry together with Hideki Shirakawa, professor of the University of Tsukuba, Japan, and Professor Alan MacDiarmid of the University of Pennsylvania in 2000.
Their research has proven that plastics, a material known as an insulator, could be converted to a conductor of electricity and their research was creative and useful.
These kind of plastics have been widely used in computers, cellular phones and television displays.

An official from ITRI said that Taiwan-produced flat panel displays and its peripheral products have reached NT$120 billion (about US$3.43 billion) last year. Taiwan should keep this trend in global research and development, he said, adding that Taiwan should break the bottleneck of the ink-jet printing technology to develop a polymer light emitting diode (PLED) and an organic light emitting diode (OLED) to be used in displays.
ITRI is trying to develop the organic light emitting OLED and PLED.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN ASKS LEGISLATURE TO RECONSIDER REVENUE ALLOCATION

TEXT.P: A motion for reconsideration of the revised Law Governing the Allocation of Government Revenues and Expenditures was delivered by the Executive Yuan to the Legislative Yuan Wednesday evening.

The legislature will have until Feb. 20 to reconfirm its decision to alter the allocation of Central Government funds or the legislative revisions will be null and void. The Executive Yuan has said that the redistribution scheme would be impossible to be implemented.

Claiming that the revision requiring the Central Government to give more of its revenues to local governments will create a financial shortfall of NT$150 billion (US$4.28 billion) in the Central Government's budget, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said he was compelled to send the revision of expenditures back to the legislature, but he said that he would abide by whatever decision the lawmakers made.
Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said he will consult various parties in the legislature Thursday on ways to put the motion on the agenda Feb. 19.

Meanwhile, Kuomintang Legislator Lin Shih-yi, whip of the party which initiated the changes in the last session of the previous legislature, said his party will summons their lawmakers to work out a common response to the move Thursday and will united the party's political allies in the legislature to scuttle any attempt to reverse the changes.
The KMT controls only 68 seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan and will have to marshal 113 votes to override the motion for reconsideration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AVIATION OFFICIALS TO ASSIST U.S. IN PROBING TAKE-OFF ERROR
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 6 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung and James Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Aviation Safety Council (ASC) is slated to dispatch officials to Alaska Feb. 17 to assist the U.S. National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) with ongoing investigations into a China Airlines take-off error that took place last month.

ASC Executive Director Jung Kai said that the ASC officials will help simulate the events that took place Jan. 25, when a China Airlines jetliner took off at 2:43 a.m. local time from a taxiway instead of the assigned runway at Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport, an incident that NTSB officials have called "a very serious case" of a lapse in aviation safety.

According to a preliminary NTSB report, the controllers at the airport tower were aware that the plane was taking off from a taxiway but did not radio the pilots to instruct them to abandon the take-off attempt.

Although the China Airlines flight CI-001 safely arrived in Taiwan 10 hours later with its 237 passengers, three pilots and 12 flight attendants, investigators found signs that the plane's landing gear scraped a mound of snow at the end of the 6,800-foot taxiway, narrowly avoiding a disaster.
The plane was supposed to have taken off from a 11,000-foot northbound runway instead of the westbound taxiway.

NTSB investigations are focusing on the experience and training of the China Airlines flight crew, their handling of the events that led to the error, the performance of the controllers at the airport tower and the airport's facilities.
The three pilots and co-pilots flying the plane were banned by China Airlines from further flying.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER INSTRUCTS THREE STATE-RUN BANKS TO MERGE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun Wednesday instructed that the Bank of Taiwan, the Land Bank of Taiwan, and the Central Trust of China should be merged into a single bank prior to forming a financial and monetary holding company.
The premier spoke while inspecting the Ministry of Finance Wednesday morning.

The three state-run banks have originally been projected to merge into a bank to form a financial and monetary holding corporation. However, the Executive Yuan has asked the ministry to reevaluate and review the plan.
According to Vice Minister of Finance Wang Teh-shan, who relayed the premier's instructions, the premier believes that merging first will upgrade the competitiveness of the new institution.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF ASKED TO REDRESS ISSUE INVOLVING INCOME TAXES FOR TEACHERS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun Wednesday instructed the Ministry of Finance to study steps to abolish the regulations which exempt the nation's teachers and military servicemen from paying income taxes.
Yu, who assumed the premiership Feb. 1, made the instruction while inspecting the operations of the ministry.

According to Vice Minister of Finance Wang Teh-shan, Yu asked the ministry to coordinate with the Ministry of National Defense and the Ministry of Education as soon as possible to redress the regulations which he described as outdated.
The premier reportedly said that the proposal to repeal the preferential income tax treatment for teachers and servicemen was first raised by then-Premier Tang Fei in the second half of 2000.
As the issue remains unresolved, Yu asked the ministry to coordinate with related ministries for a satisfactory solution.
He said that the ministry should study ways to raise the wages of teachers and servicemen before revoking the preferential treatment so that their interests will not be affected.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LAWMAKERS LOBBY THEIR FRENCH COUNTERPARTS FOR WHO ACCESS
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A group of Republic of China (ROC) lawmakers lobbied their French counterparts Tuesday in Paris for the ROC's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) as an observer.

The five lawmakers: Lai Ching-teh, Chiang Chi-wen, Liu Shih-fang, Yeh Yi-chin and Chien Chao-tung, led by Presidential Adviser Wu Shu-min, called on a group of pro-Taiwan French parliamentarians Tuesday to seek their support for Taiwan's bid to join the WHO as an observer.
They were greeted by Senate Vice Speaker Jean-Louis Lorrain, National Assembly Deputy Jean Francois Mattei and others.

Legislator Lai who is a physician said Taiwan is an island with a good health care system, but it could not get any aid from WHO when it was hit by a 7.3-magnitute earthquake Sept. 21, 1999 because it is not a member of the WHO.
The earthquake claimed 2,400 lives and injured thousands of people.
Citing another example, Lai said Taiwan was plagued by illness caused by the enterovirus in 1998, but had no way to know WHO's precautionary measures against the disease.

It is not difficult to become an observer of the organization according to its charter. The Vatican, Palestine and the International Red Cross are all WHO observers. There is no reason why Taiwan should not be an observer too, Lai said.

Legislator Chien Chao-tung said Taiwan's participation in the WHO would be a win-win scenario where the country can share WHO's health-care information and help WHO with its work by providing medical aid to less-developed countries.
Legislator Liu Shih-fang said WHO's worldwide anti-disease network will continue to have a big loophole if Taiwan remains excluded from the organization.

Jean-Louis Lorrain was impressed with the ROC lawmakers' reasoning. He said after the meeting that the ROC lawmakers made clear their reasons for ROC's WHO bid and he believed that the WHO will open its door to the island soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO INSTIGATE 73 MAJOR PROJECTS THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Christine Tsung said her ministry will launch 73 public projects, each with a price tab of more than NT$100 million (US$2.85 million), this year.
In a briefing to Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Tsung said the total outlay for these projects will be NT$198.1 billion (US$5.66 billion).
As to the economic policy toward mainland China, Tsung cited President Chen Shui-bian's "active opening, effective management" approach toward Beijing as the supreme guideline of her ministry.
That means limitations on direct trade with mainland China will be eliminated in phases, and the island will open its market to imports of mainland agricultural products step by step, Tsung said.

The minister also spelled out the five priorities of her ministry, namely formulating policy which will accelerate economic recovery, promoting the long-term competitiveness of local industries, bettering the infrastructure for industrial development, strengthening the system complimentary to industrial development and setting the nation's sights on the world while making economic policy for the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES BEIJING TO RESTART DIALOGUE WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged Beijing leaders Wednesday to take the opportunity to restart dialogue with Taiwan.

Speaking at a dinner given by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to foreign ambassadors and representatives to the Republic of China, the president said the ROC would like to co-exist with mainland China peacefully and thereby usher in a stable and prosperous period for both sides of the Strait.

Reiterating his repeated hope to talk with Beijing leader Jiang Zemin in person about ways to ensure peaceful ties between the two sides, the president urged Jiang to make the most of the historic opportunity to restart dialogue with Taiwan and bring peace to people on both sides of the Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 7, or the 26th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1478: Sir Thomas More, English Lord Chancellor who was executed by Henry VIII for refusing to deny the Pope's authority, is born.
1685: King Charles II, king of England, Scotland and Ireland known as the "merry monarch" who reigned during the Restoration, dies at the age of 55.
1792: Austria and Prussia sign a military pact against France.
1812: Charles Dickens, the great English novelist who wrote a number of well-loved classics like "Oliver Twist" and "David Copperfield," is born.
1816: Italian missionary Giovanni Lantrua of Triora is executed by the Chinese.
1870: Alfred Adler, Austrian psychoanalyst who introduced the concept of the inferiority complex, is born.
1885: Sinclair Lewis, U.S. novelist and Nobel Prize winner who wrote "Main Street," is born.
1886: George Walker, an English carpenter, strikes gold in the Transvaal in South Africa while building a cottage for a prospector.
1948: Liaoning Province falls into the hands of Chinese communist troops.
1950: Vietnam splits in two, with the Soviet Union recognizing the provisional government of Ho Chi Minh and the United States and Britain endorsing the French-backed government of Emperor Bao Dai.
1955: Republic of China government troops begin to evacuate the Tachen Islands.
1960: Israeli archaeologists unearth a number of Dead Sea Scrolls.
1968: The ROC's Ministry of Education agrees to the establishment of National Central University in Chungli, Taoyuan County.
1971: Switzerland grants women the right to vote.
1973: Former Kaohsiung City Mayor Yang Chin-hu and his wife are arrested for suspected involvement in a bribery case during his term in office.
1974: Grenada gains independence, with Eric Gairy as its first prime minister.
1982: Luis Alberto Monge becomes president of Costa Rica.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the project to make Yushan into a National Park.
1986 Self-styled "President for Life" Jean Claude "Baby-Doc" Duvalier flees Haiti with his loot, bound for exile in France in the face of a national uprising.
1986: Both Ferdinand E. Marcos and his chief election opponent, Corazon Aquino, claim victory in the Philippine presidential election. The National Assembly would later rule that Marcos won the election.
1990: The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party votes for a package of reforms that will end its monopoly on power.
1991: In its most daring daylight raid to date, the Irish Republican Army fires three mortar bombs at British Prime Minister John Major's residence at No. 10 Downing Street.
1992: Representatives of the 12 European Community members formally sign the Treaty of European Union in Maastricht, the Netherlands, also known as the Maastricht Treaty, providing for the creation of the European Union.
1996: A Boeing 757 passenger jetliner on its way from the Dominican Republic to Frankfurt crashes into the Atlantic Ocean, killing all 189 aboard.
1999: Crown Prince Abdullah becomes the king of Jordan following King Hussein's death from cancer.
2001: ROC Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen says that this year's arms sales meeting between Taipei and Washington will take place as scheduled despite reports of pressure from mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen to call off the meeting.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Perfectly honest men I do not expect to see; if I could only meet with scrupulous men I would be satisfied. But in a state of society in which men must pretend to possess what they really do not possess; pretend to have plenty, when they have really nothing; and pretend to be in affluence when they are in actual want -- in such a state of society, it is difficult to be even a scrupulous man."

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND HAS STUDIED USING WTO FOR CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES: ROC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 6 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A visiting Republic of China official said Wednesday that mainland China has recently studied the question of whether to handle exchanges with Taiwan under the World Trade Organization (WTO) framework after the admission of both sides into the world trade regulatory body.

John Deng, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks while speaking on how the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can carry out exchanges under the WTO framework in a speech sponsored by the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a Washington-based think tank.

Overall, Deng said, Beijing authorities do not intend to engage in cross-strait dialogue or consultations under the framework of the WTO, although information collected by the MAC shows that mainland China has studied the issue.

Beijing has yet to make clear its stance on using the mechanism of the WTO to handle cross-strait trade issues, although Mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qi Qichen did mention in a major speech late last month that the WTO admission of both sides of the Taiwan Strait is a new opportunity for the further development of cross-strait trade.

Deng said that both sides realize that the WTO will provide an opportunity for the further development of cross-strait relations, noting that not only will there be closer cross-strait trade and economic relations, but both sides will also be able to use the WTO's spirit of consultation to handle other issues resulting from closer trade relations.

Deng told the audience during his speech that the ROC has stated openly several times that it is willing to make use of all possible channels, including the WTO, to tackle problems resulting from promoting cross-strait trade normalization.

The ROC also realizes that the WTO is an international organization that promotes trade among its members, Deng said, adding that Taiwan hopes both sides can stick to dealing with trade issues and refrain from bringing political issues into the WTO.
The ROC also hopes that both sides handle cross-strait relations based on the spirit of equality, and not confrontation, he said.
With a new round of WTO talks set to begin, Deng said that both sides can cooperate on many issues and that this can serve to promote cross-strait trade if both sides realize this potential.

Deng stressed that the ROC hopes the WTO will be a starting point for the normalization of cross-strait relations, noting that greater cooperation and exchanges between Taiwan and the mainland would certainly help inject new strength into their respective economies and contribute to the prosperity of the entire Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR REGRETS CABINET'S DECISION ON REVISED ALLOCATION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Feb. 6 (CNA) (By Tang Ping-chun and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that the Cabinet's decision to try to overturn a revision in the law governing the allocation of government revenues and expenditures showed that the central government is resorting to the old practice of "centralization of power and financial resources."
Ma, who is currently on a European tour and is in Amsterdam said that he heard with regret of Premier Yu Shyi-kun's decision to ask the legislature to reconsider the revised finance allocation law.
As a matter of fact, President Chen Shui-bian was against the old practice of "centralization of power and financial resources," according to Ma.

An important promoter of the revision in the law, the mayor said that the revision was meant to allow local governments more freedom in managing their finances and to fulfill their basic needs. The Cabinet's attempt to reverse the resolution of the previous legislature gives the impression that it was a decision of political concern rather than professional consideration, he added.

Referring to Premier Yu's comment that the motion to reconsider the revision was "a last resort" that he was forced to take, Ma said, adding that it was understandable that the premier was concerned about the development of relations and interactions between the administration and the legislature.

While the motion may lead to a confrontation between the ruling and opposition camps at the beginning of the new legislature, Ma said, it would definitely not reflect positively on the relations between the Executive Yuan and the Legislative Yuan.

Questioning the intention of the Cabinet's motion, Ma said that the Executive Yuan has other alternatives if it finds the implementation of the revised allocation law too difficult. While the revised law will only be in force starting fiscal year 2003, the Executive Yuan will have time in case it wishes to have further revisions, he added.

Ma said the revision approved by the previous legislature in January will help the local governments greatly with their finances. Kaohsiung City, for instance, will have NT$11.2 billion more revenues from the annual allocations, while counties and provincial cities will each have between NT$1 billion and NT$2 billion additional revenue.
The revised allocation law was initiated by the opposition Kuomintang caucus in the Legislative Yuan at the last session of the previous legislature.

The revised law stipulates that starting fiscal 2003, 30 percent of the income tax revenues, 50 percent of the business tax revenues and 30 percent of the commodity tax revenues levied by local governments should be given to the central government for public financial redistribution. Currently, only 10 percent of the income tax revenues, 40 percent of the business tax revenues, and 10 percent of the commodity tax revenues are given to the central government for redistribution.

While the central government has more financial sources, the revised law requires that the central government to set aside 7 percent of its revenues from these taxes as special funds for emergency projects, and the rest should be allocated to local governments. Taipei City should get 16 percent of the allocations, Kaohsiung City 14 percent, counties and provincial cities together 48 percent, and villages and townships 15 percent.

The Executive Yuan delivered the motion to the Legislative Yuan Wednesday evening, hoping the new legislature will reconsider the redistribution formula in view of a possible financial shortfall of NT$150 billion caused by the revision.
To override the motion for reconsideration, the opposition parties need to mobilize 113 votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET ASSESSING INHERITANCE TAX ISSUES: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday the Cabinet is assessing the feasibility of lowering or scraping the inheritance tax, stressing that this is only a proposal under study, and not yet a government policy.
The premier made the remarks one day after reports said that he had instructed the Ministry of Finance to scrap or lower the inheritance tax to avoid domestic capital flight overseas.

Tsai Huang-liang, legislative party whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said that since the government currently channels 80 percent of inheritance tax revenues to local governments, the scrapping of the inheritance tax will have a big impact on their finances.
Legislator Chiang Chao-yi said that though the scrapping of the inheritance tax will help stem capital flight, it will run against the principle of fairness and of government tax revenue collection.

The Ministry of the Finance officials said that currently 95 percent of those who inherit do not have to pay inheritance tax and that the total current value of inheritance taxes was around NT$25 billion (US$714.28 million) a year.

P.K. Chiang, vice president of the legislature, said that the issue of whether to scrap the inheritance tax can be studied, noting that a lot of countries do not impose inheritance tax and such taxation induces capital flight.

But the former chief of the Council for Economic Planning and Development also said that the adjustment of the inheritance tax will have to take into consideration the reduced tax revenues, adding that even if it is scrapped, it would be done in stages.

Legislator Tsai Cheng-yuan of the opposition Kuomintang said that the current inheritance tax ratio is indeed high, and he has no opposition to lowering it. But he thinks that scrapping it altogether is not feasible.
He said that the taxation of inheritance serves the function of social equality.

Current inheritance tax law stipulates that NT$7 million will be exempt from inheritance taxation. This and NT$4 million for the spouse and NT$1 million for the funeral expenditure means that the average person will have up to NT$12 million exempt from inheritance taxation. If the recipient of the inheritance has to support their parents or children, or inherit agricultural lots, they enjoy extra deductions.

A major national conference in mid-August last year suggested to study the inheritance tax system. The Ministry of Finance said that in line with the suggestions, the ministry will complete its review by September this year, although it will only study the scope and ratio of the inheritance tax, and will not discuss scrapping the inheritance tax.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW BREED OF ROC VOLUNTEERS HELP TAIWAN'S IMAGE OVERSEAS (I)

TEXT.P: God may help those that help themselves, but in Taiwan, many people in their 20s or 30s are finding the rewards of volunteering to work in foreign countries to help boost diplomacy.

The International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) under the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) began to train a new generation of Taiwan volunteers five years ago amid the rising popularity of voluntary services around the world.
ICDF Secretary-General Yang Tzu-pao said in a recent interview that Taiwan has sent agricultural and fishery experts to assist its diplomatic allies in economic development since the early 1960s.

"Many of these specialists are aging and our diplomatic budget has been shrinking in recent years. Against this backdrop, we must use a more cost-efficient way to accomplish what we should do in the diplomatic arena," Yang explained.
In addition, he said, the foreign ministry needs an injection of new blood and new vitality into its work force.

"The ICDF then took the initiative to cultivate a new breed of volunteers," Yang said. "Over the past five years, more than 60 professional volunteers have joined our diplomatic corps to work in selected countries with or without diplomatic ties with Taiwan."

Yang said the trained Taiwan volunteers have been using unofficial methods to strive for expansion of the Republic of China's diplomatic frontiers. "With professional expertise and perseverance, they are helping governments and people of other countries better understand Taiwan."

According to Yang, the new crop of Taiwan volunteers share several common features. "They are very young and mostly come from well-to-do families," Yang said, adding that he admires their determination to suspend their career pursuits and sometimes carefree lives in Taiwan and travel to unfamiliar and even barren lands to help others.
Yang admitted that the ICDF has suffered some setbacks in training and dispatching the new-style volunteers.

"All of the five volunteers sent to our African diplomatic ally of Swaziland in 1997 failed to serve out their working contracts because they failed to adapt to the living environment there," Yang recalled.
The following year, he said, 50 percent of the volunteers assigned to the Central American country of Honduras also had to return home ahead of schedule because of similar reasons.
After more than five years of experimenting and making improvements, Yang said the ICDF is now able to train and send qualified volunteers for overseas assignments without any problems.

Recounting the ICDF's volunteer training programs and procedures, Kao Hsiao-ling, an ICDF division chief in charge of volunteer affairs, said what impresses her most is the passion and undaunted spirit shown by the young volunteers.
"Many local people have taken part in domestic voluntary services, but they tend to work on a short-term basis," Kao said. "In contrast, the ICDF volunteers must work abroad for at least two years."

In her view, Kao said, it's no easy feat for these youthful volunteers. "Besides their heavy workload, they have to tackle many difficult language and cultural barriers and adapt to alien working and living environments."

Given that their presence in foreign countries may enhance the profile of Taiwan abroad, these volunteers are cut from a very special bolt of cloth. Three of them recalled their overseas sagas during their recent vacation trips to Taipei. WHAT A HELL
"What a hell!" was the mantra that Lee Shu-chin often murmured to herself in the first few weeks after her arrival in Myitkyina, the third-largest city in Myanmar.

"It's no ordinary city. It's more like a wasteland in northern Myanmar," Lee said. "Almost none of its roadways have pavement. Pedestrians and vehicles travel along in a dusty haze. Rundown tricycles serve as 'taxi cabs' and its city buses carry not only people but pigs." (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW BREED OF ROC VOLUNTEERS (II)

TEXT.P: Moreover, Lee said, armed troops or militiamen are everywhere as Myitkyina borders China to the north. Worse still, there is no tap water there and power supplies are rationed.

"I had to adapt myself quickly to a life that has electricity supply only between 5 a.m. and 7 a.m., and then again between 6 p.m. and 10 p.m.," Lee recalled. "And simply for taking a bath, I had to draw water from a well and heat it with charcoal fire."

While struggling to get accustomed to her new life, Lee was also taking pains to fulfill her duty as an ICDF volunteer -- teaching English and history at the senior high school section of a Chinese school in Myitkyina.

Lee, who has a master's degree from a U.S. university, said that at the beginning, she had to use a number of hand signs and body language to communicate with her students as most of them were neither fluent in Chinese nor English.

The 30-year-old's determination to serve out her two-year volunteer contract faced a severe test after an accidental fall while preparing hot water for a bath which resulted in burning most of her body. In addition to enduring debilitating pain, Lee was very anxious over the possibility of infection by mosquito bites.

Due to the seriousness of her burns and poor medical services available in Myanmar, Lee had to return to Taiwan for treatment. On the eve of her departure, her doctor asked Lee whether she would return after she recovered. Without pausing, Lee replied: "Of course. I will return as my dream has not yet been realized."

Lee told the bewildered doctor that her decision to give up her NT$40,000-a-month job to work as a volunteer with a living expense of about NT$10,000 was mainly prompted by her desire to enrich her life with some exceptional, meaningful episodes.
"Although I had some doubts about my wisdom after suffering the burns, I had braced up again. I would not shorten my service just because of a single setback," Lee said.
The brave woman really went to Myitkyina again to continue her voluntary service after regaining her health. LIFE IN PANAMA

In comparison, Tsai Pei-chi's tale was completely different. The 21-year-old was assigned to teach Chinese at the largest Chinese school in Panama City, Panama's capital, after finishing the ICDF-organized training courses.

Panama is one of the most advanced countries in Latin America. It has a world renowned canal and many skyscrapers. "Some people say if you come to Panama City at night, you may mistake it for New York's Manhattan," Tsai said jokingly. "I originally expected to work in a backward area to get a taste of hardship and the old-fashioned lifestyle."

Much to her "disappointment," Tsai said she has not found a large gap between lives in Taipei and Panama City. Her challenges mainly lie in her work. She has to teach the school's first graders to speak Mandarin under the Panamanian regulations that require "no homework and no corporal punishment."
"All of my students are born in Panama. Despite their Chinese origin, they are more like Panamanians. It's not easy to have them speak Chinese, and few of them know where Taiwan is," she sighed.

Nevertheless, Tsai said she has learned much after one year of voluntary work in the Central American state. "I feel that I have changed a great deal," Tsai said during her recent vacation trip to Taipei. "I found that I can no longer tolerate the frivolous lifestyle to which I was so accustomed in the past. I want to return to Panama soon to continue my work and 'simple but orderly and exuberant life' there." MODEL VOLUNTEER
In the eyes of the ICDF staff, Huang Hsing-wei deserves the title of a "model volunteer" as she has adapted herself well to both work and everyday life in Nicaragua.

A Spanish major, Huang said her strong curiosity about Spanish culture and Spanish-speaking countries had pushed her to abandon a teaching contract in Taiwan and travel halfway around the globe to work as a volunteer.
Huang has been teaching Chinese at a school known as the most expensive educational institute in Managua, Nicaragua's capital. The age of her students varies from nine to those in their 60s.

In her view, Huang said, Nicaragua is a country where wealth is not equitably distributed. "While the rich and the famous reside in plush houses, beggars are common street scenes even in the capital city." (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW BREED OF ROC VOLUNTEERS (III)

TEXT.P: For security reasons, Huang recalled, she kept a dog shortly after her arrival in Managua. Five months later, the dog died in a traffic accident near where she lived. When she went to a night school to study Spanish literature that day, a frustrated Huang told her classmates the sad story.

The following day, her classmates gave her a lovely dog and told her: "You're not alone here. You have friends all around." Huang said she wept. "The tears were shed for my classmates' kindness and friendship."

Because of geographical distance, Huang said, Nicaraguan people are unfamiliar with Taiwan. "They generally feel that Taiwan is a mysterious country. One student once asked me whether all the people in Taiwan eat mice as a normal part of their diet."

With her superb adaptability, Huang has managed to take time out of her busy working schedule to attend a night school to advance her knowledge about Spanish language and culture. "I like my work and life in Nicaragua and am considering extending my job contract for another year."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WINTER OLYMPIC TEAM ATTENDS FLAG-RAISING CEREMONY
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Feb. 6 (CNA) (By Nail Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China national team participating in the 19th Winter Olympic Games in Salt Lake City, Utah attended a flag-raising ceremony Wednesday, marking the official beginning of its activities in this international sporting event.

The 10-member ROC national team, led by C. W. Tsai, vice chairman of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee, took part in the ceremony held at the athlete's village, along with their counterparts from Andorra, the Georgian Republic and Hungary.
A children's chorus from Salt Lake City and an aboriginal dance troupe performed on the occasion to welcome the athletes from these four countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU INDUSTRIAL PARK 2001 TURNOVER DECLINES 28.7 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The 312 companies located in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park had a combined annual turnover of NT$662.5 billion (US$18.9 billion) in 2001, down 28.7 percent from the previous year, park administrators announced Thursday.

The park's deputy director, Yen Tsung-ming, said that last year marked the first time that the park registered negative growth since it opened in 1980. The high-tech companies posted 43 percent annual growth in combined sales in both 2000 and 1999.

Yen said that the companies are expected to regain momentum with 10 percent to 20 percent annual growth this year, aided by an additional 35 companies capitalized at about NT$28.1 billion (US$802 million) that are applying to set up in the park. Fifty-one companies set up shop in the park in 2001.

IC manufacturers, whose annual turnover in 2001 accounted for 57 percent of the total turnover of the companies in the park, suffered the greatest decline in aggregate sales last year, at 35 percent year-on-year.
Meanwhile, turnover for computer and peripheral manufacturers, whose aggregate sales accounted for 24.3 percent of the park's total, slipped 25 percent from 2000.
Telecommunications and biotechnology companies in the park were the only industries that showed sales growth in 2001, at 11 percent and 18 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA LOOKING FOR SOLUTIONS TO SLUGGISH SALE OF INDUSTRIAL LAND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has recently made a proposal to Premier Yu Shyi-kun that the government set aside NT$30 billion in the next six years to help solve the problem of sluggish sales of industrial land, an economic official said Thursday.

The changes in the industrial structure and the mass exit of traditional industries have had a great impact on Taiwan's industrial zones, and vacant industrial zones which the government and the private sector have spent tremendous amounts of money on are all around the island, according the official.

While high costs to acquire or to rent industrial land remains an important factor that prevents manufacturing industries from moving into industrial zones, the MOEA has suggested that the government set aside NT$5 billion annually from 2003 to 2008 to acquire the land, and then sell or rent it to manufacturers at low prices.
In the past years, the government has invested NT$78.4 billion in developing industrial land, according to statistics released by the Industrial Development Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SPIRIT OF THE DANCE' TO PERFORM IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The troupe "Spirit of The Dance," established by David King, arrived in Taipei Thursday to make a two-week performing tour in Taiwan.

The New Aspect art promotion foundation, which organizes the performance of the troupe in Taiwan, said the tap-dancing group is expected to give Taiwan audiences a different kind of show, mixing Irish dance, tap-dancing, jazz, flamenco and Broadway styles during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday next week.
The troupe will perform at the Taipei International Convention Center Feb.12-17, Kaohsiung Feb. 19-20, Taichung Feb. 21-22, and Tainan Feb. 25-26.

A total of US$388 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$34.996 Thursday morning and was traded between NT$35.980 and NT$35.031.
