DOC.HEADLINE: PINGTUNG UNIV. INKS ACADEMIC EXCHANGE PACT WITH NICARAGUAN UNIV.
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, Feb. 6 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: National Pingtung University of Science and Technology has signed an academic exchange agreement with Zan Morano Agricultural University of Nicaragua.

Liu Hsien-ta, president of the National Pingtung University of Science and Technology, and Francisco Telemaco Talavera, president of the Zan Morano Agricultural University, signed the pact on behalf of their respective universities at a ceremony held at the Republic of China Embassy in Managua recently.

Lai Sheng-fung, counselor at the ROC Embassy in Managua, Lai Po-yung, chairman of the Tropical Agriculture Institute of National Pingtung University of Science and Technology and others witnessed the signing ceremony.
Under the cooperation agreement, the two parties will strengthen academic exchanges in agriculture, livestock, fishery, personnel interchanges and student exchanges.
A four-member delegation from National Pingtung University of Science and Technology led by Lai Hsien-ta, president of the University, arrived in Managua last week.
While in Managua, visiting Pingtung University delegation called on Francisco Telemaco Talavera, president of the Zan Morano University and visited establishments of the university.

Under the introduction of former ROC President Lee Teng-hui, who visited Nicaragua in 1994, and the International Cooperation and Development Fund, National Pingtung University of Science and Technology offered scholarships for students of ROC diplomatic allies to pursue higher learning in universities in Taiwan.

Tomas Javier was one of the Zan Morano Agricultural University's students who benefited from National Pingtung University's scholarship and came to Taiwan to study undergraduate courses at National Pingtung University of Science and Technology.
Javier's excellent academic performance in Taiwan was one of the reasons the two universities decided to further strengthen their cooperation, Telemaco said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL DEFENSE HEAD WISHES HAPPY NEW YEAR TO MILITARY

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Tang Yao-ming wished a "Happy Chinese New Year" Thursday to the Republic of China military and encouraged them to fully play their role as the front-runners in the country's military and security buildup.
Tang made the remarks at a spring festival banquet held by the ministry to celebrate the Chinese Lunar Year of the Horse, which will begin Feb. 12.

The new national defense head, who was sworn in Feb. 1, also praised the capable leadership of his predecessor, Wu Shih-wen, saying that Wu's efforts have helped reform the country's military defense system.

For instance, the military's first-phased "streamlined package" completed in June last year and its neutrality in December's legislative elections won widespread public support, Tang noted, adding that he will continue carrying out the second-phase military reform to build an institutionalized and modern military.

Commenting on a separate development, Tang said his ministry will fully support the government policy should the Executive Yuan decide to abolish the long-standing tax-free privilege of military personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SECURITY OFFICIAL: BEIJING IS TRYING TO DENATIONALIZE ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 6 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's National Security Council Adviser Kau Ying-mao, who has been tapped to be the vice minister of foreign affairs, said in Washington Wednesday that Beijing is going out of its way to "denationalize" the ROC.
Taipei should guard against Beijing's intentions amid a rush of Taiwan businessmen anxious to do business in the mainland, Kau warned.
Kau was speaking at a symposium organized by the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies on Taiwan's economy.

Noting that the more modernized and the deeper democratization mainland China becomes, the easier it will be for the ROC to engage with the People's Republic of China, Kau said Beijing is bucking the worldwide trend of globalization by building up its military strength and deploying missiles across the Taiwan Strait.
There are no signs, however, that Beijing will ever move to the path of democratization, Kau said.

Beijing has never renounced the use of force against Taiwan, and is bending over backward to isolate Taiwan diplomatically with an eye to depriving the island of its statehood, Kau said, adding that this may explain why Beijing has always insisted that there is only one China.

Michael Hsiao, an adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, echoed Kau's views at the symposium, saying that the economic ties between Taiwan and mainland China cannot be normalized because of politics which cannot be separated from cross-strait economic ties.

The absence of trust between Taipei and Beijing gives politics a considerable role to play in cross-strait trade and economic exchanges, and economic decisions cannot be made without taking political factors into account, Hsiao said.
Both Kau and Hsiao arrived in Washington Monday along with a group of Taiwan politicians and academics to attend the U.S. National Prayer Breakfast on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTRUCTION OF HIGHWAYS IS THE BASIC GOVERNMENT WORK: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that the construction of highways is the basic government work, because it is an indicator of government efficiency.
President Chen made the remarks when presiding the inauguration of the Yuehkwanshan Tunnel in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan, which connects two remote villages that are separated by mountains.
The 3,100-meter tunnel is expected to cut travel time between the two points from 40 minutes to about eight minutes. The construction of the tunnel, that began in 1996, cost NT$800 million.

President Chen said the completion of the tunnel not only can save traveling time between the two villages, but also allows people to easily visit nearby tourist spots. This, he said, is expected to stimulate the prosperity of the area.
President Chen also visited a veteran's center in Kaohsiung, chatting with retired soldiers and expressing concern about their daily lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTRUCTION TO BEGIN ON NEIHU LINE OF TAIPEI MRT SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Taipei's Department of Rapid Transit Systems announced Thursday that bidding has begun for the Ta-chi section of the Neihu Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) line, with construction expected to begin in May.

According to the department, long-stalled construction on the entire Neihu line is expected to be completed in mid-2008, with construction on the six-kilometer Ta-chi section to be finished in February 2007.
City officials said that the government will try to minimize the impact that the construction will have on traffic in the area.
The Neihu line will eventually connect with the Mucha line, which went into operation in 1996 after eight years of construction.
Once the Neihu line is completed, the Taipei MRT network will have a total length of 86.8 kilometers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE MILITARY TRAINING `BECOMING REALISTIC': CIA CHIEF

TEXT.P: Taiwan remains the focus of Beijing's military modernization programs and the goal of mainland China's military training exercises are now more focused on gaining "real-world" experience than before, according to George Tenet, director of the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency.
Over the past year, Tenet told a Senate panel Wednesday, Beijing has been "emphasizing rigorous practice and operational capabilities, and improving the military's actual ability to use force."
"This is aimed not only at Taiwan," he said, "but at increasing the risk to the United States itself in any future Taiwan contingency."

In a separate testimony given before the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, the director of the Defense Intelligence Agency also said Beijing's ability to attack Taiwan will have grown significantly by the end of the decade.
"By 2005-2010, China's conventional force modernization will provide an increasingly credible military threat for short-duration attacks against Taiwan," said Vice Adm. Thomas Wilson.
Wilson said, however, that he is less concerned than a year ago about the prospects of a major confrontation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

In a prepared testimony, Tenet said that Beijing's latest policy statement -- inviting select members of Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to visit the mainland -- was "designed as a conciliatory gesture."

Beijing might resume a more confrontational stance, however, if it suspects President Chen Shui-bian of using the DPP's gain in the legislative elections last December to move toward independence, Tenet added.

Both Tenet and Wilson believe that Beijing would like to see stability in its foreign policy front, particularly in ties with the United States, while trying to cope with domestic challenges related to their accession to the World Trade Organization and the imminent leadership succession.

On Beijing's ties with Washington, Tenet said the nature of the bilateral relationship remains the same, despite the new atmosphere of cooperation -- particularly on counter-terrorism -- following the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington last September.
"September 11th changed the context of China's approach to us," he said, "but it did not change the fundamentals."
He said that the mainland is developing an increasingly competitive economy and building a modern military force with the ultimate objective of asserting itself as a great power in East Asia.

Although Beijing joined the coalition against terrorism, he told the senators, it remains skeptical of U.S. intentions in Central and South Asia and views Washington's encouragement of a Japanese role in counter-terrorism as support for Japanese rearmament, which Beijing firmly opposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2000 NOBEL PRIZE WINNER IN CHEMISTRY VISITS HSINCHU

TEXT.P: Alan J. Heeger, winner of the 2000 Nobel Prize in chemistry, visited Hsinchu County Magistrate Y.C. Cheng Thursday.

Heeger told Cheng that it was his first visit to Hsinchu and said that he was impressed by the hi-tech development in the northern Taiwan county. He encouraged Taiwan's academic and industrial sectors to continue their concerted efforts to pursue greater progress.

Heeger has visited the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI), National Chiao Tung University, and National Tsinghua University over the past few days. He also praised Hsinchu's cultural and tourist resources and hailed it as a good place to live.

Cheng told Heeger that in a bid to retain businesses in Hsinchu, the Hsinchu county government has decided to earmark a 400-hectare landlot within the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park to set up a biotech park and will also promote tourist farming to help create opportunities for Hsinchu residents.
Heeger is paying his second visit to Taiwan at the ITRI's invitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RATINGS CORP. UPGRADES CREDIT RATINGS ON TAIWAN CELLULAR CORP.

TEXT.P: Taiwan Ratings Corp. upgraded its long-term and short-term corporate credit ratings on Taiwan Cellular Corp. Thursday from "twA" and "twA-2" to "twAA-" and "twA-1," respectively, a day after the company secured one of five third-generation mobile phone service licenses.
The credit rating agency also removed Taiwan Cellular from CreditWatch, where it was placed with positive implications Dec. 20 last year. The agency added that the company's outlook is stable.

According to the credit rating agency, Taiwan Cellular had approximately 6.4 million clients as of September 2001, comprising 31 percent of the mobile telecommunications market in Taiwan and followed by Chunghwa Telecom Co. Ltd. at 28 percent.

Taiwan Cellular bid NT$10.28 billion (US$293 million) to win a license for 3G telecommunications services put up for auction by the Directorate General of Telecommunications. Chunghwa Telecom was awarded a 3G license for NT$10.18 billion.

On Jan. 31, Taiwan Ratings Corp. affirmed its "twAAA" long-term corporate credit rating and "twA-1" short-term corporate credit rating on Chunghwa Telecom and said the outlook for that company is stable also.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL: WASHINGTON MIGHT HELP TAIPEI'S BIDS FOR INT'L BODIES
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 6 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China official said in Washington Wednesday that U.S. officials have expressed willingness to exchange views with Taipei officials on the country's participation in international organizations.
Kao Ying-mao, an adviser to the ROC National Security Council, described the U.S. officials' remarks as a "concrete step forward" in Taiwan's bid for membership of international bodies.
Kao arrived in Washington Monday along with a group of Taiwan politicians and academics led by Senior Adviser to the President Peng Ming-min to attend a National Prayer Breakfast Thursday.

He told a news conference that Peng and his entourage talked with U.S. State Department officials on Taiwan's attempts to join international bodies and was told that the U.S. government would like to exchange views in depth with the Taipei authorities on the issue, and might give Taipei a leg-up in its efforts.
Kao, who has been named vice minister of foreign affairs, said the proposed discussions would boost Taiwan's campaign to join the World Health Organization.
Peng also referred to Taiwan's attempts to join the Montreal-headquartered International Civil Aviation Organization during his talks with U.S. officials, Kao added.
The U.S. House of Representatives has already passed a bill requiring the administration to come up with a plan to help Taiwan join the WHO as an observer in May.
The bill has been referred to the Senate for debate.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT WTO ENTRY TO REDUCE POLITICAL TENSION: US OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington D.C. Feb. 6 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The World Trade Organization (WTO) is not supposed to be a venue for political agendas, but with entry by both sides of the Taiwan Strait, tensions between Taiwan and mainland China should ease, a senior U.S. trade official said in Washington Wednesday.

William H. Lash III, U.S. Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Market Access and Compliance, said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will gradually find economic cooperation through their repeated contacts at WTO meetings.
Lash, who visited Taipei last Jan. 22, said that the United States attached importance to Taiwan's WTO admission and said that the United States will continue to support Taiwan as a good WTO member.
Lash made the remarks while delivering a speech at a seminar on Taiwan's economic development outlook sponsored by the Center for Strategic & International Studies (CSIS), a U.S. think tank.

Lash said that although the WTO is not a place to discuss political affairs, Taiwan and mainland Chinese WTO entry will reduce political tensions between the two sides because they will have to deal with each other and further improve their relations through repeated contacts at WTO meetings.
Lash said that his viewpoint was basically as same as the viewpoint stated by U.S. Trade Representative Robert B. Zoellick.

Zoellick said on Jan. 31 that substantial economic relations between Taiwan and mainland China already existed before the two sides became members of the WTO. Both Taiwan and mainland China can regard WTO as a channel of communications and negotiations to mutually review their respective regulations and laws to speed up talks and negotiations.
WTO participation is just a beginning, Lash pointed out, adding that difficulties lay ahead.

Touching on intellectual property rights protection, Lash urged Taiwan and mainland China to be vigilant for the sake of "your own interests." "You will eventually benefit from the implement of intellectual property rights protection," Lash said.
Taiwan is experienced in international trade, Lash said, adding that Taiwan's admission into WTO has set a good example.
Taiwan has the ability to make contributions to the WTO, Lash added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AGRICULTURAL OFFICIALS WARN CHICKEN FARMERS OF AVIAN FLU

TEXT.P: Taiwan agricultural officials warned Thursday that although there have been no reports of avian flu outbreaks on the island, local chicken farms should heighten their alert, adopt preventive measures and report any suspicious cases immediately.

The Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Council of Agriculture recommended that travelers should refrain from visiting chicken farms in Hong Kong or mainland China in order not to risk the safety of Taiwan's poultry industry.

The bureau urged all local chicken farmers to take extra sterilization measures when entering or leaving their farms and to make sure their chickens are not given the opportunity to mingle with waterfowl, which might carry the virus.
About 186,000 chickens were killed in Hong Kong this week in an attempt to contain the spread of avian flu.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO CRACK DOWN ON ILLEGAL RADIO STATIONS

TEXT.P: The government will begin another massive crackdown on illegal radio stations after the Lunar New Year holiday and anticipates eradicating all illegal stations by the end of the year, Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Tui said Thursday.

Tsai said that the Cabinet has formally established a special task force to handle the crackdown on the 130-some illegal stations that remain unlicensed, disrupting aviation communications and "affecting public safety."

According to the Directorate General of Telecommunications, 663 pieces of broadcast equipment were seized over the past five years, with over NT$10 million (US$285,000) in fines levied and 184 people convicted, with the longest sentence being three years and five months in prison.

Although the government has released 10 batches of frequencies since 1993, allowing illegal stations to apply for broadcast licenses, only 151 broadcasters have taken advantage of the government's liberalizing moves.
Official figures indicate that most of the illegal stations provide programming content such as astrology, medicine sales and matchmaking.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES GREATER MILITARY STRENGTH TO SAFEGUARD TAIWAN PEOPLE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun urged the Republic of China military Thursday to strengthen their combativeness to protect the people of Taiwan and help safeguard regional and world peace, according to a press release from the Ministry of National Defense (MND).

The statement said that the premier made the remarks after an inspection visit to the MND. Yu and Vice Premier Lin Hsin-yi were briefed by Minister of National Defense Tang Yao-ming and Chief of the General Staff Gen. Lee Chieh, the statement added.

According to the press release, Yu encouraged the ROC troops to upgrade their combat readiness and capabilities to protect the Taiwan people and the ROC territories. He also called on the military to make a greater contribution to peace in the Asia-Pacific region and the rest of the world.

The premier also expressed support for widespread reform and advocated new thinking for the military to tackle the huge threats lying ahead, especially in the wake of recent remarks by mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen regarding Beijing's stance toward Taiwan and the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks against the United States.

As the second-phase military reform will be launched March 1, Yu instructed the MND to follow six principles centering on stability, security, coordination, coherence and continuity as guidelines to achieve its goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REGISTERS RECORD-HIGH TRADE SURPLUS IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign trade totaled US$17.05 billion in January, leaving a trade surplus of US$2.33 billion, a record monthly high, according to statistics released Thursday by the Ministry of Finance.
Taiwan's exports in January totaled US$9.69 billion, while imports reached US$7.36 billion.
Although the figures represented drops of 1.4 percent and 20.9 percent, respectively, on a year-on-year basis, Taiwan registered the 23rd consecutive monthly trade surplus.
MOF officials said the decline of exports in January narrowed to a single digit from the double-digit falls registered since April of last year.
The officials added that although signs of prosperity in Taiwan's foreign trade remain unclear, exports are expected to grow in May or June, while growth in imports will lag slightly.
The officials attributed the decline of 20.9 percent in imports in January to the abundant stocks held by importers last year because of the recession.

Referring to this year's economic prospects, the officials cited an IMF report on the world economy issued last December, saying that many countries are adopting more relaxed monetary policies, international oil prices are falling and the economic structures of many countries are improving. All these are conducive to the recovery of the world economy, the officials added.

The U.S. economy is also emerging from recession, although slowly, while Japanese economic prospects are less optimistic because of a lack of consumer confidence, low stock prices, bad financial systems and slow structural reform, according to the officials.

Turning to Taiwan, the officials maintained that the island's economy is expected to shake off the recession this year, thanks to the government's implementation of public construction projects, promotion of financial and economic reforms and improvement of the investment environment, in addition to the increased trade exchanges brought about by the entry of both sides of the Taiwan Strait to the World Trade Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVERAGE DOMESTIC OVERNIGHT INTERBANK RATE FALLS TO 2.283 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taipei's average domestic overnight interbank rate fell 0.017 percent to 2.283 percent Thursday, the Central Bank of China (CBC) said.
The drop was due mainly to the abundant capital on the market, the CBC added.

The total value of the CBC's time deposit certificates that expired Thursday reached NT$58 billion (US$1.65 billion), while the bank also issued a batch of new time deposit certificates worth a total of NT$49 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG TO STAY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A senior official of the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) said Thursday that FPG will keep not only its roots but also its entire enterprises in Taiwan.

FPG General Manager Wang Yung-tsai admitted that FPG has invested in the petrochemical industry in mainland China along with the largest petrochemical industry in the United States, he said that FPG's investment represents only a small share of the total compared with the U.S. investment.

Asked to comment on Economics Minister Christine Tsung's remarks that FPG cannot blame the government for its business setbacks, Wang stressed that the group should blame only itself for its bad performance. However, he added that the government should take responsibility for failing to lead the growth of Taiwan's enterprises.
He reiterated that FPG will adhere to government policy but stressed that the government should help the private sector grow.

Wang said that private sector investment in the mainland is a trend because domestic enterprises are not competing with mainland enterprises but with global enterprises. Taiwan's competitiveness will only increase if local enterprises can take advantage of the mainland's cheap labor, he added.

Commenting on Tsung's remark that national interests are more important than the interests of private enterprises, Wang said that he agrees with the viewpoint but attaches importance nonetheless to the mainland market.
Wang also expressed doubt over Tsung's prediction that Taiwan's economy will take off within two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE TO VOTE ON GOVERNMENT ALLOCATION MOTION

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan agreed Thursday to vote on an Executive Yuan motion to reconsider the revised Law Governing the Allocation of Government Revenues and Expenditures on Feb. 19.

The agreement, worked out after negotiations among the four main political parties and independent lawmakers, will give Premier Yu Shyi-kun a chance to explain the reasons for the motion and field questions from legislators, after which a vote will be taken.
Although the government has said the motion for reconsideration is more a fiscal than a political issue, it is expected nevertheless to cause a showdown between the ruling and opposition parties.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party vowed to support the motion for reconsideration. However, DPP Legislative Whip Tsai Huang-lang said the party will not discipline party lawmakers who do not follow the party line in the vote, given that the issue is not political.

Since the revised law will hurt rather than benefit local governments, Tsai said he believes any "sensitive" lawmakers will vote for the motion to annul the revision in the interests of their own constituencies, even without urging from the party.

Meanwhile, the main opposition Kuomintang, which initiated the changes and railroaded them through the legislature on the last day of the last session, vowed to override the motion and threatened to discipline any party lawmakers who flout the party's policy.
KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng gave a pep talk to party lawmakers Thursday day in which he claimed that the motion for reconsideration is "both unwise and unnecessary."

He rebutted Premier Yu's claim that the revised law, which obliges the central government to give more of its revenues to the country's local governments, is "impractical" and said it is not an emergency requiring a motion of reconsideration.

Lin added that the motion, coming as it does at the beginning of the new legislature and new administration, will only spark confrontation between the two branches of the government, which is not in the best interest of the nation.

He accused Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics chief Lin Chuan, who spearheaded the government's campaign to scuttle the revised law, of hypocrisy, saying that Lin had spoken out for more revenue to be allocated to local governments in 1995-1998 when he served as financial chief of Taipei city government, but has reversed his position since serving in the central government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 8, or the 27th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Spanish explorer Capt. Francisco Hernandez de Cordoba sets sail from Cuba and later "discovers" Mexico.
1587: Mary, Queen of Scots, who had been found guilty of plotting to assassinate England's Queen Elizabeth I, is beheaded.
1725: Peter the Great of Russia dies. He would be succeeded by his wife Catherine.
1902: The eruption of a volcano on the French island of Martinique in the Lesser Antilles kills more than 26,000 people.
1904: Japanese warships launch a surprise night attack against Lushun (Port Arthur) in northern China, destroying three Russian warships and causing the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War.
1906: A strong typhoon hits Tahiti in the South Pacific, killing about 10,000 people.
1910: The Boy Scouts of America organization, a cousin to the movement founded by Sir Robert Baden-Powell in Britain two years earlier, is inaugurated.
1924: The gas chamber as a method of execution is used for the first time in Carson City, Nevada, when Gee Jon, a Chinese gang member, is put to death.
1926: American archaeologists discover relics from the Mayan civilization in the jungles of Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula near the Caribbean coast.
1931: More than 3,000 miners are killed in an accident at the Fushun mine run by a Japanese company of the Southern Manchuria Railway in Liaoning Province, northeastern China.
1946: A provisional people's council is set up in Soviet-occupied North Korea, with Kim Il Sung serving as chairman.
1949: The National Central Library moves to Taiwan from the Chinese mainland.
1954: More than 14,000 Communist Chinese prisoners of war in Korea who refuse to return to the Chinese mainland begin to undergo job training in Tahu, Siahu, and Yangmei in Taiwan.
1955: Nikolai Bulganin becomes premier of the Soviet Union, replacing Georgi Malenkov.
1963: President Abdel-Karim Kassem of Iraq is overthrown and killed in a military coup.
1964: Princess Irene of Holland renounces her right to the throne in order to marry Spanish Prince Carlos Hugo of Bourbon-Parma.
1965: British Health Minister Kenneth Robinson announces that cigarette ads will be banned from television.
1966: The Republic of Vietnam and the United States issue the Declaration of Honolulu, outlining their aims for Vietnam.
1974: Chinese investors in Taiwan and Gulf Oil Corporation officials agree on the establishment of a joint company to produce low-density polyethylene.
1976: Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan decorates Dr. Harry Bodan Shields, visiting vice minister of foreign affairs of the Republic of Nicaragua, with the Grand Cordon of the Order of Brilliant Star.
1980: Louis Vorster, the new South African ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1984: ROC athletes re-enter the Olympic Games, taking part in the 1984 Winter Olympic Games in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia under the name "Chinese Taipei."
1995: The U.S. liaison office in Vietnam begins business operations, marking the first step in the return to normal relations between the two countries.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui says the ROC and the Vatican should join hands to strive for freedom and democracy for the enslaved people in mainland China and other parts of the world.
2001: Chen Li-fu, a member of the presidium of the opposition Kuomintang Central Advisory Committee, passes away at the age of 103.
2001: Two reporters from Xinhua News Agency arrive in Taipei, marking a new milestone for news exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are, perhaps, men who propound theories they themselves do not understand. That is a thing I never do. I read and learn everything and, choosing that which is excellent, I adopt it; I see everything and take note of what I see: that is, perhaps, next to having a great understanding."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Friday are as follows:
The China Times:
CEPD agrees in principle with the building of Taipei's first dome stadium at former tobacco company located in Sungshan.
The United Daily News:
Former Hsinchu Mayor Tsai Jen-chien was charged for violating privacy laws and was sought a one-year jail term if found guilty by the court.
The Liberty Times:
Both Taiwan's parliament and media were said by Premier Yu Shyi-kun as being used by Chinese communists.
The Taiwan Daily:
U.S. intelligence official Thomas Wilson says he is "less concerned than a year ago about the prospects of a major confrontation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The Central Daily News:
Eleven charged in sex video scandal; former Hsinchu Mayor Tsai Jen-chien, whom prosecutors sought a one-year jail term for involvement in the secret Chu recording while Tsai and Chu's common friend, Kuo Yu-ling, were sought a four-year jail term for being the one who was responsible for the installation of hidden pin-hole cameras.
The China Post:
Eleven charged in Chu Mei-feng sex video scandal.
The Taiwan News:
Former Hsinchu mayor indicted for involvement in Chu Mei-feng sex video.
The Taipei Times:
CIA director warns U.S. of China threat.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN ARRIVES IN PARIS FOR PRIVATE VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Feb. 7 (CNA) (By M.J. Tzou and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, and members of his family arrived in Paris Thursday for a three-day private visit.

Lien was met at the airport by Hsieh Hsin-ping, the Republic of China's representative to France, but Lien's support group "Lien's Friends" and other KMT officials in France were not on hand for his arrival as they were not aware beforehand of his visit.
This trip represents the third time that Lien has come to France for a private visit in the past three years. As with his past visits to France, he has during this trip maintained a low-profile.

Members of Lien's accompanying entourage said the KMT chairman was in France for private activities and had no plans for any official visits, adding that Lien had declined offers by his French friends to arrange public appearances.
Lien is scheduled to travel to Italy Saturday to continue his private European trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOLSTERING TIES WITH JAPAN ONE OF MOFA'S TOP PRIORITIES: P.M.

TEXT.P: One of the top priorities of the Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) in its diplomatic work in the new year will be bolstering diplomatic ties with Japan, Premier Yu Shyi-kun was quoted as saying Friday.

The ROC will continue to work to strengthen its diplomatic relations with its allies and other friendly countries in the coming new year, with particular emphasis on its relations with Japan, Foreign Affairs Minister Eugene Chien quoted Yu as saying.

Premier Yu, who presided over the Presidential Office's task force on work toward Japan when he was serving as the presidential secretary-general, instructed the MOFA to try harder in the new year to improve bilateral relations between the ROC and Japan as there are still policies being imposed by the Japanese government involving unfair and unequal treatment for ROC citizens, according to Chien.

After Premier Yu's first official visit to the MOFA since he assumed the post Feb. 1, Chien relayed Yu's directives as exhorting the MOFA to try its utmost to raise bilateral ROC-Japan relations to an equal and reciprocal level.
Yu also instructed that Minister-without-Portfolio Chiou I-jen will be the top director of Taiwan's diplomatic work toward Japan from now on, according to Chien.
Other diplomatic priorities will include continuing to work for Taiwan's entry into the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other international organizations, Chien quoted Yu as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY APPROVE OF NEW N.Y. MAYOR'S PERFORMANCE: POLL

TEXT.P: Although New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg has only been on the job for a little more than a month, some 65 percent of the city's voters approve of his performance, according to the results of a poll released Wednesday.
According to the poll conducted by Quinnipiac University, only 6 percent of those surveyed gave Bloomberg a negative rating on his performance, while 29 percent said they are undecided.
Meanwhile, 76 percent of the respondents said they are optimistic about the next four years with Bloomberg in office.

Bloomberg's performance approval rating was slightly better than the 58 percent his predecessor Rudolph Giuliani received in a poll by the university when he first took office in 1994, but it was somewhat lower than the previous mayor's rating of 79 percent received in a similar poll last October prior to his leaving office.
A total of 1,008 registered New York City voters were interviewed between Jan. 29-Feb. 4 in the most recent survey by the university. The poll's margin of error is said to be 3.1 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC URGED TO FURTHER RELAX POLICIES TOWARD TOURISTS FROM OVERSEAS

TEXT.P: All 15 members of the first group of mainland Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan made a common statement near the end of their four-day visit, saying they would like to visit Taiwan again but only after the island relaxes its policies toward mainland visitors.

The group of mainland Chinese tourists residing in Japan, led by Jin Huei, president of a travel agency in Osaka, was the first group of mainlanders to visit Taiwan since the Republic of China government at the beginning of this year opened Taiwan to tour-group visits by mainland Chinese citizens.

"Everything was good while we were touring Taiwan, except that there were too many rules," said Jin, reflecting the opinions of his tour companions who complained that the rule requiring the group members to return to their hotel rooms no later than 11 p.m. every night was "ridiculous."

Commenting on the curfew -- which Jin reckoned is a measure that was adopted by the ROC government to prevent the "mainlanders" from overstaying their visas or absconding -- Jin said he is 100 percent sure that none of the group members, all of whom are senior citizens enjoying a certain level of social and economic status in Japan, would abscond during their short stay in Taiwan.
Meanwhile, all the tour group members, who are scheduled to depart Taiwan Friday for home, expressed regret for only being able to visit for four days, saying it is too short a period of time.

Carrying packages of Taiwan's famous Oolong tea and powdered pork with them as souvenirs to take back to Japan, the tourists said the next time they visit they will definitely not miss visiting such scenic spots as Mt. Ali and Sun Moon Lake in southern and central Taiwan.
For those in the group who were born in Taiwan -- more than 50 years ago -- being unable to travel to southern Taiwan to visit their birthplaces was particularly regrettable, according to Jin.

Over the past three days, the mainland Chinese tourists have visited famous tourist attractions in the greater Taipei area, including the National Palace Museum, Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall, Lungshan Temple and the Martyrs' Shrine.

They have also toured the Wulai hot-spring resort area, sampled the well-known Taiwanese snack foods in the Shihlin night market and enjoyed banquet-like feasts at various restaurants ranging from Shanghai-style to Peking-style.

In addition to eating out and sightseeing, the tourists -- most of whom are in their 60s and 70s and leaders of major mainland Chinese organizations in Tokyo, Osaka and Kobe -- stayed at the five-star Taipei Westin Hotel. The four-day three-night package cost each of them NT$20,000.
"Taiwan is so close to Kobe, but I have waited for nearly 50 years to enter the island," said Lin Tung-chun, one of the tour members, upon arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Tuesday.

As part of its efforts to boost exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, the ROC government enacted a policy Jan. 1 allowing mainland Chinese citizens with permanent resident status in a foreign country as well as mainland students studying abroad to make pleasure trips to the island.
Meanwhile, the Taipei Association of Travel Agents said the second mainland tour group will probably arrive after the Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 12 this year.
Tourist sources said scores of mainland Chinese residents in San Francisco have expressed interest in joining a Taiwan-mainland China tour package organized by a travel agency there.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO HOST FIRST BIOBUSINESS CONFERENCE IN ASIA-PACIFIC REGION

TEXT.P: BIOBUSINESS Asia 2002, the first bio-business conference in the Asia-Pacific region, will be held Feb. 28-March 1 at the Far Eastern Plaza Hotel in Taipei.
More than 300 experts in the biomedical field as well as representatives from research institutions and venture capital companies will attend the two-day event.

Organized by the Industrial Technology Research Institute's (ITRI) Biomedical Engineering Center (BMEC), the conference is being co-sponsored by Bayer Taiwan Co., Becton, Dickinson and Company, Celera Genomics Group, China Development Industrial Bank, the Industrial Bank of Taiwan, Integrated Taxonomic Information Systems, MDS Capital, Merrill Lynch, MPM Asset Management LLC, and Pricewaterhouse Coopers LLP.

Experts attending the conference will introduce the global trends in biotechnology as well as successful business models and investment opportunities, according to conference chairman Dr. Johnsee Lee, BMEC general director.

Lee said that the conference will provide biotechnology firms in Asia an opportunity to introduce their research and development achievements to the world. More than 20 manufacturers in the United States, Israel, India, Australia, South Korea, Japan, Singapore and Taiwan are attending the conference to look for partnership opportunities.

On Feb. 27, the Asia-Pacific Economic Forum's biotechnology conference, which will focus more on policy, regulations and infrastructure of biotechnology in the Asia-Pacific region, will be held at the same venue. Representatives from seven countries in the region will attend the meeting.

While biotechnology is deemed one of the research areas with the most potential in the 21st century, the Ministry of Economic Affairs in recent years has coordinated the efforts of the industry as well as academic institutions to upgrade Taiwan's biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries.
As of the end of last year, there were 150 biotechnology firms in Taiwan and the number of contract research organizations has continued to grow.

With the assistance of the government and business community, the ITRI in July 1999 set up the BMEC. The center has coordinated the institute's expertise in electronics as well as mechanical and material technologies to conduct multidiscipline biomedical research projects, such as those for biochips, biomaterials and medical devices.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS TO MAKE INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITY AWARE OF ROC STANCE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 7 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A senior advisor to the Republic of China's Presidential Office said Thursday in Washington D.C. that faced with the constant threat from mainland China, Taiwan needs high-tech weapons for defense and also needs to make the international community aware that Taiwan's only goal is for peace and stability.

Peng Ming-min, who headed a ROC delegation of politicians and academics at the U.S. National Prayer Breakfast Thursday, made the remarks when he addressed a dinner party given in the delegation's honor by Chen Chien-jen, the ROC representative to the United States.

Speaking to around 240 overseas and academic leaders in the greater Washington area, he said that Taiwan's political changeover in 2000 has shown that Taiwan is moving toward mature democratic development.

He said that Taiwan has turned from an authoritarian regime to a democratic society over the past 15 years, and that the people of Taiwan now enjoy full freedom of speech and assembly. Although the democratic system is not yet perfected and although there is some chaos in the wake of the political changeover, Peng claimed that this is because neither the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which swept the Kuomintang (KMT) from its five-decade grip on power, nor the KMT have played by the rules.
Peng said that he is convinced that through repeated trial and error and reforms, Taiwan's democratic system will mature.
He said that if there is another political changeover within a few years, the adjustment difficulties will be greatly lessened.
Michael Hsiao, an adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, also said that the concept of democracy still needs to be entrenched in the general public in Taiwan.

Kau Ying-mao, an adviser to the ROC National Security Council, who has been named vice foreign minister, noted that he met with U.S. officials, parliamentarians, scholars and media during his visit and that they understand that Taiwan's request for the basic values of democracy, peace and stability is the same as that of the United States and in line with the goals and interests of U.S. policy in the Western Pacific.
Legislator Parris Chang and Taiwan Institute of Economic Research Director Wu Rong-yi, said that Taiwan's economic and political prospect are not as grim as media reports have claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OFFICIAL URGES MORE OPEN-MINDEDNESS FROM BEIJING

TEXT.P: An official in charge of mainland China policy urged Beijing to be open-minded in welcoming members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in "their appropriate capacities."

Speaking in an interview with a local radio station, Vice Chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chen Ming-tung said that compared with the verbal attacks and military intimidation in 1996 when Taiwan held its first popular presidential election, and the verbal attacks in the run-up to the 2000 presidential election, mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen's remarks last month on welcoming visits by DPP members seems more relaxed than before.
But he also said that although there appears to have been a modest change in Beijing's attitude, the basic precept of "one country, two systems" has not changed.
Chen said that as a democratic country, the people of the Republic of China enjoys the freedom of expression, that the mainland should be open-minded toward Taiwan.

He noted that the atmosphere between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is subdued and that there is currently no saber-rattling, but he added that the mainland should face the reality of Taiwan's existence.
He also said that since the two sides have joined the World Trade Organization, they should take that as an opportunity to forge a channel for mutual exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MAJOR PORK PRODUCER SAYS TAISUGAR PORK SAFE

TEXT.P: Taiwan Sugar Corp. (Taisugar), the largest pork producer in Taiwan, reassured pork consumers islandwide Friday that all the company's swine are chemically tested and verified safe before being sold to private butcher shops.

Responding to a recent Chang Gung Memorial Hospital report that blames the abuse of antibiotics used on meat-producing swine as being partly to blame for the drug resistance of certain deadly bacteria in pigs, Taisugar Vice President Yeh Hung-chan claimed that Taisugar-contracted pig farms have never used antibiotics, including ciprofloxacin, or growth-boosting chemicals.

Taisugar pig farms do use certain germ-killing chemicals to assure the swine's growth, he went on, but stressed that all doses are stopped 130 days before the animals are sold or after the pigs have reached a weight of 50 kilograms -- a policy adopted to ensure that no chemical residue is left in the pigs before they go to the butchers.
The Chang Gung Memorial Hospital report has caused widespread concern among consumers and butcher shops are afraid that pork sales over Chinese New Year will be badly affected.

In the report, Dr. Chiu Cheng-hsun said that because of excessive use of antibiotics, the local strain of salmonella enterica serotype choleraesuis has become immune to nearly all of the most effective bacteria-fighting drugs, such as ciprofloxacin.
Chiu stated that since the drug-resistant bacteria can be passed on to humans through the ingestion of infected meat, many Taiwan residents could die if they become infected by eating such meat.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WISHES PUBLIC `HAPPY LUNAR NEW YEAR' VIA E-CARD

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu have posted electronic greeting cards on the Presidential Office Web site, wishing the public a happy Lunar New Year.

The e-card from the president and his wife shows a Chinese painting of stallions and mares greeting the coming of spring amidst fireworks, rendered in Flash animation. The First Couple wished for seasonable weather for crop raising, prosperity for the country and peace for the people.
Meanwhile, the vice president's e-card shows a traditional god of wealth wishing for a prosperous nation and united families.
The first day of the Lunar New Year falls on Feb. 12 this year. It will be the Year of the Horse under the Chinese zodiac.
The president's electronic greeting card can be viewed at www.president.gov.tw/card/year1.html, while the vice president's can be viewed at www.president.gov.tw/card/year2.html.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2002 TAIPEI BADMINTON OPEN TO BE HELD IN JULY

TEXT.P: The 2002 Taipei Badminton Open will be held July 16-21 in Yunlin County, central Taiwan, the Chinese Taipei Badminton Association announced Friday.

The association had originally planned to organize the tournament in June, but decided to push the date back to avoid the competition coinciding with that of the football world cup scheduled to be held that month in Korea and Japan.
The Taipei Badminton Open is usually held in Taipei, but this year, it will take place at the Toulio Stadium in Yunlin County, thanks to strong lobbying by the badminton commission of Yunlin County.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S LABORERS HAD TEMPESTUOUS YEAR IN 2001: REPORT

TEXT.P: Laborers in Taiwan had a tempestuous year in 2001, with rising unemployment and controversy over revisions to the Labor Standards Law, according to an analysis based on news reports concerning laborers in the past year.
The National Policy Foundation (NPF), an opposition Kuomintang think tank, released the analysis Friday.
The amendment of the Labor Standards Law regarding maximum working hours and its repercussions was chosen as the news event with the greatest social impact.

The amendment cut the maximum working hours per employee from 48 hours per week to 84 hours every two weeks, effective Jan. 1, 2001. As the amendment impacted business and industry, especially in the face of the recession, industrial and trade associations called on the government to adopt supplementary measures to reduce the adverse impact.

Other items that drew the focus of public attention included flexible new regulations regarding workers' retirement funds and pension payments, the jobless population exceeding 500,000, Council of Labor Affairs restrictions on recruitment of foreign workers, heavy losses of the labor insurance and workers' pension funds, the difference between labor policies and the expectations of the laborers, and the proposal of the Council of Economic Planning and Development to cancel the minimum wage level regulation, according to the analysis.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VISITS POLICE, FIREFIGHTERS IN TAIPEI COUNTY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian inspected police and firefighters stationed in the Taipei County township of Pali Friday and wished them a happy Chinese New Year.

Chen was accompanied by Wang Chien-wang, director-general of the National Police Administration, Chao Kang, director-general of the National Fire Administration, and Taipei County Magistrate Su Chen-chang.

During the inspection, Chen heard a joint briefing from Wu Chia-lin, director of the Luchow police station and Lu Jung-shih, commander of the No. 3 Squad of the Taipei County Fire Bureau on the operation of "Chun-an," an operation launched by security forces around the island to ensure a peaceful and secure lunar new year holiday.
After the briefing, Chen thanked the police and firefighters around the nation for their hard work and handed out red envelopes containing a total of NT$50,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO STRIVE FOR GLOBAL COMPETITIVENESS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday that the newly inaugurated Cabinet will make every effort to upgrade the nation in terms of global competitiveness.
Yu stressed that his Cabinet will "absolutely not" fight just for election but for the people.
He made the remarks while inspecting the operations of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
Yu praised MOFA for its good performance in helping high-ranking Republic of China officials to visit diplomatic allies in the past two years.
He also explained why his Cabinet has been dubbed the "combat Cabinet," saying that the word "combat" is supposed to mean "meeting challenges."
Yu was accompanied by Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan and Minister without Portfolio Chou I-jen during the MOFA visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: `GOOD NEWS' ON WAFER FABS IN MAINLAND CHINA SOON: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Christine Tsung said Friday that there will be "good news" after the Lunar New Year regarding when the government will allow Taiwan companies to set up eight-inch wafer fabrication plants in mainland China.
Tsung made the remark before meeting with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Chairman Morris Chang to ask for his opinions on the matter.
Chang said after the nearly one-hour meeting that he remains optimistic about the prospects of being allowed to invest in mainland China to set up wafer fabs.

Chang added that he is also optimistic about Taiwan's future economic outlook, despite recent comments from other local tycoons that the domestic economic outlook will remain poor if cross-Taiwan Strait issues cannot be resolved.
Evergreen Chairman Chang Yung-fa and Formosa Plastics Group Chairman Wang Yung-ching have both expressed their belief that Taiwan's economy will depend on mainland China in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI DOME COULD BE COMPLETED IN 3 YEARS: CITY OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: If everything goes well, the construction of a domed stadium could begin this year at the earliest and be completed in three years after the government approved the plan under conditions the previous day, a Taiepi City government spokesman said Friday.

Wu Yu-sheng, director of the Information Department of the city government made the remarks when commenting on the approval of the long-stalled project by the Council for Economic Planning and Development under four conditions.
Wu said that Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou has expressed his appreciation for the government's "professional" review of the matter.
Mayor Ma was elated to learn that the government has approved the construction of a domed stadium on the site of the Sungshan tobacco factory, Wu added.
The project to construct a 45,000-seat stadium was approved in a coordination meeting a day earlier by the CEPD, under four conditions.

The CEPD instructed the Taipei city government to take into account the fact that the Sungshan tobacco factory is designated as a historic site, and that the stadium project must consider the impact on the historic value of the site.
As the site is located close to the Sungshan domestic airport, the CEPD also said that a height limitation must be imposed for the sake of aviation safety.
The city government must also communicate with area residents, some of whom are opposed to the construction plan, the CEPD said.

The central government also agreed that the city government can appropriate the land needed for the project, but must pay, either with cash or comparable land elsewhere. The land occupied by the tobacco factory is valued at about NT$29.2 billion (US$831.9 million) according to current prices.
Wu said that the city government believes the first three conditions can be met, while the most difficult part will be the land acquisition.
He said the city government appreciates the central government's understanding of the city government's financial straits, evidenced by its willingness to accept a "land for land" deal instead.

But he added that the city government in fact does not have a single landlot equivalent in value to that of the Sungshan site and will have to collect various scattered lots for the exchange. However, this would then affect future construction plans, so it is not certain if will be acceptable to the central government.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar maintained its upward trend for the third day against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange market Friday, rising NT$0.051 to close at NT$35.080.
A total of US$463 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$35.035, and was traded between NT$35.093 and NT$35.020.

DOC.HEADLINE: 23 WORKS TO VIE FOR TAIPEI FILM FESTIVAL AWARDS

TEXT.P: A total of 23 film and animation works have been nominated for the NT$1 million top award in the Fourth Taipei Film Festival, the Cultural Affairs Bureau of the Taipei city government said Friday.
According to the bureau, which is organizing the film festival, the list of winners will be announced March 16 and an award ceremony will be held that same day.
The 23 nominees will compete in categories divided into theatrical, animation, documentary, experimental and amateur works.
The organizer noted that 83 works are being shown in this year's festival and said the quality of this year's entries is higher than in previous festivals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISUGAR PLANNING TO SET UP GREENHOUSES IN SOUTHERN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: State-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. is planning to cooperate with agricultural establishments in mainland China to set up orchid houses in the southern mainland, Taisugar President Cheng Hung-tsai said Friday.
Cheng had just returned from a week-long tour of the mainland, where he visited agricultural establishments in coastal Guangdong, Fujian, Zhejiang and Jiangsu provinces.

Because the mainland has become an important market for phalaenopsis plants from Taisugar's Orchid Propagation Center, the corporation is interested in investing in orchid culture and plantation there, he said.

Cheng said that he found the weather in Guangzhou and Hweizhou, Guangdong Province, most suitable for the cultivation of small orchids, while greenhouse facilities in the mainland costs around 30 percent less than in Taiwan.

The Orchid Propagation Center has become model of success for government enterprises trying to diversify. Using the site of an old sugar mill in Tainan, southern Taiwan, the center, with 46,000 square meters of computer-controlled greenhouses, supplies phalaenopsis, as well as dendrobium and oncidium.
The phalaenopsis plants are mainly exported to the United States, Japan and France, although in the past two years, they have become popular gift items in the mainland, according to Cheng.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNI AIRLINES MAKE PROFIT ON TAIWAN-KINMEN ROUTE

TEXT.P: Despite the fact that the domestic air traffic market has been hard-hit by the recession, UNI Airlines has managed to chalk up profits on its Taiwan-Kinmen route, according to a recent report in the Commercial Times.

The report quoted UNI Airlines as saying that its business revenue on the route increased by 85 percent over the course of the year, making it the most profitable carrier operating the route. At the same time, TransAsia Airways registered growth of 7 percent, while the business of Far East Air Transport Corp. remained stable.

Thanks to the establishment of direct trade, postal and transportation links between Kinmen and two ports in mainland China's Fujian Province Jan. 1, 2001, the offshore island has become a popular destination for Taiwan residents wishing to purchase mainland Chinese products and do sightseeing.
UNI Airlines runs more than 20 flights on the Taiwan-Kinmen route per day. A round ticket costs around NT$4,000 (US$110).

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI COMPLETES TESTING ON BLUETOOTH BASEBAND IP
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Feb. 8 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) has completed its internal Bluetooth baseband intellectual property (IP) testing, ensuring the design's compatibility with Bluetooth radio frequency integrated chips (RF ICs) made by major companies worldwide.

According to the ITRI Computer and Communications Lab, the cost for manufacturing Bluetooth chips has already fallen from US$12 to US$7.5 per chip -- close to the ideal cost of US$5 and thus making mass production and commercialization feasible.

The lab's deputy director, Huang Te-di, said that the low-temperature co-fired ceramics (LTCC) Bluetooth chip it developed can be applied to notebook computers, third-generation mobile phones, personal digital assistants and digital cameras, greatly increasing their added value.
The ITRI has called its LTCC Bluetooth module the world's smallest, measuring 20 millimeters by 12 millimeters by 3.5 millimeters.
The ITRI is a national-level non-profit organization that researches, develops and transfers to Taiwan industry new technologies that increase competitiveness and create new market opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM LOOKING FORWARD TO `TAKING CARE OF ROC ALLIES'

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Eugene Chien said Friday he looks forward to the Republic of China and its allies "attending to each other" and vowed to step up cooperation with the country's diplomatic partners.

At a tea party held by his ministry for foreign ambassadors, Chien said that the ROC is a sovereign state with the ability to carry out its will despite Beijing's attempts to shut it out of the international community.
He pledged to beef up the country's cooperation with its allies for the sake of mutual prosperity, peace and security.
Noting that Taiwan values its friendships with its diplomatic allies, the minister said he and his staff will do their utmost to cement these friendships.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA WORKING ON MEASURES TO PREVENT SEXUAL HARASSMENT IN WORKPLACE

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) is working on a draft bill on the prevention of sexual harassment in the workplace in line with the March 8 enactment of the Law on Sexual Equality.
The measures being planned have yet to be approved first by a CLA committee before being able to be enacted together with the Law on Sexual Equality next month.

In compliance with the law, business owners have the responsibility of preventing sexual offenses in the workplace. Any businesses with over 30 employees must devise its own measures to avoid such cases, and the owners will be fined between NT$10,000 and NT$100,000 for failing to do so.

The CLA draft bill will also require business owners to make public all punitive measurers to their workers and that the owners must set up a special hotline or an e-mail address to handle sexual harassment cases. Any such case must be closed within three months following a collective labor-management investigation should a compliant be filed.
According to the bill, business owners are entitled to punish the offenders should their alleged behavior prove to be true. Anyone who is found to make false accusations will also be punished.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL BANK OF CHINA NAMES NEW DEPUTY GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: Liang Fa-chin, a member of the board of directors of the Central Bank of China (CBC), was promoted to deputy governor of the bank, effective Feb. 15, the CBC announced Friday.

Liang is to take over the post vacated by former CBC deputy governor Chen Shih-meng, who was appointed chief of staff to President Chen Shui-bian when former Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun became premier Feb. 1.
According to the CBC, Liang's specialties lie in currency theories and policies, general economic theories and policies, and applied quantitative economics.
Liang is a vice president and economics professor at National Taipei University.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY FINDS HIGH PUBLIC CONFIDENCE IN CABINET'S ECONOMIC EFFORTS

TEXT.P: Some 43 percent of the respondents to a recent survey expressed confidence in the Cabinet's efforts to improve the economy, according to the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC).
The results, published Friday, show that only 23.9 percent of the respondents said they lack confidence in the Cabinet.
The survey, which was conducted by the RDEC via telephone interviews with 1,093 adults around the island from Jan. 28-29, had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent.
Some 9.8 percent of the respondents said that they are very confident in the Cabinet's efforts, while 34 percent expressed "some confidence."
Meanwhile, 16 percent of the respondents said that they have little confidence in the Cabinet, while 7.9 percent said that they totally lacking in confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: US FORESEES NO CHANGE REGARDING TAIWAN DURING BUSH'S CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: The United States expects the Taiwan issue to come up during President George W. Bush's visit to Beijing later this month but U.S. policy will not change as a result, a senior U.S. official said Thursday.
"The Chinese will try to get us to discuss Taiwan but we don't have much room there for discussion," said the White House official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
"There will be no change in our policy toward Taiwan," he said during a background briefing for Washington-based reporters from Japan, South Korea and mainland China.

Bush leaves Washington Feb. 16 for a six-day trip to Tokyo, Seoul and Beijing. This is originally part of a visit last October that was cut short because of America's counter-terrorism campaign in Afghanistan.
Bush is scheduled to arrive in Beijing Feb. 21, the 30th anniversary of the first trip to mainland China by U.S. President Richard Nixon.
Asked whether the president may issue a joint statement with Chinese leaders to commemorate that historic event, the senior official said, "There may be some kind of statement."
"Actually, what's more important," he said, "is to use this visit as an opportunity to look to the future."
The official said that Washington appreciates the muted reaction to Bush's decision late last year to pull out of the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty with the Russians.
He said that Bush will also thank Beijing's leaders for their cooperation in the war on terrorism.

Bush is expected to spend less than 48 hours in Beijing, during which a meeting with President Jiang Zemin and a speech at Chinghwa University are planned. He will also see the Great Wall and tour a busy downtown shopping area.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN TO RELAX VISA REQUIREMENTS FOR HONG KONG PASSPORT HOLDERS

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (SAR) government has received confirmation from the Consulate-General of Japan that the Japanese government will introduce relaxed visa measures to facilitate Hong Kong people to visit Japan for business purposes effective from Feb. 15.

According to an announcement released by the government today, SAR passport holders working for recognized companies (e.g. those listed on the Hong Kong stock exchange) will be eligible to apply for a five-year multiple-entry visa (i.e. APEC Business Visa) for short-term business visits to Japan. This is part of the visa relaxation measures for APEC member economies.
A spokesman for the Security Bureau said, "Greater travel convenience will help further enhance the business relationship between Japan and Hong Kong."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAYI AIRPORT TO BE REBUILT TO MEET TRAVELERS' NEEDS
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi County, central Taiwan, Feb. 8 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Officials at Chiayi Airport said Friday that the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has decided to spend NT$150 million (US$4.3 million) to rebuild the airport, a project to be completed by the end of 2003.

Chiayi Airport Director Wang Yo-lin said that the number of travelers that the airport serves peaked in 1998 at approximately one million a year, gradually declining after the country sank into recession to the current figure of around 300,000 travelers a year.

Wang said that the transportation ministry made the decision to build newer and more spacious facilities for the airport to meet future travelers' needs after anticipating the number of people using the airport to rise to 500,000 annually by 2021 because of Chiayi County's status as a major tourism area in central and southern Taiwan.

According to Wang, the ministry's administrating agency overseeing the Mount Ali National Scenic Area is interested in setting up a bus depot at the airport to make it more convenient for travelers to visit the area, which is well known for its view of the sunrise over a sea of clouds.
Visitors usually reach Mount Ali from Chiayi by bus or train, through a 72-kilometer scenic railway.

To accomodate the expected growth in domestic air travel, facilities have already been enlarged at the Tainan, Hualien, Chiayi, Makung, Kinmen and Orchid Island airports, according to the Government Information Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ARTS STUDENTS TO PERFORM IN JAPAN, UNITED STATES

TEXT.P: In an effort to promote international cultural exchanges, students of the Taiwan Folk Arts and Music College (TFAMC) will perform in Japan and the United States during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday under the sponsorship of the Council for Cultural Affairs.

TFAMC students who study Chinese Opera will perform in Denver, Chicago, New York and in Vermont from Feb. 8 to Feb. 22. In addition to traditional Chinese Opera, the students will also stage pieces adapted from foreign works, featuring a combination of traditional and modern elements.

At the same time, some other TFAMC dance students will take part in a "Spring Festival Show" slated for Feb. 13-19 in Kobe, Japan, in which they will display traditional Chinese folk dances and acrobatics.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE FOREIGN MINISTER MEETS WITH ROC DIPLOMATS IN AFRICA
DOC.DATELINE: Mbabane, Feb. 8 (CNA) (By Chang Jer-shong and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Chiou Jong-nan presided over an annual meeting with ROC diplomats in Africa Thursday at the Swaziland capital of Mbabane, jointly reviewing their diplomatic works on the continent.
Chiou discussed with 11 ROC ambassadors and representatives issues regarding ROC-Africa relations, multilateral trade, technical cooperation and cultural exchanges.
Officials from the ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs and Government Information Office also attended the meeting.
During his stay in Swaziland, Chiou met with Swazi King Mswati III, the premier and foreign minister, and inspected the work of major technological cooperation projects between the two countries.
Before arriving in South Africa, Chiou visited Liberia, Senegal, Cote d'Ivoire and Malawi.

The Republic of China has formal diplomatic ties with Burkina Faso, Chad, The Gambia, Liberia, Malawi, Sao Tome and Principe, Senegal and Swaziland. It also has representative offices in Angola, Mauritius, Nigeria and South Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ENCOURAGES ARMED FORCES TO FIGHT FOR COUNTRY'S SURVIVAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian encouraged the country's armed forces Friday to fight for the survival of the country and the well-being of the people.

Speaking to a brigade of the ROC Army stationed near Taipei, the president said the Republic of China has no intention of provoking a conflict or starting an arms race against any country, but everyone should be well aware that national security cannot be ensured without paying a price, and an appropriate deterrent force is vital to achieving this goal.

The president encouraged the armed forces to strengthen their rapid response capabilities to emergency, saying it is vital for both the armed forces and the government to be ready to react quickly to whatever challenges they must face.

Chen also called on the people of the nation to pull together and be vigilant in the defense of their country, citing the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington on Sept. 11 as an example of the kind of uncertain events that can befall a nation. "The strength of national defense is only as strong as the weakest link and that every individual counts in keeping the country free and safe", said the president.

The president, whose only son is now doing one year and 10 months compulsory military service in the army, urged military officers to train and treat recruits humanely, and take care of them as a parent would take care of their own children.
Chen arrived at the army brigade on a tour of armed forces units around Taipei. He was flanked by Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min and other military leaders on the trip.

The tour also took him to an ROC Navy radar station in Linko, Taipei County and an air force unit earlier in the day. The president wore the uniform of each branch of the military service he visited during his inspection and wherever he went, he was given a warm reception by the soldiers. They scrambled to shake hands with the president with the same enthusiasm usually reserved for fans of movie stars.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER HOPES TO ASSURE PEOPLE A SAFE NEW YEAR

TEXT.P: Minister of Interior Yu Cheng-hsien asked National Police and Fire Administrations Friday to strengthen security measures to assure citizens to have a safe Chinese Lunar New Year vacation.
During his inspection visit to the National Police Administration and the National Fire Administration, Yu urged workers to follow Premier Yu Shyi-kun's economizing efforts and focus on teamwork.
Yu also instructed all the staff of the ministry to cancel unnecessary social public activities during the Chinese Lunar New Year vacation.

Yu added that he will "inspect" all the agencies under his ministry during the New Year holiday, and will try to improve the morale of officials on duty next week, especially those police and fire officials responsible for social order and public security.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER EDUCATION MINISTER TO JOIN ACADEMIA SINICA

TEXT.P: Former Minister of Education Ovid Tseng took over the vice presidency of the Academia Sinica Friday, the most prestigious academic institution in Taiwan.

Tseng said the priorities for him will be the promotion of international academic exchanges and a national "digital learning" project, in addition to integrating the study of the way the human brain works and behavioral and cognitive sciences.
Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said Tseng will be a valuable addition since he has both global vision and the energy to help develop the nation.

Tseng holds a Ph.D. in cognitive psychology from Pennsylvania State University and helped establish the Psychology Department at Taiwan's National Chung Cheng University in 1990. He became president of National Yang Ming University in 1999 and joined the Chen Shui-bian administration as education minister in 2000.

After teaching at Ohio State University, and the universities of California at Riverside and Berkeley, Tseng was barred from returning to Taiwan because of what the government termed his "remarks designed to incite." He finally return to Taiwan in 1984 thanks to the assurances of the Academia Sinica.

Although being Taiwan's education minister for just 622 days, Tseng said there is still much reform work to be done. He said that his understanding of the differing characteristics of the island's universities will help him better integrate educational experiences at the Academia Sinica.

Tseng added that he also aspires to elevate Taiwan's academic research to the international level. He pointed out that Taiwan's academic level is already quite high in some areas, but is lacking in others. Tseng said realizing the potential in all areas is a personal goal of his.
Citing the example of Japan and Singapore -- which have integrated different sciences efficiently -- Tseng said Taiwan needs to catch up with these regional academics.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2002 GREEN EXPO OF ILAN TO KICK OFF IN MARCH

TEXT.P: The 2002 Green Exposition of Ilan will begin from March 9 and run until April 21 with an estimated participation of 250,000 visitors, according to a statement released by the Ilan County Government.

Organizer of the green exposition said people will better understand environmental protection after visiting the green exposition in Ilan, eastern Taiwan, and can view orchids, genetically-engineered fish, and see a variety of environmentally-friendly exhibits.

Some Taipei tourist agencies are eager to offer one or two-day tour packages to Ilan and some qualified hotels in the county are also planning to offer special services to the visitors. Interested visitors can visit Ilan County Government's Web site at www.ilccb.gov.tw

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORS' NOTE: CNA WILL SUSPEND ITS CEP SERVICE ON FEB. 12 AND
PREMIER DIRECTS AGENCIES TO COME UP WITH BETTER ALLOCATION PLAN

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun directed the Ministry of Finance and the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics Friday to study the issue of central government budget allocations so that disputes of the kind currently pending in the legislature can be avoided in the future.
Yu gave the agencies three months to work out a system for the central government to provide financial aid to local governments in such a way that there would be parity for all concerned.
The system should be fair and transparent but it should not spell out a fix proportion of the revenues to be given to any one agency as this is usually the catalyst for controversy, the premier said.

The re-think of the allocation issue should be done as part of the government's reform plan where the government is downsized yet more efficient by handing over more power and funds to local governments, Yu said.

The current methods of allocating revenues among central and local governments provided in the Law Governing the Allocation of Government Revenues and Expenditures is at the center of the current controversy.

It was revised by the previous opposition-controlled legislature despite the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's opposition to the move on the grounds that it would create a shortfall in the budget needed to effectively operate the central government.

Yu's administration is asking the newly-assembled legislature to review the revision. The changes to the way the funds are allocated will be invalidated unless the new legislature, which is almost evenly divided between the ruling and opposition camps, upholds the revision by a simple majority.

Although political analysts said the opposition is fighting an uphill battle in the legislature, lawmakers of the leading opposition Kuomintang (KMT), which initiated the original changes, gathered Friday to work out a way to scuttle the motion for reconsideration.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng said KMT lawmakers will stick to their guns in the fight and will fan out across the island in the next few days to marshal support for the party's opposition to the Cabinet's motion.
The motion is scheduled to be debated Feb. 19 and a vote will be taken immediately afterward.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 9, or the 28th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1775: Hostilities between Britain and the American colony of Massachusetts become imminent as the British Parliament announces the state is in rebellion and approves new laws to control the situation.
1799: The U.S. Navy draws first blood in a war with France.
1801: France signs the Peace of Luneville with Austria, dissolving the Holy Roman Empire.
1825: John Quincy Adams, an American politician who helped formulate the Monroe Doctrine and who advocated antislavery measures, is elected the sixth president of the United States, defeating Andrew Jackson.
1830: Explorer Charles Stuart discovers the source of Australia's longest river, the Murray.
1881: Feodor Mikhailovich Dostoevski, Russian writer who wrote such great novels as "Crime and Punishment," "The Idiot," "The Possessed" and "The Brothers Karamazov," dies at the age of 60.
1899: The Boxer Uprising breaks out in China. Sparked by popular discontent with internal misgovernment and anti-foreign sentiment aroused by unequal treaties, the boxers lay siege to the foreign legion in Peking, where a combined force of Japanese, French, British, Russian and American troops held out for over a month.
1921: The Living Buddha of Outer Mongolia proclaims "independence" after Mongolian and Russian communists gain control of Outer Mongolia. They established the Mongolian People's Republic in 1924, after the Living Buddha died.
