1942: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek visits India after assuming office as supreme commander of the China Theater of War on Jan. 2, 1942.
1945: Mia Farrow, the American actress who first made her name in the television series Peyton Place and went on to make many films, notably comedies with Wooden Allen, is born.
1955: The U.S. Senate approves the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty by a vote of 64-6.
1957: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China advocates independence for the Ryukyus. China and Japan both claimed the Ryukyus until 1874, when the Ching court signed a treaty recognizing Japanese rule. After Japan's defeat in World War II, the U.S. took over the Ryukyus. In 1953, the U.S. returned the islands north of Okinawa to Japan. Okinawa and the southern Ryukyus were returned in 1972.
1962: The Taiwan Stock Exchange formally begins operations.
1964: Beatlemania hits the United States as 73 million Americans watch four lads from Liverpool appear on the Ed Sullivan Show.
1973: H.E. Hisham Muhiuddin Nazer, state minister of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: Six winners of the Second Cathay Children's Music Contest leave Taipei for Hong Kong to attend the Arts Festival.
1981: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's defense minister, becomes prime minister and chief of the Polish Communist Party.
1993: President Francois Mitterrand visits Vietnam, ending Vietnam's isolation in the international community. He was the first Western head of state to visit the communist country since 1966.
1994: President Lee Teng-hui leaves for the Philippines, Indonesia and Thailand on an eight-day visit.
1999: A 352-page collection of news photographs depicting historic moments in ROC diplomacy over the past six decades is published by the Central News Agency, which was founded in 1924.
1999: The Republic of the Marshall Islands opens an embassy in the Republic of China, heralding a new era in relations between the two countries.
2000: The Taiwan Stock Exchange performs well in the first trading session after the Chinese New Year holiday, with the market's weighted price index breaking the 10,000 point level at the close.
2001: The undersea cable between mainland China and the United States breaks, seriously limiting millions of Taiwan Internet surfers' access to North American websites.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Why should one be too severe? When a man reforms and comes to me for advice, I accept his present reformation without inquiring what his past life has been. I am satisfied if I find that, for the present, he has really reformed, without being able to guarantee that he will not relapse again. But why should one be too severe?"

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY (Feb. 10)
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 10, or the 29th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1763: The Treaty of Paris is signed, ending seven years of war and heralding Britain's emergence as the leading world power. Britain gained both Canada and Florida and established dominance in the East.
1840: Queen Victoria of Britain and Ireland and empress of India, whose sense of duty and strict moral code had great influence on 19th-century British society, marries her first cousin, Prince Albert.
1846: British forces defeat Sikh forces at Sobranhan, India.
1890: Boris Pasternak, the Russian author famed for his prize-winning novel "Doctor Zhivago," is born.
1894: Harold Macmillan, British statesman and Conservative prime minister, is born.
1904: The Russo-Japanese War breaks out after Japan formally declares war on Russia.
1923: William Rontgen, the German physicist who discovered X-rays and developed X-ray photography, thereby revolutionizing medical diagnosis, dies in Munich at the age of 77.
1939: Haikou falls after Japanese troops land on Hainan Island in southern China.
1946: In the first Jakarta (Batavia) meeting between the two sides, the Netherlands government bows to the inevitable and agrees to let Indonesia become independent, on the condition that Indonesia forms a confederation of states.
1955: Thousands of armed South African police begin evicting 60,000 black people from their homes in Sophiatown near Johannesburg, with bulldozers flattening the township in the people's wake.
1955: All 14,483 residents of the Republic of China-held Tachen Islands near mainland China's Chekiang Province are evacuated to Taiwan.
1962: In a historic exchange, captured U.S. spy-plane pilot Gary Powers starts walking to freedom from the communist side of a Berlin bridge, while the highest-ranking Russian spy ever caught, KGB Col. Rudolf Abel, sets off from the American side.
1964: The government of the ROC recalls its envoy from France and announces the severance of diplomatic relations with the European country.
1964: More than 80 people die as the HMAS Voyager, a destroyer of the Royal Australian Navy, sinks after a collision with the HMAS Melbourne.
1976: Work begins on an elevated road across the North Gate area of Taipei, in a move designed to relieve traffic congestion.
1980: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severance of diplomatic relations with Colombia.
1981: King Juan Carlos names Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo as prime minister of Spain.
1982: President Chiang Ching-kuo sends a congratulatory message to President-elect Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez of the Republic of Costa Rica.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Finance orders the 10th Credit Cooperative of Taipei to stop transactions for three days for violating operating regulations.
1996: On the Japanese island of Hokkaido, a landslide crushes a highway tunnel, killing 20 people.
1998: Former French Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann, considered a founding father of the European Union, dies.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua sign a joint communique reaffirming their commitment to further expanding bilateral cooperation.
2001: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung travels to Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung to inspect the pollution along the coast caused by an oil spill from a grounded Greek freighter that is threatening to lead to an ecological disaster in the area.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Is moral life something remote or difficult? If a man only wishes to live a moral life -- there and then his life becomes moral."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL, LEGISLATORS CALL FOR E.U. SUPPORT OF ROC'S WHO BID
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Feb. 8 (CNA) (By Tang Ping-chun and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China presidential adviser along with five ROC legislators met with members of the international media stationed in Brussels Friday to promote Taiwan's bid to re-join the World Health Organization (WHO) as an observer.

National policy adviser Wu Shu-min, who is also head of the Medical Professionals Alliance in Taiwan (MPAT), was accompanied by ROC Representative to the European Union David T.W. Lee and legislators William C.D. Lai, Liu Shih-fang, Chien Chao-tung, Yeh Yi-chin and Chiang Yi-wen at the news conference.

Wu said that his delegation is seeking the support of European countries for the ROC's WHO bid. He pointed out that the U.S. Congress has already ratified a resolution in support of Taiwan's efforts to participate in the WHO, but added that more backing from other countries is needed.

He said that Taiwan's accomplishments in the areas of medical and public health give it the ability to contribute to the international community but that the island has been unable to become a member of the WHO because of Beijing's continued obstruction.
Wu's delegation arrived in Brussels Thursday and met with several E.U. and Belgian health officials and lawmakers to solicit their support.

As a founding member of the WHO, the ROC participated in the organization's activities and programs for 24 years before being forced to leave the WHO in 1972 in the wake of mainland China's admission into the United Nations.

In 1997, when Taiwan began seeking re-admittance to the WHO, representatives of the MPAT and the Department of Health (DOH) attended a meeting of the World Health Assembly (WHA) in Geneva to promote support for the ROC's WHO bid.

Since then, ROC allies have submitted numerous proposals to the WHA, urging the international community to respect the health rights of Taiwan's nearly 23 million people and to recognize the island as a valuable partner in world health care.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIANT "I LOVE YOU" ROADSIDE SIGN ERECTED FOR V.P. LU BY ADMIRER

TEXT.P: Another "explicit" admirer of Vice President Annette Lu has come forth, this time via a large sign saying "I love you" placed Saturday alongside the highway near Changhua, central Taiwan.

The admirer, Tony Chen, who is an English teacher at a cram school, said the move was absolutely not a momentary impulse, adding that he has planned it for a long time as a gift to Lu for the upcoming Valentine's Day.
The "I love you" T-bar sign will stand for one year at cost of NT$1.028 million, including location rent, fees to have the sign made, the electricity bill and building costs, according to Chen.

Chen denied putting up the highway sign to gain personal publicity, saying that "I don't need to publicize myself as I'm already a popular cram school English teacher, a well known writer and a scholar with two master's degrees from the United States who has more than 100 lecture chairs a year."

He stressed that the sign is only an expression of his admiration for the vice president whom he said he has for long been attracted to for her "compassion for people, congeniality, courage, political perceptiveness and global vision."

Noting that a roadside sign is the "most direct" way of showing his love for Lu, Chen said that he wants the entire country to see his expression of love and that he hopes the vice president will give him a kindly response.
If possible, Chen said, he would be pleased to help the vice president to fulfill one of her wishes of seeing the English level of the people of Taiwan further upgraded.

Some people have expressed concern that the sign might be viewed as illegal and therefore removed. Chen responded by arguing that if that is the case, all the T-bar advertisement signs that appear one after another several hundreds meters apart along the Sun Yat-sen Freeway should also be removed.
Vice President Annette Lu's first "explicit" admirer, a man who runs a debt collection agency in Taipei, came forth last year by attempting to bring 999 roses to her at the Presidential Office.

Tung Nien-tai tried to bring Lu the roses to court her, but the move caused a commotion in front of the Presidential Office and Tung and his roses were barred by police and guards from entering the premises.
The flowers were not acknowledged by Lu's office, which Tung said made him very upset. Lu also did not make any response to Tung's courting.

DOC.HEADLINE: SYSTEM PROVIDERS SEE POTENTIAL OF ERP MARKET IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: While increasing numbers of businesses in Taiwan have applied commercial software and enterprise management systems, software and systems providers in Taiwan are doubling their efforts to explore the domestic market, especially among small- and medium-sized businesses, according to an industrial source.

A spokesman of the Data Systems Corp. specializing in enterprise resource planning (ERP) said Saturday that ERP has focused attention of visitors to the 2002 Spring Multi-media Computer Show sponsored by the Taipei Computer Exhibition at the Taipei World Trade Center exhibition hall from Feb. 6-10.

So far, the integrated ERP systems have been applied mostly by medium-sized or large enterprises due to the considerably high cost. The minimum NT$1.5 million investment is considered much too high by most small companies with an annual turnover below NT$200 million.

As more and more industrial firms have computerized their operations in terms of accounting, personnel administration and logistic systems, domestic software houses are developing integrated ERP systems for small- and medium-sized enterprises.
The SmartERP system developed by the Data Systems Corp., for instance, costs less than NT$300,000 and is suitable for small- and medium-sized businesses, according to the company spokesman.

In recent years, many leading information technology manufacturers in Taiwan, such as Acer Group, ASUSTek, CMC Magnetics, and United Microelectronics, have made big investments in software research and development, according to the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB).
The IDB forecasts that the production value of Taiwan's software industry will rise to US$14 billion by 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWELVE LOTTERY WINNERS IN TAIWAN TO JOINTLY SHARE US$ 14.9 M. JACKPOT

TEXT.P: Twelve people hit the jackpot in the latest drawing of Taiwan's "public benefits" computerized lottery to share the approximately NT$524 million (US$14.9 million) in grand prize money, TAIPEIBANK announced Saturday.

Bank officials explained that although the winning numbers were drawn the previous night, compiling the statistics on the winning tickets took much longer than expected due to the record number of computer lottery ticket purchasers and also because of an error relating to the bank's other traditional lottery drawing that forced the entire computer system to be shut down for two hours.

According to the bank, the sixth drawing of its computerized lottery broke the world record for the highest number of single-drawing transactions, while also recording the fifth highest amount ever in terms of single-drawing turnover.
A total of 39.8 million computerized tickets were sold islandwide between Tuesday night and Friday evening, raking in NT$1.99 billion (US$56.7 million) for the state-sponsored lottery.

Although the odds of winning the jackpot are estimated at only one in 5.25 million, the low investment of NT$50 (US$1.43) per ticket has set people's imaginations on fire, with many hoping to strike it rich.

Bank officials said that the computer system used to tally statistics on the geographical distribution of lottery winners was shut down after it was discovered that two of the bank's branches sold 4,300 tickets for the traditional lottery without registering them in the system.

The system was brought back online after several attempts to key in the numbers for those tickets failed because of the computer program's security measures that prevent changes to be made after the winning numbers for the traditional lottery have been drawn, the officials added.
The bank stressed that holders of those 4,300 tickets who have won prizes can still redeem them at TAIPEIBANK instead of at the lottery vendors.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN IS THEME COUNTRY OF 2002 TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL BOOK EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: Japan will be the theme country of the 2002 Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE) opening at the Taipei World Trade Center exhibition hall Feb. 19.
A total of 1,017 publishing companies from 47 countries will participate in the six-day exhibition organized by local publishers associations.

The organizers said Saturday that several prominent Japanese writers, cartoonists and editors have been invited to attend the book fair. The organizers have arranged workshops featuring Taiwan-Japan cultural exchanges on a project of reproducing masterpieces from the National Palace Museum, databases in Japanese about Taiwan issues, Japanese animation, and flexibility in human relations at the exhibition venue during the exhibition.

Marking the 10th anniversary of the book fair, the organizers are also hosting two special exhibitions featuring Russian illustrations and the French printing-engraving technique "chalcographie" which has been in use since the 16th century.

Co-sponsored by the Louvre, the "Reunion des musees nationaux" (RMN) of France, the French Institute in Taipei, and the Le Pigeonnier Bookstore in Taipei, the chalcographie exhibition will display copper plates from the 16th century and a 200-kilogram handpress machine loaned by the Louvre.
Francois Baudequin, studio director of the Louvre Museum chalchography workshop, will give demonstrations of the handpress at the exhibition hall, according to the organizers.

The exhibition of Russian illustrations is being sponsored by the Chinese Publishers Development Foundation. On display will be 300 illustrations from popular fairy tales, Russian encyclopedias, and historical stories created by some 100 Russian artists. A noted Russian illustrator Kirill Chelushkin will attend the exhibition and sign autographs of his posters at the venue.

In view of the rising Internet applications in the publishing business, the organizers have also arranged a series of discussions featuring online reading, literature on the Internet, multimedia design, digital archives, and the knowledge-based economy during the exhibition.

With some 400,000 visitors expected, the TIBE has developed into the largest book exhibition in Asia, according to the organizers. While rights exchanges and marketing of publications are the two major functions of the annual event, the book fair has established its reputation as a trade center of Chinese literary works.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORS' NOTE: CNA WILL SUSPEND ITS CEP SERVICE ON FEB. 12 AND
FIRST GROUP TO TAKE M'LAND-KINMEN-TAIWAN ROUTE ARRIVES IN KINMEN

TEXT.P: A group of mainland China-based Taiwan business people and their relatives were ferried directly from the Fujian Province port city of Xiamen to the Republic of China-held island of Kinmen Saturday, on the first leg of their journeys back to Taiwan for the Chinese New Year holidays.

The sailing of the 181 ROC citizens aboard the Kinmen-based ferry "Tai Wu" marked the first ROC government-approved direct transportation of people, rather than goods, from mainland China to ROC-held territory, following the government's initiation of the "mini three links" Jan. 2, 2001.
The mini three links allows for direct trade, postal and shipping links between the ROC's outlying islands of Kinman and Matsu and the mainland port cities of Xiamen and Fuzhou in Fujian Province.

Upon their arrival at Kinmen's Shuitou port, the Taiwan passengers, most of them members of the Taiwan Investment and Business Association in Xiamen, were warmly greeted by Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng and Kinmen-based New Party Legislator Wu Cheng-dien.
All the passengers said they were thrilled with the trip, not only because the voyage was the first of its kind, but also because it saved them a lot of time and money.

The direct Xiamen-Kinmen-Taiwan sea and air trip will save roughly NT$10,000 (US$286) for each person per trip. In the past, a traveler had to spend about NT$16,000 for a one-way trip to Jujian Province from Taiwan via a "third place," namely Hong Kong or Macau, or vice versa.
Sailing from Xiamen port to Kinmen takes about 90 minutes. And a flight from Kinmen to Taipei takes about 50 minutes.

Chen Kuan-ting, an assistant director of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) -- Taiwan's top agency in charge of policies toward mainland China -- and Liao Yun-yuan, director of the Business and Trade Department of the quasi-official intermediary organization of the Straits Exchange Foundation, traveled to Kinmen from Taiwan to witness the arrival of the group.

Kinmen Magistrate Lee expressed the hope that the direct Xiamen-Kinmen-Taiwan trip formula, a "tentative arrangement" as labeled by the MAC, will turn out to be popular and successful and will eventually persuade the government to make it a fixed policy.

Huang Tieh-jung, chairman of the Taiwan Investment and Business Association in Xiamen, who was among the group, said now that both Taiwan and mainland China are full members of the World Trade Organization, it is both sides' duty to further strengthen business and trade exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

He added that he hopes that the Xiamen-Kinmen-Taiwan trip formula will become a fixed policy and that the ROC government will eventually turn the Xiamen-Kinmen passenger ferries into a regular service to make people exchanges between the two sides much more convenient and cost efficient.

The second group of its kind, which will include 115 Xiamen-based Taiwan business people and their relatives, is scheduled to depart from Xiamen on Sunday for Kinmen, from where the group members are also expected to fly to Taiwan the same day for the Chinese New Year holidays.
The same travelers are scheduled to return to Fujian Province later in the month by taking similar ferries from Kinmen on Feb. 16, 17 and 24 to return to work on the mainland after the holiday break.

Meanwhile, the Kinmen county government is planning to establish a school exclusively for children of mainland China-based Taiwan business people to further serve the special group of people and their dependents, according to Magistrate Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STRAIT SHOULD REMAIN STABLE: U.S. BUSINESS LEADER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 8 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A U.S. business leader said Friday the situation in the Taiwan Strait should remain stable amid rapid cross-strait economic integration, Taiwan's recent assurances it won't declare formal independence in the short term and Beijing's upcoming leadership transition later this year.

Christian Murck, chairman of the American Chamber of Commerce in mainland China, said at a seminar in Washington that although cross-strait relations are currently facing an impasse, economic integration between the two economies appears to be an inevitable trend.

Murck said that some of his Taiwanese friends spend equal parts of the year between living in Taipei and living in Shanghai because many of the restaurants and other stores that they frequent in Taipei have also opened branches in the cosmopolitan mainland city.

He added that although a sign of good will on the part of mainland China can be glimpsed from mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen's recent public invitation to select members of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party to visit the mainland, the People's Liberation Army remains set on building up its strength -- particularly its amphibious fighting capabilities.

Murck said that he expects U.S. President George W. Bush to touch on cross-strait issues during his upcoming visit to Beijing, in addition to issues related to human rights, anti-terrorism and mainland China's recent World Trade Organization accession.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT THREATENS TO BAR PREMIER FROM GIVING REPORT AT LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) threatened Saturday that the party may choose to bar Premier Yu Shyi-kun from making his administrative report at the Legislative Yuan if the Executive Yuan does not execute the governmental budget law as resolved by the Legislature.

Lin Yi-shih, KMT party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said it is unacceptable that the Executive Yuan does not execute nor acknowledge the budget law -- apparently out of disapproval -- while failing to move to overturn the legislation.
The KMT claimed that the Cabinet is picking a fight with the Legislature over the newly revised Law Governing the Allocation of Government Revenues and Expenditures.

President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that he hopes the Executive Yuan and the Legislative Yuan will find time and opportunities after the Chinese New Year to coordinate together more closely and resolve the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2001 TAIWAN-CHINA TRADE AMOUNTS TO US$ 32,339 MILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan was mainland China's fifth biggest trading partner in 2001 with two-way trade amounting to US$32,339 million, according to a report by Beijing's New China News Agency.
In last year, mainland Chinese imports from Taiwan totaled US$27,339 million. Exports to Taiwan reached US$5,000 million in the same year, the report said.
Investments made by Taiwan investors in mainland China totaled US$3,138 million in the same year, the report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG SMUGGLER OF BIBLE RELEASED FROM CHINESE PRISON

TEXT.P: Hong Kong businessman Lai Kwong-keung, who was sentenced to two years in prison last month for smuggling the Bible into China, has been released from Chinese prison and has returned to Hong Kong.

Hong Kong news media reported Saturday that mainland Chinese law authorities have temporarily permitted Lai to serve his two-year sentence outside of prison, because he has hepatitis B. Security authorities have confirmed that Lai returned to Hong Kong Saturday afternoon.
U.S. President George W. Bush had expressed concern over Lai's case, the news media reported.
