DOC.HEADLINE: THAI COUPLE AMONG 'LUCKY 12' TO SHARE FIRST PRIZE IN LOTTERY

TEXT.P: A Thai husband and wife, in Taiwan as contract laborers, hit the jackpot in Friday's lottery draw, but their luck didn't stop there -- they also won the second prize, a major daily newspaper reported Sunday.

China Times said that the Thai couple working at a Hsinchu textile plant in northern Taiwan will share the first prize of NT$524,531,100 (US$1,494,390) with 11 others, and share the second prize of NT$109,436,958 (US$311,786) together with 32 others.
The couple was the first foreign workers to win the top prize in the state-sponsored lottery, the reports said.
"Who would have thought that Thai laborers would win the first and second prize as well?" a dormitory manager at the textile plant said upon learning of the news.
The manager, surnamed Wu, added, "The company has decided to send the couple back to Thailand for their safety as soon as we find out where they are."
The Thai man, 33, and his wife, 29, had just completed their two-year contracts with the plant and had extended their contracts for another year, Wu said.
The couple disappeared soon after learning that they had hit the jackpot.

They purchased five NT$50 (US$1.42) lottery tickets, Wu said. The foreman at the plant, for unknown reasons, took down all five sets of numbers, and broke the news when the winning numbers were announced Friday.

Wu said that when the winning numbers were drawn, the couple was working the night shift. When the couple heard that they had won, they went wild, shouting and hugging the other Thai workers. They also said that they would give the other workers NT$10,000 (US$284.9) each. But by dawn the next day, the couple were not at the plant dormitory.

Wu said that their personal data showed that they had used their birthday dates, their ages, and the validity date of their passports for their "lucky numbers." These numbers, together with the number 39, which has appeared several times in past drawings, turned out to be the winning combination: 2, 4, 15, 16, 29, 33 and 39.

Lottery fever has gripped the island since the lotto was started last month. Every Tuesday and Friday, people can be seen queuing up before ticket booths, because they believe that buying tickets on the last day will bring them extra luck.

Of the previous drawings, there were no first prize winners in the first and fifth drawings. This drawing, the sixth, produced the largest number of first-prize winners, even more than the 11 who combined to win in all the previous drawings.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORS' NOTE: CNA WILL SUSPEND ITS CEP SERVICE ON FEB. 12 AND
BIRTHPLACE RESTRICTION FOR PRESIDENCY REFLECTS PUBLIC OPINION: TSU

TEXT.P: The proposal to revise the law to allow only those born in Taiwan to be qualified to run for the presidency and vice presidency of the Republic of China is only a reflection of public opinion, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Sunday.

A spokesman for the tiny TSU, whose spiritual leader is former President Lee Teng-hui, said it was just a topic discussion within the party and that it has not yet become a policy or a plank of the party.

In response to criticism by Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chen that the idea is a "Hitler-style, fascist trick aimed at creating ethnic hatred in Taiwan," the TSU official said that the only thing fascist would be if the people were denied the right to discuss the issue in public.

He claimed that the TSU's proposal to amend the President and Vice President Election and Recall Law such that only those born in Taiwan could run for the presidency and vice presidency was made out of the party's concern over national security and country identification.

Stressing that the TSU has not yet reached any resolution on the issue, the spokesman said the party does not wish to provoke any independence-unification dispute regarding Taiwan's fate. The TSU just wishes to express its strong desire to safeguard Taiwan, he noted.

Meanwhile, Lien, who is vacationing in France, blasted the TSU's proposal as a "vile act" aimed at creating ethnic confrontation in Taiwan society. He said such a move goes against the world's prevailing trends of democracy and will eventually be forsworn by the people of Taiwan.
Lien made the remarks during a gathering in Paris with scores of ROC nationals residing in France.

The chairman of Taiwan's largest opposition party also voiced deep regret over the KMT's major loss in December's legislative election, but said he was satisfied with its victory in January's elections for local city and county councilors. He added that the KMT's taking of over 70 percent of the votes in last month's elections is an indication that the KMT enjoys widespread support at the grassroots level.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF AIDS CASES REACHES NEARLY 4,000 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The number of people in Taiwan with AIDS reached 3,985 in 2001, or an increase of more than 20 percent from the previous year, a major daily newspaper quoted a Department of Health (DOH) report Sunday.
The China Times reported that DOH officials said that one worrying phenomenon is that young people are not paying enough attention to safe sex practices.

The officials noted that the trend has resulted in an increase in AIDS patients -- 644 new AIDS cases were reported in 2001, or an increase of 21.1 percent over the previous year and the largest increase over the past years.

Statistics showed that 98 percent of those with AIDS got the disease through having sex, and among these the ratio of gay or bisexual patients has increased every year. The ratio surged to 57.4 percent in 2001 from 53 percent in 1997 and the trend is especially obvious in young people.
For those between age 15 and 24, the ratio of gays with AIDS was higher -- up to 75 percent of those infected in that age group over the last five years are gay or bisexual.

The health department said that this could be attributed to the fact that gays are more concerned with AIDS and are regularly checked for AIDS, so that the number of them being diagnosed is relatively higher.
But on the other hand, it could show that gays, especially the younger ones, have not paid enough attention to safe sex, DOH officials said.

They noted that the younger group is becoming more closely related to AIDS, noting that although statistics still showed that those between 20 and 39 are still the mainstay of those contracting AIDS, ratio of the group between 15 and 24 with AIDS has increased rapidly. Although only 74 people fell into this younger group, the number of those with AIDS has risen in five years to 134.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2ND GROUP OF TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN XIAMEN RETURN VIA KINMEN

TEXT.P: The second group of 108 mainland China-based Taiwan businessmen and their relatives left Xiamen, Fujian province for Taiwan's offshore island of Kinmen Sunday for the Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 12.
The group followed the first 181-member group the previous day, and then traveled on to other parts of Taiwan for the most important holiday for Chinese people.
The 108 people aboard the ferry Ta Yang No. 11, departed from Heping Wharf in Xiamen and arrived in Shuitou Wharf at 11 a.m. to warm greetings by Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng.

Taiwan businessmen, after a nearly two-hour trip across the Kinxia (Kinmen-Xiamen) Strait, said that they felt happy upon landing on Kinmen, adding that in the past they had to go to Hong Kong or Macau on their way to Taiwan, which was a waste of time and money, and they were elated to be able to return to Taiwan through Kinmen this year.

Some Taiwan businessmen also said that they believe cross-strait exchanges should be improved. A Taiwan businessman surnamed Chen said that full cross-strait links on trade, post and transportation is inevitable, and the government should face the issue pragmatically.
They said even with the "three mini links" in effect, the trip is still arduous having to take the ship first to Kinmen and then take a plane to Taiwan.
Taiwan inaugurated the "mini three links," -- the direct trade, post and transportation links between two of Taiwan's offshore islands, Kinmen and Matsu, and mainland China, on Jan. 1, 2001.

Kinmen County Magistrate Lee said the revised offshore island construction regulations stipulate that Taiwan people could use the offshore islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu to enter or leave for the mainland after prior approval.

Lee said the successful trips by Taiwan businessmen will serve as a good beginning, adding that he hoped that there will be regular shipping between Kinmen and Xiamen, and that Kinmen will play the role as a mid-point of cross-strait exchanges.
The 108-member group, except for 12 Kinmen residents, then took planes to Taipei, Taichung or Kaohsiung later for family reunions.
The first and second group of Taiwan businessmen and their relatives are scheduled to retrace their routes to return to mainland China Feb. 16, 17 and 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S WHO BID WINS EP SUPPORT

TEXT.P: A lobbying mission composed of ROC lawmakers and Taiwan's medical sector returned Sunday from a week-long European tour after getting enthusiastic response from the European Parliament (EP) for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO).

A news release issued by the group said Georg Jarzembowski, leader of the EP's pro-Taiwan Amity Group, and various EP members of liberal parties voiced support for Taiwan's WHO bid, while leading members of the French Parliament also promised to back Taiwan's membership at the WHO.

Members of the lobbying delegation included lawmakers Liu Shih-fang and Yeh Yi-chin of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and Chiang Chi-wen of the leading opposition Kuomintang and presidential advisor Wu Shu-min.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP IS WEIGHING ALTERNATIVE WAY OUT OF BUDGET ALLOCATION DISPUTE

TEXT.P: The best way to get out of the dispute over the revised budget allocation law lies in a comprehensive revision to current regulations rather than negating or upholding the revised rules, People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said in Los Angeles Saturday.

Soong who arrived in L.A. on a private vacation during the Chinese New Year holiday said that although the revised rules governing the allocation of the central government budget are not comprehensive, as admitted by the Kuomintang (KMT), the original rules are not perfect either, as the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has admitted.
So why should the two parties lock horns in a partisan dispute while both sides know their arguments don't hold water, Soong said.
The PFP will try to find middle ground and come up with an alternative way for the allocation of funds rather than just sustain the revision or reinstate the original rules, the PFP leader said.
The dispute stems from a KMT-initiated revision to budget allocation rules which, the DPP claims, are impractical and should be negated.

A vote in the legislature on a motion for reconsidering the revision is scheduled for Feb. 19. The KMT, which controls 68 seats in the legislature, needs to field support of at least 113 lawmakers, or a simple majority, to retain the changes.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW WESTERNIZATION TAKING ROOT IN MAINLAND CHINA (I)

TEXT.P: Quietly and without much fanfare, the "Middle Kingdom," which has embraced an insular view of themselves and the rest of the world, is moving on a way of westernization -- supplanting authoritarian dictates with individual efforts to enhance prosperity.

A Beijing historian specializing on the Ching Dynasty said the country is in a similar situations to that during the reign of Emperor Tungzhi when his regime came to realize the advantages of the West's powerful gunboats and cannons.

The Ching Dynasty used the West's weaponry to put down the rebellion by Hung Xiu-chuan, who founded the short-lived Taiping Heavenly State between 1851-1864, and defeated France in a 1894 war for the control of Vietnam -- which had been a vassal state under the Ching dynasty, according to the historian.

The victory over France in the China-France War encouraged Chinese of that time to study Western ways of building cannons and warships out of cast iron to defend their county, but this trend died out with the collapse of the Ching dynasty in 1911.
NEW BORROWING FROM THE WEST
Mainland China faces a much different world today from the one nearly a century ago. Westernization is now more related to words like "Internet," "Olympics," "APEC," "WTO" and "citizenship."
And for Chinese wanting to tap into the secrets of success in the West, there is one essential ingredient: the ability to speak English.
A good example is Wang Ying, a senior at a leading university in Beijing. He attends an English language cram school five days a week but must pay for tuition by holding down three jobs.

The young man, originally from southern China, said he must work hard because the tuition is very expensive, but there is another reason -- the dream of saving enough money to study abroad in an English-speaking country.

Working three jobs has stretched Wang to the limits of his endurance, but a good command of English, and the possibility of studying in the West -- and the good job that could come his way -- make all the work seem worth it.
"This is what all of my classmates dream of," said the young man.
SUCCESS IS THE GOAL

The leaders of the Chinese Communist government are experiencing the same feelings now that the country, after two decades of "reform and opening," has seen 100 million people out of its 1.3 billion population enter the middle-class, and even the poorest 100 million are not as bad off as in past years, according to the Beijing historian.

Beijing's successful bid to host the 2008 Olympics, its successful hosting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum summit in Shanghai, and the country's admittance to the World Trade Organization, have reinforced the conviction of both the Chinese government and the people of the country that they are moving on the right path -- one that incidentally happen to mirror the West.
Guo Cheng-yuan, a well-known scholar of international relations in Beijing said the modern history of China is in some ways like a helix. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW WESTERNIZATION TAKING ROOT IN MAINLAND CHINA (II)

TEXT.P: In other words, Guo said, modern Chinese history looks as if it is a series of repeating events, but in fact, it is a string of similar causes and effects with different outcomes because of the impact of the particular circumstances of the time.

The scholar said it doesn't take a historian to know that the Westernization campaign during the Ching dynasty was different from the current one. The previous campaign was aimed at strengthening the weak Ching dynasty with western weaponry, but the current changes have less to do with consolidation of the power of the state than with individuals' pursuit of a higher living standard -- or, more precisely, increased personal wealth has become more pressing that defending the country by borrowing technologies from foreign countries.
The current craze to learn English in mainland China is just one symptom of the desire for personal growth -- and a fatter wallet, Guo said.
A ONE-WAY STREET?
Will the current westernization campaign be more successful than the previous one?
"Sure, there is no question about it," a Beijing businessman said who studied overseas when he was a student.

The businessman, surnamed Chang, said unlike the Westernization during the Ching dynasty -- which prompted bitter controversy about how thoroughly the country should copy the Western system -- the current campaign is supported by the whole country from its top leaders to the grassroots level, since the pursuit of a better living is believed to be in the best interests of China.

Chang said that since capitalism has flourished amid the communist government in mainland China, "citizenship" has become a current catch-word among Chinese intellectuals, and is a catalyst for the new campaign.

Citizenship, Chang said, which contains the notion of legal responsibility and rights, is a new idea to Chinese who used to considered themselves as subjects of the state who owed allegiance only to the nation and were expected to follow its leaders with complete obedience.

On the contrary, the idea of being a citizen contains patriotism, but not to the exclusion of all else. A citizen is supposed to demand -- even fight -- for his rights from the government, and wants to have these rights enshrined in law.

A Taiwan businessman in Beijing, surnamed Ni, said he sincerely hopes Beijing's new Westernization campaign will succeed. A country with mature citizens will never go to war over ideological differences, and such a situation promises a peaceful solution to the disputes between Taiwan and mainland China, he said.

Noting that the gross domestic product gap between mainland China and Taiwan is narrowing because of the rapid economic development in mainland China, Ni said the lessening of the relative economic disparity across the Taiwan Strait bodes well for an amicable resolution of so-called "Taiwan issue."

However, a professor at a leading university in Beijing said the Westernization in the Ching dynasty would not have fallen by the wayside if all it demanded was learning English, studying in the West, building skyscrapers, hosting international conferences or doing business in the way of the West.

What mainland China needs now is not cosmetic realizations of "Western progress," but a solid grounding in the rule by law and the establishment of democracy, two elements that will lay the groundwork for the country's sustainable development, the professor said.

Borrowing a remark from the late national leader Liu Shaoqi that China never moves straight forward its goal, but rather it wanders toward it, the professor said anyone who longs for democracy in mainland China should be patient. He said the most populous country in the world may wander for a while longer before finding its true way on the path to real democratization.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG SMUGGLER OF BIBLES TO CHINA SAYS HE HAS NO REGRET

TEXT.P: Hong Kong businessman Lai Kwong-keung, who was sentenced last month to two years in prison by a court at Fuqing city in southeastern Fujian province for smuggling Bibles to China, said here Sunday at a press conference that he had no regret about it.

Lai, whose name is also spelled as Li Guangqiang, was caught by customs officials last year for illegally shipping more than 30,000 copies of the Bible to mainland China. He told the press that he had no regret about it, because he didn't know Chinese customs regulations at that time and because what he wanted to do at that time was to help Christians in China better understand the Bible.
Lai, 39, returned to Hong Kong Saturday soon after Chinese law authorities allowed him to serve his sentence outside prison for medical reasons.

He expressed concern about his two colleagues, who were imprisoned along with him in the same case and are still in prison. He also expressed the hope that China will allow his wife to go to Hong Kong as soon as possible.
At the press conference, Lai thanked President George W. Bush for helping him regain freedom.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Monday are as follows:
@The China Times:
Government to develop Changpin Industrial District on export-processing zone model.
The United Daily News:
Medical subsidies for children under 3 years old to be legalized.
The Liberty Times:
Finance Ministers of the G-7 expect global economic recovery.
The Taiwan Daily:
Ruling and opposition parties are actively soliciting support for a reconsideration vote next week regarding the allocation of the government budget.
The Central Daily News:
Traffic is good on Chinese New Year's Eve.
The China Post:
Taiwan film Web site threatens to reignite chronic IPR debate.
The Taiwan News:
Kuomintang looking to trim away party fat.
The Taipei Times:
Thai laborers strike veins of lottery gold.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ENTITLED TO TAKE PART IN WHO: NEWSPAPER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 10 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Despite Beijing's objection, Taiwan will continue seeking to take part in the World Health Organization (WHO), because the island's 23 million people have the right to fully participate in the body and acquire information through it, the Washington Times reported Sunday.

Quoting Republic of China Department of Health Director-General Lee Ming-liang, the report said Taiwan has offered US$100 million in economic aid to 78 countries over the past seven years, while the ROC government's efforts to eradicate hepatitis-A in Taiwan were also approved by over 70 percent of the Taiwan people.

According to the report, the U. S. House of Representatives passed a resolution last year calling on the administration to support Taiwan to join the WHO as an observer. Former U. S. President Bill Clinton also signed an agreement in Dec. 1999 backing Taiwan's participation at the WHO, but the move provoked strong opposition from Beijing.

A spokesman for the Beijing Embassy was cited as saying that Beijing is opposed to Taiwan's WHO membership because it is an international organization which requires statehood. The Beijing official was also quoted as pointing out that Beijing also opposes Taiwan's joining the WHO as an observer.

Lee said Taiwan will not challenge Beijing's "one China" policy and it just wishes to join the WHO as an observer which requires no statehood. The International Red Cross Society and Palestine Liberalization Organization are WHO observers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VISIT BY MAINLAND PEOPLE POINTS TO EASE IN TENSIONS: MAGAZINE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 10 (CNA) (By Jane Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The first visit to Taiwan by a group of mainland Chinese visitors last week is historically significant for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and is an indication that tensions between both have lessened, according to Times magazine.

According to the report published in the latest edition of the magazine, the visit by 13 mainland Chinese tourists from Japan to Taiwan is important for both Taiwan and mainland China, which have remained under separate rule over the past 50 years.

During their stay in Taiwan last week, the mainland Chinese tourists visited famous tourist spots in Taipei, such as the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, Lungshan Temple and the National Palace Museum, the report said.
The Taiwan authorities decided in November last year to partially open its tourism market to mainland China by allowing mainland Chinese people residing abroad to visit Taiwan as tourists.

The report also said the recent talks by mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen allowing members of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party to mainland China is also a major revelation that cross-strait tensions have eased.
Along with the report was a picture showing the mainland Chinese visitors watching the changing of the guards at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD HIGH ARRIVALS AND DEPARTURES AT CKS AIRPORT

TEXT.P: The number of inbound arrivals and outbound departures at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport hit a record single-day high of 67,790 Saturday, the United Daily News reported Monday.

According to the mass-circulation newspaper, the number was up from Friday's 64,821, which had already exceeded the previous record of 61,334 posted Feb. 21, 1999. The Lunar New Year of the Horse begins Feb. 12.

Citing customs statistics, the report said the number of inbound arrivals has been increasing over the past three days. There were 29,345 arrivals Friday, with the figure rising to 30,253 Saturday and 32,323 estimated for Sunday. Customs officials were cited as attributing the rising inbound arrivals to Taiwan businessmen coming home from mainland China for the new year.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE: CNA WILL SUSPEND ITS CEP SERVICE ON FEB.12 AND FEB. 13
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT IN M'LAND NOT OVERLY OPTIMISTIC FOR 2002: MAC

TEXT.P: The mainland Chinese economic powerhouse may find the going tough in 2002, despite a projected increase in foreign investment, a study released by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said.

International financial experts believe that becuase of the global economic slump, growth in the mainland could be lower than 7 percent this year -- the first time in the past 11 years that the figure has dipped that low, the MAC said.
The study noted that various figures indicate that since last year the mainland has eased inflationary pressures. Overall, consumption last year also picked up over the previous year.

But the slumping stock market signifies the shrinking of mainland people's wealth and in turn has eroded the public's confidence in the market. This and the slow growth of farmers' incomes and the prediction by analysts that the world economy may not rebound as quickly as expected have all dimmed the prospects for the mainland's economy this year.

The study also said that the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States and the world economic slump have seriously affected mainland China's exports. Export growth in the mainland in 2001 was only 6.8 percent -- the lowest level since 1996 -- and the situation is expected to remain stark this year. Mainland Chinese Minister of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Shi Guangsheng had said that the unstable world economy will further impact exports from the mainland and the result could be worse than the situation the country faced in 1997 during the Asian financial crisis.
Losses by state-owned enterprises also continue to rise, spilling more red ink in the financial sector, where the debt reached US$30.2 billion in 2000.
One positive sign is that foreign capital inflow to the mainland is expected to reach a new high of US$61 billion in 2002, the study said.

A study by Harvard University, however, said that foreign investment is not an elixir for sustained development of the mainland economy, noting that those enterprises that do not have sound structures could rapidly fold after losing their competitive edge, especially after mainland China's entry into the World Trade Organization.

Overall, the MAC said that the economic outlook in the mainland this year is not overly optimistic. In addition, mainland China will face uncertain economic and political development in the future, which will pose serious challenges to the leadership and financial navigators of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE-BRAZIL BOY CELEBRATES 1ST CHINESE NEW YEAR IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Iruan Erguiwu, the boy at the center of a custody dispute because of his deceased parents -- a Taiwanese father and Brazilian mother -- had his first taste of a Chinese New Year when he received a lot of red envelopes of money (hungpao) recently.

Su Yi-hua, the boy's name in Chinese, was born out of wedlock. The Brazilian mother had granted custody of the boy to her mother before she died. But the father took the boy back to Taiwan from Brazil in mid-March last year.

After the father also died, the boy was placed in the home of Wu Huo-yuan, the father's younger brother, and thus triggering a fierce custody war between the boy's uncle and his grandmother in Brazil.
The boy, who has already received a residence permit to live in Taiwan, is now registered at his uncle's house in Chiehtin village, Kaohsiung, in southern Taiwan.

Lee Shu-hua, the boy's aunt, said that the boy enjoys living at their house. The boy has already received his national health insurance card and should now be attending primary school, but the relatives, saying that the child's Mandarin skills are not good enough for school and have kept him in kindergarten.
Lee said that this is Yi-hua's first Chinese New Year in Taiwan. Yi-hua has been curious about all the customs of the Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 12 this year, and has asked about them.

Yi-hua was especially surprised about receiving money during the Chinese holiday, which is usually given by elders to youngsters to signify a greeting, because in Brazil nobody exchanges red envelopes with money.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT 'CAUTIOUSLY' OBSERVING LOTTERY FEVER (I)

TEXT.P: The government is adopting a "cautious" attitude toward the current lottery fever that has gripped the nation after sales of the tickets broke the NT$7 billion (US$199.43 million) mark -- with only six drawings having been held so far, local media reports said Monday.

Chen Hsih-meng, secretary-general to the Presidential Office, said he felt that with the lottery only having run for less than a month it was too early to pass judgment on the effects on society the lottery may have, preferring to adopt the same "wait and see" view as the Cabinet.

The Ministry of Finance recently asked Taipei Bank, which sponsors the state-run lottery tickets, to pay special attention to the phenomenon of residents going to extremes to find "magic numbers" at temples and to watch carefully the habits of gamblers. The message was deemed by observers to have a veiled subtext -- watch that the lottery fever does not get out of hand. This has triggering speculation that the ministry may try to find ways to reign in the lottery.

The latest drawing, which will be held Tuesday, or Chinese New Year Day, has attracted betting of over NT$1 billion so far. With a tendency to try one's luck on festive days, it is expected that the amount could hit a new high.

Lee Yuan-tseh, the highly respected president of the Academia Sinica and a Nobel laureate, asked Premier Yu Shyi-kun to keep a close eye on the remarkable effects that the new lottery is having on society and specifically to monitor the seemingly uncontrolled buying of tickets.

Cabinet spokesman Chuang Shou-han said that although it is generally agreed upon that runaway sales of lottery tickets is a serious concern, the Cabinet is still observing events, and has no formal policy on the issue.

One Taipei Bank official, trying to head off worries over the overheated buying by the public, said that the phenomenon would most likely die down in several months -- just like the craze for Portuguese egg-tarts which threw the nation into a buying frenzy a few years ago.
Ting Yu-kang, the president of Taipei Bank, said that lottery tickets are simply a consumer product, and that it is unnecessary to give them any moral significance.
Ting said that to understand more about consumption behavior regarding the lottery, Taipei Bank has commissioned a market survey to learn what segments of society buys lottery tickets and why.
As the lottery is barely a month old, Ting believes that it is too early to conclude that lotto mania has infected the public and needs to be subdued.

Ting said initial surveys have found that people, on average, buy around NT$390 worth of lottery tickets and that much of this is impulse buying. There are very few people who spend NT$10,000 on tickets, for example, said Ting.

He said that the long lines at ticket vendors is not an indication that the lottery is overheated; rather, there are too few booths to satisfy consumer demand. Currently there are 3,200 computerized vending stalls around the island. Ting said that Taipei Bank will increase that number to 5,000 by the end of March, and 8,500 by the end of year.

Meanwhile, a foreign labor rights protection group has expressed concerns about reports that a Thai husband and wife working in a textile plant in northern Taiwan disappeared after winning the first and second prizes of the latest lottery drawing Feb. 8.

A Catholic service center for foreign labor has implored Taipei Bank to keep the identities of the Thai couple confidential, and that the Council of Labor and representative offices for foreign labors come up with regulations to help foreign workers claim prizes and safely return to their countries, if they desire. (By Lilian Wu) (to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT 'CAUTIOUSLY' OBSERVING LOTTERY FEVER (II)

TEXT.P: The Thai couple shared the first prize of NT$524,531,100 (US$14,943,905) with 11 others and the second prize of NT$109,436,958 (US$3,117,862) with 32 others.

After celebrating their win on the factory floor with other Thai workers, the plant management found that the couple had disappeared by morning. The couple had previously offered all the Thai employees that they worked with NT$10,000 each as a gift out of their winnings.
Reports said the Thai couple, who together won more than NT$47 million (US$1.33 million), had gone into hiding and are biding their time until the spotlight is no longer on them.
The couple, who made a monthly salary of about NT$20,000 at a textile plant, reportedly told their friends that they plan to use the money to buy an island in Thailand to start a new life.

Though the company they work for earlier expressed worries about their safety, and ranking officials have been instructed to find the couple, the two notified the company not to bother to find them, saying they would come out in due time to handle the details of ending their employment and returning home.
The company has said that they would arrange for the safe return of the lucky couple.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES NATION TO BE READY FOR CHALLENGES IN NEW YEAR'S MESSAGE

TEXT.P: ROC President Chen Shui-bian urged his fellow countrymen Monday in his Chinese Lunar New Year speech to be ready for all challenges that lie ahead.

In his message released on the eve of the Chinese Lunar New Year, Chen recalled that Taiwan suffered many hardships over the past year, including typhoons that hit the island one after the other and resulted in destructive flooding.
In addition, the terrorist attacks on the United States last Sept. 11 brought down global economic growth and Taiwan has also felt the economic pinch.

However, Taiwan has stood tall in the face of these difficulties because of the wisdom and perseverance on the part of both the people and the government. "We have passed the challenges," the president said.

Chen added, however, that greater challenges and difficulties are waiting for the nation now that Taiwan is a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO). Taiwan was granted full member status on Jan. 1 this year.
WTO membership for Taiwan will mean all-out global competition, which will not only affect trade and economics, but also the fields of science, culture, art and thought, he said.
"We must, in the shortest possible time, make a thorough change, turning ourselves into a 'global individual with a global vision,'" Chen said.
"If we do not change now, we will not be able to find our place in the future global landscape," the president warned.
Chen encouraged the new Cabinet, which was sworn in Feb. 1, to complete cross-the-board reforms as soon as possible to further buttress Taiwan's foundation.

"Only by doing this can Taiwan take advantage of the opportunity at the very moment that the global economy begins to rebound. In this way we will be confidently telling the world community: We are ready, we are coming."
The president also wished his fellow countrymen a prosperous and peaceful Year of the Horse.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 14, or the third day of the first month of the Year of the Horse according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1766: Thomas R. Malthus, the British economist who wrote "An Essay on the Principle of Population," is born. His 1798 work argues that populations tend to increase faster than food supplies unless the increase is checked by moral restraints or by war, famine or disease.
1779: Captain James Cook, the British navigator and explorer who commanded three major voyages of "discovery," charting and "naming" many islands in the Pacific Ocean, is killed by a native's spear in Hawaii.
1797: British naval forces under Adm. John Jervis and Capt. Horatio Nelson defeat the Spanish fleet off Portugal's Cape St. Vincent.
1859: Oregon becomes the 33rd state of the United States.
1893: Hawaii is annexed by the United States by a treaty.
1912: Arizona becomes the 48th state of the United States.
1924: Thomas John Watson, the U.S. industrialist who worked for the National Cash Register Company (now NCR Corporation) for 15 years, is made president of a company that later becomes International Business Machines Corporation (IBM).
1933: The League of Nations refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet regime known as "Manchukuo." To deflect world condemnation of their hegemony, the Japanese invaders of northern China installed the Manchukuo regime in 1932. This "land of the Manchu" proved to be no more than another stepping stone for the extension of Japanese aggression.
1939: The German battleship Bismarck is launched.
1950: The Communist Chinese regime and the Soviet Union sign the "Sino-Soviet Friendly Alliance and Mutual Assistance Treaty" in Moscow.
1956: Soviet President Nikita Khrushchev denounces the policies of Joseph Stalin at the 20th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party.
1962: Gen. Hu Chung-nan, strategic adviser to President Chiang Kai-shek, dies in Taipei at the age of 68.
1972: Mexico establishes diplomatic relations with mainland China.
1972: The Soviet Union launches its Luna 20 spacecraft to the moon.
1972: Washington relaxes trade restrictions against Beijing, putting it on the same basis as Moscow.
1973: Walter Benche Medina, newly-appointed ambassador of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1974: A six-member Jordanian trade mission led by S.A. Matouk, president of the Amman Chamber of Commerce, arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1975: The Marinas Islands in the Pacific becomes a territory of the United States.
1977: Shih Wei-liang, a noted Republic of China musician, dies in Taipei at the age of 54.
1989: Ayatollah Khomeini, Iran's religious leader, issues a "fatwa," or death sentence, against British writer Salman Rushdie for what he deemed to be blasphemy in the author's book "The Satanic Verses," sending him into years of hiding.
1999: Former Nixon White House aide John Ehrlichman dies at the age of 73. He served 18 months in prison for his role in the Watergate cover-up.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of the Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Cor Boonstra, president of Royal Philips Electronics, in recognition of his company's contributions to Taiwan's economic development.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian says that he will visit Beijing and invite mainland Chinese leaders to visit Taipei if he wins the March 18 election.
2001: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announces the resumption of construction on Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant, ending a protracted standoff between his Cabinet and the opposition-dominated Legislature over the project.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Earnestness without judgment becomes pedantry; caution without judgment becomes timidity; courage without judgment leads to crime; uprightness without judgment makes men tyrannical."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CHILD POPULATION DWINDLING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's child population has been dwindling steadily in recent years, with its ratio to the island's total population dropping to 16.58 percent by the end of last June, according to government tallies.

Statistics compiled by the Children's Bureau under the Ministry of the Interior showed that the number of those aged under 12 totaled about 3.85 million at the end of 1996, but had fallen to 3.71 million as of the end of June 2001.
In percentage terms, those aged under 12 accounted for 17.86 percent of Taiwan's total population at the end of 1996, plunging to 16.56 percent by the end of last June.
The statistics further indicated that the number of children younger than six had declined to slightly more than 1.76 million as of June 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE GOV'T TO TAP FOREIGN ESTABLISHMENTS IN JOB CORPS PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The Philippine Department of Labor and Employment (DOLE) and the Commission on Higher Education (CHED) are working out a training program that would help generate one million jobs in 2002, as pledged by President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo.
In a report to Malacanang, Labor Secretary Patricia Sto. Tomas said that the DOLE is now tapping the academic world as a major element in the Job Corps program of the government.

Sto. Tomas said the DOLE and CHED will soon finalize a working arrangement with some local schools and foreign governments to enable Filipino students to train at foreign establishments and institutions.
She said the arrangement would be formalized with the signing of Memorandums of Agreement (MOAs) with at least eight schools offering courses in nursing and hotel and restaurant management.

Teresita Manzala, director of DOLE's Bureau of Local Employment, said consultations were ongoing on the forging of agreements with nursing schools like the University of the Philippines-Manila, the University of Santo Tomas, St. Louis University-Baguio, St. Paul University-Cagayan, St. Paul University-Iloilo, Silliman University in Dumaguete City, Liceo de Cagayan and San Pedro College.

She said the DOLE and CHED have discussed with the U.S. Embassy education attache an overseas training program in the United States for nursing interns, adding that U.S. officials appeared to be receptive to the program.

Aside from the nursing internship program, Manzala said the DOLE and CHED are also pushing for other training programs in the United States and Canada for outstanding hotel and restaurant senior students.

The DOLE has already signed a memorandum of agreement with 14 maritime training schools, manning and training agencies on the deployment of maritime apprentices, cadets and learners on board ocean-going vessels. Sto. Tomas said the agreement is meant to hone the skills of student mariners and help them meet the upgraded standard training certification and watch-keeping requirements.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PHILIPPINE GOV'T PROGRAM TO HELP OVERSEAS FILIPINO WORKERS

TEXT.P: Thousands of Overseas Filipino Workers (OFWs) stand to benefit from a Philippine government program that will provide them with medical and counseling services.

Recognizing the need to augment social services for OFWs, the departments of Labor and Employment, Health, and Social Welfare and Development signed a memorandum of agreement Tuesday that established the Overseas Comprehensive Social Service Package (OCSSP).
Labor Secretary Patricia A. Sto. Tomas, Health Secretary Manuel M. Dayrit and Social Welfare Secretary Corazon J. Soliman signed the agreement at a simple ceremony at Malacanang's Premier Guesthouse.
The OCSSP, initiated and coordinated by the Labor Department, will institute coordinated responses, focused on medical and counseling services, packaged to cater to the specific needs of OFWs.

The program will augment existing services, such as legal and emergency housing, for distressed OFWs. Under the program, social workers and medical practitioners seconded to the labor department will be deployed to overseas posts, initially in Riyadh and Jeddah in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, as well as to Kuwait, Singapore and Hong Kong.
They will complement Department of Foreign Affairs and Overseas Workers Welfare Administration personnel in serving OFWs on-site at Filipino Workers Resource and Development Centers.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SENATOR INITIATES NEW BILL SUPPORTING ROC'S WHO BID
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 13 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. Senator Robert G. Torricelli (D-N.J.) came up with a bill Tuesday demanding that the Bush administration help Taiwan obtain observer status at this year's World Health Organization (WHO) annual conference scheduled for May.
Senate sources said Wednesday the content of the Torricelli-authored bill is the same as that of one passed by the House of Representatives last December.

Both bills express full support for the Republic of China's bid to join the Geneva-based organization as an observer and authorize the U.S. secretary of state to draw up a comprehensive plan to help Taiwan realize this goal at the 2002 WHO annual conference.

The Torricelli-drafted bill also demands that the secretary of state present a written report containing the above-mentioned action plan to Congress within two weeks after the bill clears the Senate floor.

The House approved the Rep. Sherrod Brown-initiated bill in mid-December last year. The bill was then referred to the Senate for deliberation. However, the Senate has so far not listed the bill in its agenda.

Against this backdrop, Sen. Torricelli decided to present a new bill with exactly the same content as the House version. Congressional sources said Torricelli is seeking Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Joseph Biden's (D-Del.) consent to have the bill brought up directly for Senate discussion and approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER YU TO MEET MAJOR MAINLAND-BASED TAIWAN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun will attend a lunch meeting with senior executives of major Taiwanese trade associations in mainland China Feb. 21 to seek their opinions about the development of economic relations across the Taiwan Strait.
This will be the first direct encounter between Yu and mainland China-based Taiwanese business and industry executives since Yu assumed office Feb. 1.

The meeting will be jointly organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) and the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) as part of the Chinese New Year celebrations, government sources said Thursday.

The meeting is also expected to serve as a major conduit for senior government officials to exchange views with mainland China-based Taiwanese business people on cross-strait trade and economic issues.
In addition to Yu, Minister of Economic Affairs Christine Tsung, MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu will also address the meeting.

Trade sources said the business community is paying close attention to the upcoming meeting as local industrial heavyweights are keenly waiting for Yu's Cabinet to announce whether it will allow them to set up 8-inch wafer manufacturing plants and upstream petrochemical facilities in mainland China.
"We hope to know whether Yu is likely to take advantage of the lunch meeting to announce any major government policy goals or directions," a CNFI executive said.

Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. Chairman Morris Chang said earlier this month that the government should decide on major cross-strait investment policies as soon as possible. Fresh from a visit to major mainland Chinese industrial parks in the Shanghai area, Chang also criticized the previous "no haste, be patient" mainland investment policy, saying that too much government interference with economic activities would only stymie business vitality.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT GEARING UP FOR FUNDING BATTLE

TEXT.P: With a legislative vote on a Cabinet move to overturn the newly revised government budget allocation law drawing near, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is stepping up preparations for the upcoming showdown with the ruling party.

KMT legislative caucus whip Lin Yi-shih said Thursday that the caucus is scheduled to call a news conference Friday morning to pledge its determination to veto the Cabinet motion to overturn the amendment bill to the Law Governing Government Revenues and Expenditures.

"We'll present a package of figures and other data at the news conference to back our claim that all city and county governments around our country will get more money from the Tax Redistribution Fund under the revised budget allocation law," Lin explained.

The Legislative Yuan passed the revisions to the tax revenues redistribution law, authored by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, a KMT stalwart, on Jan. 18, but the Cabinet filed a proposal Feb. 6 asking the Legislature to reconsider the revisions before the amendment bill took effect.

Lin said his party will invite mayors and magistrates of all KMT-controlled cities and counties to a meeting Friday afternoon to discuss the controversial funding issue and work out effective strategy to uphold the Ma-initiated allocation revisions.

"Friday is the first work day for government agencies after the Chinese New Year holiday. We must start our lobbying drive on the same day to underscore our determination to win the 'funding battle,'" Lin stressed.

On Saturday, Lin said, the party's policy coordination commission will invite KMT mayors and magistrates as well as KMT legislators who once served as local government chiefs to further discuss feasible "winning strategy."

In addition to mobilizing all KMT legislators to vote against the Cabinet's motion for reconsideration, Lin said, the party will also use every possible means and channels to help all social quarters understand that the Ma-authored new tax revenues allocation law can really help resolve local governments' financial problems.
However, the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) expressed doubts about the reasonability and feasibility of the new allocation law.

DPP legislative whip Tsai Huang-lang said he would not like to see the issue become a partisan feud. "The KMT should let its lawmakers vote on their own discretion through rational and professional discussion."

Tsai said he is convinced that if the KMT allow its lawmakers to vote freely, many of them would vote against the Ma-authored version as its allocation formula is impractical under the current government fiscal situation.

Under the revised allocation law, Tsai said, the central government will have to blow up the base of the tax redistribution fund, so that local governments can receive more money. "But a bigger tax redistribution funding base obviously means a cut into other spending," he noted, adding that the central government will have to slash its subsidies to local governments for education and social welfare programs in order to allow for increased tax redistribution funds.

The Legislature is scheduled to vote on the Cabinet's motion to overturn the newly passed revision bill Feb. 19. To override the motion, the opposition camp need to mobilize 113 votes. The KMT, which controls 68 seats in the 225-member Legislature, will have to seek the support of the People First Party (PFP), which controls 45 seats. The PFP has yet to announce its stance on the funding dispute.

DOC.HEADLINE: LUCKY THAI COUPLE TO RETURN TO BANGKOK WITH TAIWAN LOTTO JACKPOT
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Feb. 14 (CNA) (By F. C. Kuo and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A married Thai couple, who hit double scoop in Taiwan's recently launched computerized lottery last week, are scheduled to return to Bangkok Feb. 18, a senior Thai labor official said Thursday.

The Thai couple, identified as Anek Madon and his wife Oramuch Madon, will be accompanied by their Taiwan employer and Thai officials stationed in Taipei on their homecoming flight, the official said.

The Madons, who just completed their two-year working contracts with a Hsinchu textile plant in northern Taiwan, won the first and second prizes in the sixth issue of Taiwan's computerized lottery drawn on Feb. 8.

The couple shared the jackpot of NT$524,531,100 (US$1,494,390) with 11 others, in addition to sharing the second prize of NT$109,436,958 (US$311,786) together with 32 others. They were the first foreign workers to win the top prize in the popular state-sponsored cash game.

A senior official with the Thai Labor Ministry said his ministry will help the couple seek the Thai government's approval to exempt them from tax payment as they have helped increase the country's foreign exchange stash.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE SHIPS OF TAIWAN MARINE COMPANIES FLYING FOREIGN NATIONAL FLAGS

TEXT.P: More and more ships of Taiwan-based marine corporations have been switching the national flag they fly out of convenience, with less than 20 percent currently flying the Republic of China flag, according to a Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) official.

The official said that the Evergreen Marine Corp.'s recent announcement that at least half of its fleet will fly the British or Italian national flag has arisen concerns which have been brewing for many years that increasing numbers of local shipping companies are switching the flags they fly on their vessels for convenience.

MOTC statistics showed that in 1992, 24.4 percent of the shipping liners of Taiwan-based shipping companies were flying the ROC national flag, while by 2000, only 16.8 percent were flying the national flag.

An executive of the Republic of China Marine Business Association said the maritime transportation sector has felt that it has not been treated as an important production sector by the government despite the fact the island is an export-oriented economy.
The transportation sector has been granted fewer investment incentives and less preferential treatment in terms of taxes, according to the executive.

He said that in order to encourage local shipping firms to have more of their vessels fly the ROC national flag, the MOTC should coordinate with other government departments in thoroughly reviewing and revising the Maritime Law.

He suggested that the government provide more preferential tax treatment to the sector on the one hand, while on the other relaxing restrictions regarding the recruitment of mariners and direct shipping links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT PUBLICIZES LIST OF NEWLY-APPROVED IMPORTS FROM M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) publicized Friday the list of some additional 2,000 items of products from mainland China that last month were allowed to be directly imported into Taiwan.

The BOFT list of 2,058 products -- mostly raw materials for manufacturing industries -- marked the largest number of items from across the Taiwan Strait to be allowed in since Taiwan became a full member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) on the first day of this year.

The BOFT made known the latest import list following approval by the Executive Yuan on Jan. 16 of newly-revised trade policies that allow direct trade between Taiwan and mainland China, direct imports of mainland products to Taiwan and new control systems responsible for monitoring imports from mainland China.

The latest list of 2,058 items increased the number of products that Taiwan allows to be directly imported from mainland China to 7,946 -- equal to 75 percent of what is desirable under the WTO framework.

The Executive Yuan approved an import list of 2,126 products from mainland China on Jan. 16. But the BOFT temporarily shelved 68 products on the grounds that some of them are finished products that if imported might pose threats to their domestically-produced Taiwan counterparts. The 68 products included confectionery, grains, feedstuffs, edible salt and natural sand.

In the future, the BOFT will conduct a routine review every two months on the mainland Chinese imports, and cross-division meetings will be held every six months to fully monitor the imports from across the Taiwan Strait, BOFT Director-General Wu Wen-ya said.

Together with the latest BOFT-publicized list was another announcement that the BOFT may take "relief" steps, including restricting the volume of the imports, if any imported mainland Chinese products are found upon review to have caused major interferences in the Taiwan market, Wu said.
The Executive Yuan also proposed on Jan. 16 that Taiwan allow funds from mainland China to be invested in Taiwan's service industry sector, including the domestic real estate and housing market.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is aiming to open Taiwan to all mainland Chinese industrial products except for about 100 items that concern national security, national defense and the military preparedness of Taiwan. The opening will take place over four years in three stages, according to Executive Yuan officials.

Household electrical appliances, such as refrigerators and television sets which could be competitive in terms of price against their Taiwan-made counterparts, are not included on the latest list, MOEA officials said.

Of the nearly 900 categories of mainland Chinese agricultural products on the list, citrus fruits, grapes, peaches, apples, papayas, whole ducks, turkeys, and squid will be allowed to be freely imported, while other items, including pears, betel nuts, chicken meat, bottled milk, mackerel, dried mushrooms, coconuts, bananas, pineapples, mangoes, dried longan and dried day lily, will be allowed to be imported under a quota system, according to Council of Agriculture (COA) officials.

Since mainland China is still designated as a foot-and-mouth disease affected area, the import of cloven-hoofed animals, including pigs, cattle, goats and sheep -- and their meat -- will remain banned, COA officials said.
Other noted agricultural products, such as potatoes, guavas and oranges, will also remain banned because those crops in mainland China have reportedly been affected by diseases, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.021 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at NT$35.101.
The local currency opened Friday at NT$35.118 and was traded between NT$35.025 and NT$35.156.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$470 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN REMAINS UNCHANGED: RICE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 14 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: U.S policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged, and according to the Taiwan Relations Act, Washington will dutifully help Taiwan defend itself, U.S. National Security Adviser Condoleezza Rice said Thursday.

Rice said the U.S. policy toward Taiwan is clear and definite, namely that the United States is against any changes to the status quo in the Taiwan Strait by either side and that both sides of the strait should resolve their differences peacefully.
She made the remarks Thursday during a press conference held at the White House mainly on the upcoming weeklong three-nation Asian trip by U.S. President George W. Bush slated to begin Saturday.
Bush is set to visit Beijing next Thursday and Friday after stops in Tokyo and Seoul.

During his stay in Beijing, President Bush has "no planned meeting" with Chinese Vice President Hu Jintao, whom it has been widely speculated will be the appointed successor to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, according to Rice.
"We don't have plans to meet separately with him. It may well be that they will see each other in some form," she said.

Bush's Feb. 16-22 trip to Japan, South Korea and mainland China is an important opportunity for the United States to "articulate and demonstrate that our strategic interests in the region are remarkably deep, diverse and enduring," Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs James Kelly said Thursday.

President Bush will discuss the fight against international terrorism, regional concerns, and bilateral issues during each stop on his trip, Kelly said in a prepared statement made before the House International Relations Subcommittee on East Asia and the Pacific.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T COFFERS COULD BE TOPPED UP BY NT$30 B. A YEAR FROM LOTTO SALES

TEXT.P: The nation's coffers could be topped up by up to NT$30 billion (US$0.86 billion) a year from state-run lottery sales if the recent frenzy in lottery ticket buying continues, Vice Finance Minister Chang Hsiu-lian said Friday.

Chang said the government could make NT$30 billion (US$0.86 billion) annually from the computerized lottery, including tax revenue and profits, if the Ministry of Finance's goal of NT$100 billion (US$2.86 billion) in lottery ticket sales a year islandwide is attained.
He added that judging from the hot sales over the past several weeks, overall lotto sales for the year might exceed that goal.
The vice finance minister, however, noted that sales might also drop in later months if the buying craze subsides.

Taipei Bank launched Taiwan's first computerized lottery on Jan. 16 together with three other kinds of scratch-and-win lottery tickets in a government program to help raise funds for the government as well as for charity purposes.

Lottery ticket sales for the first drawing of the computerized lotto on Jan. 22 reached NT$776 million, with sales gradually increasing over the past several weeks to over NT$2 billion for the seventh drawing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER STRESSES PRINCIPLE OF FAIRNESS IN ALLOCATION OF FINANCES

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday the reason the Executive Yuan has submitted a motion to the Legislative Yuan requesting that it "reconsider" and "discuss" the revised finance allocation law is so that the issue is settled based on the principles of fairness and transparency.

On the first working day after the Lunar New Year holidays, Premier Yu reiterated his concern regarding the motion which was submitted to the Legislative Yuan Feb. 6 and will face a legislative vote Feb. 19.

The revised allocation was approved by the previous Legislature during its last session in January. Although it is only scheduled to take effect from the start of fiscal 2003, the Executive Yuan said that it finds implementing the revised allocation law too difficult due to a possible financial shortfall of NT$150 billion caused by the revision.
The Premier said the Executive Yuan is asking the Legislature to think over whether the revision is beneficial to the balanced development of Taiwan's cities and counties.

Referring to Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's role as a major promoter of the revision in the law, Premier Yu said metaphorically that the finance allocation must not be the lone decision of the "eldest brother" and that each of the 25 "brothers" (cities and counties) in the "family" should have a say.

Responding to Premier Yu's statement, Mayor Ma said that the revised law takes into consideration the welfare of "all brothers and sisters" and is meant to fulfill President Chen Shui-bian's election campaign promise of allowing local governments more freedom in their financial management.

The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called for a press conference Friday morning to explain the ruling party's position. Tsai Huang-liang, secretary-general of the DPP Caucus in the Legislative Yuan, reiterated the party's concern that the Executive Yuan will not be able to make both ends meet under the revised allocation law.
While calling for all the DPP legislators to support the administration, Tsai said that the DPP will not use party discipline to confine its members on an issue of public policy.

Since the revised law was approved by the previous Kuomintang (KMT)-majority Legislature, the KMT, which is the largest opposition party in the current Legislature, is resolute that the Legislative Yuan will not pass the motion Feb. 19.

At the weekly meeting of the Central Standing Committee Feb. 6, KMT Chairman Lien Chan gave the directive that all KMT legislators must be mobilized to block the motion. Lien will call for a KMT caucus meeting at the Legislative Yuan in the evening of Feb. 18.

Lin Yi-shih, secretary-general of the KMT Caucus, also called on legislators of other parties to support the KMT position. He pointed out that the motion is nothing but a "political gesture" by the DPP. The administration can request further revisions to the allocation law if it is necessary instead of having to overturn the revised law.
To override the motion for reconsideration, the opposition parties need to mobilize 113 votes.
Lin Feng-cheng, secretary-general of the KMT Central Committee, convened a meeting of mayors and magistrates of KMT-ruled cities and counties Friday afternoon to discuss measures against the motion.

The National Policy Foundation, a KMT think tank, is calling for a public hearing Saturday morning. Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, Lin Chuan, who is the director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, and Lin's predecessor Wei Duan will discuss with scholars and specialists the issue of the proper distribution of public finances.

While the KMT is gearing up for the battle, the People First Party (PFP) has remained undecided on the issue. Chin Huei-chu, deputy convener of the PFP Caucus, said the party caucus will reach a resolution Feb. 18, although a preliminary opinion survey among PFP legislators shows that more than half will choose to block the motion first and submit a new revised version for discussion thereafter.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS FOR RECONCILIATION AMONG PARTIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Friday called for reconciliation among Taiwan's political parties to help secure peace and stability in the nation's politics.

In a group greeting ceremony held at the Presidential Office after the Chinese New Year holidays, Chen said he hopes that during this new year, peace and harmony will replace bickering and confrontation between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition parties.

Chen said because of everybody's hard work, the nation and the people survived many challenges last year. In the new year, he said, "we have to work even harder, because the new challenges will neither be fewer nor milder than last year's."
In the face of increasingly harsh competition in the international arena, Chen said, "we have no time to hesitate and no resources to waste."
Only by pooling together the will and efforts of the entire nation's people can Taiwan move ahead and not be left behind in the global competition, Chen said.

Also speaking at the ceremony, Vice President Annette Lu said that in the new year, Taiwan faces five major challenges in the areas of the environment, the economy, politics, society and ethics, all of which will severely test the wisdom and confidence of the people of Taiwan.
Lu said in order to tide over these challenges, the nation should first consolidate its leadership so that the people can regain their confidence in the government.
Most importantly, she said, the people should seek to bolster brotherhood and compassion among each other.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI BANK WILL WIND UP POPULAR LOTTERY IF ORDERED: BANK OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: TAIPEIBANK will wind up the recently launched government-sponsored lottery if and when ordered to do so by regulators, a manager for the bank was quoted as saying Saturday after Vice President Annette Lu denounced the lottery as a "social landslide."

Yang Jui-tung, the manager for the lottery organized by TAIPEIBANK, said his bank will stop running the lottery if the government gives the order, according to a report in the China Times Express Saturday.
He also told the newspaper the bank has already withdrawn a television commercial which boasts the lottery as a way of converting papaya seeds into caviar, which has a similar appearance.
Instead of encouraging the purchase of lottery tickets, Yang said, his bank will focus future advertisements for the lottery on its contributions to social welfare.
The lottery has enthralled people around the island since it was launched Jan. 16, with people waiting in long lines to purchase tickets.

The enthusiasm stirred up by the lottery has drawn fire from critics who claim it is encouraging gambling and the idea of getting rich quick instead of through hard work. Underground lotteries have also begun using the winning numbers of the lottery to choose their winners.
Annette Lu represents the most prominent figure who has criticized the lottery with her "social landslide" comments.

Her remarks have led to speculation that the government may backpedal on its approval of the lottery as was done in 1990 when the government at the time ordered TAIPEIBANK to put a halt to a similar lottery after only three drawings.
The present lottery has been so popular that many venders have run out of the special paper used to print the tickets before Saturday.

Yang Jui-tung said Saturday that the paper shortage could not be relieved until next week as all the bank's paper which was expected to last six months has already been used up in a single month and the next consignment of paper imported by the bank will not arrive until next week.
The bank is mulling over whether to change the computer program to allow for five bets per single ticket, but such a change would take at least one month to carry out, Yang said.

He estimated that about one-tenth of the 2000 to 3000 lottery ticket venders have run out of the paper for printing the tickets, but local newspapers have reported that about one-fifth of the venders have suffered shortages of the paper, with each vender sustaining losses of about NT$20,000 per day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO CONTINUE IN EFFORTS TO JOIN WHO: HEALTH DEP'T HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 15 (CNA) (By David Wang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue in its efforts to join the World Health Organization (WHO), Taiwan's top health policy planner said Friday in New York.
Lee Ming-liang, head of the Republic of China's Cabinet-level Department of Health, made the remark while being interviewed by the German press agency Deutsche Presse-Agentur (DPA).

He said that Taiwan meets all the requirements for joining the organization and has the resources to help solve other countries' health issues, adding that "joining the WHO is a fundamental right of the 23 million people of Taiwan."
Because of mainland China's opposition, Taiwan has only been seeking to become a WHO observer instead of a full member. At present, the Geneva-based WHO has 191 members, including mainland China.
The WHO holds an assembly each May, and mainland China has each year consistently obstructed proposals put forth for granting Taiwan entry into the organization as an observer.

Lee said that Taiwan will continue in its efforts this year to become a WHO observer. Although the United States has not openly supported Taiwan in achieving this goal, it has also not stated that it will not support it, he noted.
He said Taiwan hopes to join the WHO "on the basis of pure humanity" because "being part of such an international organization will not only help many other countries, it will also benefit Taiwan."
He pointed out that Taiwan spends more than US$100 million annually on aid to dozens of countries, including the sending of medical care experts to these countries to help solve health issues.

However, he added that Taiwan's medical care experts stationed abroad, especially in those countries that do no have diplomatic relations with Taiwan, do not yet have the same protections provided by international conventions that are enjoyed by United Nations personnel.
Only by Taiwan joining the WHO can the island's medical care experts be put under the same protections, Lee said, adding that Taiwan needs the WHO and the WHO needs Taiwan.

Lee told the DPA that 90 percent of the people of Taiwan are covered by the island's national health care system, a figure that is second only to Sweden in terms of the percentage of a nation's population receiving such coverage.

Because Taiwan has not been admitted into the United Nations, it cannot quickly receive aid from abroad, according to the DPA report, which cited the disastrous earthquake that hit Taiwan in 1999 when reluctance on the part of Beijing to allow relief aircraft to use its airspace meant aid materials were unable to quickly reach quake-stricken areas.
Lee is scheduled to depart for Taipei Friday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY TO GET ITS FIRST MOVIE THEME PARK

TEXT.P: A movie theme park, the first of its kind in Taiwan, is expected to appear in downtown Taipei in the next two years, sources with Taipei City Government's Bureau of Cultural Affairs said Saturday.

Taipei City Government will earmark NT$32 million (US$914,286) over two years for the construction of the park, which will be located at the intersection of Kangting Road and Wuchang Street at Hsimenting, the sources said.
The first-phase installations of the park are slated to be completed by late this year, the sources added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE SPEAKER OF LEGISLATURE CALLS FOR ROC-JAPAN FREE TRADE PACT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 16 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The vice president of the Republic of China Legislative Yuan said Saturday that Japan should enter into a free trade agreement with Taiwan, just as it did with Singapore.

In an interview published in the Saturday edition of Japan's Nihon Keizai Shimbun, P. K. Chiang, the former ROC economics minister, said such a pact, preferably including South Korea and Hong Kong, would significantly reduce costs for Japan's manufacturing industry.

He said that compared to their Japanese counterparts, Taiwan businesspeople are more accustomed to mainland Chinese trade practices, adding that closer cooperation with Taiwan businesspeople would help Japanese businesspeople to venture into the market of mainland China, which operates more by the rule of administrators than by the rule of law, which often confounds Japanese traders who are used to the latter.

The former ROC government's chief economist prescribed two kinds of medicine for Japan which, like Taiwan, has been suffering from a hollowing-out of its industry with many domestic companies relocating their manufacturing operations overseas.

The two remedies for Japan he mentioned were the upgrading of its technology to churn out products with higher added-value, and the improving of its research and development capabilities as well as of its capability of exploring new markets to sustain its status as one of the logistics centers in Asia.

Hong Kong has held its own with other cities in the region by maintaining itself as a center of logistics, while Taiwan has had an advantage over Hong Kong in terms of research and development as well as manufacturing.
A free trade pact with Hong Kong and Taiwan would offer Japan a valuable opportunity to exploit the competitive edges of these two regions for its own benefit, Chiang continued.

He blamed Japan's mismanagement of its bubble economy for the exodus of many of its companies, which has in turn worsened the country's economy, not to mention the effects of the emergence of the mainland Chinese economy which has attracted huge amounts of investment.
Taiwan has been plagued by the same problems over the last year or two, Chiang noted, adding that a free trade pact with Japan would help stem the outflow of capital and business in both places.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN UNCHANGED: U.S. NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISER

TEXT.P: White House National Security Adviser Condoleezza Rice on Thursday ruled out a major restatement on U.S. policy toward Taiwan during President George W. Bush's trip to Beijing next week, saying America's policy is "very clear" and unchanged.
"The United States doesn't want to see any unilateral change in the status quo (across the Taiwan Strait)," Rice said in response to a question during a special briefing on the president's trip.

She said that cross-strait issues should be resolved peacefully by both sides of the strait and that the United States has certain obligations under the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act to help Taiwan defend itself.

"Those are the cornerstones of American policy toward Taiwan," she pointed out, adding that this "has not changed, and I don't think it needs particularly to be restated (during the president's trip)," she added.
The comments came as President Bush prepares to leave on Saturday for a weeklong tour to Northeast Asia, with scheduled stops in Beijing as well as in Tokyo and Seoul.

Earlier in the day, a senior State Department official said that Bush will reiterate to the mainland Chinese leadership a "strong interest in a candid, cooperative and constructive relationship that reflects fully American ideals and values".

James Kelly, the assistant secretary of state for Asia and the Pacific, told a congressional hearing that in addition to discussing the war on terrorism, Bush will during his visit try to expand common ground with mainland China in critical areas.

The areas for possible cooperation include fighting the illicit drug trade and the trafficking in people. Kelly also said that the U.S. side will "speak frankly with Chinese leaders about our differences on issues such as non-proliferation and human rights".
At the White House briefing, Rice said that the United States also wants to engage Beijing on issues of strategic nuclear policy.

Bush will tell Beijing's leaders that the U.S. missile defense program "is not aimed at anybody, it is not intended to give the United States unilateral advantage, and all peace-loving countries should be comfortable" with the program, she said.

The president will arrive in Beijing on Feb. 21 after stops in Tokyo and Seoul. Highlights of Bush's visit to Beijing will include meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Premier Zhu Rongji, delivering a speech at Chinghwa University, and touring the Great Wall.

This will be Bush's second trip to mainland China in four months. He was in Shanghai in October for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation informal leadership summit. At the time, he was scheduled to visit Beijing as well as the Japanese and South Korean capitals, but the trip was cut short because of the war in Afghanistan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISPUTE OVER BUDGET SIMMERING

TEXT.P: A war over how to divide revenues between the central and local governments was simmering Saturday with both the ruling and opposition parties going out of their way to canvass support for their positions.

The lawmakers of the leading opposition Kuomintang (KMT), which initiated and pushed through a change to the existing rules governing the allocation of revenues among the various governments during the last session of the previous Legislature in January, fanned out across the island Saturday to gain support for a rejection of the Executive Yuan's request for a cancellation of the revision which gives local governments a bigger share of revenue.

Claiming the revision will give local governments more financial resources without damaging the central government's ability to carry out its policies, the KMT organized a symposium on the issue Saturday to press home its case.

Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou of the KMT, who asked KMT lawmakers to come up with a revision, said at the symposium that by suggesting a change in the allocation of finances, he was only trying to fulfill President Chen Shui-bian's campaign promise of giving more power and money to local governments.
The KMT, which now controls 68 seats in the 225-seat Legislature, needs to marshal 113 votes to override the Executive Yuan's request for reconsideration.
Meanwhile the ruling Democratic Progressive Party is lobbying independent lawmakers to rally behind the Executive Yuan in its push to annul the revisions.
Another opposition party, the People First Party (PFP), which had helped the KMT to pass the revisions, is expected to come to a decision on its stance in a meeting Monday.
Political analysts said the PFP, which has 46 legislative seats, is likely to unite with the KMT in rejecting the reconsideration.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOVES SHOULD BE MADE TO REDRESS HOW LOTTERY IS OPERATED: V.P. LU
