TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Sunday that the public should refrain from overindulging in the recently launched government-supported lottery, saying that it has caused a "social landslide."
However, Lu noted that she has no intention of seeing to it that the lottery, operated by TAIPEIBANK and designed to help the government raise funds in part for disadvantaged groups, is suspended.
The vice president made the remarks while speaking at a ceremony marking the opening of the 13-story Buddhist Cheng Te Cultural and Educational Building in Taipei to use.
Lu said that the people should speak, behave and earn money with a good conscience and that they should not get lost in what she called a "political, economic, cultural and social mudslide."

Several other prominent political figures also attended the ceremony, including Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, Vice Minister of the Interior Hsu Ying-shen and Legislative Yuan members Chen Hsueh-sheng and Chin Hui-chu.
Lu told reporters later that the lottery, which was launched several weeks ago, has had a negative impact on society, adding that moves should be taken to redress how it is operated.
She also urged the media to report on the lottery in a composed and objective manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T PROMOTES COMPREHENSIVE LICENSING SYSTEM FOR FINANCIAL WORKERS

TEXT.P: The government plans to issue new executive orders requiring certain financial industry professionals such as credit analysts to undergo examinations and obtain licenses, Minister of Finance Lee Yung-san said Sunday.
Lee said that several banks in Taiwan have already carried out such a policy internally, and that he hopes all domestic banks will follow.

The move will help establish a comprehensive professional licensing system for Taiwan's financial industry, which already requires its securities, trust, monetary, futures and insurance professionals to undergo examinations and licensing, Lee said.
An appropriate and reasonably long grace period will be given for the banks to adapt to the new measure, which is currently being discussed and formulated at the ministry, he added.

Speaking on the challenges and opportunities of the financial industry at a seminar on the management and development of financial holding companies, Lee said that his ministry will try to liberalize the operational aspects of the industry as much as possible while encouraging innovation.
However, Lee added that his ministry will work to strengthen the financial management and risk management aspects to provide stability and efficiency for the industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAYAN PRESIDENT MAY VISIT ROC IN MAY

TEXT.P: Paraguayan President Luis Angel Gonzalez Macchi has expressed the hope that he can visit the Republic of China sometime this May, a senior official of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Sunday.

Yeh Ming-feng, secretary general of the CEPD, said that the Paraguayan head of state made the remark recently while receiving a ROC mission serving as an economic advisory mission to the Paraguayan government.
Yeh said that President Gonzalez attached great importance to the ROC economic advisory mission, meeting twice with members of the mission.
During his meetings with the mission in Asuncion, President Gonzalez repeatedly expressed his gratitude to the ROC for its assistance in helping Paraguay's economic development, Yeh said.

While accompanying President Chen Shui-bian on a visit to Paraguay last May, former CEPD Chairman Chen Po-chih proposed sending an economic advisory group to Paraguay to help the ROC's sole diplomatic ally in South America with its economic planning and development.

Chen's Paraguayan counterpart accepted Chen's proposal, and the ROC sent a mission of over 10 members, including experts and officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Council of Agriculture, the Chunghwa Institution for Economic Research, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research and others, for a field visit to Paraguay in late January, Yeh said.
The ROC advisory group made suggestions to President Gonzalez at the end of its 10-day visit.
They suggested that Paraguay improve its investment climate so as to lure more foreign investment and also advised that the Paraguayan government speed up its industrialization, Yeh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO CLOSELY MONITOR EFFECTS OF BUSH'S VISIT TO ASIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will closely monitor the effects of U.S. President George W. Bush's ongoing Asian visit on the political situation in Beijing and the Asia Pacific region, a MOFA spokeswoman said Sunday.

Chang Siao-yue said that although Washington has assured Taipei that ROC interests will not be sacrificed, MOFA officials will continue to follow the events carefully because Bush's visit comes only months before Beijing's leadership transition expected to take place at the 16th National Congress of the Communist Party of China.
The MOFA established an ad hoc task force Friday to analyze all relevant information on Bush's trip and submit reports to the premier and the president.
Bush's week-long visit, which began Saturday, will take him to Japan, South Korea and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELDERLY POPULATION ON THE RISE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The number of people in Taiwan over 65 years old totaled 1.97 million at the end of 2001, accounting for 8.81 percent of the total population, or a 2.71 percent increase over the previous year, according to government statistics released Sunday.
The Population Administration under the Minister of the Interior listed Taiwan's population at 22.40 million in 2001, for a 0.58 percent increase over 2000.
Those aged under 14 years old were tallied at 4.66 million, accounting for 20.81 percent of the total population, or down 0.88 percent over 2000.
Those aged between 15 and 64 were registered at 15.77 million, accounting for 70.39 percent of the total, or up 0.75 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LU HOPES TAIWAN AND MAINLAND CHINA WORK TOGETHER FOR PEACE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu of the Republic of China Saturday expressed the hope that mainland China and Taiwan will avoid confrontation and work together for "permanent peace" through cooperation.

In a video conference with some 500 Taiwanese American students attending the 2002 annual meeting of Taiwanese American Student Associations at Harvard University, Lu said she hoped the two sides of the Taiwan Strait would be reconciled with each other and cooperate with each other. The students are from Harvard, Yale, Cornell, and other leading universities of the United States.

Speaking from her office at the Presidential Palace in Taipei, Lu said mainland China and Taiwan are "distant relatives" and "near neighbors," pointing out that the Communist government established by Mao Zedong in 1949 has never ruled Taiwan even for one minute. "Taiwan is absolutely not a part of the People's Republic of China," she added.
Lu hoped that mainland China and Taiwan should help each other as relatives and neighbors. "They should work together for peace and prosperity, and avoid war and hatred," she said.

She encouraged Beijing to embrace the system of freedom and democracy and abandon its "one country, two systems" rhetoric. She hoped that the two sides would "compete with each other," and not "struggle against each other."

Since the two sides have joined the World Trade Organization (WTO), they should be able to increase their economic and other exchanges in a peaceful and reciprocal way under the framework of the world trade regulating body, Lu asserted.

The vice president predicted that Beijing would try very hard to have President George W. Bush say something unfavorable to Taiwan during his visit to Beijing on Feb. 21-22. This kind of mentality (to hurt Taiwan) will certainly strengthen Taiwan people's suspicion and fear of China and hinder the development of friendly relations, she pointed out.

Lu told the students that in the past 50 years Taiwan has made a great achievement in the promotion of democracy, freedom, human rights, and benevolence for the people, and also in the development of high technology. This is a kind of what she called "soft national strength," which mainland China doesn't have.
She encouraged the students to make the "soft national strength" known to their American friends in the hope that they will better understand Taiwan and help it join more international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTIES CONTINUE GEARING UP FOR REVENUE ALLOCATION REVISION VOTE

TEXT.P: Both the ruling and opposition parties continued their battle Sunday over the Executive Yuan's request for a cancellation of the revenue allocation law revision passed in January during the last session of the previous Legislature.

Legislator Tsai Huang-lang, secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) legislative caucus, called on the opposition parties not to resort to party discipline so as to allow all legislators to vote freely on the issue in this coming Tuesday's vote.
Tsai told a CNA reporter that the DPP's legislative caucus will meet Monday afternoon to discuss the Executive Yuan's request, saying that the DPP will not use party discipline against its members.

He said that a DPP legislative caucus task force was continuing to lobby those legislators elected from counties in southern Taiwan and the aboriginal areas, stressing that the results of these efforts have been good.
The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said it will back the Executive Yuan's request for a cancellation of the revision.
Lin Chih-chia, deputy secretary-general of the TSU'S legislative caucus, said the TSU will not resort to the party discipline for Tuesday's vote.
He called on the Executive Yuan to present a new revenue allocation plan within two months.

Opposition KMT Chairman Lien Chan, who is currently on a visit to Europe, has decided to cut his trip short and return to Taipei Monday to lead KMT lawmakers in rejecting the Executive Yuan's request.
Lien will attend the KMT's legislative caucus meeting to be held Monday evening to map out the party's strategy in blocking passage of the Executive Yuan's request.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said that the KMT chairman is deeply concerned over the Executive Yuan's proposal and that Lien has discussed counter-measures with him and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and has directed him to convey his instructions to all KMT lawmakers.
The KMT will do its utmost to mobilize its lawmakers to reject the Executive Yuan's request, Lin noted, but he refused to say whether the KMT will resort to party discipline.
Members of the KMT legislative caucus will call on Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh Monday with the aim of pushing Hsieh to express his position on the revision issue.

Meanwhile, Legislator Chou Hsi-wei of the opposition People First Party (PFP) said that a great majority of PFP lawmakers are opposed to the Executive Yuan's request. He pointed out that the final decision will be made Monday at the party's legislative caucus meeting, adding he believes that all PFP lawmakers will vote against the Executive Yuan's request.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER LUNCHES WITH 25 MAYORS AND MAGISTRATES

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun lunched with 25 mayors and magistrates from around Taiwan Sunday, apparently to canvass support for the Executive Yuan's request for a cancellation of the revision to the revenue allocation law.

Initiated by lawmakers of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), the Legislative Yuan in January passed a revision to the existing rules governing the allocation of revenues among the various governments in Taiwan.
The revision, which was initiated on a suggestion by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, immediately invited criticism from both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Executive Yuan.
Yu stressed while addressing the luncheon gathering that both the central and local governments maintain a partnership relationship and should share the glory and the burden regardless of their size.
He said that "the whole family" will prosper if the individual members of the family are united.
The premier also announced that such gatherings will be held every three months with Interior Minister Yu Cheng-hsien chairing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S EXPORTS, IMPORTS DOWN IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange income from exports in January totaled US$11.34 billion, down 5.5 percent over the same month last year, according to statistics released by the Central Bank of China (CBC) Sunday.

Expenditures from imports for the same month were listed at US$9.08 billion, or a decrease of 7.6 percent over the same month a year earlier, resulting in a surplus of US$2.26 billion for the first month of 2002.
CBC analysts attributed January's decline in foreign trade mainly to protracted global stagnation, slumping demand at home and abroad, and a decline in commodity prices.
They said the situation for January was an improvement over the preceding several months when a double-digit decline in foreign trade was registered.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMEN URGE BUSH TO MENTION FALUN GONG IN BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 16 (CNA) (By David Wang and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Several members of the U.S. Congress have urged President George W. Bush to raise issues regarding the Falun Gong during his upcoming visit to Beijing, the Falun Dafa Information Center in New York reported Saturday.

According to the information center, 94 members of the U.S. House of Representatives signed a letter to Bush requesting him to convey America's "great concern over the Chinese government's campaign of terror against innocent Falung Gong practitioners, and solicit the immediate release of specific victims."
The letter was initiated by Rep. Benjamin Gilman of New York and Rep. Sherrod Brown of Ohio, with the support of U.S. representatives from 28 states, the center added.

According to the center, in a separate letter signed by five U.S. senators, Sen. Paul Wellstone of Minnesota wrote: "We are deeply concerned about continuing reports of Falun Gong practitioners in China suffering restrictions on freedom of belief and expression, arbitrary detention, torture and death in custody."
Under domestic pressure from religious groups in the United States, Bush is expected to touch on the Falun Gong issue when he meets with mainland Chinese leaders in Beijing.
Bush's week-long visit, which began Saturday, will take him to Tokyo, Seoul and Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE GROUPS URGE CLINTON NOT TO SACRIFICE TAIWAN'S INTERESTS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 16 (CNA) (By David Wang and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The Greater New York chapter of the Taiwanese Association of America has called for a petition letter drive urging former U.S. President Bill Clinton to refrain from making remarks unfavorable to Taiwan during his upcoming visit to Australia.

At the invitation of a group that favors unification between Taiwan and mainland China, Clinton is scheduled to speak in Sydney Thursday, when U.S. President George W. Bush will be in Beijing on the last leg of his ongoing three-nation trip to Asia.

The timing of Clinton's visit has raised the concern of some Taiwanese groups in the United States that Beijing might use Clinton's presence at the pro-unification group's gathering to further its own pro-unification agenda.

Meanwhile, the Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) has also called for a petition letter drive to solicit the support of U.S. representatives for a bi-partisan "Taiwan Caucus" to be officially established at the U.S. House of Representatives on April 10, the 23rd anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act.
The caucus is expected to focus on U.S. policy toward Taiwan and provide the U.S. administration with advice on U.S.-Taiwan relations.

Established in 1982 in Los Angeles, the FAPA is a worldwide, Washington-based, non-profit organization that seeks to promote international support for "the right of the people of Taiwan to establish an independent and democratic country." It also seeks to promote peace and security for Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTRY TO ESTABLISH WATER CONSERVANCY ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is scheduled Monday to convene its first preparatory meeting for the establishment of a water conservancy administration under the ministry.

According to MOEA officials, the ministry's existing Water Conservancy Agency and Water Resources Bureau will be combined with relevant agencies under the Council of Agriculture to form the new administration.

The establishment of such a government agency, the plans of which were kicked off during Vice Premier Lin Hsin-yi's term as economics minister, is meant to unify the management of water resources in Taiwan, the officials added.
The farming and manufacturing industries in Taiwan rely on large quantities of water, but regional and seasonal water shortages necessitate careful centralized planning and conservation.

According to the Water Resources Bureau, agriculture accounts for approximately 71 percent of the total water usage in Taiwan, while the residential and industrial sectors account for about 19 percent and 10 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL BOOK EXHIBITION TO OPEN FEB. 19

TEXT.P: The 10th Taipei International Book Exhibition will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center Feb. 19 through Feb. 28.
The main theme pavilion of the exhibition will feature Japanese literature. Some 100 noted writers, scholars and cartoonists will be invited to the exhibition.
Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian has been invited to speak at the opening of the exhibition.
Organizers said that 1,015 publishing firms from 47 countries will display books at 1,856 booths this year.
The first two days of the exhibition will be open only to those from the publishing industry and specially-invited guests. The public is welcome to visit from Feb. 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 18, or the seventh day of first month of the Year of the Horse according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Mary Tudor, the English queen known as "Bloody Mary" because of her relentless persecution of Protestants, is born.
1546: Martin Luther, German theologian and the 16th century Protestant reformation leader who confirmed the Augsburg Confession in 1530, effectively establishing the Lutheran Church, dies in Eisleben, Germany at the age of 63.
1564: Michelangelo Buonarotti, Italian sculptor, painter, architect, poet and the most brilliant representative of the Italian Renaissance, dies in Rome at the age of 89. He created some of the greatest works of all time, including the marble sculpture "David," the paintings on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, and the plans for St. Peter's Cathedral.
1678: John Bunyan, English preacher and writer celebrated for his "Pilgrim's Progress," the allegorical tale of a Christian's journey from the City of Destruction to the Celestial City, publishes the first part of his masterpiece.
1685: La Salle, a French explorer, sets up the first European settlement in Texas.
1745: Alessandro Volta, Italian physicist who invented the electric battery, is born. The volt is named in his honor.
1855: Nicholas I, the czar of Russia who suppressed the December Movement and led his country into the Crimean War, dies at the age of 59.
1915: German submarines start a maritime blockade of Great Britain.
1930: Clyde William Tombaugh, U.S. astronomer, discovers the planet Pluto at the Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Arizona.
1932: Japan announces that the "Manchukuo" regime will be installed in northeastern China.
1943: Madame Chiang Kai-shek addresses a joint session of the U.S. House and Senate.
1945: The battle for Iwo Jima starts in the Pacific.
1951: Prime Minister Tran Van Huu announces the formation of a new government in Vietnam.
1960: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Mexico, Paraguay, Peru and Uruguay agree to establish the Latin American Free Trade Association.
1965: The West African nation of Gambia proclaims independence.
1967: Robert Julius Oppenheimer, the American physicist known as the father of the A-bomb, dies at the age of 65.
1976: C.C. Yang, Republic of China economic affairs vice minister, and S.M. Osman, secretary-general of the Afro-Asian Rural Reconstruction Organization, sign an agreement on technical cooperation.
1984: McDonald's, the Chicago-based fast-food chain, opens its first branch in Taiwan.
1986: The Asian Development Bank votes to admit mainland China.
1988: Boris Yeltsin is ousted from the ruling Communist Party Politburo in Moscow.
1991: The U.S. assault ship Tripoli and the guided missile cruiser Princeton are damaged by mines in the Persian Gulf during the Gulf War.
1992: A delegation from the U.S. president's Export Council arrives in Taipei to promote bilateral trade.
1994: Lin Wen-chiang, a mainland Chinese hijacker, commandeers a Southwest Airlines passenger plane from the mainland to Taiwan.
2000: Philippine President Joseph Ejercito Estrada formally proposes the formation of a subregional economic cooperation bloc in central East Asia composed of the Philippines, mainland China, Japan and South Korea, with Northern Luzon serving as the main gateway to this area.
2001: Taiwan's Lin Cheng-sheng wins the Best Director Award at the Berlin Film Festival for the movie "Betelnut Beauty."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A person may have abilities as admirable as our Lord of Chou (the Chinese equivalent of Moses or Solomon), but if they are proud and mean, you need not consider the other qualities of their mind."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Monday are as follows:
The China Times:
ROC Chief of the General Staff Lee Chieh will attend a Taiwan-U.S. military summit meeting.
The United Daily News:
Opposition and ruling parties gearing up for Tuesday showdown over allocation law amendments.
The Liberty Times:
Premier Yu will visit the Legislature today to lobby for support of the Cabinet motion to overturn the newly revised allocation law.
The Taiwan Daily:
The Legislative Yuan will vote on whether to uphold budget allocation law amendments Tuesday.
The Central Daily News:
Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan orders all KMT lawmakers to veto the Cabinet motion to overturn the revised allocation law.
The China Post:
The Cabinet rallies support to reject funding revision.
The Taiwan News:
Bush lands in Tokyo to cheers, jeers.
The Taipei Times:
The Cabinet defends its budget-fight tactics.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 42.53 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 42.53 points to close at 5,968.61.
Market turnover amounted to NT$122.81 billion (US$3.5 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: YU MAKES LAST-MINUTE EFFORTS TO HAVE ALLOCATION REVISION OVERTURNED

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun made last-minute efforts Monday to have the newly-revised allocation law overturned by visiting separate party caucuses at the Legislative Yuan.

Yu met with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and the legislative caucus leaders to lobby for support of the Executive Yuan's motion to overturn the allocation law revisions that were passed Jan. 18 during the last session of the previous Legislature.

The Legislative Yuan passed the revisions to the tax revenues redistribution law, authored by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, a stalwart of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), but the Cabinet filed a proposal Feb. 6 asking that the Legislature reconsider before the amendment bill takes effect.

Yu noted that the amendment bill was enacted by the "old Legislature" elected on public opinion of three years earlier, saying that the bill should be looked at and discussed again by the new Legislature elected based on present public opinion.
The Executive Yuan has opted to try to have the new revenue allocation law overturned as it said it finds it extremely difficult to carry out, Yu pointed out.

The Legislature is scheduled to vote Tuesday on the Cabinet's motion to overturn the revision bill, with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition parties gearing up for battle as partisan disputes over the issue rising.

On the eve of the Tuesday showdown, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said he takes no sides on the issue. "Whether the revision bill is overturned or not, in my opinion, there is a third case -- namely that new amendments to the revision bill are inevitable," Wang noted.
Taipei Mayor Ma said if the revision bill were to be overturned in Tuesday's vote, it would be tantamount to a failure of financial reform regarding local-level governments.

Ma said the newly revised allocation law can really help resolve local governments' financial problems, adding that most of all, it is designed to fulfill President Chen Shui-bian's campaign promise of giving more power and money to local governments.

At a public hearing at the Legislative Yuan called by independent Legislator Sisy Chen over the much-disputed issue, Lin Chuan, head of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, said if the revision bill were indeed to take effect, it would leave both the central and the local governments in a deeper financial quagmire with nobody faring any better.

Lin called for support for the overturning of the revision bill, saying that if it is successfully overturned in Tuesday's vote, the Executive Yuan will submit a new amendment bill in three months to replace the Ma-authored revision.

The opposition People First Party (PFP) said in a position paper Monday that it is opposed to the ruling DPP's scheme to highlight the revision dispute by ordering an overturn motion which has made the legal issue a political one.
The PFP requested that the Executive Yuan put forth a new amended version of the finance allocation law in two months so as to help settle the dispute.
PFP Policy Center director Chang Hsien-yao noted that the PFP expressed strong protest and regret over the ruling DPP's recent moves to exert pressure on local governments over the overturn plan.
According to Chang, many local governments have been threatened recently that if they don't support the overturn plan, their regular subsidies and subsidies under special plans will all be cut.
He added that the threats to the local governments have in turn affected the attitudes on the revision issue of some of the elected legislators representing local counties.

The KMT fanned out across the island over the weekend to gain support for a rejection of the Executive Yuan's request for a cancellation of the Ma-authored revision, which gives local governments a bigger share of revenue.
The KMT claimed that the revision will give local governments more financial resources without damaging the central government's ability to carry out its policies.

To override the Executive Yuan's planned overturn motion, the opposition camp needs to mobilize 113 votes in the 225-seat Legislature. The KMT, which controls 68 seats, will have to gain the support of lawmakers from the PFP, which holds 46 seats, and possibly other independent legislators in order to be successful in Tuesday's showdown.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and then fluctuated on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 42.53 points to close at 5,968.61.

Despite a decline in U.S. stock prices over the weekend, the bourse opened at 6,048.65 but began to go down later due to a drop in plastics and chemical share prices. The index fluctuated between 6,048.65 and 5,953.75 during trading.

A total of 3.52 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$122.81 billion (US$3.5 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 3.89 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$138.88 billion (US$3.97 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with textile issues moving down the most at 3 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 1.5 percent, and bank and insurance stocks at 0.3 percent.

The other major categories gained ground, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 2.5 percent, followed by electrical shares at 1.2 percent, cement stocks at 0.5 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.3 percent, and construction stocks at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 371 to 231, with 89 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO BECOME 29TH CONTRACTING PARTY TO GPA

TEXT.P: The Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) is expected to approve the Republic of China's application to join its Government Procurement Agreement (GPA) Thursday, making Taiwan the 29th signatory to the multilateral accord.
The WTO's GPA commission is scheduled to hold a meeting Wednesday and Thursday whose agenda will include endorsing the ROC's GPA membership.

An ROC delegation, headed by Kuo Yao-chi, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission (PCC), left for Geneva Monday to attend the upcoming GPA conference as Taiwan became a full WTO member at the beginning of this year.

Once the GPA commission approves Taiwan's GPA accession protocol, the document will then be referred to the ROC's Legislative Yuan for approval. According to WTO regulations, Taiwan will formally become a GPA signatory or contracting party 30 days after it deposits its instrument of ratification at the WTO's Secretariat.

If all goes smoothly, Taiwan will become the GPA's 29th signatory around the end of March or early April. Joining the GPA will create both opportunities and challenges for Taiwan. While other GPA signatories must open their government procurement markets, worth an estimated NT$6.8 trillion (US$194.29 billion) annually, to Taiwan, the island will also have to allow foreign companies to bid for its government procurement projects, including engineering, financial and labor services, worth about NT$200 billion per year.

In view of Taiwan's impending participation in the GPA, Premier Yu Shyi-kun has ordered the PCC and other relevant government agencies to brace up for both the opportunities and challenges that will come with the GPA accession.

A PCC official said Taiwan's civil engineering and construction industries still lack the experience of cooperation in exploring overseas markets. "Local engineering and construction companies must streamline structures and management in order to upgrade their competitiveness," said the official.
He pointed out that many of Taiwan's engineering and construction firms should merge among themselves so that they can pool their resources for securing overseas construction contracts.

For its part, the official said, the PCC will coordinate with the Ministry of the Interior and other government agencies in revising the existing laws governing construction, consulting services, architects and civil engineering technicians to facilitate their merger and cooperation.
Meanwhile, the domestic power generation equipment manufacturing industry will also face increased foreign competition after Taiwan becomes a GPA contracting party.

The state-owned Taiwan Power Co. purchases about NT$30 billion worth of electricity generating facilities annually. The Ministry of Economic Affairs plans to open 67 of those items to both domestic and foreign bidders from July 1. Most of the listed products are no longer suitable for domestic production.
As for 28 other items that local manufacturers still command some competitive edge, they will not be opened to international bidding within the first five years following Taiwan's signing of the GPA.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MIXED ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported mixed results on Monday as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for February moved down 13 points to close at 5,956, with 6,555 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March rose 2 points to close at 5,953, with 2,591 contract transactions, while June futures lost 48 points to finish at 5,932, with only one contract traded.
December futures gained 214 points to close at 6,149, with one contract traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,969 for February, 5,951 for March, 5,980 for June, 5,981 for September, and 5,935 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also reported mixed results.
February TE futures moved up 2.25 points to close at 318.75, with 1,743 contract transactions, while March TE futures increased 2.8 points to finish at 318.8, with 522 contracts changing hands.
December TE futures remained unchanged at 330.7, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
February TF futures moved down 7 points to finish at 717, with 535 contract transactions, while March TF futures fell 4.4 points to close at 720.6, with 152 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER YU TO MEET MAINLAND CHINA-BASED TAIWANESE BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun will meet with representatives of mainland China-based Taiwanese businessmen at a dinner party celebrating the Spring Festival on Feb. 21, an economics official said Monday.

The official said that the Industrial Development and Industrial Center under the Ministry of Economic Affairs arranged for mainland-based Taiwan businessmen to meet with officials of the economics ministry and the Mainland Affairs Council, as well as executives of the Chinese National Federation of Industries and the Straits Exchange Foundation on the occasions of the Spring Festival, the Dragon Boat Festival and the Moon Festival.
The official said that in the previous meetings, the businessmen had brought up problems and issues regarding their investments on the other side of the Taiwan Strait.

While the local electronics and chemical manufacturing sectors are expecting that the government will relax its restrictions on Taiwan businessmen's investments in eight-inch chip plants or upstream chemical manufacturing plants in mainland China, industrial circles hope that the premier will make a policy statement during Thursday's meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEELUNG GOVERNMENT TO SEARCH FOR RUMORED GOLD NEAR OLD FORT

TEXT.P: Annoyed by repeated acts of vandalism by people looking for gold rumored to have been buried in an old battery fort in Keelung by Japanese forces during World War II, the government of the city in northern Taiwan has decided to try its own luck at uncovering the alleged cache.

Rumor has it that some 5,000 kilograms of gold were buried by the Japanese near the Tahwulun Battery Fort on a hill in Keelung City before the invaders fled the country after Japan was defeated in the war.

The rumors have led to many stealthy raids by fortune-seekers over the past decades, including the last one on Jan. 21 this year. The latest attempt to find the gold was particularly brazen, with those responsible running an excavator over a low brick wall during the dead of night and driving into the fort dig.
Nobody knows if anything was taken away, nor is there any evidence that gold was recovered in earlier attempts in 1994 and 1999.

Keelung City Government officials said the rumored 5,000 kilograms of gold would currently be worth over NT$1 billion and could be contained in a relatively small container of about 65cm x 65 cm x 65 cm. Officials said that if the government does not step in the site will continue to attract unlawful attempts to strike it rich.

Lin Chen-hsing, a Keelung City Government official in charge of civil and cultural affairs, said the government will explore the battery fort, now a park, to determine whether the rumors are true before vandals do more damage to the fort and its adjacent environment.
The Tahwulun Battery Fort, built in the Ching dynasty to fight against and watch for invaders from the sea, is now a second-class national legacy location entitled to government protection.
According to Lin, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) is willing to allocate funds to financially support the Keelung City Government's exploration plan.
It is expected that the first-stage of the examination of the location will begin in March, with the Keelung government offering open bids for potential diggers to compete the excavation work.

According to Liu Wen-shih, director of the MOI Department of Civil Affairs, a man surnamed Chen from Taipei County wrote the Ministry of National Defense (MND) authorities in 1983, saying that he intended to apply for MND permission to excavate for gold on the site. Back then, the fort was under the jurisdiction of the MND.

Chen said he was told by a Japanese soldier during the period when Taiwan was still under Japanese colonial occupation that some 5,000 kilograms of gold were buried near the battery fort in Keelung. Chen said he is positive that the Japanese were unable to recover the gold in their rush to leave the island.

At the time, the MND authorities didn't take Chen's application seriously. The application was subsequently passed on to the MOI, which also ignored Chen's proposal, considering it nonsense, Liu said.
Since then, many have speculated on the veracity of Chen's claim and others have searched -- illegally and in vain -- for the gold.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGNERS ACCOUNT FOR 8.9% OF TAIWAN'S GRASSROOTS LABOR FORCE

TEXT.P: Foreign nationals have become an important group in Taiwan's grassroots work force, accounting for 8.9 percent of the island's total manual labor force in 2001, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) reported Monday.
CLA tallies showed that 304,605 foreign laborers legally worked in Taiwan last year, with the manufacturing sector accounting for the lion's share of alien workers.
According to CLA statistics, 157,000 foreigners worked in various manufacturing industries in 2001, marking a 14 percent drop from the year-earlier level amid a lingering domestic economic slowdown.

In contrast, the number of foreign nationals engaging in social and personal services increased 6 percent from the 2001 level to 113,000 due to local people's increasing demand for family helpers and housemaids.

In terms of nationalities, Thailand remained the largest source of foreign laborers, accounting for 128,000. Indonesia came in second with 91,000, followed by the Philippines with 72,000, and Vietnam with 13,000.

CLA tallies also showed that Taoyuan County had the largest number of foreign laborers last year, totaling 64,740. Next was Taipei County with 43,538; Taipei City, 35,733; Taichung County, 33,022; and Changhua County, 19,527.
"The figures indicate that counties with industrial parks or export processing zones remain the main areas of concentration for foreign laborers," a CLA official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN SUPPORT GROWING FOR TIBET-CHINA DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: Canadian parliamentary and civilian support for dialogue between Tibet's exile government and the mainland Chinese government is growing despite the cancellation of a visit by the Dalai Lama to the Canadian capital scheduled for late April.

Tibet's spiritual leader was to visit Ottawa April 28-30, but the visit was canceled as a result of his recent illness. The Kashag (Cabinet of the Tibetan Government in Exile), as well as friends and supporters of the Dalai Lama and Tibet, have expressed concern about the many demands on his time.

Thubten Samdup, president of the Canada Tibet Committee, which was to host the visit to Ottawa, said that "we will continue to press the Canadian government to play an active role in bringing the Government of China to the negotiation table to resolve the ongoing conflict peacefully.
Samdup noted that the Dalai Lama's scheduled visit to Canada in 2004 has not been affected by the current cancellation.

The Canada Tibet Committee has kicked off Campaign 2002, with the goal of getting half of the members of Parliament, or 150 members, to sign on to a letter to Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien asking him to convene face-to-face negotiations between representatives of the Dalai Lama and the mainland Chinese government.
"We already have more than 80 signatures," including those of 20 Liberal members of Parliament, Samdup said.
Meanwhile, a group of twelve prominent Canadians has sent a letter to Chretien encouraging him to meet with the Dalai Lama if he visits Canada.
The twelve, who formed an advisory committee for the visit, include representatives from Canada's First Nations, business, non-governmental, labor and entertainment communities.

"The diversity of the committee reflects the broad-based support for Tibet among Canadians", said Samdup, adding that "the willingness of these individuals to lend their names to the Dalai Lama's visit is a reflection of their sentiment towards this man and his cause."

They include Ms. Patricia Adams, executive director of Probe International; Hon. Mr. Warren Allmand, president of Rights & Democracy; Hon. Mr. Ed Broadbent, author and former leader of the federal New Democratic Party; Mr. Matthew Coon Come, national chief of the Assembly of First Nations; and Mr. Ken Georgetti, president of the Canadian Labour Congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped slightly on the Taipei Foreign Exchange market Monday, dropping NT$0.016 to close at NT$35.085.
A total of US$333 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$35.110 and was traded between TN$35.056 and NT$35.110.

DOC.HEADLINE: WARNING: VALENTINE'S DAY E-MAIL COULD BE KISS OF DEATH FOR YOUR COMPUTER

TEXT.P: Anti-virus software maker Trend Micro warned Monday that a medium-risk VBScript worm called VBS_NUMGAME.A has been masquerading as a Valentine's Day e-mail message to infect Windows-based computers of unsuspecting users.

According to the Taiwan-based company, the worm was first discovered Feb. 15 and propagates by sending itself to every address listed in the infected user's computer address book. The worm arrives in an e-mail with the subject: "Are you (name) my valentine?"

The worm then prompts the recipient to open an attached number-guessing game. Upon execution, it deletes several files and folders including the root directory of Windows, all user programs, and all files in the My Document directory.

The company warned computer users to delete messages fitting the description of VBS_NUMGAME.A immediately upon receiving them, to refrain from opening attachments from unfamiliar senders, and to update the virus pattern files of their anti-virus programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTRY WILL ACT TO IMPROVE INVESTMENT ENVIRONMENT

TEXT.P: ROC Minister of Finance Lee Yung-san said Monday that his ministry will establish a sound financial monitoring system for creating a better investment environment as soon as possible.
Following Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), Lee said that the island faces new challenges originating from globalization and liberalization of international capital markets.
Efforts will be made to create a better investment environment so that better services can be provided for the securities and futures operations, the minister noted.
Lee said that Taiwan registered a negative 2.12 percent growth last year mainly because of the adverse effects on the island's foreign trade caused by the global recession.

Regarding the performance of the stock market, Lee said that improvement is expected this year owing to the gradual recovery of the world economy, the return of capital and the increase in stock transactions.
The minister made the remarks while speaking at a Lunar New Year's party organized by securities and futures firms.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI LANTERN FESTIVAL INSPIRED BY EXPRESSIONIST PAINTINGS

TEXT.P: The 2002 Taipei Lantern Festival will feature a series of giant lanterns representing Vincent van Gogh's "Irises in the Garden," Marc Chagall's "I and the Village," Gustav Climt's "Kiss," and Pablo Picasso's "Dream," an official of the Taipei City Government said Monday.

The official said that the lantern craftsmen in Taipei are trying to present new designs with motifs borrowed from the most prominent European painters of the 19th and 20th centuries, adding international flavor to the traditional Chinese festival on the 15th of the first lunar month, which falls on Feb. 26 this year.

The official said that the giant theme lantern, however, will be modeled on the Chinese zodiac animal of the year -- a horse. Since the Taipei Lantern Festival was first held in 1990 on and around the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, the zodiac animal of the year has been chosen every year as the motif of the theme lantern.
In the evenings from Feb. 26 to March 3, the city government has arranged a series of gala activities at the plaza in front of the memorial hall.
A most lively festival which marks the conclusion of the Chinese New Year celebrations, the Lantern Festival will be celebrated at temples and cultural centers around the island.

In Kaohsiung, the city government and the Tourism Bureau will jointly sponsor a parade of lantern-decorated wagons. The Taichung City Government is presenting an exhibition of lanterns featuring Chinese folklore as well as environmental protection themes at the city park Feb. 20-28.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KMT STALWART PROMOTED AS SECRETARY-GENERAL OF RIVAL PARTY

TEXT.P: A former opposition Kuomintang (KMT) stalwart, now deputy secretary-general of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), was promoted to secretary-general of the party Monday, a TSU source said.

Lin Chih-chia will succeed Su Chin-chiang, who was recently designated by President Chen Shui-bian as an adviser to the National Security Council and will take the new post in the next two days, said Hsiao Kuan-yu, director of the TSU's cultural and publicity affairs department.
Lin had served as KMT legislator, secretary-general of the party's caucus in the legislature, and director of the KMT's policy research department.

Lin originally planned to run for the magistrateship of Taipei County, northern Taiwan, in last yearend's legislative and local elections. However, he decided to let the opposition New Party-nominated Wang Chien-shien run for the post to keep his promise that he would withdraw from the election if his approval rating was lower than Wang's in an opinion poll.

Wang took a slight lead against Lin in the opinion poll and represented the so-called "pan-blue alliance," which had support from the KMT, the People First Party as well as the New Party, to run for the magistrateship of Taipei County. Wang was defeated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party-nominated Su Tseng-chang.

Lin quit the KMT recently to join the TSU, which was founded on Aug. 12, 2001. The TSU, under the leadership of former Minister of the Interior Huang Chu-wen, regards former President Lee Teng-hui as its "spiritual leader."
With 13 legislative seats, the TSU has become the fourth largest party in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR TAPPED TO BE NEW DEPUTY CHIEF STAFF FOR PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Joseph Wu, director of the Institute of International Relations under the National Chengchi University, confirmed news reports Monday that he will serve as the deputy secretary-general for the presidential office.

The U.S.-trained political scholar said he will assume the job on Feb. 27. The post has been left unfilled after the former deputy chief staff Eugene Chien was named to head the foreign ministry late last month.

Wu said he was offered the job by Secretary-General of the Presidential Office Chen Shih-meng in a meeting several days ago. Wu said he accepted the job which will be charged with foreign affairs in the presidential office.

Wu, who has praised the achievement of the President Chen Shui-bian's government in letters to foreign newspapers, is also the executive director of the Institute for National Development, a think tank founded in 1998 by Vice President Annette Lu. Local newspapers said he has good connections with senior government officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 250,000 TOURISTS VISITED TAITUNG DURING LUNAR NEW YEAR HOLIDAY

TEXT.P: Over 250,000 visitors from across Taiwan poured into Taitung County during the nine days of the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, the East Coast National Scenic Area Administration reported Monday.

Recreational resorts and tourist spots located in the Chihpen Hot Springs, the East Rift Valley National Scenic Area and the East Coast National Scenic Area were the most popular destinations in the eastern county which is rich in natural tourism resources.

The statistics revealed that the number of private cars visiting the three major scenic areas dropped to 24,560 from 25,442 a year ago, while the number of large tour buses increased to 1,101 from 1,030. During the same period, the number of motorcycles also rose to 841 from the year-earlier level of 590.
According to the administration, the traffic jam began Feb. 11 -- Lunar New Year's Eve -- and did not ease until Feb. 15. The 250,000-visitor level was up by 10 percent over year before.

DOC.HEADLINE: VALUE OF INTERNET ADS ESTIMATED TO EXCEED NT$1 BILLION FOR 2002

TEXT.P: Fueled by a global economic recovery and a large increase in the number of broadband users, the value of ads on the Internet may break the NT$1 billion mark for the first time to hit NT$1.11 billion for 2002, the Market Information Center (MIC) under the Institute for Information Industry has forecast.

MIC analyst C. L. Kung said the Internet ads market began to burgeon in 1996 with the spread of online businesses. The market scale was NT$120 million in 1998, with the figure rising to NT$350 million in 1999 and NT$870 million in 2000, respectively, Kung said. However, the figure fell to NT$830 million for 2001, the first decline in six years, as a result of the economic slump, he added.

Affected by the recession, advertisements in major news media such as newspapers and on television stations registered an average decline of 10 percent in 2001, ahead of the 4.59 percent fall on the Internet, he noted.
According to an MIC investigation, the leading reason behind those businesses which did not post ads on the Internet last year was a "skepticism about their effectiveness."

Kung said the number of Taiwan's wide-band household users is expected to reach 2 million this year and that has raised high expectations in the local Internet industry that a new era of GPRS and third-generation mobile phones will be heralded in the near future.

He forecast that the scale of the Internet ads market will further expand by 42 percent to NT$1.58 billion in 2003, with the figure continuing to increase to NT$2.38 billion in 2004 and NT$3.74 billion in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MEMBERS QUESTION POLICE ROLE AS CABINET'S 'DELIVERY SERVICE'

TEXT.P: Four opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers filed an appeal with the Control Yuan Monday asking the nation's highest watchdog body to look into whether the Cabinet had abused its power in ordering police to deliver documents to local government chiefs.

KMT legislative caucus deputy whip Lee Chuan-chiao and three of his colleagues -- Lee Chia-chin, Chu Feng-chi and Cheng Feng-shih -- filed the joint appeal on the eve of a legislative vote on a Cabinet motion to overturn an amendment bill to the Law Governing Allocation of Government Revenues and Expenditures.

The four legislators asked the Control Yuan to probe the propriety of the Cabinet's directive that demanded city and county police bureaus deliver their position papers on the budget allocation issue to the country's 25 mayors and magistrates as well as the 225 lawmakers before Feb. 16.

They enclosed with their appeal a duplicate copy of the National Police Administration's notice to city and county police bureaus regarding delivery of the Cabinet's position paper for the reference of the watchdog body.
The KMT lawmakers claimed that the Cabinet's move to mobilize the police force to deliver the Cabinet's documents seemed to have violated the police service law and the administrative procedural law.
"We hope that the Control Yuan will check whether the Cabinet should be held responsible for any irregularities or malfeasance," the lawmakers said in their petition letter.
Control Yuan member Ku Teng-mei met with the four opposition lawmakers and accepted their petition letter on behalf of the watchdog body.
"We'll ask the Cabinet to explain in detail the whole thing and will decide on possible subsequent actions after receiving a Cabinet reply," Ku said.

In response to opposition criticism about the Cabinet's move, National Police Administration (NPA) Director-General Wang Chin-wang said he saw nothing wrong in the Cabinet asking police authorities to assist in delivering documents of "great urgency" to local government chiefs and lawmakers during the Chinese New Year holiday when postal offices and private courier services were not available.
Noting that the NPA is part of the government's administrative system, Wang said, local police bureaus certainly can help deliver the Cabinet's important documents under such "special circumstances."
Moreover, Wang stressed that police officers, while delivering the documents, didn't lobby any city mayor, county magistrates or lawmakers to support or oppose the new tax revenues allocation law.
Wang further said the document delivery was just an isolated case and should not be "politicized."

Commenting on a reported claim by Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun, a KMT stalwart, that the Cabinet had threatened to transfer the county's police chief, Hou Yo-yi, to other post if the county fails to support the Cabinet's move to overturn the new funding allocation law, Wang said he has no knowledge about the source of the report.

Wang said all of his superiors, including the premier, vice premier, the Cabinet secretary-general and the minister of the interior, have denied that they had made any contact with Chu during the Lunar New Year holiday. "Nor did they make any kind of threat to force the Cabinet to act in a certain way," Wang said, adding that the NPA has so far not taken any action regarding a personnel reshuffle.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN INDUSTRIAL PARK 2001 TURNOVER RISES 103 PERCENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan County, southern Taiwan, Feb. 18 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The 65 companies located in the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park had a combined annual turnover of NT$50.1 billion (US$1.4 billion) in 2001, up 103 percent from the previous year, park administrators announced Monday.
According to the officials, 18 high-tech companies set up shop in the park last year, and another 20 to 50 companies are expected to follow in 2002.
The combined annual turnover of the companies in the park is expected to grow by another NT$30 billion to NT$50 billion this year, creating over 3,000 job opportunities, the officials added.

Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and United Microelectronics Corp. are two of the major players in the park, where approximately 9,000 employees currently work. Official projected estimates indicate that the park may eventually accomodate 77,000 people.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs has estimated that factories in the park will produce an annual total of US$30 billion in goods by 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE MAY TOP 3% THIS YEAR: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Christine Tsung said Monday that Taiwan's economic outlook has almost hit rock bottom and that this year will see positive growth.
Tsung also claimed that various economic projectors that estimate Taiwan's economic growth rate at between 2.7 percent and 3 percent this year are "too conservative."
She made the remarks to reporters prior to attending a meeting of the Council for Economic Planning and Development chaired by Vice Premier Lin Hsin-yi.

Speaking on the work of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), Tsung said that the ministry's efforts will center on industrial upgrading, the upgrading of value-added products and the strengthening of research and development programs.
Meanwhile, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics will convene a meeting Friday to evaluate the first quarter's per capita income.
In related news, an official from CitiBank Investment Consultation Ltd. said that Taiwan's economic prospects are gradually improving.
He suggested that investors should put their money into Asian markets, especially Taiwan and South Korea.
He pointed out that both Taiwan and South Korea's stock exchanges performed better than other Asian exchanges in 2001 and the first part of 2002.
The official further pointed out that leading indicators have grown in the past three consecutive months.
He attributed the growth to the increase of money supply (M1b), increased export value and increased stock index.

He said that the M1b has grown from 5 percent in November, 2001 to 10.72 percent in December, 2001, indicating that the money supply is sufficient. In addition, he went on, general indicators of the economic prospects also posted positive growth of l point in November to 5 points in December for a total of 15 points.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAY BOAST WORLD'S LARGEST GONG

TEXT.P: Taiwan may soon boast the world's largest gong, as a temple in central Changhua County is preparing to register its gong with the Guinness Book of Records.

To celebrate this year's Lantern Festival, Tienhou Temple in Lukang Township -- one of Taiwan's most historic towns -- has been preparing to present a gong weighing 3.6 tonnes and with a diameter of three meters for the holiday season.

President Chen Shui-bian will be invited to give the gong "three strikes" Feb. 23 to ask for prosperity, peace and health for Taiwan and its people. Chen's presence is expected to mark the climax of a series of activities, including acrobatics and folk exhibitions, to mark the occasion.
Tienhou Temple, which worships Matsu, Goddess of the Sea, is a noted ancient building in Lukang. An average 100,000 worshippers visit the temple per day during the Lunar New Year holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH'S CHINA VISIT NOT EXPECTED TO HURT TAIWAN'S INTEREST: ROC MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said Monday he does not expect any surprise developments to come from U.S. President George W. Bush's visit to mainland China later this week.

"The United States has more than once briefed us on the main purposes of Bush's Asia tour before his departure and repeatedly guaranteed that Taiwan's interests won't be sacrificed during Bush's trip," Chien told a news conference.
Bush arrived in Japan Sunday at the start of a three-nation Asia tour that will also take him to South Korea and mainland China.

Noting that this is Bush's first visit to the Asia-Pacific area following his attendance at the annual informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum last October, Chien said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is keeping close tabs on the current trip.

According to Chien, the government has set up a special task force to facilitate communications with the United States and analyze relevant developments. "The task force is working around the clock to monitor Bush's visit to Japan, south Korea and mainland China," he added.

The minister further said that since the communication channels between Taiwan and the United States have been operating smoothly, MOFA can fully grasp any possible developments. "We hope that people will keep calm. They need not be nervous," he said.
Chien said he appreciated statements made by Bush prior to his departure that Taiwan is a friend of the United States and that the Taiwan Strait issue should be resolved peacefully.
Chien said the Republic of China government hopes that the United States will continue to play the role of "promoter, stabilizer and balancer" in cross-strait relations.

In his view, Chien went on, the main purpose of Bush's current Asia visit is to promote world peace and security. "Bush hopes to take advantage of his trip to forge a consensus with U.S. allies in the Asia-Pacific area on his administration's fight against terrorism and the proliferation of nuclear weapons.
He said Bush is expected to discuss bilateral security cooperation, Japan's economic reforms and financial aid to Afghanistan in his talks with Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi.
During his trip to Seoul, Chien said, Bush is expected to exchange views with South Korean leaders on arms procurement and policies toward North Korea.

"As for the topics to be touched upon in Bush's talks with Beijing leaders, the agenda will include mainland China's agricultural market opening, religious freedom and human rights condition, missile shield and Taiwan Strait issues," Chien noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROAD ACCIDENTS CLAIMED 52 LIVES DURING LUNAR NEW YEAR HOLIDAY

TEXT.P: A total of 52 persons were killed in traffic accidents in Taiwan during the Lunar New Year holiday Feb. 9-14, the National Police Administration (NPA) said Monday.
NPA statistics showed that 48 road accidents were reported during the period. Fifty-two were killed while 19 others were injured.
The number of accidents and casualties were fewer than the same period last year, an NPA official said.
He noted that 86 accidents occurred during last year's Lunar New Year holiday Jan. 21-29, claiming 92 lives and 57 injured.
Of the 48 road accidents reported this year, sedans were involved in 22 cases. Rear-end collisions accounted for 12 cases, followed by speeding (seven cases) and failure to reduce speed (six cases).
By counties, seven accidents were reported in Kaohsiung County, five in Changhua County and four in Hsinchu County.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO ESTABLISH ECOTOURISM STANDARDS

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau will establish a set of ecotourism standards this year to tap into Taiwan's abundance of ecological resources and help promote the development of the island's tourism industry, officials said Monday.

On Jan. 16, the Executive Yuan passed a "2002 Ecotourism Working Plan" proposed by the Tourism Development and Promotion Committee, as well as the committee's suggestion that 2002 be designated "Taiwan Ecotourism Year."

The Tourism Bureau is currently soliciting logo designs for "Taiwan Ecotourism Year," with applications accepted until Feb. 20 and final entry submissions accepted until Feb. 28. The creator of the winning design will receive a prize of NT$30,000 (US$855).
The government began formulating its ecotourism plan last August to coordinate with the U.N. proclamation of 2002 as the International Year of Ecotourism.
The plan includes six strategies and more than 30 concrete measures aimed at turning Taiwan into an internationally known "island of tourism."

According to the Tourism Bureau, the primary measures include the drafting of a white paper on ecotourism, the setting of ecotourism standards, the formulation of regulations governing the administration of professional guides for natural and cultural ecology, the provision of training in ecotourism, the promotion of publicity activities and the selection of 40 ecotourism routes.
The first ecotourism activity for this year is a butterfly-watching tour of Butterfly Valley organized by the Maolin National Scenic Area Administration in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan.

Tourism officials said that the goals of the plan are to integrate local residents and home-stay operators with the ecotourism industry to create more job opportunities, protect the island's ecological resources, avoid the adverse impact of tourism on the environment and heighten appreciation of Taiwan's native resources, culture and society.

In December 1998, the U.N. General Assembly declared 2002 as the International Year of Ecotourism to generate greater awareness among public authorities, the private sector and consumers regarding ecotourism's capacity to contribute to the conservation of the natural and cultural heritage in natural and rural areas, and the improvement of living standards in those areas.

Another goal for the activities surrounding the U.N. International Year of Ecotourism is to disseminate methods and techniques for the planning, management, regulation and monitoring of ecotourism to guarantee its long-term sustainability.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER WANTS SURVEY OF MAJOR PRIVATE INVESTMENT PROJECTS

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i instructed government agencies Monday to complete a survey of major private sector investment projects within one month.

Lin, who concurrently serves as chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), designated "major" private investment projects as those that exceed NT$200 million (US$5.69 million).
He also asked the relevant government agencies to carry out monthly checks on the projects to make it easier to predict future investment.
Lin said that if the nation is to reach the government's stated goal of 2.7 percent economic growth this year, public investment will have to go hand in hand with private investment projects.

Although there is already a one-stop window to promote investment under the Ministry of Economic Affairs -- which is in charge of dealing with the hurdles surrounding investment and keeping track of investment projects -- CEPD Vice Chairman Ho Mei-yueh said private investment is crucial to the nation's economic growth and that any problems in this regard should be referred to the CEPD for discussion.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HARBOR CHIEF HOPES PORT CAN REGAIN WORLD TITLE
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Feb. 18 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The head of the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau expressed hope Monday that Kaohsiung harbor will regain its title as the world's third-largest container harbor.
Huang Ching-tern made the remark at a Chinese New Year party attended by some 200 dignitaries.

The number of containers loaded and unloaded in South Korean Pusan harbor surpassed that of Kaohsiung harbor in 2000, making Pusan harbor the world's third-largest container harbor, behind Hong Kong and Singapore.

Hong Kong is the world's largest container harbor by handling a total of 17.9 million TEUs in 2001, Singapore handled 15.54 million TEUs, Pusan harbor handled 7.9 million TEUs, Kaohsiung harbor handled 7.54 million TEUs and Shanghai harbor handled 6.33 million TEUs, according to statistics released Monday by the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ATTEND 2002 INTERNATIONAL BIOLOGY OLYMPIAD IN LATVIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan will send a team to compete in the 2002 International Biology Olympiad scheduled to be held this summer in Latvia, a Ministry of Education (MOE) official said Monday.
The official said that Taiwan will also try to win the right to host the 2008 International Biology Olympiad.
It will be the fourth time Taiwan has sent a team to the competition since 1999.

The official said that the selection process has been under way since last year, with some 203 people chosen from 8,961 participants in the preliminary selection. The second round of the selection process will be held March 2 to whittle the number down to around 40, from which a four-member team will be chosen.
The MOE has also mapped out a talent cultivation program with cooperation from Academia Sinica, National Tsinghua University and National Sun Yat-sen University, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI TEAM LEAVES FOR THOMAS/UBER CUP BADMINTON TOURNEY

TEXT.P: A 16-member Chinese Taipei team led by Chinese Taipei Badminton Association Chairman Cheng Jung-hui left Monday for Melbourne to take part in the 2002 Thomas/Uber Cup Badminton Tournament that opens Wednesday.
The team is composed of eight male and eight female players, with the men competing for the Thomas Cup against South Korea, Thailand and Macau in the preliminary round's Group B.
The women will compete for the Uber Cup against Japan, Malaysia, Singapore and Hong Kong in the preliminaries.
Chien Yu-chin, ranked 66 in the world, will represent the women against Japan in the singles competition and will pair with Cheng Wen-hsin for the doubles.
The winners will qualify for the Thomas Cup finals scheduled to be held in Guangzhou, mainland China, May 9-19.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA PROVIDES US$ 1.99 M. IN RESEARCH GRANTS FOR 31 ENTERPRISES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Monday approved grants of more than NT$70 million (US$1.99 million) to help 31 small- and medium-sized enterprises engage in the research of new technology.

The Small & Medium Enterprise Administration under the MOEA said that the grants, which will augment NT$170 million (US$4.84 million) provided by the 31 companies themselves, will be of great benefit to new technology in industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DECIDE WHETHER TO ALLOW WAFER MAKERS TO INVEST IN PRC

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government will decide by the end of March whether to allow wafer makers to invest in mainland China, Minister of Economic Affairs Christine Tsung said Monday.
She made the remarks to reporters before attending a meeting on the matter called by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development.
Tsung said that the government has reached a basic consensus on whether to permit chip manufacturers to build eight-inch wafer plants in the mainland.

She said her ministry hopes to work out "reasonable and lawful" regulations based on the government's principle of "positive opening and effective management" regarding local investment in the mainland.
The policy replaces the more restrictive "go slow, be patient" policy upheld by the previous administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POLICE TRACK DOWN OPERATORS OF MOVIE88.COM TO MALAYSIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Criminal Investigation Bureau has tracked down the operators of Movie88.com -- an online movie provider that offers live "streaming rentals" of copyrighted movies at US$1 each -- to a lawyer in Malaysia, local police officials said Monday.

The officials said that Tan Soo Leong and an accomplice, Yap Hun Leong, registered their Web domain with the name, address and telephone number of Taiwan's Chunghwa Telecom, "purposely trying to let Taiwan shoulder the blame" for the site.

The Criminal Investigation Bureau of the National Police Administration had originally planned to arrest the suspects when they returned to Taiwan to update computer equipment they left on the island, but recent reports by Time magazine, CNET and other media on Movie88.com blew the case open prematurely, the officials said.
Local police contacted Interpol to assist their Malaysian counterparts in the investigation and to help the Motion Picture Association of America take legal action against Tan, the officials added.

Meanwhile, the head of Taiwan's online criminal investigation division, Lee Hsiang-chen, denied claims by S.E. Tan, an ethnic Chinese man affiliated with Movie88.com and interviewed by Time magazine, that Taiwan's Internet copyright laws cannot protect foreign copyrighted works.

Citing Article 92 of Taiwan's Copyright Law, Lee said that Tan's remarks are a misinterpretation of the Taiwan law under which Movie88.com's actions of profiting from copyrighted movies without obtaining licenses are considered illegal.

DOC.HEADLINE: BATTLE LINES DRAWN AMONG PARTIES OVER REVENUE ALLOCATION DISPUTE (I)

TEXT.P: Battle lines were drawn Monday between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the two major opposition parties over a simmering dispute about how to divide the annual revenues among the central and local governments.

The People First Party (PFP) -- the second-largest opposition party, decided Monday to vote against an Executive Yuan request for a reconsideration of the revised rules governing the allocation of revenues.

After four hours of discussions, PFP legislative whip Lee Ching-an said the party decided to uphold the revision it helped shepherd through the chamber during the last session of the previous legislature in January.

The decision was taken by a vote among the party lawmakers, Lee said, adding that the party, which controls 45 seats in the legislature, would vote in unison during a showdown on the issue the following day.

However, Lee added that the party authorities will not threaten to punish party lawmakers who do not follow the party line, out of "conviction that party members will abide by the PFP decision voluntarily."

The PFP's decision gave the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), which initiated the changes and vowed to stick to its guns in the dispute, a much-needed shot in the arm. The two parties between them control 112 seats, one short of the simple majority needed to override the reconsideration request.
The KMT threatened that day to discipline party lawmakers who failed to heed the party's order to vote against the Executive Yuan's request for reconsideration of the revised rules.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan cut short a trip to Europe and rushed back to Taipei that evening to make sure the party line is followed by all of its lawmakers.

Lien urged the Executive Yuan to avoid a showdown with the opposition in the legislature at the very beginning of the new session and withdraw its request before the legislature begins debating the request Tuesday. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: BATTLE LINES DRAWN AMONG PARTIES OVER REVENUE ALLOCATION DISPUTE (II)

TEXT.P: Otherwise, Lien said, his party will be "forced" to fight against the request tooth and nail.

In order to ensure its 67 lawmakers toe the party line, Tzeng Yung-chuan, acting director of the KMT's policy coordination committee, said any KMT lawmaker deviating from the party line or absent, or abstain from Tuesday's legislative vote will be punished.
The minor opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), declared meanwhile that it will join the ruling DPP in supporting the Executive Yuan's request.
TSU Chairman Huang Chu-wen said the revision is ill-thought out and will widen the gap between the country's rich and poor counties.
However, Huang urged the Executive Yuan to come up with a comprehensive plan within two months to revamp the reinstated rules, which he said are flawed.
If the Executive Yuan fails to meet the TSU's demand, Huang said, his party will reconsider its pro-DPP stance in the future.
The TSU, which has 13 seats in the legislature, will boost the ruling party's camp to 100 seats, which is only 13 seats short of the majority needed to push through the reconsideration.
Both the DPP and Premier Yu Shyi-kun have pulled out all the stops in their efforts to push through the reconsideration request, which will annul the revisions passed by the previous legislature.
The DPP was desperately lobbying KMT lawmakers Monday to vote across party lines and was seeking the support of 12 independent lawmakers who might help the party defeat the KMT and the PFP.

However, independent lawmaker Kao Meng-ting said these political mavericks are torn over the issue because of the different interests of their various constituencies and therefore cannot form a united front.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun went out of his way to canvass support for the reconsideration, both in and out of the legislature.

In a news conference Monday evening, the premier said the revised rules, which oblige the central government to give a bigger share of revenues to local governments, will disrupt the agenda of his administration and will not necessarily improve local governments' coffers.

Noting that the original rules are not perfect, the premier argued that the revised rules are much worse and far more impractical, and he promised to revamp the original rules thoroughly should the reconsideration request be approved.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO SUBSIDIZE R&D CENTERS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The government will subsidize local and foreign enterprises wishing to establish research and development centers in Taiwan, according to a resolution passed by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Monday.
To encourage local and foreign enterprises to set up R&D centers in Taiwan, the government will come up as much as half the money for those companies setting up their first R&D centers on the island.

According to a draft passed by the CEPD to promote R&D centers, the government will promote Taiwan as the regional R&D center for more than 100 multinational enterprises over the next five years, although neither the Ministry of Economic Affairs nor the CEPD have estimated the expenditure needed for such a subsidy.
Meanwhile, the CEPD also drafted a major economic policy during its first council meeting since the new Cabinet was sworn in Feb. 1.

The policy calls for the development of the domestic information industry with a global perspective, the sound development of land management, the construction of a welfare state and the enhanced welfare of Taiwan's people, and the upgrading of government efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO INAUGURATE WATER CONSERVANCY ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials announced Monday that a water conservancy administration under the ministry will be inaugurated March 28.
The MOEA made the decision at the first preparatory meeting for the establishment of the administration.
The ministry also decided to consolidate its Water Conservancy Agency, Water Resources Bureau and other related units to form the new 429-strong administration.
The move marks the MOEA's efforts to unify the management of the island's water resources, the officials said.
They added that it has not yet been decided who will head the administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE INTERIOR MINISTER IMPEACHED

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of the Interior Hsu Ying-shen was impeached by the Control Yuan Monday for alleged misconduct in issuing a license to operate an incinerator when he served as acting Taoyuan County magistrate.

Hsu and five other former and incumbent local officials were accused of failing to comply with regulations by not consulting with air force authorities regarding the erection of the incinerator before issuing the license.

Although they were also warned that the height of the projected incinerator chimney exceeded the limit set for military security, they disregarded the warning and allowed the operator to use the incinerator.
Hsu said that he will appeal against his impeachment to the Public Officials Disciplinary Committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS ON ARCHITECTS TO IMPROVE TAIWAN'S BUILDING DESIGNS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged architects Monday to join forces with the government in improving Taiwan's living environment.

In a meeting with the winners of this year's distinguished architects prize, the president said elite architects have a "noblesse obliges" to improve the country's image with buildings that combine international character with domestic traits.

Noting that the construction industry is one of the locomotives of economic development and an important gauge of the country's competitiveness, Chen said this industry features large on the government's agenda.
Describing buildings as achievements of technology, science and art, the president urged Taiwan architects to fold artistic beauty and the spirit of modern times into their creations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
