Today is Tuesday, Feb. 19, or the eighth day of the first month of the Year of the Horse according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1473: Nicolaus Copernicus, the Polish astronomer who advanced the theory that the Earth rotates daily on its axis and, with the other planets in the solar system, revolves around the Sun, is born.
1800: Napoleon Bonaparte proclaims himself First Consul of the newly established French dictatorship.
1861: Tsar Alexander II signs a proclamation setting free 20 million serfs, almost a third of Russia's population.
1878: Thomas Edison, the U.S. inventor who once described genius as "1 percent inspiration and 99 percent perspiration," is granted a patent for his phonograph.
1909: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th U.S. president, who won the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War and was a big-game hunter, calls for a world conference on conservation.
1915: A French-British fleet begins shelling Turkish fortifications along the strategic Dardenelles waterway in a bid to defeat Turkey and reopen the critical Black Sea supply route to Russia.
1927: The Chinese Nationalists extract a reduction of concessions from Britain at Hankow and Kiukiang.
1932: The United States refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet state of "Manchukuo" (State of Manchuria).
1934: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National Military Council of the Republic of China, launches the "New Life Movement" in Nanchang, Kiangsi Province.
1942: Japanese forces invade Bali in Indonesia and make their first raid on the Australian mainland when they bomb the Northern Territories port of Darwin.
1945: U.S. forces launch an invasion of the island of Iwo Jima, killing most of the 22,000 occupying Japanese troops and eventually taking the Pacific island on March 26 at the cost of 6,821 American lives.
1951: Andre Gide, the French writer who won the 1947 Nobel Prize for literature and was noted for his diaries and novels such as "The Immoralist" and "Lafcadio's Adventures," dies at the age of 82.
1953: The ROC and the Kingdom of Spain sign the Sino-Spanish Friendship Treaty in Madrid.
1955: The Southeast Asian Treaty Organization is established, with eight countries participating.
1958: The ROC Navy sinks three Communist Chinese warships and damages three others in a battle off the Min River estuary.
1959: Britain, Greece and Turkey guarantee the independence of the island of Cyprus.
1963: U.S. President John F. Kennedy announces that the Soviet Union has agreed to pull out several thousand of its troops from Cuba by March 15.
1964: The Sungshan International Airport terminal in Taipei is inaugurated.
1972: Japan establishes diplomatic relations with the Mongolian People's Republic.
1974: The presiding bishop of the American Episcopal Church, the Most Rev. John Hines, arrives for the Thanksgiving and Holy Communion Service on the 20th founding anniversary of the Taiwan Episcopal Church.
1977: Representatives of the disabled celebrate their first "Torch-Light Day" at the Taipei New Park.
1985: A Spanish Airlines Boeing passenger plane crashes in a mountainous area, killing 142 people aboard.
1990: The Liberal Democratic Party under Toshiki Kaifu wins the general elections in Japan.
1991: Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian Federation, urges Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to resign, accusing him of sacrificing reform for "absolute personal power."
1997: Mainland China's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping, who ruled from 1978 until his retirement from his last official post in 1990, dies in Beijing at the age of 93.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian awards the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon to visiting Paraguay Vice President Julio Cesar Franco Gomez in recognition of his contributions to promoting friendship between the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who educates himself for three years without improvement is seldom to be found."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The China Times:
Lawmakers are scheduled to vote on the new budget allocation law today in what is likely to be another showdown between the 'pan-green' and the 'pan-blue' camps.
The United Daily News:
Ruling and opposition parties marshaling support for showdown vote today.
The Liberty Times:
The Legislature will vote on the new budget allocation law in yet another showdown between the 'pan-green' forces of the DPP and the TSU on the one side and the 'pan-blue' camp of KMT and PFP on the other.
The Taiwan Daily:
Parties lining up support for crucial vote on the budget allocation law.
The Central Daily News:
The KMT will discipline its lawmakers who fail to vote against the Cabinet motion to overturn the new allocation law.
The China Post:
No choice over funding request: Premier Yu.
The Taiwan News:
The Cabinet to push new budget law revision.
The Taipei Times:
Premier Yu lobbies for Cabinet motion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 106.95 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 106.95 points to close at 5,861.66.
Market turnover amounted to NT$119.59 billion (US$3.41 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF NEWLY REGISTERED FACTORIES FOR 2001 HITS 20-YEAR LOW

TEXT.P: With Taiwan experiencing a sluggish economy, the number of newly registered factories for 2001 totaled only 3,793, marking a 20-year low, a local daily on Tuesday reported statistics released by the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) as indicating.

The United Daily News reported that the low number of newly registered factories coupled with the fact that 5,187 factories closed down last year meant the number of factories in Taiwan dropped to its lowest level since 1996.

IDB officials said that the industrial production index declined by more than 8.2 percent last year, while interest in domestic investment was also low. Against this background, the number of newly registered factories for last year was down 33 percent over that of the previous year.

The officials also said that with the sharp decline in export orders and the large exodus of domestic manufacturers, 5,187 factories closed up shop in Taiwan in 2001, representing a rise of 3.84 percent in the figure over the previous year and the highest number in three years.

IDB statistics showed that last year represented only the third time that the number of factory closures outnumbered the number of newly registered factories -- the other two years being 1996 and 1998 -- with the figure of 1,394 more closures than newly registered factories marking a new record.

Looking ahead, IDB officials predicted that with the lack of interest among domestic manufacturers in making new investments, the amount of private investment in Taiwan for 2002 could decline by 37 percent over the figure for last year, while the number of newly registered factories could hit a new low.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 106.95 points to close at 5,861.66.

Despite a decline in stock prices in most Asian-Pacific markets, the bourse opened at 6,000.61 but began to go down later due to a wait-and-see attitude on the part of many investors. The index fluctuated between 6,000.61 and 5,857.49 during trading.

A total of 3.79 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$119.59 billion (US$3.41 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 3.52 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$122.81 billion (US$3.5 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with pulp and paper issues moving up 1.5 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 2.4 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 1.5 percent, construction stocks at 1.3 percent, textile issues at 1.2 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.8 percent, cement stocks at 0.2 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 362 to 244, with 82 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER REITERATES NEED TO RECONSIDER BUDGET LAW AMENDMENTS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun reiterated Tuesday that he had "no choice" but to request a legislative reconsideration of amendments to the nation's budget allocation law that were ratified last month.

Only hours before the Legislative Yuan was scheduled to vote on whether to uphold or reconsider the amendments to the Law Governing the Allocation of Government Revenue and Expenditures, Yu urged lawmakers to debate the issue "rationally and professionally."
Reconsideration would mean nullifying the amendments, which were railroaded through on Jan. 17 during the last session of the previous Legislative Yuan.

The Cabinet filed a request with the president on Feb. 6 for a reconsideration by the current Legislature of the amendments, which were set to become law Feb. 9, and Yu pledged that the Cabinet will come up with a more reasonable budget allocation plan within three months.

Yu said that if he had not requested reconsideration, the Cabinet would have been compelled to carry out the changes outlined in the amendments, which he said would necessitate the 2002 fiscal budget already being carried out to undergo revisions, as well as disrupt the central government's monitoring of local financial spending and actually widen the gap between urban and rural areas.

The amendments would allow local governments to keep a bigger share of tax revenues, but Yu said that such a move would make it necessary for the central government to raise additional funds and to reallocate money originally intended for other programs.

Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who helped author the amendments, again urged lawmakers to vote against reconsideration in order to help local governments gain greater budgetary autonomy. He said that many local governments have trouble paying salaries and that they urgently need the central government to provide resources to help local construction.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jyn-ping said that if the budget allocation law has to be amended again, such amendments should be completed before the 2003 central government fiscal budget is drafted in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Tuesday as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for February moved down 131 points to close at 5,825, with 5,563 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March lost 152 points to close at 5,801, with 8,763 contract transactions, while June futures fell 29 points to finish at 5,903, with two contracts traded.
December futures plunged 247 points to close at 5,902, with one contract traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,956 for February, 5,953 for March, 5,932 for June, 5,968 for September, and 6,149 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were generally lower.
February TE futures moved down 7.4 points to close at 311.35, with 1,172 contract transactions, while March TE futures decreased 11.3 points to finish at 307.5, with 1,533 contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
February TF futures moved down 11 points to finish at 706, with 596 contract transactions, while March TF futures fell 7.6 points to close at 713, with 420 contracts traded.
June TF futures gained 11.8 points to finish at 721, with one contract changing hands, while September TF futures increased 11.8 points to close at 721, also with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHERY EXECUTIVES TO MEET WEDNESDAY TO DISCUSS MAINLAND LABOR BAN

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Provincial Fishery Association will host a meeting of chief executives of city and county fishery groups Wednesday to hammer out a strategy to cope with a mainland Chinese ban on exports of fishery workers to Taiwan.

The Tungkang Fishery Association in the southern county of Pingtung confirmed Tuesday that mainland China has indeed decided to ban its fishery workers from working aboard Taiwanese fishing boats after the Chinese New Year holiday.

"The ban will pose great troubles to our offshore fishing industry as many local ship owners rely heavily on mainland workers to operate their fishing vessels," said Chen Kun-yu, secretary-general of the Tungkang Fishery Association.
According to Chen, Tungkang and the Suao Fishery Association in the northeastern county of Ilan are the two local fishing groups whose members are most reliant on mainland Chinese fishery laborers.
At present, Chen said, some 1,130 mainland fishermen are staying aboard special "floating hotels" off the Tungkang fishing port.

"As most of them still have valid working permits, we'll try to persuade them to stay there for the time being," he said, adding that "we are afraid that they won't be able come to Taiwan again once they return to the mainland."
Most local ship owners prefer to hire mainland Chinese fishery workers as they speak the same language and share a common cultural background, Chen said.

"Although there are some Indonesian, Philippine, Thai and Vietnamese fishery workers in the Tungkang area, they can't compete with their counterparts from mainland China due to the language barrier and different living habits," Chen explained.
There have been reports about the mainland Chinese decision to ban its people from working aboard Taiwanese fishing boats since the beginning of this year.
With the assistance of mainland Chinese manpower agencies, Chen said, the Tungkang association has come to know for certain that the mainland fishery labor export ban is for real.
Previous press reports said the temporary export ban was mainly aimed at forcing Taiwanese ship owners to improve working terms and living conditions for mainland fishery workers.

Chen said the Fishery Administration under Taiwan's Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) has offered financial subsidies to major regional fishery associations to build new placement centers for mainland Chinese and foreign fishery workers.

For instance, Chen said, his association will hold an open tender in the near future to select a qualified contractor to build a new placement center near Tungkang fishing port with a view to offering a safe and comfortable living environment for mainland and foreign fishery workers. "The new center is expected to be completed by the end of this year," he added.

Meanwhile, the COA's Fishery Administration has asked various city and county governments and fishery associations to assist local fishing ship owners in employing foreign workers to make up for labor shortages caused by the latest mainland export ban.

As most local ship owners have years of experience in cooperating with mainland fishery workers, they still hope that relevant government agencies can continue consultations with mainland authorities on gaining a lifting of the labor export ban or achieving mutually acceptable alternative measures.

Fishery sources said about 1,000 fishing boats at major Taiwan fishing ports have been affected by the mainland labor export ban, with the northern port of Keelung and the northeastern port of Nanfangao being hardest hit.

The sources said about 200 fishing boats have been "stranded" at Keelung due to a lack of fishery workers. "We need about 800 mainland fishery workers, but many of them returned to the mainland before the Chinese New Year holiday," said an executive with the Keelung Fishery Association.

Many Nanfangao-based fishing ships are facing similar problems. A "floating hotel" operator said he managed to persuade 200-plus mainland fishery workers not to return to the mainland for family reunions before the Chinese New Year holiday. However, the Nanfangao area needs more than 2,000 fishery workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL BOOK EXHIBITION OPENS

TEXT.P: The 10th Taipei International Book Exhibition opened Tuesday, with 1,015 publishers from 47 countries participating in the event and displaying books at 1,856 booths.
President Chen Shui-bian said at the opening of the exhibition that the 21st century has ushered in the era of the global knowledge-based economy.

He said that the government will assist various domestic industries in coping with the necessary transformations and that a major target for government support will be the "knowledge industry" -- of which he said the publishing industry is the foundation.

Chen also urged Taiwan's publishing industry to embrace innovation and utilize the various opportunities for exchanges with its international counterparts to introduce representative works from Taiwan to the world.

The main theme pavilion of the exhibition this year features books from Japan, which publishes approximately 67,000 new titles each year, with a total of over 700 million titles accumulated over the years.
Some 100 noted writers, scholars and cartoonists have been invited to the exhibition, which will be open to the public beginning Feb. 21.
The exhibition is being held at the Taipei World Trade Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO FOCUS ON FREE TRADE AGREEMENTS AFTER WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: With Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) this year, the focus of the island's foreign trade work will be the signing of bilateral free trade agreements with the United States, Japan, Singapore and New Zealand, officials said.

The officials noted that China and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations agreed in November that they would promote a regional free trade zone and that Taiwan could be marginalized if it is left out of the free trade agreement.
Taiwan relies heavily on foreign trade and it is imperative that Taiwan sign free trade agreements with other nations, the officials said.
It is known that the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the Council of Agriculture (COA) are now assessing the potential impact of such agreements.
The COA is worried that the signing of bilateral agreements with the United States and New Zealand will probably send a second shock wave through the agricultural sector on the heels of WTO entry.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs said that Taiwan's electronics and information products mostly go to the United States and that if free trade agreements are signed, then most exports will benefit from the removal of tariffs.

The MAC is concerned about the impact on cross-strait relations by the formation of a free trade zone between mainland China and Southeast Asian and Northeast Asian nations. It said that though Taiwan's promotion of bilateral free trade agreements with nations in the region will have an impact on agricultural products, overall, the impact will be more positive than negative.

P. K. Chiang, vice president of the Legislative Yuan, will attend a meeting Thursday organized by a private group to discuss the economic prospects of Japan and Taiwan this year. He is expected to advocate that the two countries sign a free trade agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICAN PRESIDENT INSPECTS BRIDGE BUILT WITH TAIWAN TECHNOLOGY
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Feb. 18 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez recently inspected the Tempisque River Bridge being built with funding and engineering technology from the Republic of China, the ROC ambassador to Costa Rica said Monday.
Ambassador Mao Kao-wen, who accompanied Rodriguez on his tour, said that the 780-meter bridge is scheduled to be completed by April 2002 and will make travel in the region easier.
He quoted Rodriguez as saying that surveying the bridge on the Costa Rican "day of friendship" was particularly significant and symbolized the friendship between the two nations.

According to the Diario Extra, a Costa Rican newspaper, Mao helped promote several cooperative projects between Taiwan and the Central American nation including the US$27 million Tempisque Bridge, the Puntarenas Sightseeing Wharf and the Moin Wharf during his five years in Costa Rica.
Meanwhile, the Tico Times quoted official estimates as saying that the bridge will help save US$4.5 million each year in commuting costs including fuel and depreciation value of automobiles.
The bridge will make four-times-a-day ferry crossings a thing of the past and cut detour driving time by approximately two hours, the daily added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$ 500 SCREENING FEE TO BE LEVIED ON APPLICATIONS FOR FOREIGN LABORERS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) announced Tuesday that starting from March 1, local employers will have to pay a screening fee of NT$500 (US$14.24) per application for foreign laborers.
CLA's Employment and Vocational Training Administration said that the fee is not refundable even if the application is rejected.

The administration said that starting from March 1, the applications for first recruits of foreign laborers, for renewed recruits, for taking over foreign laborers from other employers and for taking over laborers from affiliated enterprises will have to pay the screening fee.
The officials explained that as the screening fee will be per application, employers can include as many individuals on a single application as they wish.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose on the Taipei Foreign Exchange market Tuesday, up 0.01 to close at NT$35.095.
A total of US$292 million dollars changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$35.066, and was traded between NT$35.066 and NT$35.095.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHANGHAI JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOL VOLLEYBALL TEAM VISITS TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Shanghai Shibei Junior High School volleyball team arrived in Taipei Monday evening on a six-day tour for friendly games with local teams.
Headed by Wang Shu, principle of the school, the 18-member team visited the Chinese-Taipei Volleyball Association Tuesday morning.
Two games were scheduled for the day -- against the Tung Fang Industry and Commerce team in the morning and the Fuhua team in the afternoon.
Chang Chin-jung, secretary-general of the Chinese-Taipei Volleyball Association, said that the visit of the Shanghai team would provide a chance for local teams to enrich their experience.
He said that although the team from the mainland and local teams are evenly matched, the Shanghai squad's players are taller, averaging over 190 centimeters.

Chang said that the Shanghai Shibei Junior High School was founded 85 years ago with a tradition of cultivating elite volleyball players. Many top volleyball players in mainland China, such as Yu Guohua, Lu Ningxing, Suan Lu, Wu Xiaodong and Chang Hong are graduates of the school.
The team will represent Shanghai City in the 2002 national meet of junior high schools to be held in Shanghai in March.
After the two Taipei games, the visiting team will visit Pingtung and Kaohsiung for several other friendlies with local teams before leaving for home from Kaohsiung's Hsiaokang Airport Feb. 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CARRIERS SUSPEND MEAL SERVICES ON DOMESTIC ROUTES

TEXT.P: Passengers who complain about lousy food on airplanes now have nothing to grouse about after Taiwan carriers dropped all in-flight meal services on domestic routes as the airlines find ways to cut costs amid a nationwide recession.

According to industry sources, domestic carriers such as Far East Air Transport Corp. (FAT), Mandarin Airlines, UNI Airlines and TransAsia Airways have all recently canceled their in-flight meal services to write off some of their operational losses.

According to the airlines' estimates, the suspension of the meal service will save them at least NT$6 million per month, based on a daily transport load of 10,000 people and an average cost of NT$20 for each meal.

Many aviation companies also have begun implementing early-retirement programs with special incentives in line with their cost-cutting efforts. More than 100 workers applied to retire last year under a FAT early-retirement plan, marking the largest streamlining ever by a domestic carrier.
Although other aviation companies did not implement early-retirement plans, they saw an average 10 percent reduction in workforce over the past year. This was achieved by not filling vacant jobs.

With the meal services -- once a major attraction for domestic air passengers -- passing into history, it will be difficult in the future for passengers to enjoy the advantages brought about by robust competition, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL HEALTH INSURANCE PREMIUM RATE TO BE RAISED

TEXT.P: The Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) plans to raise the premium rate from the current 4.25 percent to 4.91 percent due to mounting expenditures and heavy deficits, Chang Hong-jen, CEO and president of the bureau, said Tuesday.

Chang said that the national health insurance premium rate has been kept at 4.25 percent since its inception in 1995. But the demographics of the island have changed, he said, as the proportion of elderly has increased. Add to this rising medical costs with the application of hi-tech equipment and the bureau felt that the time had come to adjust its rate, Chang said. The bureau has been in debt since 1998.

Statistics released by the BNHI show that as of the end of 2000, the number of insured individuals exceeded 21.4 million, with a coverage rate of 96 percent. Nearly 91 percent of the more than 17,000 medical institutions are participating members of the national health insurance.
Over the past seven years, the bureau's revenues from premium payments grew by an average 4.26 percent annually, while the expenditures increased by a yearly average of 6.26 percent.
According to Chang, the accumulated deficit of the past years has exhausted the bureau's reserve fund and the amount of the reserve has dropped below the minimum required level.
Chang added that the bureau may have difficulties paying all the participating institutions by March or April due to a serious shortfall in revolving funds.

In view of the imminent financial difficulties, the BNHI is seeking to borrow from financial institutions. It is estimated that the bureau will need at least NT$28 billion in loans to balance its finances this year.
Chang said the bureau has no choice but to raise premiums and increase revenues.

Under the National Health Insurance Act, the total amount of the reserve fund must be equal to the total amount of benefits payments over the most recent one to three months based on actuarial principles. The ratio of premiums or reserves must be adjusted when the total amount of the reserve exceeds three months of payments or falls below one month.

Chang said that the bureau has submitted a draft for the adjustment of the ratio of premiums to the Department of Health under the Executive Yuan. The new ratio will become effective with the approvals of the Department of Health and the Executive Yuan.

A major reason for the financial difficulties to the bureau has been that all local governments have delayed their subsidiary payments to the BNHI in recent years. Of the NT$33.35 billion owed by local governments, the Kaohsiung City Government is NT$9.3 billion in debt and the delayed payments by the Taipei City Government have accumulated to NT$9.1 billion.
With the implementation of the new ratio, the monthly premium payment of a group insurance applicant will be 15.5 percent higher than the current payment.

From December 1998, the average premium has remained at NT$1,007. The insured shares 60 percent of premium and the government shares 40 percent. The premium of the community population -- without salaried income -- is NT$604, according to statistics compiled by the BNHI.
With the new ratio, the monthly premium payment of a family of four will be about NT$250 higher than the current level.

Chang said that despite the fact that the national health insurance program has been constantly operating in the red, a recent survey has shown that public satisfaction with the compulsory social insurance program was high at 71 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER GOV'T OFFICIAL TAKES POST AS DPP DEPUTY SECRETARY-GENERAL

TEXT.P: A former government official took the post as deputy secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Tuesday, a DPP source said.

You Ying-lung, former vice chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) under the Executive Yuan, succeeded Hsu Yang-ming, who was transferred to the new post as deputy mayor of Tainan City, southern Taiwan, DPP Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen said.
The takeover and handover ceremony for You and Hsu was held shortly after DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh reported the personnel adjustment at the party's Central Standing Committee in the afternoon.
Throwing great support behind Chen Shui-bian during the 2000 presidential election, You served as RDEC vice chairman after Chen was elected.
You resigned his post as RDEC vice chairman to run for the magistrateship of Hualien County, eastern Taiwan, in late last year's legislative and local elections. He did not win.

DOC.HEADLINE: UMC SUSPENDS PARTNERSHIP WITH HITACHI
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, Feb. 19 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) announced Tuesday that it suspended a partnership with Japan's Hitachi on a 12-inch silicon wafer fabrication joint venture in Japan, effective the same day.

Hitachi will own 100 percent of Trecenti -- the world's first 12-inch wafer fabrication plant that began commercial production in March 2001 -- after it buys back the 40 percent stake in the shares of Trecenti that UMC held, said Wu Hung-jen, UMC's president and one of the company's board directors.

Satoru Ito, the CEO of Hitachi's semiconductor division, said that although the Trecenti partnership has ended -- primarily as a result of the poor global business climate -- the two companies will maintain close relations in other businesses.

Because of the global economic slowdown, UMC will focus its attention and resources on three major operations: the Fab 12A located in the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park in southern Taiwan; UMCi Partnership Ltd., a joint venture between UMC and Germany's Infineon Technologies AG; and AU Pte Ltd., a joint venture with U.S.-based Advanced Micro Devices Inc., Wu said.

Both UMCi and AU are involved in 12-inch silicon wafer fabrication plants which are located in Singapore's Pasir Ris Wafer Fab Park. AU is scheduled to begin commercial production on 65-nanometer technology in mid-2005.
Because of the global recession, UMC's revenues for 2001 were NT$64.49 billion, a net loss of NT$3.15 billion from a year earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EXPECTS TO TAKE DELIVERY OF KIDD-CLASS DESTROYERS BY 2005

TEXT.P: The ROC Navy expects to take delivery of the first two Kidd-class destroyers from the United States by the end of 2005, military spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said Tuesday.
Huang told the media at a tea party hosted by the Ministry of National Defense (MND) in celebration of the Chinese New Year that the navy has completed a Kidd-class destroyers procurement plan.
"We'll include the procurement plan in the MND's 2003 budget," Huang said, adding that if all goes smoothly, the first two Kidd-class destroyers can be delivered to Taiwan by the end of 2005.

The United States agreed to sell the Republic of China four of its Kidd-class destroyers last April. With the assistance of the MND, Huang said, the navy has finalized a relevant systematic analysis and investment plan.
"If the plan can receive full support of the Legislative Yuan, we'll be able to acquire the highly advanced warships by 2005," Huang said.

The navy began to prepare for the purchase of Kidd-class destroyers when current Chief of the General Staff Adm. Li Chieh was still navy commander-in-chief. As the 172-meter, 8,910-ton warships have basic battlefield management capabilities, Lee reportedly intended to organize four naval battle groups, with the four Kidd-class destroyers as their flagships.
Lee once said the ROC Navy will be able to carry out deep-sea patrol and defense missions after acquiring the four Kidd-class destroyers from the United States.

The Kidd-class destroyers, powered by four gas turbine engines, are capable of cruising at a maximum of 33 knots. Military sources said that although the destroyers are 20 years old, they still have another 20 to 30 years of service left in them. Moreover, they carry a price tag only about one-sixth that of a new vessel.
The destroyers were originally built for use by Iran during the reign of the Shah, but the U.S. Navy took control of the ships in 1981 and 1982 after Iran's revolutionary Islamic regime took power.

On Tuesday, Huang also denied that Minister of National Defense Tang Yao-ming and Chief of the General Staff Li Chieh have been invited to attend a defense conference to be held March 10-12 in the southeastern U.S. state of Florida.
To date, Huang said, neither Tang nor Li has received an invitation to attend the conference, to be organized by the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council.
Nevertheless, Huang said, the MND will be pleased to see any meeting that would contribute to stability, security and peace in the Taiwan Strait.

According to foreign wire service reports, the upcoming Taiwan-U.S. defense conference will be a large-scale event rarely seen after the break in formal diplomatic ties between the two countries in 1979. The reports said many senior U.S. and Taiwan defense officials have been invited to address the meeting. Several U.S. defense contractors, including Boeing, Lockheed-Martin and Raytheon reportedly will co-sponsor the conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS SECTOR TO PRESENT INVESTMENT-RELATED PROPOSALS TO GOV'T

TEXT.P: The business and industrial sectors are preparing a draft of proposals for the improvement of Taiwan's investment environment and will present them to President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Yu Shyi-kun at a meeting in early March, Wang Ling-lin, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the ROC, said Tuesday.

Wang said that representatives of the six leading business and industrial associations will prepare the proposals regarding the restructuring of government organizations, monetary reforms and public finance, and the utilization of land.
At a meeting Tuesday afternoon, business leaders and economic specialists outlined key points of the proposals.
Referring to the government's restructuring, the participants suggested that the government should take into consideration the cost factor in personnel recruitment and deployment.
While the business and industrial sectors are most concerned about taxation and the financial system, Wang said that the government should create a low-tax environment to attract investors.
Representatives of business and industrial associations will attend a dinner party celebrating the Spring Festival at the Taipei International Convention Center March 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA REITERATES BAN ON EXPORTS OF WASTE

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Tuesday it has ordered all local environmental agencies to reject any application for shipping domestic industrial waste or household trash abroad for permanent disposal.

The EPA was responding to an appeal by a local environmental protection group urging the government to prevent a Taiwan company from dumping factory waste in the South Pacific island nation of the Solomon Islands.
Lu Hung-kuang, director of the EPA's Solid Waste Control Bureau, said the EPA has been keeping close tabs on the reported deal since it received relevant information last November.

"The deal apparently has violated international and domestic regulations," Lu said. "In addition to reminding the local company not to break the domestic law, we have alerted customs authorities and environmental police forces to intensify monitoring of relevant developments."
Lu said the company in southern Taiwan does not have a license to handle waste disposal services and has never filed for any application to export garbage.
"We already asked customs authorities in January to carefully inspect Solomon Islands-bound goods exported by the company in question," Lu explained.

Quoting the multilateral Basal Convention on cross-border shipment of waste, Lu said that without the approval of the recipient country's environmental protection agency, no waste can be exported to that country.
According to information received by the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Lu said, the Solomon Islands authorities have revoked their import permit for the Taiwan garbage deal.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE APPROVES CABINET REQUEST FOR ALLOCATION RECONSIDERATION

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved Tuesday an Executive Yuan request for reconsideration of controversial changes to the rules governing the allocation of revenues.
The outcome of the vote was 103 for and 109 against, which is four votes short of the 113 majority needed to uphold the change.

DOC.HEADLINE: BELIZE PRIME MINISTER TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Belize Prime Minister H.E. Said W. Musa will arrive in Taiwan Feb. 25 for a four-day visit in the Republic of China, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday in a press release.

While here, Musa will call on President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, and will attend a dinner hosted by Premier Yu Shyi-kun and a luncheon hosted by Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien.
He will also visit several cultural and economic establishments.

A cordial friend of the ROC, Musa has previously visited Taiwan three times -- when he was leader of the People's United Party (PUP) in 1988, when he was foreign minister in 1991 and when he was prime minister in 1998.

Musa took office as concurrent prime minister, minister of finance and minister of foreign affairs in 1998. He has served since early this year as prime minister, minister of finance, minister of economic development and minister of foreign trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER HAILS BUSH'S REAFFIRMATION OF COMMITMENT TO ROC

TEXT.P: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien issued a public statement Tuesday hailing U.S. President George W. Bush's reaffirmation of security commitments to the people of Taiwan.
In a speech to the Japanese Diet Tuesday morning, Bush stated clearly and firmly that the United States will remember its commitments to the people of Taiwan.
"We recognize and welcome Bush's reaffirmation of U.S. commitments to our country," Chien said. "The move betrays Bush's support for Taiwan's democratization and peace in the Taiwan Strait."

As Japan is the first leg of Bush's current Asia tour, Chien said, Bush's reaffirmation of commitments to Taiwan is of great significance. "The statement highlights solid U.S. support for democratic Taiwan and the importance the Bush administration has attached to Taiwan Strait peace and security," he noted.
Since the ROC and the United States share common values, concepts and interests, Chien said he is convinced that relations between the two countries will further strengthen based on mutual trust.

"The recent strings of Bush statements indicate that the United States regards Taiwan as its good friend, values Taiwan's democratic achievements and is concerned about Taiwan Strait security," Chien said, adding that the ROC government will continue doing its utmost to upgrade bilateral relations.
Bush ended its three-day visit to Japan and flew to Seoul Tuesday afternoon to continue his Asia tour, which will also take him to mainland China later this week.

A local political analyst familiar with Taiwan-U.S.-mainalnd China relations said Bush's reaffirmation of U.S. commitments to Taiwan in his address to the Japanese Diet was partly aimed at encouraging diplomatically conservative Japan not to take a hands-off policy toward Taiwan Strait issues.

Moreover, he said, Bush's statement was also designed to send messages to Beijing leaders that the basic tone of U.S. China policy will not change and that the Taiwan Strait issue will not be a main focus of his mainland visit.

Meanwhile, Mainland Affair Council Vice Chairman John C. C. Teng said at a seminar on investment in mainland China that Bush's upcoming visit to Beijing is not expected to result in any surprise changes to the delicate Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations.

Teng further said mainland China's imminent reshuffle of its ruling hierarchy will not necessarily lead to changes to its policy toward Taiwan. According to Teng, 14 mainland provinces have completed personnel reshuffle.

Commenting on mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen's recent remarks that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should establish a mechanism for economic cooperation, Teng said he hopes mainland authorities can take concrete steps to materialize Qian's pragmatic call.

For its part, Teng said, the ROC government will continue revising its regulations to pave the way for mainland capital to enter Taiwan, Taiwan people to take jobs on the mainland and expansion of direct cross-strait transshipment services.

DOC.HEADLINE: KUANSHAN WILDLIFE CONSERVATION PARK BEING PLANNED IN TAITUNG

TEXT.P: In an effort to protect Taiwan's wildlife and preserve its ecosystems, the Taiwan Forest Bureau (TFB) under the Council of Agriculture is planning to build a wildlife conservation park in eastern Taitung County.

The planned 69,000-hectare Kuanshan Wildlife Conservation Park, which will include the 0.265-hectare Chiaming Lake at the height of 3,250 meters above sea level, will become a part of an "ecological corridor" linking the Chilan Mountain Area in northern Taiwan and the Tanda Mountain Area in central Taiwan via a "green corridor" extending from north to south through the island's Central Range.
The Chiaming Lake is Taiwan's sole meteoric lake, which is a rarity anywhere in the world.

The plan has won widespread support from the aboriginal tribes living in the area, with Yenping Township Chief Hu Wu-jen of the Bunun Tribe calling on his tribesmen to support the policy. The Kuanshan Area is the traditional home of the Bunun Tribe, one of Taiwan's major indigenous peoples.

In line with the building of the wildlife conservation park, the TFB's Taitung branch will also set up a databank on the area's animals and plants to ensure the conservation of the area's ecosystem, natural landscape and geology.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TOP BRASS NOT INVITED TO U.S.-TAIWAN MILITARY SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Republic of China National Defense Minister Tang Yao-ming has not received an invitation to the U.S.-Taiwan defense industry summit scheduled to be held in Florida March 10-12, military spokesman Huang Suey-sheng said Tuesday.
ROC Chief of the General Staff Li Chieh, who summit organizers claimed had been invited, has also not received an invitation as of Tuesday, Huang said.

Huang made the remarks in response to foreign wire service reports that said both Tang and Li had been invited to the summit -- the first of its kind to have been arranged by the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council.
Huang stressed, however, that the Ministry of National Defense welcomes all kinds of meetings or gatherings conducive to peace, security and stability across the Taiwan Strait.

According to the foreign wire service reports, the three-day meeting -- rare since Washington switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979 -- will focus its discussions on arms sales procedures and Taiwan's defense needs in the years ahead, particularly in the so-called C4I -- command, control, communication, computers and intelligence.
Scheduled speakers will include U.S. Deputy Secretary of Defense Paul Wolfowitz and several senior U.S. state and military officials.
The military summit, to be held in St. Petersburg, Florida, will also be attended by U.S. defense industry big names, including Boeing, Lockheed Martin and Raytheon.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD LUNAR NEW YEAR DEPARTURES, ARRIVALS AT CKS AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Airport authorities registered a record high of 72,189 arrivals and departures Feb. 17 at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport during the Lunar New Year holiday, a local newspaper reported Tuesday.

Citing statistics compiled by the airport police authorities, the China Times reported that inbound and outbound passengers totaled more than 64,000 Feb. 8 -- the first day of the 10-day holiday season -- at the airport that is Taiwan's principal gateway. That number also exceeded the previous single-day record registered Feb. 16, 1999, while the number posted Feb. 9 was also a new high of 67,790.
In a bid to process the huge numbers of arriving and departing passengers during the 10-day period, customs officials, police and security officers had to inspect more than 1,000 people per shift.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT INTERACTION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China reiterated a call Tuesday for a resumption of official dialogue and interaction across the Taiwan Strait.

Quoting a Chinese poem about the arrival of spring, Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said the springtime of cross-strait relations has yet to arrive. "We will meet the spring only after we have weathered the severe winter," Koo said.
In a "group greeting function" held at SEF headquarters Tuesday following the Chinese New Year holiday, Koo was asked about the prospects of a resumption of cross-strait dialogue.

He said official cross-strait relations seemed to have improved a little over the past year, evident in Beijing's proposal to establish an economic cooperation mechanism across the strait and his claim that both sides have reached "verbal consensus" on various issues.

Koo said he hopes that this consensus can be upgraded into action in the new year, and that interaction between the SEF and its Beijing-based counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- can be normalized.

SEF-ARATS interaction is important "and inevitable," Koo said, adding that if indeed the two intermediary bodies resume their talks and interaction, springtime for cross-strait relations will be right around the corner.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES PUBLISHERS TO HELP DISSEMINATE TAIWAN CULTURE

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian urged the publishing industry Tuesday to help introduce Taiwan culture to the international community.

Speaking at the opening of the 10th Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE), Chen said that the 21st century will be an era of knowledge-based economy and added that future economic competition will be based on knowledge.
He went on to say that "the creation and use of knowledge will be the key to the success or failure of competition between countries or industries."
Now that Taiwan has become a World Trade Organization member, the president said, the government will make all-out efforts to help industries transform so as to cope with the upcoming challenges`.
Describing the publishing industry as the foundation of the "knowledge industry," Chen encouraged it to introduce excellent publications on Taiwan culture to foreigners through book fairs.
TIBE 2002, being held at the Taipei World Trade Center, attracted 1,015 exhibitors from 47 countries.
The first two days are open to representatives from the publishing industry and specially invited guests, while the show is open to the public from Feb. 21-24.
Along with the book fair, special exhibitions featuring Russian illustrations and French printing-engraving techniques, called chalchography, from the Louvre gallery in Paris, are being held.
Five topical exhibit areas are set aside for international exhibitors, children's books, general books, comic books and an e-books forum.

The main theme pavilion of the exhibition this year features books from Japan and many noted Japanese writers and cartoonists have been invited to sign autographs for their fans and attend various seminars.

A seminar titled "The Beauty of Small Things: The Late Japanese Writer Yasunari Kawabata," will be presented Feb. 22, with the participation of Kawabata's adopted son, Kaori, director of the Yasunari Kawabata Foundation.

On Feb. 23, a panel on Taiwan-Japan relations and related political developments will be held. The panelists will include former ROC President Lee Teng-hui, Taiwan independence activist Alice King and Japanese scholar Mineo Nakajima.
Fair organizers predicted that some 400,000 visitors from Taiwan and abroad will visit the exhibition this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S JANUARY TRADE DROPS 10.8% YEAR-ON-YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two-way trade totaled US$17.05 billion in January, a decrease of 10.8 percent over the previous year's level, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Of the total, exports accounted for US$9.69 billion, representing a drop of 1.4 percent, while imports amounted to US$7.36 billion, or a decrease of 20.9 percent over the year-earlier level.
The January trade surplus registered US$2.22 billion, an increase of 339.5 percent over the previous year's level and the 23rd consecutive monthly surplus.
Taiwan exported US$2.05 billion-worth of goods to the United States in January, a drop of 11.6 percent.
Exports to Hong Kong reached US$2.37 billion, an increase of 39.5 percent over the previous year's level, making Hong Kong the country's largest buyer for the past three consecutive months.
Taiwan exported US$960 million-worth of goods to Japan, a decrease of 19.9 percent over the previous year, apparently affected by the prolonged recession in Japan.
Exports to members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nation decreased by 18.8 percent.
At the same time, exports of Taiwan-produced electronic products dropped 15.4 percent over the year-earlier level, indicating that the global recession has had a great impact on the sector.
In terms of the top ten import items, all major items, with the exception of IT products, dropped compared with the previous year's level.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LAW ENFORCEMENT CLOSES WEB SITE OF MOVIE88.COM

TEXT.P: A law enforcement team Tuesday under the direction of the Prosecutor's Office of the Taipei District Court ordered the closure of the Web site movie88.com on the Chunghwa Telecom's server because the site was illegally offering movies via "streaming rentals" at US$1 each.

According to investigations made by Taiwan's Criminal Investigation Bureau, movie88.com was originally registered in Virginia but the operators of the Web domain -- with the name, address and telephone number of Taiwan's Chunghwa Telecom -- "purposely tried to let Taiwan shoulder the blame" for the site.

After making contact with American Music Association and a reporter who filed a report from Hollywood, police tracked down the server operators to Tan Soo Leong, a lawyer in Malaysia and his accomplice, Yap Hun Leoung.

The police also found that the online credit card company -- asiadebit.com was registered in Thailand, police said. However, payments to the service provider were made by check through a bank in New York, police said, adding that the details of the payments will be further investigated by U.S. law enforcement.

The head of Taiwan's online criminal investigation division, Lee Hsiang-chen, said that a company or a individual wanting to apply for a Web site is not researched by the service provider, therefore, allowing numerous dubious sites to open offering gambling and pornography, Lee said.
Movie88.com has not only violated the "author rights law" but has also damaged Taiwan's image in the international community, Lee added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTRY TO DRAFT NEW ALLOCATION BILL AMENDMENT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will put forth a new version of amendments to the law on government revenues and expenditures within three months, Finance Minister Lee Yung-san said Tuesday.

Lee said the MOF will invite officials from local governments, scholars and finance experts to jointly draft the amendments in the hope that the amendments will help the central and local governments solve their financial problems once and for all.

Lee made the announcement following the Legislative Yuan's vote to overturn an earlier amendment -- authored by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, a stalwart of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -- to the budget allocation law.
The Legislative Yuan passed Ma's revision Jan. 18, but the Cabinet filed a proposal Feb. 6 asking that the Legislature reconsider the amendment.

The KMT and the other main opposition party -- the People First Party -- tried hard over the ensuing few weeks to gain support for a rejection of the Executive Yuan's request for a cancellation of the Ma-authored revision, which gives local governments a bigger share of the government's total revenues.

However, their efforts failed and Vice Finance Minister Wang Teh-shan noted that Ma's amendment cancels the allocations of general subsidies, which he said is improper in practical terms. Wang said the general subsidies system is an inevitable measure that helps narrow the gap in finances between local governments and municipalities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE RESPECTS LAWMAKERS' DECISION ON REVENUE ALLOCATION

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Presidential Office said Tuesday that the Presidential Office respects the Legislative Yuan's decision to accede to the Executive Yuan's request for a cancellation of the revision of the budget allocation law.

Huang Chih-feng, director of the Public Affairs Office of the Presidential Office, said that the request to cancel the revision law passed at the end of the last legislative session in January, is a democratic mechanism under a constitutional system.

Opposition lawmakers managed to get 109 votes against 103, but this was four votes short of the 113 required to override the Executive Yuan's request. The Presidential Office expressed the hope that the Legislative Yuan's decision would be respected.
Huang noted that the issue was a dispute over between the Executive Yuan and the legislative Yuan and said that the Presidential Office maintains a neutral position.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT CALLS FOR REGROUPING OF POLITICAL PARTIES

TEXT.P: Former president Lee Teng-hui called for the regrouping of Taiwan's political parties Tuesday.

Speaking at the commencement of a training camp for his young followers, the former president said although there are 95 political parties in Taiwan, only four of them are active ones, namely the Democratic Progressive Party, Kuomintang, the People First Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) of which he is the spiritual leader.
Lee said the four parties should reorganize into two groups , with one devoted to Taiwan and the other not so-devoted to Taiwan.

A division of political groups in this way will offer the public an easy choice in elections, and political showdown which has dogged the country ever since the DPP was swept to power last year will end for good, Lee said.

Declaring that Taiwan's economy has come to a critical point this year, Lee called for the conclusion of free trade pact with the United States which will offer Taiwan-produced goods a free access to United States market with lower tariffs and no limitations of quota, Lee said.
The TSU will come up with a motion for such a trade pact in the Legislative Yuan Thursday, Lee went on.

Fielding questions from his audience, Lee dismiss a young man's fears that mainland China could annex the island in the future. Lee told him mainland China will be transformed peacefully by the force unleashed by its won economic reform before it could use military force against Taiwan.
He also urged the opposition parties to give President Chen Shui-bian a free hand in leading the country, rather than blocking him at every turn.
The four-day camp, dubbed by Lee's followers as "Lee's School", has brought together 66 college or university students around the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL, EVA PLANES TO USE JAPAN'S NARITA AIRPORT

TEXT.P: China Airlines and EVA Airways flights will use Narita International Airport instead of Haneda Airport from April 18, when a second runway at Narita is inaugurated.

To coincide with the move, CAL will increase the number of its weekly flights between Taipei and Tokyo from the present 21 to 22, while EVA's weekly flights on the same route will be boosted sharply from two to 14.
In addition, EVA and Japan's ANK will also jointly operate seven flights per week on the profitable route.

After the severance of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Japan in 1972, Tokyo refused to let CAL -- at the time the Republic of China flag-carrier -- use the New Tokyo International Airport at Narita, a move designed to ensure that aircraft from mainland China and Taiwan did not use the same airport.
After the inauguration of Narita International Airport, Haneda airport became a domestic-only facility, with the exception of CAL flights.

However, CAL in fact profited greatly from the discriminatory step because many passengers chose to use CAL and arrive and leave Japan via Haneda rather than Narita -- for obvious reasons. It takes only 30 minutes to reach Haneda from downtown Tokyo by car, while a car ride from Tokyo to Narita in Chiba Prefecture takes 90 minutes.
EVA has also been using Haneda airport since it started operating flights between Taipei and Tokyo in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION FAILS TO SUSTAIN REVISION TO REVENUE-ALLOCATION RULES

TEXT.P: The two main opposition parties failed Tuesday to muster enough votes to override the Executive Yuan's request for a reconsideration of a controversial change to the rules governing the allocation of budget revenues.

The Kuomintang (KMT), and the People First Party (PFP), which jointly pushed through the changes Jan. 18, managed to get only 109 votes to oppose the Executive Yuan's motion, four short of the simple majority of 113 votes they needed in the 225-seat legislature.

The two parties control 114 seats between them at the Legislative Yuan, but two lawmakers from each party failed to show up for Tuesday's vote, despite the party whips' repeated calls for their members to rally behind the party's position.
The opposition's defeat means the revision to the revenue allocation rules lapses automatically.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun lauded the outcome of the vote as a successful result of rational dialogue between the ruling and the opposition parties. He called it a beneficial situation for the Legislative Yuan, the Executive Yuan, the country and the people.
He went to the legislature to thank Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng after being informed of the results of the vote.
For his part, Wang called on Yu to quell the controversy over how to allocate revenue among central and local government by setting up a fair mechanism.

KMT legislative whip Lin Yi-shih said that his party regretted, but would respect the outcome. He urged the Executive Yuan to fulfill its promise to revamp the existing rules governing the allocation of revenues within three months.

Legislator Tzeng Yung-chuan, the acting director of the KMT's central policy coordination committee, said the two KMT lawmakers absent from the vote would be referred to the disciplinary committee for possible punishment.

Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, the KMT stalwart who inspired his party to change the revenue allocation rules in the first place, said he was disappointed with the results but did not regret his failed efforts.

Claiming the campaign to address the "flawed" revenue allocation rules is a continuing war, Ma said Tuesday's setback was only a lost battle and not the end of the war. It was rather the beginning of a struggle to break the central government's stranglehold on power and funds.

The mayor, who had been calling lawmakers of various parties on the phone until the last minute to seek their support for the KMT-initiated changes, said his struggle was not completely in vain, pointing to the fact that the drawbacks to the existing rules have been widely discussed in the leadup to Tuesday's vote.
PFP legislative whip Lee Ching-an blamed the Executive Yuan for what she called "interference with the legislature's vote by putting undue pressure on the lawmakers." She did not elaborate.

As to the two PFP lawmakers who did not show up Tuesday, Lee said they were absent for "personal reasons" and would be sent to the disciplinary committee for punishment to the full extent of the party rules.
The ruling DPP was pleased with the vote result, but refrained from being too jubilant over its victory.
DPP legislative whip Ker Chien-ming said there is "no winner or loser" in the vote and that his party would prefer dialogue over showdown votes with the opposition in future disputes.

Lo Chih-ming, a lawmaker of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), a minor opposition party and a DPP ally in the legislature, said Tuesday's results indicate that public opinion, not party will, prevailed in the vote.
He warned the DPP against complacency over the results, pointing out that four more lawmakers voted against the reconsideration motion than those who approved it.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HARBOR AIMING TO PROMOTE CROSS-STRAIT SEA-AIR TRANSPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Feb. 19 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau (KHB) plans to use the harbor's status as the only transshipment channel for goods arriving from mainland China to push for joint cross-strait sea-sea and sea-air transportation, a KHB source said Tuesday.

KHB Director Huang Ching-tern said it is most important for shipping agents to transport goods to consumer markets quickly and added that Kaohsiung can develop joint sea-sea and sea-air transport to achieve this goal.

Kaohsiung is Taiwan's only harbor allowed to engage in cross-strait offshore fixed-site transshipping services. The mainland ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou perform the same function on the other side of the strait.

Despite the sluggishness of the global shipping market, Kaohsiung harbor performed well in January, with 2,984 ships sailing in and out of Kaohsiung harbor, an increase of 4.56 percent from the same month of the previous year, according to KHB statistics.
The gross tonnage amounted to 52.3 million tonnes, a year-on-year growth of 3.92 percent, the statistics show.

A total of 29.96 million tons of bulk cargo was handled at Kaohsiung harbor in January, up 5.89 percent from the year-earlier level and a total of 609,014 TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent units) were handled, up 5.91 percent from last January, according to the KHB figures.
Kaohsiung harbor handled 7.5 million TEUs during the whole of last year and the KHB has set this year's goal at 8 million TEUs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 20, or the ninth day of the first month of the Year of the Horse according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1437: James I, King of Scotland, is assassinated by a group of nobles seeking to place a rival on the throne. He was 42.
1694: Voltaire, French philosopher, writer and moralist who waged a lifelong campaign against intolerance and injustice, is born.
1707: Aurangzeb, the sixth and perhaps last of the great Mogul emperors of India, dies at the age of 88. He seized the throne at Agra from his father, Shah Jahan, 49 years earlier, killing two of his brothers and jailing the third to secure his succession.
1811: Austria declares itself bankrupt.
1904: Alexei Kosygin, Soviet prime minister from 1964 to 1980, is born.
1915: The Panama-Pacific Exhibition, in celebration of the opening of the Panama Canal linking the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, kicks off in San Francisco.
1916: The Battle of Verdun begins after Chief of the German General Staff Falkenhayn chooses to attack the French city of Verdun, despite his belief that France will defend it to the last man.
1919: Afghan head of state Habibullah Khan is assassinated. He was succeeded by one of his sons, Amanullah Khan.
1922: Hong Kong police fire on striking workers, killing two and severely injuring seven.
1933: The U.S. House of Representatives passes an act to abolish the law prohibiting the consumption of alcohol in the United States.
1938: British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden resigns in protest against Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's policy of appeasement of Italy's Fascist dictator Benito Mussolini and Germany's Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler.
1942: Portugal protests to Japan after Japanese troops invade Portuguese Timor.
1946: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China declares the Yalta Secret Agreement not binding in the case of China.
1952: A meeting on the Treaty of Peace between the Republic of China and Japan is held in Taipei.
1960: The third plenary session of the first ROC National Assembly opens in Taipei.
1962: Astronaut John Glenn circles the Earth three times in less than five hours, becoming the first U.S. citizen to orbit the planet.
1966: Chester William Nimitz, admiral of the U.S. Pacific Fleet during World War II who halted Japanese expansion and ultimately destroyed the Japanese fleet with a strategy based largely on the use of aircraft carriers, dies at the age of 81.
1967: President Sukarno surrenders all executive power to Gen. Suharto, keeping only the title of president of Indonesia.
1971: Maj. Gen. Idi Amin Dada heads the new government of Uganda as president after the Ugandan army overthrows Apollo Milton Obote.
1972: Radio telephone service between Taipei and Madrid is inaugurated.
1976: Gen. Wego Chiang, president of the Armed Forces University, and 30 foreign cadets studying war techniques in the ROC visit the offshore island of Kinmen.
1979: Mount Sinira erupts in Indonesia, claiming 175 lives.
1988: Torrential flooding in Rio de Janeiro leaves 500 dead and 10,000 homeless.
1997: Washington refuses to recognize the World Trade Organization's authority in its dispute with the European Union over trade with Cuba.
2000: ROC presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party stresses that only political party rotation can maintain Taiwan's administrative neutrality and achieve independence of the government's judicial branch.
2001: Newly appointed Solomon Islands Ambassador to the ROC Seth Gukuna presents his credentials to President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who is not in office in the government of a country, should never give advice as to its policy."

DOC.HEADLINE: WORKSHOP ON CROSS-STRAIT TRADE OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The First Workshop on Trade Across the Taiwan Strait kicked off Tuesday in Taipei for three days of brainstorming and speeches on issues pertaining to the new trade climate and challenges that Taiwan and mainland China are facing.

In his address to the opening session, Vincent Siew, former premier of the Republic of China and current chairman of the Cross Strait Common Market Foundation, which is sponsoring the workshop, said Taiwan is now facing new challenges of various types amid the changing political and economic situations in the world.
Mainland China is now Taiwan's biggest rival as well as its greatest challenge in terms of trade and business, and Taiwan can neither shun nor pretend not to see it, Siew said.

With the accession of both Taiwan and mainland China to the World Trade Organization (WTO) at the beginning of this year, further integration of the trade regimes across the Taiwan Strait has become an irreversible trend, he added.

Noting that there are still numerous obstacles and barriers in the increasingly hustle-and-bustle cross-strait trade, Siew said the Cross Strait Common Market Foundation is committed to helping bolster the constructive development of cross-strait trade and business based on the principles of reciprocity, exchange, peace and co-prosperity.
Siew noted that both sides should make the most of the opportunities that WTO membership brings to prosper themselves and at the same time normalize trade and business relations across the strait.
He added that Taiwan and mainland can then talk about the formation of a free trade agreement which would eventually pave the way for the two sides to establish a cross-strait common market.

Scheduled speakers at the three-day workshop include Vice Economic Minister Chen Ruey-long; Yen Wan-chin, deputy secretary-general of the quasi-official intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF); Jan Jyh-horng, director of the Research and Planning Department under the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), who also doubles as a SEF deputy secretary-general; and Fu Don-cheng, director of the MAC's Department of Economic Affairs.

Others scheduled to speak at the workshop include Chang Wu-yueh, dean of Tamkang University's Institute of Mainland China Studies; Tseng Fan-cheng, deputy CEO of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., which is planning to relocate part of its manufacturing operations to mainland China; and Yeh Kuo-yi, chairman of the Inventec Group, which already operates a computer processing business on the mainland.

Participants to the workshop are mainly graduate school students and doctorate candidates in Taiwan's major colleges and universities who are currently studying cross-strait trade and business relations and related subjects.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 169.48 points to close at 5,692.18.
Market turnover amounted to NT$96.92 billion (US$2.76 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONSUMER CONFIDENCE UP CONSIDERABLY: MASTERINDEX SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan enjoyed a considerable increase in consumer confidence between mid 2001 and the end of the year, with the index for the island of a survey by MasterCard International Corp. gauging such sentiment surging from 23.8 to 46.2 between the two periods.

The MasterIndex survey, conducted twice a year, measures consumer confidence in 13 markets within the Asia-Pacific region. The latest survey was completed in December 2001, with a total of 5,457 respondents from across the region providing their input, a company spokesman said Wednesday.
In the survey, five variables were analyzed, including the employment and economic situations, regular income, the stock market, and quality of life.

While consumers in Taiwan gave higher scores for all five variables in the December survey, improved perceptions were most notable for the economic situation, with the score surging to 52.2 from 24 in the previous survey, and the stock market, with the score rising from 32.2 to 59.1.
The spokesman said that the improved index was a sign of economic recovery, which he said would definitely help boost consumers' purchasing power.

Among the 13 markets, mainland China was the best performer in the latest MasterIndex survey, with mainland respondents providing the highest ever index scores for quality of life at 92.1, for regular income at 90.9, for the economy at 90.6, and for the employment situation at 76.5.
South Korea had the second highest index score of 68.1, a remarkable recovery from the index score of 25.9 in the same survey a year ago and from 54.4 in the survey conducted in mid 2001.

The survey report indicated that consumer confidence in Hong Kong at the end of last year was at an all-time low, dropping to 12.5. While Hong Kong consumers indicated the most anxiety about their future quality of life, the economy and employment prospects, the scores for all five variables dropped from those recorded in previous surveys.

The spokesman said the responses are based on consumers' thoughts on the six months ahead, namely for the December 2001 to May 2002 period in the latest survey. The survey is said to be accurate within plus or minus four percentage points nine times out of ten.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 169.48 points to close at 5,692.18.

Affected by a plunge in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,817.74 and continued to go down due to heavy selling pressure and a lack of confidence on the part of investors. The index fluctuated between 5,838.45 and 5,685.82 during trading.

A total of 3.17 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$96.92 billion (US$2.76 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 3.79 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$119.59 billion (US$3.41 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with construction stocks moving up 0.5 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 3.4 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 2.2 percent, pulp and paper issues at 2 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1.7 percent, cement stocks at 1.4 percent, textile issues at 1.3 percent, and foodstuff shares at 1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 489 to 136, with 60 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENIOR COUPLE GLAD TO BECOME CARETAKERS OF LONELY RAILWAY STATION

TEXT.P: A writer in his 60s living in Taichung was thrilled recently that he and his wife were awarded the opportunity to become the caretakers of a small railway station in the northern Hakka county of Hsinchu.

Hohsing Railway Station, located on a bypass of the hilly Neiwan Route in Hsinchu County, is not an ordinary railway station, at least in the eyes of Tseng Chuen-chao and his wife, Peng Chih-hui, because the station was where they first met.

Tseng, who now runs and owns a chain of mental arithmetic schools in Taichung City, central Taiwan, wrote a novel titled "Chasing" to tell the love story of him and his wife, with the railway station of Hohsing, his hometown, as the "main character."
In the novel, Tseng recounted how he once as an 18-year-old high school student chased the passing train, which came only once every hour, in order not to miss his final exams on a morning in 1954.

He ran after the train at a superhuman speed and was finally able to catch it at the next stop, making it to school on time to take his exams. He also met on the train a girl whom was also from Hohsing and took the same train to school every morning but whom he had never talked to until that "rushed" morning.

From that day, Tseng and Peng became more and more acquainted, taking the same train to Hsinchu City for school everyday. They have now been married for 36 years and both love the railway and the trains.

The couple are thrilled because they are now allowed to look after Hohsing Railway Station -- "their railway station" -- which is currently half-deserted with no personnel from the Taiwan Railway Administration being stationed there.
Although trains still pass through and stop at Hohsing Station everyday on a regular basis, the station presently does not maintain any ticketing or other services.

After a contract signing scheduled for Feb. 23, Tseng and Peng will be the only persons who will look after Hohsing Station -- a wooden structure built during the period of Japanese occupation with red tile roof and green walls and surrounded by a white wooden picket fence.

Hohsing Station has the only "reversible rails" in Taiwan in its vicinity which are historically invaluable, as well as a waiting room that is similar to that of an old-style Japanese railway station. There are also several cherry trees in the station's backyard which make the station look much more beautiful while sakura bloom during spring time.

Tseng said he and his wife would invite volunteers -- "who must be lovers of the railway and trains" -- to help keep and maintain the Hohsing Railway Station in order to give the old station a new lease on life.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER TO HEAD TASK FORCE TO DRAFT NEW BUDGET ALLOCATION LAW

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun directed Vice Premier Lin Hsin-yi Wednesday to head a special task force to draft a new amendment bill to the Law Governing Government Revenues and Expenditures within three months.

Yu issued the directive at a weekly Cabinet meeting in which Minister of Finance Lee Yung-shan offered a detailed report on the Cabinet's success in overturning opposition-authored amendments to the budget allocation law and possible follow-up developments.
The premier said the Cabinet is now obliged to come up with a new version of amendments to the allocation law, along with relevant supporting measures, for public debate and deliberation.

In drawing up new amendment proposals, Yu said, several key factors should be taken into account, such as government restructuring, downsizing of the central government and upgrading of national competitiveness.

"We should refer to general practices adopted by other countries in determining the tax revenues allocation ratios between central and local governments," Yu said, adding that the Cabinet is determined to follow the prevailing trend of delegating more power, as well as more financial and manpower resources, to local governments.

Moreover, he went on, the new amendments must meet the principle of fairness and set a standard formula for tax revenues. "The new budget allocation law should offer grassroots governments enough financial clout to administer local affairs effectively," he said.
In addition to appointing Lin as convener of the special task force, Yu also assigned Lee as the team's executive secretary.

Members of the team will include Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien, Director-General Lin Chuan of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Minister-without-Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung, Central Personnel Administration Chairman Lee Yi-yang and Chairman Lin Chia-cheng of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission.
Yu said he hopes that the task force can outline a working schedule within one month and finalize a draft revision bill for public discussion by mid-May.

In the previous day's showdown with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), an opposition alliance of the Kuomintang and the People First Party failed to get enough votes to veto the Cabinet's motion to scrap the recently passed changes to the budget allocation law. The opposition-proposed changes would have given an additional NT$150 billion annually to local governments from central government coffers.

While the DPP and its ally in the Legislative Yuan -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- were victorious in the vote, the outcome does not necessarily mean an end to the funding row that has long pitted the central government against local governments and urban areas against rural areas.

Besides drafting a new package of amendments to the budget allocation law, Lee said the Finance Ministry will also push for new legislation to allow local governments to levy various local taxes and service charges on residents to increase their financial autonomy.
