DOC.HEADLINE: VETERAN WRITER PUBLISHES LATEST BOOK AT AGE OF 92

TEXT.P: Veteran writer and columnist Hsia Cheng-ying, better known by his pen name of Ho Fan, has just seen his latest book -- Another Collection of the Prose of Ho Fan -- roll off the press. He is 92 years old.
The book is on display at the ongoing Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE) which opened Tuesday at the Taipei World Trade Center.

Ho, who is lauded in Taiwan's literary circles as "a Chinese pen which never stops" for having written continuously for nearly 70 years, appeared at a book-signing and speech event devoted to him and his book at TIBE Wednesday.
Ho began as a professional writer at the age of 24 in 1934 in Beijing, becoming a regular columnist for the Beijing Daily News in 1945.

He continued his prose and column writing with the United Daily News after moving to Taiwan in the early 50s with his wife, Lin Hai-yin -- also a renowned writer -- who died in her 80s two months ago.
During his 31-year career as a columnist, Ho has written 5,500 columns for a total of more than 5 million words. Besides writing columns, prose and short stories, he also translates.

During Wednesday's speech, which was attended by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and many of his literati friends, Ho said the publication of his latest book is proof that an author's writing career can be "as long as his life."

Ma said he has been a devoted reader of Ho since his younger years and made special reference to a column written in 1973 in which Ho said that "sports and exercise are most nutritious," describing it as a "new and inspiring idea" even decades later.

China Times President Huang Chao-sung said Ho, to him, is best remembered for his crisp translations of the columns written by Art Buchwald, the Pulitzer Prize-winning U.S. syndicated columnist. Ho's writing style has been influenced by Buchwald's brand of political satire, Huang noted.
Other literary friends of Ho who were also present at the function included Mandarin Daily News Chairman Lin Liang and National Taiwan University English Professor Chi Pang-yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2ND MAINLAND CHINESE TOUR GROUP TO ARRIVE NEXT WEEK FROM U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Feb. 19 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A tour group composed of mainland Chinese nationals with permanent residency in the United States is scheduled to leave here Feb. 28 for a sightseeing trip to Taiwan, travel sources said Tuesday.

It will be the second such group to visit Taiwan since the Republic of China government opened its doors to overseas mainland Chinese citizens traveling in groups at the beginning of this year. The first group, composed of elderly mainland Chinese residents of Japan, visited Taiwan Feb. 5-9.
The San Francisco-based Phoenix Travel Agency has cooperated with Taipei's Richmond Travel Agency in organizing a six-day, five-night tour package for the 12-member group.

A Phoenix spokesman said members of the group include people working in the high-tech industries and banks as well as social group volunteers and housewives. "All of them have permanent residency in the United States and have passed qualification screening by Taiwan's representative office here," he said. "And our Taipei partner has asked the Taipei Association of Travel Agents to apply for travel permits for our customers with the Taiwan authorities."

In addition to touring Taiwan's major tourist attractions and historic relics, the spokesman said, the mainland visitors also hope to see for themselves Taiwan's general lifestyle, social customs and cultural development.

"We have arranged for them to visit noted sightseeing spots in northern and central Taiwan, including the National Palace Museum in suburban Taipei and scenic Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County," he added.

As part of its efforts to boost exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan began Jan. 1 to allow mainland citizens with permanent foreign residency or mainland students studying abroad to make pleasure trips to the island, as long as they travel in a group at all times.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EPZS SEEKING `SECOND SPRING' BY EXPORTING KNOW-HOW

TEXT.P: The Export Processing Zone (EPZ) Administration of the Ministry of Economic Affairs is planning to export Taiwan's EPZ know-how and related facilities in an attempt to create a "second spring" for the sector that used to be the island's golden goose.

The EPZ Administration co-founded the Taiwan International Industrial Cooperation and Development Association with a number of private firms for the purpose of exporting the EPZs' extensive experience in industrial processing to developing countries.

Addressing a ceremony to mark the establishment of the association, EPZ Administrator Chou Yen said the EPZs have earned immeasurable foreign exchange for Taiwan over the past 35 years, during which business turnover in the island's three major EPZs has reached NT$6.4 trillion (US$182.8 billion).

With the business climate changing domestically and globally, the EPZs are past their prime and their operations are facing new bottlenecks, Chou said, adding that by reinvigorating their operations, the EPZs can seek to export their manufacturing know-how and sell related production facilities to nations in Southeast Asia and Central and South America, where small- and medium-sized enterprises are mushrooming.

The Taiwan International Industrial Cooperation and Development Association, with more than 100 enterpreneurs as its members, will sponsor regular seminars and meetings on international industrial cooperation to help Taiwan manufacturers find foreign buyers for their technologies, expertise and facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA PLANNING TO SEND 330 MISSIONS TO EXPLORE OVERSEAS MARKETS

TEXT.P: The semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) is planning to organize 330 trade-promotion groups to take part in overseas exhibitions and fairs this year to help explore foreign markets for Taiwan goods.

CETRA officials said Wednesday that the council will also dispatch five large delegations to countries in Latin America, the Middle East, East Europe, the Commonwealth of Independent States and Japan in the first half of this year to promote Taiwan-made products. They estimated that all these activities may help chalk up orders worth US$3.2 billion for Taiwan businesses.

The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) reported a day earlier that thanks to Taiwan's Jan. 1 entry into the World Trade Organization and a global economic recovery, Taiwan exports are expected to expand by 5.38 percent in 2002.

Although the island's January outbound shipments to the United States, Japan, East Europe and the European Union all registered drops of more than 10 percent from a month ago, the BOFT said exports to Hong Kong posted growth of 39.5 percent last month.

The BOFT said Hong Kong was Taiwan's largest overseas market for the past consecutive three months due to its status as the major transshipment hub for the booming indirect trade between Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT AND PFP MAY PRESENT NEW VERSION OF REVISED FINANCE ALLOCATION

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) will come out with a new version of the revised finance allocation law, "likely" before the Executive Yuan submits its own version to the legislature.

Referring to Premier Yu Shyi-kun's promise that the Executive Yuan will submit a draft of the revised tax revenues allocation law to the legislature within three months, Ma, whose previous revisions were kicked out a day earlier, claimed that the latest opposition machination is being taken to prevent possible manipulation of the administration. He did not elaborate.

While the allocation of tax revenues between the central and local governments has long been a controversial issue, the previous legislature railroaded through a revised allocation bill promoted by Ma during its last session in January.

Upon assuming office in early February, Yu submitted a motion to the Legislative Yuan requesting a reconsideration of the revision, which was approved after a vote in which the opposition was unable to get enough votes to gain the required absolute majority. With only 109 votes, the opposition camp was four votes short of the 113 it needed.
However, Ma said he might be willing to support a Cabinet-initiated revision under certain conditions.
First, he said, the central government should provide more financial resources to the local governments than the allocations defined in the revised allocation law approved last January.

He added that the local governments should be able to manage at least 70 percent of the tax revenues that they receive instead of the current ratio of 50 percent, and that the revenues of local governments must not be cut.
Ma said that the overridden revised law would have required the central government to set aside an additional NT$54.3 billion from tax revenues to distribute to the local governments.
The mayor said that enriching the financial resources of the local governments and allowing them more freedom in their financial management should be the criteria for drafting a revision.

While the legislature's approval of the motion of reconsideration was interpreted by many as a sign of the fading of Ma's limelight as the "first knight" of the KMT, the mayor said that the maneuver in the Legislative Yuan was only the practice of a constitutional system. The outcome had nothing to do with him personally, he claimed.

However, he admitted that he "could be related to the controversy" surrounding the revised law. "The revised bill might not have created such considerable attention if it had not been raised by me," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES RULES ON LAND ACQUISITION BY FOREIGN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved Wednesday a package of regulations governing land acquisition by foreign investors in major construction projects and farms in Taiwan.

The Cabinet adopted the new package to facilitate implementation of the revised Land Law, which allows foreign companies to invest in Taiwan's real estate market in line with the government's efforts to promote economic liberalization and globalization. Revisions to the Land Law were passed last October.
The new package will take effect after it is promulgated next week. The Cabinet only needs to serve notice to the Legislative Yuan.

Under the new regulations, foreigners will be able to invest in construction of tourist hotels, amusement and recreational facilities, stadiums, high-rise residential apartments, public facilities, new townships, and new communities. They will also be allowed to invest in high-tech farms and animal husbandry in Taiwan.

The new regulations are expected to help make best use of Taiwan's land resources and boost the island's overall economic and agricultural development through the introduction of foreign capital and technology into the domestic market, government sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO LOSER IN OVERTURNING REVISED ALLOCATION LAW: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday he sees no loser in the passage of the Cabinet's motion to overturn the recently revised budget allocation law.
Chen was referring to the Legislative Yuan's Tuesday passage of the Cabinet motion to scrap the opposition-proposed amendments to the Law Governing Government Revenues and Expenditures.

"The veto of the amendments would allow ruling and opposition parties to pool wisdom and conduct rational discussion on the issues regarding budget allocation," Chen said while meeting with a group of outstanding environmental protection volunteers.

Noting that the central and local governments have long been squabbling over tax revenue allocation, Chen said major domestic political forces must sit down to consult and jointly work out a more reasonable, more fair, more transparent allocation formula for the common well-being of local people.
Chen further said he hopes that the result of Tuesday's legislative vote would mark an end to partisan "war of attrition."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER VICE PREMIER CALLS FOR INTEGRATION AMONG UNIVERSITIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's institutes of higher learning and the ministries overseeing them must embrace a system of integration and innovation to enhance their competitiveness, former Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Wednesday.

Speaking on the need for Taiwan's 130 colleges and universities to continue their pursuit of excellence, Liu, who currently heads a Ministry of Education (MOE) task force promoting such academic excellence, lamented that the quality of Taiwan's higher education has failed to keep up with the increase in the number of schools.
Liu said that the MOE's subsidies for the universities have continued to decline as the number of schools vying for a piece of the budget has gone up.

He proposed that the schools should integrate with each other and within themselves through mergers and the establishment of cross-disciplinary research teams. This would help pool talented human resources and provide Taiwan with world-class academics, he said.

Meanwhile, he added, the National Science Council (NSC), which subsidizes innovative research projects but cannot maintain them in the long run, and the Ministry of Education, which has the resources to provide long-term subsidies but has a more rigid overall mechanism, should integrate with each other to become a powerful government agency in charge of promoting science and education.

The former NSC chairman and National Tsinghua University president said that universities are where innovative talent is nurtured and that any nation pursuing economic progress must begin with the development of "universities of excellence."

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD SETS UP WEB SITE PROVIDING BUSINESS INFORMATION

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has established a new "global investment business network" Web site to serve as a portal to business information provided by various government agencies and private organizations.

CEPD officials said that the site is currently aimed at providing local businessmen with access to a comprehensive body of information about doing business abroad and in mainland China, while work is underway to create a section devoted to helping foreign investors gain access to information about investing in Taiwan.

The CEPD site (www.cedi.cepd.gov.tw/bsns) has links to business information sites such as Taiwan Trade (www.taiwantrade.com.tw) maintained by the China External Trade Development Council, the Global Chinese Business Network (www.gcbn.net) maintained by the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission and a site catering to Taiwanese businessmen in mainland China (www.chinabiz.org.tw) maintained by the Mainland Affairs Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: APPROVAL SOUGHT FOR RELOCATION OF 8-INCH WAFER FABS TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: As the government seems set on allowing Taiwan chip makers to relocate their eight-inch wafer plants to mainland China, although under strict restraints, the local semiconductor industry has urged the government to dispense with what it sees as "unnecessary interference."

Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association Chairman S.H. Hsu said Tuesday that the government should discuss the issue with the local industry in order to meet their needs before hammering out relevant measures and policy.

As major Taiwan chip makers already have or are preparing to acquire the technology to produce 12-inch silicon chips, Hsu said moving the eight-inch wafer plants to the mainland will not have a negative impact on the Taiwan industry and that the government does not need to worry about Taiwan's competitiveness being hurt by relocating outdated technologies.

Citing statistics provided by the Taiwan Semiconductor Association, Hsu said all Taiwan-based chip makers will shift to the 12-inch technology level within five years, creating more than 5,000 jobs on the island. He claimed that no adverse effects will be produced, even if all the chip makers cease the operations of their eight-inch wafer plants by that time.
Representatives of the Taipei Computer Association also urged the government to promote its "active opening, effective management" mainland investment policy.

During a meeting with Economic Affairs Minister Christine Tsung on the same day, association chairman C.J. Huang and executives of leading computer firms such as Acer Inc. and RITEK called on the government to step up its pace to achieve the policy goal.

Stressing that cross-Taiwan Strait economic integration will be a vital strategy for Taiwan firms hoping to gain the upper hand in the world market, they suggested the government set up a comprehensive network to provide mainland-based Taiwan businessmen with efficient trade information and services and to help them in market distribution and business management with e-solutions.

Huang also voiced his support for a final government decision to allow the relocation of eight-inch wafer plants to the mainland. He said, Premier Yu Shyi-kun should make the move swiftly because, he said, it will benefit the whole country and the industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose NT$0.003 against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange market Wednesday, closing at NT$35.098.
A total of US$318 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$35.098 and was traded between NT$35.090 and NT$ 35.125.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRMS CONCERNED OVER DUMPING OF MAINLAND CHINESE GOODS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan firms are concerned over the possible dumping of mainland Chinese products in the domestic market and over the establishment of direct links with the mainland in the wake of World Trade Organization (WTO) entry, according to a recent survey.

The results of the survey released Wednesday by the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) show that the largest ratio of local firms surveyed -- 49.5 percent of the total -- hope to get government help to avoid what they see as "likely dumping" of mainland products in Taiwan, while 48.5 percent hope to see direct trade, transport and postal links set up across the Taiwan Strait.

The third most important issue for Taiwan firms, aired by 46.9 percent of the respondents, is that the government should provide sufficient customs information for mainland-based Taiwan businesses, while 45.9 percent wish the government to offer detailed and timely information on cross-strait trade regulations, according to the survey.
At the same time, 43.8 percent of the respondents expect the government to help collect trade information on the mainland market and to help them explore overseas markets.

As to the question of what benefits WTO entry will produce for the local business community, 49.7 percent said the major advantage is the reduction in customs duties, ahead of 38.2 percent who said the main benefit is an upgraded international status.

Meanwhile, 79.2 percent said they believe the leading disadvantage is that competition in the domestic market will become strong, while 64.5 percent said they are worried about the reshipping of products made by Taiwan companies in the mainland.

CNFI Chairman K.C. Lin said the survey results indicate that Taiwan-based businesses must strengthen their marketing and innovation, and must slash their production costs if they want to ride out the impact of WTO membership.

The poll of 393 CNFI member companies was conducted from Jan. 10-25, with 201 valid questionnaires recovered. The CNFI carried out the poll to gain a better understanding of the difficulties facing the local business community following Taiwan's WTO entry and to help serve as a reference for the government when drawing up relevant measures and policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER CALLS FOR INDUSTRIAL INTERNATIONALIZATION

TEXT.P: ROC Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said in Kaohsiung Wednesday that Taiwan should pursue industrial internationalization and liberalization following the nation's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).
He noted that Taiwan has established a good technical base and a sound production system, but said more efforts must be made in research and development, as well as marketing.
Chen said Taiwan should also speed up the pace of industrial upgrading and establish a sounder economic system with higher self-reliance.
The official made the remarks at a ceremony marking the inauguration of the Council for Taiwan International Industrial Cooperation and Development.

He expressed the hope that the council, formed by the Export Processing Zone Administration and the Kaohsiung industrial community, will play a role in helping local industries engage in international cooperation.

Through the operation, he said, Taiwan can also transfer the know-how that is no longer current in Taiwan to other developing countries, a move that could also benefit Taiwan traders doing business abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 2001 CURRENT ACCOUNT SURPLUS HITS RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's current account surplus reached a record high of US$19.082 billion last year, the Central Bank of China (CBC) reported Wednesday.

At the same time, the island's current account surplus for the fourth quarter of 2001 also registered a historical high of US$7.062 billion since 1988, which the CBC said is an indication that Taiwan's international payments remain in good shape.

J. C. Yeh, vice director of the CBC's Economic Research Department, attributed the quarterly high of Taiwan's current account surplus to a huge trade surplus of US$7.158 billion incurred from large falls in inbound shipments, coupled with sharp growth in remittance from aboard and a noticeable drop in travel expenditures overseas in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks against the United States.
The major reason behind Taiwan's record high of yearly current account surplus last year, Yeh said, was the CBC's increase of its reserves worth US$17.353 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY POPULATION STOOD AT 2.633 MILLION AT END OF 2001

TEXT.P: The population of Taipei City stood at 2.633 million at the end of 2001, a decrease of 12,672 or 0.481 percent from a year ago, according to statistics released Wednesday by the city's Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.
The city's population density was 9,690 people per square kilometer at the end of 2001, the statistics show.

Of the 12 administrative areas in the city, Ta An district was the most densely populated with 316,000 individuals, followed by Shihlin district with 292,000. The Neihu and Wenshan districts were next with 250,000 people each. Nankang was the most sparsely inhabited district with 114,000, according to the statistics.

Compared with the end of 2000, only Neihu, Wenshan and Chungshan districts registered a positive population growth at the end of 2001, increasing 0.37 percent, 0.312 percent and 0.237 percent, respectively.
Wanhua district recorded the largest decrease in population at the end of 2001 at 1.369 percent, the official figures show.
Ta An district also had the highest population density with 28,000 people per square kilometer, followed by Tatung district and Wanhua district, each with 23,000.
The population of Taipei citizens aged 65 or above was 9.94 percent at the end of 2001, up 0.27 percentage points from a year earlier.
Chung Cheng district had the highest aged population at the end of 2001 at 11.91, followed by the Wanhua and Ta An districts.
Neihu district had the fewest elderly people at 6.73 percent.
Taipei City Hall last adjusted the city's administrative districts in 1990.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC PERFORMANCE WILL IMPROVE THIS YEAR: P.K. CHIANG

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Vice President P.K. Chiang said Wednesday that Taiwan's economy is certain to recover this year from the record low figures of the year before.

He noted that Taiwan relies on foreign markets for 50 percent to 60 percent of its economic growth, and added that as Japan's prospects this year will be better than in the past few years, the island is expected to improve as well.

Chiang, a former chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, made the remarks while delivering a speech on Taiwan's present and future economic situation at the invitation of the "San San Society," formed by local firms doing business with Japan.

He said that many government and private economic institutions, including the Academia Sinica and the Taiwan Economic Research Institute, have forecast a real growth rate ranging from 2.03 percent to 3.08 percent for Taiwan this year.

Nevertheless, Chiang pointed out that some challenges remain for Taiwan this year, such as a slowdown in the recovery of the world economy, the effect originating from capital flight from Taiwan to mainland China and the rise of regionalism.

He urged the government to give priority to economic development, take steps to improve the investment environment, promote financial reform, restore investment confidence of enterprises and improve financial operations to cope with the difficult situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHIEF DEFENDED HIS SUPPORT OF REJECTION OF ALLOCATION REVISIONS

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung mayor and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman Frank Hsieh said central government leaders promised him that local governments would be given more power and funds after he supported the Executive Yuan's request to reject revisions to revenue-allocation rules which would have been beneficial to his city.
Emerging from a weekly conference of the Executive Yuan, Hsieh said that central government leaders also promised to finance Kaohsiung's development.
He said he hopes the Executive Yuan will revamp the existing revenue-allocation rules now that controversial changes to it have been vetoed in a vote at the legislature Tuesday evening.

Hsieh was feeling the heat after the administration led by his party wanted to get rid of the opposition-initiated changes under which Kaohsiung City was expected to get some NT$10 billion more from the central government.
Hsieh decided to follow the party line on the issue and backed revoking the revisions.
He argued that any windfall from the revisions could be difficult to realize since the opposition-controlled legislature still might reverse the revisions and ultimately cut Kaohsiung's share.

Meanwhile, Lin Chin-hsing, a DPP lawmaker from Kaohsiung City, called on the Executive Yuan Wednesday to come up with a new version of an amendment under which local governments will get more funds than they will be given under the now-rejected revisions.

Another DPP legislator from Kaohsiung City, Chen Chi-mai, said many other DPP lawmakers from the city agreed with him that they should introduce a proposal in the Legislative Yuan to change the revenue-allocation rules to give local governments not only enough funds but also the full power to govern.
Claiming that decentralization is the global order of the day, Chen said revamping the revenue-allocation rules should be done in line with the government's reform campaign.

The major opposition Kuomintang (KMT), which initiated the original changes, vowed Wednesday to monitor the Executive Yuan despite the party's failure to sustain the revision in the legislature Tuesday.
The KMT whip at the Legislative Yuan, Lin Yi-shih, said Wednesday that the ball was now in the Executive Yuan's court and his party would wait and see what changes the Cabinet will propose.

However, the KMT Taipei mayor, Ma Ying-jeou, who inspired his party to change the allocation rules, said the KMT and its political ally, the People First Party (PFP), might put forward their own proposal for changes if the government disappoints them.
The PFP, which helped the KMT pass the revisions near the end of the last session of the legislature last month, had no comment Wednesday about Tuesday's setback.

Its chairman, James Soong, was quoted as saying that what matters is not the results of the vote, but how to work out a fair and transparent mechanism to divide revenues among governments of various levels.

PFP Legislator Lee Ching-an said Soong preferred more comprehensive changes to the existing rules but was forced to throw the weight of his party behind the KMT after finding that there was no other way to resolve the dispute.

DOC.HEADLINE: A COMPETITIVE TAIWAN NEEDS FREE TRADE AGREEMENTS: FORMER ROC PREMIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan should improve its relations with mainland China and sign a greater China free trade agreement to maintain the island's global competitiveness, former Premier Vincent Siew said Wednesday.
Siew said at a workshop seminar on cross-Taiwan Strait commerce that Taiwan's World Trade Organization accession is only the first step in maintaining its edge.

If Taiwan cannot sign a free trade agreement with mainland China and Hong Kong or with other countries in the region but mainland China is successful in doing so, then the island will be marginalized, and its future development will be affected immensely, he added.

Siew, who is currently chairman of the Cross-strait Common Market Foundation, said that the United States is already assessing the possibility of signing a free trade accord with Taiwan, while senior officials from New Zealand, Australia and Singapore have voiced support for similar plans.

Touching on U.S. President George W. Bush's visit to mainland China Thursday, Siew said that he believes an amelioration of relations between the United States and mainland China will help Taiwan and the mainland engage in beneficial interactions, making the region more stable.
He said that the mainland's next generation of top leaders are mostly technocrats who will be more pragmatic, and that he expects future cross-strait relations to be handled in a pragmatic manner.

Siew added that he believes relations between Taiwan and the United States will not be affected by Bush's visit, as indicated by a statement that the U.S. president made in Japan that "America will remember our commitments to the people on Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INTERNATIONAL BOOK INDUSTRY EXCHANGE ASSOCIATION INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: A Taiwan International Book Industry Exchange Association was inaugurated Wednesday with the aim of strengthening anti-piracy precautions against textbook publication, according to an association spokesman.

Liu Han-wen, convener of the association, said that although imported textbook piracy by local publishing companies has been curtailed, piracy in the form of illegal copying by students and school authorities is increasing daily.

A number of political figures, including Legislator Lo Wen-chia of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and Legislator Hsu Yen-kuo of the opposition People First Party, witnessed the founding ceremony at the Taipei World Trade Center.
According to unofficial statistics, 40 percent of imported textbooks presently being used in schools are pirated copies, representing a total loss of US$50 million for the legal publishers.
Liu urged the government to set up a task force and ad hoc committees to strengthen anti-piracy measures and protect intellectual property rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN MAINLAND CHINA HOPING TO USE `MINI-LINKS'

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessmen in mainland China are hopeful they can cross the Taiwan Strait using the "mini three links" between the islands of Kinmen and Matzu and the mainland ports of Xiamen and Mawei.

Some 302 Taiwan businessmen working in the mainland used the links to return to Taiwan for the Lunar New Year holiday, but Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said that trip was "only a single case" and not the start of a new policy.

However, Liao Yun-yuan, director of the Trade and Service Department of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), who met the Taiwan businessmen upon their arrival at Liaolowan Port in Kinmen, said that they all expressed their satisfaction with the method of cross-strait travel.

Therefore, he went on, many Taiwanese businessmen now doing business in the mainland will propose that they be allowed to use the mini-links until direct links between Taiwan proper and the mainland are implemented.

The proposal is expected to be made at a seasonal gathering jointly sponsored by the MAC, the SEF, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Chinese National Federation of Industries scheduled to be held in Taipei Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH'S BEIJING VISIT NOT TO AFFECT TAIWAN-US TIES: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush's upcoming Beijing visit will not affect current Taipei-Washington relations, a senior official of the ROC Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Wednesday .

Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the MAC, the mainland policy-making body, said that no single nation has a monopoly on relations among Washington, Beijing and Taipei. She said that improving Washington-Beijing ties will help maintain cross-strait peace and improve cross-strait relations.
Tsai said that communications channels between Taipei and Washington are flourishing and that Taiwan will closely monitor Bush's upcoming Beijing trip.

Tsai made the remarks prior to attending the inaugural ceremony of the first cross-strait economic and trade seminar sponsored by the Cross-strait Common Market Foundation, founded by former Premier Vincent Siew.
President Bush is expected to arrive in Beijing Thursday for a two-day official visit to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-JAPAN UNIVERSITY GOLF TOURNAMENT TO BE HELD IN LINKOU FEB. 22

TEXT.P: The 2002 Republic of China-Japan university golf tournament will be held Friday at the Chang Gung Golf & Country Club in Linkou, a suburb of Taipei, the Golf Association of the Republic of China announced Wednesday.
A 20-member golf team from National Physical Educational College will take on a 21-member team from Japan's Daiichi Keizai University for the one-day competition.
The purpose of the tournament, which is being sponsored by the Golf Association of the Republic of China, is to promote friendship through golf as well as exchanging views on the game.
The event will have group and individual divisions.
A welcoming party will be held Thursday night at the Chang Gung Golf & Country Club with Chien Lung-kuo, secretary-general of the ROC golf association chairing.
Wang Yung-chai, president of the association and concurrently general manager of the Chang Gung Golf & Country Club, will ceremoniously waive green fees and other costs for the participants.
The Taipei team has average handicaps ranging from zero to six. The Japanese team averages between two and three.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN THIRD AFTER FIRST ROUND OF 72TH THAI AMATEUR GOLF TOURNEY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 20 (CNA) (By F.C. Kuo & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Two Taiwan players were third in both group and individual divisions after the first day of the 72th Thai Amateur Golf Tournament now under way in Bangkok, according to the Golf Association of the Republic of China Wednesday.

Taiwan players Chen Chih-hung and Hsu Chia-hao both carded a three-under par 69, placing them third in the individual section. They also ranked third in the group division with a combined total of 138.
A total of 140 amateur players from six countries in Asia are participating in the four-day event. They are from South Korea, the Philippines, Taiwan, Malaysia, Thailand and India.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WANTS TO NORMALIZE TRADE TIES WITH MAINLAND, SAYS MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Normalization of economic and trade relations with mainland China is the goal and the only option for the Taipei government, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Wednesday.
Tsai made the remarks while speaking at the opening of a seminar on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade relations organized by the Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation.
Tsai said that Taiwan and the east coast of mainland China have been playing a very important role in the world's economy.
However, she admitted that problems regarding cross-strait economic and trade issues are the "most difficult, most complicated and most unique" ones that remain unresolved.

As normalization of cross-strait economic and trade ties is the government's policy, Tsai noted that proper handling of cross-strait political relations is required, together with an early establishment of a proper communication mechanism.
Only through a stable political environment and a proper communication mechanism, the MAC chief said, can both sides of the Taiwan Strait engage in dialogue and discussions on related issues.
Talking about the recommendations made by the cross-party Economic Development Advisory Conference last fall, Tsai said that the government will implement them.
Among the recommendations was a call for replacing the "no haste, be patient" with a policy of "active opening, effective management" in dealing with economic matters relating to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: POWER NEWS NEWSPAPER FOLDS AFTER AMASSING LARGE LOSSES

TEXT.P: Power News, a Taipei-based newspaper, decided to cease operations from Feb. 21 and lay off all its staff, Liu Tu-hsing, the president of the paper, said Wednesday.

Liu said the difficult decision was made reluctantly by the paper's board of directors who were faced with losses by the evening newspaper of more than NT$1.6 billion (US$45.71 million) over the last three years.
"It is more a pause than an end," Liu stressed, adding that the paper could resume business in the future.
He promised to fully refund the paper's subscribers and offer its employees severance pay according to the Labor Standards Law.
The paper, founded with much fanfare in 1999, was the only full color morning paper in Taiwan at the time and boasted of using state-of-the-art presses and pagination systems.

Although the newspaper expected to break even after its first year, the economic slowdown in Taiwan and cutthroat competition among the island's established morning papers forced the newcomer to struggle just to stay alive.
To try to keep afloat, the price of the paper was cut from NT$15 to NT$10 and finally to NT$5. At that point it became an evening newspaper last year while its three rivals remained at NT$10.
All these efforts were in vain, however, and the paper finally had to stem the losses by closing down altogether.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TO START TAIPEI-DELHI ROUTE FROM APRIL 1

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL) will start a Taipei-Delhi route from April 1 to meet the increasing need from tourists and businessmen of Taiwan and India, CAL sources said Wednesday.

CAL will begin by operating three flights between Taipei and Delhi each week, the sources said, adding that the planes from Taipei to Delhi will take off at 9:45 p.m. (local time) each Monday, Thursday and Saturday, while those from Delhi to Taipei will take off at 3:15 a.m. (local time) each Tuesday, Friday and Sunday.
India is the second-largest country in the world by population. It registered an economic growth rate of 5.5 percent in 2000, ninth among the fastest economic growth countries.

There were 11,800 tourist arrivals in India from Taiwan in 2000, a year-on-year increase of 30 percent, and 13,200 tourist arrivals in Taiwan from India, up 15 percent from the previous year, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
CAL estimated that the Taipei-Delhi route will bring in an additional US$1.6 million each month for the carrier.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHING COMPANIES MUST LOOK AWAY FROM MAINLAND FOR LABORERS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Provincial Fishery Association Wednesday urged local fishing companies to hire foreign laborers to fill the gap caused by the recent withdrawal of mainland Chinese fishermen.

Taiwan fishing companies had been relying heavily on mainland Chinese fishermen mainly because of the low labor costs and the lack of a language barrier until Beijing authorities banned mainland fisherman from working on Taiwan boats recently.
The fishery association called a meeting of representatives from local fishermen's associations to exchange views on how to resolve the problem.
It urged fishing operators to employ foreign fishermen and to register with associations regarding the number of foreign fishermen they are ready to hire.
The association also called on the government to simplify the procedures for foreign laborers to work for Taiwan fishing companies to shorten the time for foreign fishermen to begin working.
An official from the Council of Agriculture said that the council had contacted brokers in Vietnam, Indonesia and the Philippines seeking information on hiring fishermen to work on Taiwan ships.
He said that the government will also encourage unemployed local workers to work as fishermen by providing them with NT$10,000 per person monthly as a subsidy.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLARITY IN DEALING WITH BEIJING SUPPORTED BY DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense supports the government's effort to build mutual trust between Taiwan and mainland China through dialogue and exchanges, Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min said Wednesday.

Speaking in a dinner party given by him for local journalists, Tang said a transparent safety mechanism serves the interests of both Taiwan and mainland China in avoiding conflicts triggered by miscalculations.
Noting that mutual trust is better than mutual threats, Tang said there is no reason to oppose the government's efforts to reach out to mainland China.
But before trust can be built, Tang said, the country cannot abandon its efforts to build up its self-defense capabilities, Tang said.

Although U.S. President George W. Bush reaffirmed his country's commitment to Taiwan's safety Monday in Tokyo , Tang said Taiwan would rather build its own deterrent forces than counting on an ally's protection in times of crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST DAUGHTER IS PREGNANT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's daughter, Chen Hsing-yu, is pregnant and is expected to give birth in late October this year, the National Taiwan University Hospital confirmed Wednesday.
Chen Hsing-yu was examined Wednesday at the National Taiwan University Hospital which confirmed she was five weeks' pregnant, according to a press release issued by the hospital.
An official at the presidential office said Wednesday the president was glad to learn the news and appreciated the well wishes from his countrymen.
The first daughter, who is a dentist at the Chang Gung Hospital, married Chao Chien-ming, a surgeon at the National Taiwan University Hospital last September.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 21, or the 10th day of the first month of the Year of the Horse according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1673: Jean Baptiste Poquelin Moliere, the French playwright whose sophisticated comedies include "Tartuffe" and "The Misanthrope," is buried in secret in a Paris cemetery.
1795: Holland surrenders Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) to Britain.
1858: Edwin Holmes of Boston installs the first electric burglar alarm.
1866: August von Wasserman, the German bacteriologist who invented a test to detect syphilis, is born.
1911: The United States and Japan sign a treaty limiting the flow of Japanese workers into the United States.
1916: Massed German artillery begin a furious bombardment of a crucial 13-kilometer sector of the French line at Verdun in the middle of the Western Front.
1917: Modern China's founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen completes "The Fundamental Knowledge in Democracy," a book dealing with the procedures of parliamentary rule.
1944: Gen. Hideki Tojo, prime minister of Japan, replaces Field Marshall Hajime Sugiyama as chief of the Imperial Army general staff.
1963: Moscow warns Washington that an American attack on Cuba would mean world war.
1969: King Hassan of Morocco is granted a patent by the U.S. Patents Office for his device to monitor the function of the human heart.
1970: A cargo plane belonging to Taiwan's Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes on top of Fushoushan in suburban Taipei, killing its two pilots.
1972: U.S. President Richard Nixon visits mainland China.
1973: Lt. Gen. Robert R. Williams, acting commander of the U.S. Army, Pacific, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: Swaziland Vice Prime Minister Z.A. Khumalo arrives in Taipei for a weeklong tour.
1975: The Taiwan Shipbuilding Corp. begins construction of a fifth 100,000-ton tanker for the Chinese Petroleum Corp.
1986: Mainland Chinese air force pilot Chen Baozhong defects to South Korea in a MiG-19 fighter.
1986: Shigechiyo Izumi, the world's oldest man, dies in Japan at the age of 120.
1989: Czech writer Vaclav Havel is imprisoned for initiating a demonstration. Havel later became president of Czechoslovakia.
1990: Hun Sen, premier of Cambodia, holds peace talks with his rival, Prince Ranaridh Sihanouk, in Bangkok.
1990: Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani visits the Republic of China.
1992: Mainland China welcomes foreigners back to its stock market in Shanghai for the first time since 1949.
1998: The U.S. government advises its citizens to leave Iraq, in anticipation of new airstrikes.
2000: ROC Defense Minister Tang Fei arrives in Singapore to attend a five-day Asian Aerospace Show.
2000: Liberian President Charles Ghankay Taylor arrives in Taipei for a six-day official visit.
2001: The Tomorrow Times, Taiwan's first online-only newspaper, halts operations, citing financial troubles.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Appearance of high spirits without integrity, of dullness without humility, of simplicity without honesty -- of such men I really do not know what to say."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The China Times:
The Presidential Office will file for 'constitutional interpretation' over planned appointment of two Grand Justices.
The United Daily News:
Defense Minister Tang Yao-ming vows to push for cross-strait military dialogue.
The Liberty Times:
Taiwan's economic growth rate may reach 2.5 percent this year.
The Taiwan Daily:
The central government is determined to delegate more power and financial resources to local governments with a view to boosting autonomy.
The Central Daily News:
KMT Chairman Lien Chan vows to lead the party to win the year-end Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections.
The China Post:
Premier seeks new funding draft by May.
The Taiwan News:
Hundreds die in Cairo train inferno.
The Taipei Times:
Task force to address budget law.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUZHOU DELEGATION IN TAIWAN FOR WEEKLONG VISIT

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese delegation led by Suzhou City Mayor Yang Weize arrived in Taipei Thursday for a weeklong visit.
The delegation was invited by Epoch Foundation, a non-profit group founded with an aim of helping Taiwan industry develop and promote regional prosperity.
Suzhou, located in Jiangsu Province, has become one of the hot spots for Taiwan businesspeople in mainland China, with more than 1,000 Taiwan businesses located in the city's industrial park.

The delegation will attend a seminar on cross-strait investment Friday. It is expected that the delegation will also call on some of Taiwan's big enterprises, including United Microelectronics Corp., Macronix International and Formosa Plastics.
As this is Yang's first visit to Taiwan, he is also expected to tour around the island as much as possible in order to get to know more about it before returning to the mainland next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 36.08 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 36.08 points to close at 5,656.1.
Market turnover amounted to NT$88.65 billion (US$2.53 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 36.08 points to close at 5,656.1.

Encouraged by a rebound in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,766.4 but began to go down later due to heavy selling pressure and a lack of confidence on the part of investors. The index fluctuated between 5,769.59 and 5,640.15 during trading.

A total of 3.01 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$88.65 billion (US$2.53 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 3.17 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$96.92 billion (US$2.76 billion).
Three of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with bank and insurance stocks moving down the most at 1.4 percent, followed by foodstuff shares and electrical stocks, both at 0.8 percent.

The other major categories gained ground, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 5.9 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares and textile issues, both at 0.3 percent, and cement stocks and construction shares, both at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 383 to 216, with 86 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Thursday as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for March moved down 10 points to close at 5,656, with 12,795 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April lost 101 points to close at 5,617, with 26 contract transactions, while June futures decreased 1 points to finish at 5,605, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,666 for March, 5,718 for April, 5,606 for June, 5,691 for September, and 5,686 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were generally lower.
March TE futures moved down 1.3 points to close at 297, with 2,743 contract transactions, while April TE futures decreased 7.45 points to finish at 296, with four contracts changing hands.
June TE futures decreased 9.25 points to close at 295, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
March TF futures moved down 8.8 points to finish at 685.2, with 707 contract transactions, while April TF futures fell 11.4 points to close at 687.2, with one contract changing hands.
September TF futures fell 4 points to close at 701, with one contract transaction, while December TF futures gained 12 points to finish at 701, also with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME NOT YET RIPE TO DISCUSS PRESIDENT CHEN'S TRAVEL PLAN: MOFA

TEXT.P: The time is not yet right to talk about whether or not President Chen Shui-bian will make an overseas visit in May, a senior Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

Lee Chen-hsiung, director of the MOFA's Department of African Affairs, was commenting on a newspaper report that President Chen is scheduled to visit three of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in Africa -- Liberia, Sao Tome and Principe, and Senegal -- in May.

"We are still evaluating the president's travel plan, and no definite decision has so far been made," Lee said, adding that the MOFA would unveil all the details at an opportune time once the plan is finalized.

Noting that high-level diplomacy is conducive to the consolidation of formal diplomatic ties, Lee said it is the government's established policy to arrange for President Chen to visit the ROC's diplomatic allies from time to time.

Nevertheless, Lee said, the president's overseas trips usually involve many issues that need careful assessment, including the effects of the visit as well as the working schedules of Chen and the host countries.
The ROC has eight diplomatic allies in Africa -- Burkina Faso, Chad, Gambia, Liberia, Malawi, Sao Tome and Principe, Senegal, and Swaziland.

President Chen visited three African allies -- Burkina Faso, Chad and Gambia -- in his first overseas trip as the ROC head of state in August 2000. And top leaders of all of the ROC's eight African allies have visited Taiwan since Chen took office in May 2000.

According to a report carried in the Thursday issue of the Chinese-language United Daily News, President Chen will visit Liberia, Sao Tome and Principe, Senegal in May, as well as Malawi if time allows.

The report said Chen may make a transit stop in a European city en route to Africa. The Vatican is the only European country that maintains formal diplomatic ties with the ROC. Vice President Annette Lu succeeded in making a transit stop in Paris on her way to Gambia last December and a two-night transit stay in Vienna and Paris on her way home from Gambia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TECO OFFICIAL COMMENTS ON BUSH'S BEIJING VISIT

TEXT.P: The director of the Information Division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York expressed the hope in an editorial published Thursday in the Republican-American that while Beijing and Washington work to improve their relations, such improvements will not come at Taiwan's expense.

Commenting on President Bush's visit to Beijing, William J. Yih wrote in the daily published in Connecticut that Taiwan treasures its relationship with the United States, pointing out that while Taiwan has voiced its continued strong support for the U.S.-led international campaign against terrorism since the Sept. 11 attacks, Beijing's support for anti-terrorism efforts has been more "ambiguous."

Furthermore, Yih said, Beijing refuses to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, and "has strengthened its forces in the Taiwan Strait and targeted increasingly sophisticated weapons systems at the island."

Unlike mainland China, Yih noted, Taiwan is willing to engage in cross-strait dialogue without imposing preconditions, saying that Beijing insists that Taiwan must acknowledge its "one-China principle" before discussions can take place, while "Taiwan believes any agreement should have the support of the people through a democratic process."
Yih said he is hopeful that the U.S. can contribute to an easing of tensions and increased stability in the region by encouraging cooperation across the strait.

"By adhering to the Taiwan Relations Act and not restating the `Three Nos' affirmed by former U.S. President Clinton as a concession to Beijing, the United States can promote peaceful dialogue," he added.
One of the most effective ways that the United States might pursue this objective, Yih wrote, is by encouraging international organizations to include Taiwan as a member.

Pointing to the recent admission into the World Trade Organization (WTO) of mainland China and Taiwan as full-fledged members, Yih said that "their concurrent accession created another forum in which leaders from opposite sides of the Taiwan Strait will have a chance to meet and interact on a level playing field."

Yih concluded his article by expressing the hope that President Bush will take advantage of his trip to Beijing "to discourage intimidation of Taiwan and encourage the improvement of cross-strait relations."
