DOC.HEADLINE: SAMPO OF TAIWAN AND HAIER GROUP IN M'LAND CHINA FORM ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: The Sampo Corp. of Taiwan and the Haier Group Company in mainland China have signed a strategic alliance agreement for full cooperation from production to marketing, a spokesman of the Sampo headquarters in Taipei said Thursday.
The spokesman said that the two companies will share sales channels, supply OEM (other equipment manufacturer) products, exchange purchasing information and make joint investments.

Sampo is one of Taiwan's leading manufacturers of home appliances, consumer electronics and telecommunications products. The Shantung-based Haier Group is the biggest telecommunications and electronics manufacturer in mainland China, with 60 billion renminbi (US$7.25 billion) in sales last year.

The spokesman said that the strategic alliance with Haier is part of Sampo's global deployment plan for the next three years. In addition to tailor-made LCD television sets and DVD players for the mainland market, Sampo is supplying the Haier Group with compressors for air conditioners and passive components for mobile phone sets.

He said that the Haier Group, with its products sold in over 160 countries, is keen to explore the Taiwan market. The mainland company first made a patent rights registration with the authorities in Taiwan in 1996. While familiarizing itself with the market climate in Taiwan, the Haier Group has also placed orders for mobile phone peripherals and other information products with Taiwan manufacturers.
Sampo is planning to sell 20-inch television sets produced by the Haier Group in the Taiwan market under the Sampo brand name in the near future, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR TAIWAN UNIVERSITIES HOPE TO USE CALIFORNIA UNIVERSITY MODEL
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Feb. 20 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Four prestigious universities in Taiwan are hoping to emulate the University of California (U of C) cooperative education system to raise the level of higher education in Taiwan.

A delegation of Taiwan university presidents and a ranking education official have been visiting the U of C headquarters in Oakland, and the University of California campuses at Berkeley and San Francisco over the past few days, hoping to use the U of C university system as a reference for Taiwan's advanced education.

The visiting academics were Vice Minister of Education Lu Mu-lin, National Chiao Tung University President Chang Chun-yen, National Central University President Liu Chao-han, National Yang Ming University President Wu Yen-hua, and National Tsinghua University President Frank H. Shu.

The four presidents are all members of the Academia Sinica, the Republic of China's highest academic research institute, and are highly respected in academic and educational fields. They said that the four Taiwan universities excel in their respective areas, and would complement each other if a unified university system could be set up similar to the one in California. Cooperation would add much to research and teaching at advanced educational facilities in Taiwan, they added.
Where the headquarters of the proposed Taiwan university system would be has yet to be decided. Likewise, who would head the system is still open.

Vice Minister Lu pointed out that if the four universities wanted to form a public university system, they would have to meet the legal requirements for such a move. President Chang stressed that the four universities have started planning for a university system and will work together to jump whatever legal hurdles stand in their way.

The four presidents said that there are several cooperation projects in the works, but that they will not make the details of them public until concrete discussions have been made regarding their implementation.

The presidents said that their goal is to establish a world-class university system in Taiwan, on par with the best schools in the world. They said that there will be basic changes to Taiwan's advanced educational system, and the function of universities will be clearer, with those schools that produce students who excel academically becoming even better.
But they also pointed out that the four schools could not copy the U of C system completely; for instance, they would not be receiving blanket funding from the state as is the case in California.

Frank H. Shu, a world-renowned astrophysicist who took over the helm of National Tsinghua University this month after serving in the U of C system for more than three decades, said that among all U.S. state universities, the U of C system is one of the most successful and Taiwan can learn from it.
The delegation, which left for the U.S. last Sunday, is scheduled to return to Taiwan Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INBOUND INVESTMENT UP, OUTBOUND INVESTMENT DOWN IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese and foreign investment in Taiwan totaled US$358.09 million in January, up 60.13 percent from the same time last year, the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Thursday.
In terms of sectors, inbound investment focused mainly in the telecommunications sector (28.30 percent), service sector (21.49 percent) and transportation sector (15.00 percent).
In comparison, outbound investment totaled US$326.35 million, down 37.30 percent from the same time last year.

Taiwan businessmen's investment in mainland China totaled US$206.21 million in January, down 28.21 percent from the same time last year, mainly focusing on electronics and electrical appliance products, and metal products.

In terms of regions, Taiwan's investment has focused on Jiangsu province (59.64 percent), Guangdong province (21.59 percent) and Zhejiang province (4.52 percent), accounting for 85.72 percent of Taiwan's total investments in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped slightly against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange market Thursday, slipping NT$0.001 to NT$35.097.
A total of US$379 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$35.118 and was traded between TN$35.080 and NT$35.118.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD HOPES FOR REOPENING OF CROSS-STRAIT TALKS: SEF HEAD

TEXT.P: The international community will be happy to see Taiwan and mainland China resume dialogue because negotiations would be conducive to world peace and improve the global economy, C. F. Koo, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, said Thursday.

Koo, chairman of the quasi-official Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), which is in charge of bilateral exchanges with mainland China in lack of official contacts between the two sides, said, however, that the reopening of cross-Taiwan Strait talks depends on both sides' willingness.
The SEF chief made the remarks while answering questions from reporters following a Spring Festival gathering with mainland-based Taiwan businessmen.

As to the question of whether the current visit by U. S. President George W. Bush to mainland China will help Taiwan and the mainland restart negotiations, Koo said Bush said before embarking on the trip that the United States will remember its commitments to Taiwan's people.
"That is Washington's basic stance and the United States will not interfere directly in cross-strait talks," Koo said.

Koo, who has talked with his mainland Chinese counterpart various times with government authorization, said that he would be willing to visit mainland China this year if his health allows him to do so. Meanwhile, Koo, who is 85, is planning to travel to the United States for a medical check-up in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: LONG-STANDING LOCAL CARTOONIST LIU HSING-CHIN HONORED

TEXT.P: Well-known cartoonist Liu Hsing-chin, who is best known for his characters "Brother A-san" and "Great Auntie," was honored for his lifelong achievement Thursday at the first Best Comics Awards presentation ceremony.
Chao Yich-hong, director of the Government Information Office's Publication Affairs Department, presented the award to the 68-year-old cartoonist.

Liu has long been one of the most popular local cartoonists. An elementary school teacher when he put out his first comic book in 1953, Liu said he always found inspiration from ordinary people and has been successful in presenting the local life and culture through his cartoon characters. Many of the 68 comic books by Liu are still best-sellers in Taiwan today.

The Best Comics Awards were sponsored by the Republic of China Publishing Industry Foundation and the Taipei Cartoonists' Association to encourage more talented individuals to enter the fields of cartooning and animation.

An official of the cartoonists' association said that in recent years, Japanese and Hong Kong comics have flooded Taiwan's comics market. The cartoonists' association arranged for the most popular local cartoonists to attend a series of symposiums last month, hoping to stimulate the interest of comics fans in local productions.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER VOWS TO HELP RESOLVE RESIDENCY ISSUE FOR NORWEGIAN COUPLE

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien paid a visit to Bjarne Gislefoss, co-founder of the Puli Christian Hospital, and his wife Thursday in the central Taiwan county of Nantou, to show his concern for their residency issue.

The elderly Norwegian couple have stayed in Taiwan for 50 years to offer medical services in remote mountainous regions, but they still have not obtained permanent residency due to the Republic of China's stiff immigration laws.

Yu said he will push relevant government agencies to come up with an amendment to the existing immigration laws during the current legislative session to help resolve residency issues for several prominent foreigners, like Gislefoss and his wife, who have devoted the prime of their lives to serving Taiwan people.

Under current Taiwan law, only foreigners who have legally and continuously lived in Taiwan for seven years and who have spent over 270 days per year on the island are eligible to apply for permanent residency.
In the past, Yu said, the government imposed stringent restrictions on permanent residency applications by foreign nationals due to national security considerations.

"But times have changed. I think such strict restrictions should be properly eased," Yu said, adding that he will push for the completion of revisions in the immigration laws during the present legislative session.
Before the law is amended, Yu said he will ask local police authorities to assist the Norwegian couple in handling tedious formalities regarding extending their residency permits.

Gislefoss, 79, a trained doctor, first came to Taiwan in 1952 to work at Taipei's Mackay Memorial Hospital. In 1954, he traveled to South Korea to head an orphanage there and returned to Taiwan in 1965 to help found the Puli Christian Hospital. He has since dedicated himself to offering medical services for aboriginal and underprivileged people in central Taiwan. In 1966, he also founded a care center for local polio patients.

Alfhild Jensen Gislefoss, 84, also a medical professional, has dedicated herself to serving local people since she came to Taiwan in 1962 to introduce new anesthetic technology to Christian hospitals around the island. She married Gislefoss in Taiwan in 1963.

As the couple have to travel abroad frequently to raise funds for the Puli hospital and polio victims' care center, they have so far been unable to acquire permanent residency in Taiwan. Nevertheless, the couple have received many awards from both the ROC and Norwegian governments for their devoted services to the people of Taiwan.

Last month, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Apollo Chen said he will propose an amendment bill to allow foreigners who have stayed in Taiwan legally for over 20 years and who have spent over 183 days per year during 10 of those years on the island to be eligible to apply for permanent residency.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN NATIONS CAN PROMOTE PEACE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said in a recent interview with a U.S. magazine on foreign affairs that countries of the world should attempt to understand and respect each other to eliminate hatred and war.

Lu said in an interview with Washington International (www.washingtoninternational.com) that the attack on the World Trade Center in New York and the Pentagon shows that there is no such thing as absolute wealth or power in the world.

She said that any attempts to focus solely on developing military armaments and ignoring mutual understanding, respect, cooperation and sharing -- which are "essential in social and international relations" -- will only lead to war and hostility.

"This is why I have promoted `soft power,' which includes human rights, democracy, peace, love and high technology," she said. "The ultimate goals of the war against terrorism should be to eliminate antagonism and reduce differences between the Muslim and Christian worlds and to bridge the gap between their spiritual and material matters."

The vice president said, "As long as we have love and peace in our hearts, and as long as we exercise our `soft powers,' we can bring the Eastern and Western Hemispheres into peaceful coexistence, cooperation and sharing, without antagonism or war."

Touching on her transit through the United States en route to visiting ROC allies in Central and South America, Lu said, "It is hard to imagine that a head of state coming from a country that enjoys democracy, freedom and peace should be restricted so much in the United States."

She said that she appreciates the Taiwan policy review initiated by U.S. President George W. Bush upon taking office that allowed her and ROC President Chen Shui-bian to be accorded better receptions than they received previously in transit.

"Regretfully, however, during my transit stay in the United States, I was not able to contact the international media," she said. "The United States is a country that upholds freedom of speech. I do hope very much that I will have the chance to meet with the media during my next visit to the United States."

On her being the first woman to become a vice president of the ROC, Lu said that President Chen asked her to be his running mate so that she could join him in managing national affairs. Therefore, she said, the people have expected her to assist the president, listen to their opinions and address their problems.
Lu said that she expects more women will participate in politics to help achieve the goal of a "feminization of politics."
"I am proud that I, as a woman, was elected vice president and have been able to win the trust of the people," she said, adding that the people's smiles are her "greatest comfort."

DOC.HEADLINE: MASTER HSIN YUN LEAVES FOR MAINLAND TO ESCORT BUDDHA RELIC TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Buddhist Master Hsin Yun left for mainland China Thursday to escort an invaluable Buddha finger relic to Taiwan for exhibition.

Hsin Yun, founder of the Fokuangshan Buddhist Temple complex in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung, said prior to his departure that the Buddha relic can help "purify human hearts" and "improve social customs."
"It is not expected to avert misfortune, but it can help devout Buddhist followers attain peace of mind," Hsin Yun said. "It's a sacred symbol of Buddhism and an invaluable spiritual asset."

Hsin Yun, accompanied by a number of local Buddhist followers, will travel to the Famen Temple in the northwestern mainland province of Shaanxi to escort the Buddha finger relic to Taiwan. The article is reputed as the only real Buddha finger relic ever found.

Hsin Yun said he hopes local people will welcome the arrival of the treasured Buddhist relic with calm and reason. The Buddhist master, who recently expressed his distaste for the island's prevailing lottery mania, said he would not like to see local people become "wild" over the relic.

The removal of the Buddhist relic to Taiwan for exhibition is widely seen as a great event in the Buddhist community. A television company will broadcast the whole process live via satellite. More than 400 Buddhist followers, including 87 mainland Chinese monks, will escort the relic to Taiwan aboard two chartered planes.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH SAYS U.S. POSITION ON TAIWAN ISSUE `HAS NOT CHANGED'
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Feb. 21 (CNA) (By Liu Cheng-ching and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush said Thursday in a joint news conference with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin that the position of the U.S. government on the issue of Taiwan "has not changed over the years."
"We believe in the peaceful settlement of this issue," he said.

Bush said that the United States will continue to support the Taiwan Relations Act, which obligates Washington to provide Taiwan with the means to defend itself. He added, "We will urge there be no provocation."
Meanwhile, Jiang said that proper handling of the Taiwan issue is the key to the stable growth of Beijing-Washington relations.
Bush arrived in Beijing earlier in the day for a two-day state visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER YU CALLS FOR UPGRADING OF TAIPEI-WASHINGTON-BEIJING TIES

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday that the Republic of China government appreciates the U.S. concern for Taiwan's security and looks forward to seeing upgrading of the triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations.
Yu made the remarks after addressing a seminar attended by senior executives of Taiwanese trade associations in mainland China.

U.S. President George W. Bush, who is currently on a three-nation Asia tour, said in a speech to Japan's Diet earlier this week that America will remember its commitments to the people of Taiwan. On another occasion, Bush also said Taiwan is one of U.S. good friends in the Asia-Pacific area.

In response, Yu said, the ROC is grateful for the importance Bush has attached to the ROC-U.S. relationship. "We cherish our friendship with the United States and will continue our efforts to promote bilateral cooperation," he noted.

Moreover, Yu said, he hopes that the delicate triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations can be upgraded in the future. Bush is currently on a two-day visit to mainland China after ending his trips to Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U. S. TIES UNHURT BY BUSH'S MAINLAND VISIT: PRESIDENTIAL AIDE

TEXT.P: Relations between Taiwan and the United States have increasingly become "harmonious and close" since U. S. President George W. Bush took office and Bush's current mainland visit is unlikely to affect the two-way ties, a presidential aide said Thursday.

Secretary-General of the Presidential Office Chen Shih-meng said the U. S. has repeatedly assured Taiwan that Bush will stick to his commitments to help protect Taiwan and he will not do or say anything that could damage Taiwan's interests while visiting mainland China.

According to Chen, the main purpose of Bush's mainland trip is to thank Beijing for its cooperation in the U.S.-led anti-terrorist war following last year's Sept. 11 terror attacks on Washington and New York.

Meanwhile, Chang Shiao-yue, spokeswoman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, reiterated that the United States had briefed Taiwan on Bush's mainland visit before his departure and made it clear that the trip would not hurt Taiwan's interests. She added the ministry has set up a task force to monitor developments and deal with all contingencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN U.S., MAINLAND IMPOSSIBLE: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: It is impossible for Washington and Beijing to develop a strategic cooperative relationship, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday.

Ma made the remark while meeting the media after a ceremony he presided over to donate admission tickets to orphans and handicapped people in the city to the performance of the world famous Vienna Boys' Choir who are now in Taipei on a performing tour.

Asked to comment on U.S. President George W. Bush's visit to mainland China, Ma said that Washington and Beijing will probably establish cooperative relations on anti-terrorism, bilateral economic and trade issues, as well as other international issues.

However, he added that the different points of view on the situation among Washington, Beijing and Taipei make it impossible for Washington and Beijing to develop a strategic cooperative relationship.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SHELVES IDEA OF FORMING NATIONAL SECURITY ALLIANCE: AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has shelved the idea of forming a national security alliance in the Legislative Yuan due to the outside world's misinterpretation and misunderstanding, a presidential aide said Thursday.

Secretary-General of the Presidential Office Chen Shih-meng said President Chen's idea to set up the group was aimed at establishing a stable majority of "middle of the road" forces in cooperation with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the legislature to secure political stability for the country.

But the idea has been misinterpreted by the outside world as a means of "battling against" the opposition camp -- namely the Kuomintang and the People First Party -- which controls a fragile majority in the 225-seat legislature, he said, adding that the situation has led President Chen to decide that now is not the right time to push for the alliance.
Chen also said that the government should hold a public debate to decide whether it should allow Taiwan-based chip-makers to relocate their eight-inch wafer plants to mainland China.
He said it is a restrictive request to demand that the government make a final decision on the far-reaching issue within a month.

The Taiwan semiconductor sector has high expectations that the government will allow them to move their old facilities for manufacturing eight-inch silicon wafers to the mainland as part of their global market deployment now that the government has decided to ease restrictions on mainland-bound investment following the recommendations of the Economic Development Advisory Conference in August last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NIPPON FOUNDATION DONATES RESCUE EQUIPMENT TO TAIWAN GROUP

TEXT.P: The Nippon Foundation, a private charitable group in Japan, donated a number of rescue vehicles and life-saving equipment worth 30 million yen (US$231,000) Thursday to the Chinese International Rescue Association in Taipei.
The Taiwan association has been active in rescue missions at home and abroad during the past few years.
In order to upgrade the rescue equipment available in Taiwan, former ROC President Lee Teng-hui asked the Nippon Foundation to provide assistance.

The Nippon Foundation had earlier responded with a donation of 300 million yen (US$2.31 million) to the National Fire Administration and extended an additional 30 million yen to the Chinese International Rescue Association Thursday.

With the donation, the rescue association commissioned the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, the largest charitable group in Taiwan, to purchase the rescue vehicles and rescue equipment.
At the donation ceremony, Lee expressed his gratitude to the Nippon Foundation for its generosity for improving Taiwan's rescue capabilities, saying that it demonstrates that "love knows no borders."

Ayako Sono of the Nippon Foundation said that Taiwan, Japan and South Korea belong to a common life-entity, and added that she believes the new rescue equipment will boost Taiwan's ability to respond quickly and effectively to disasters at home and abroad.

Dignitaries present at the donation ceremony included Chinese International Rescue Association President Wang Mei-chu, Taiwan Television Enterprise Chairman Lai Kuo-chou, Taipei Office Director Katsuhisa Uchida of the Japan Interchange Association, and Vice Minister of the Interior Chien Tai-lang.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIRGIN, CAYMAN ISLANDS INVESTORS TOP TAIWAN'S INBOUND INVESTMENT LIST

TEXT.P: Foreign and overseas Chinese investments in Taiwan totaled US$358.09 million in January, an increase of 60.13 percent over the previous year's level, according to statistics released by the Industrial Development and Investment Center (IDIC) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Thursday.
Investments from the Virgin Islands, the Cayman Islands, Singapore, the United States and Japan accounted for 92.21 percent of the total.

Investment from the Virgin Islands topped the list of inbound investments in Taiwan with 31.5 percent, followed by the Cayman Islands and Singapore at 26.46 percent, the United States at 17.42 percent, Panama at 11.03 percent and Japan at 5.8 percent.

The telecommunication industry topped the list of business investments with 28.3 percent, followed by the service industry at 21.49 percent, the transport industry at 15 percent, the construction industry at 9.96 percent and electrical machines and electronics at 9.69 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE HOPES TO SPONSOR REGIONAL VOCATIONAL EDUCATION SEMINAR

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education hopes to sponsor the region's first seminar on vocational education to promote academic exchanges, a senior ministry official said Thursday.

Chen Teh-hua, the ministry's director of the technological and vocational education department, said that the ministry has recently asked National Yunlin University of Science and Technology to organize the seminar.
The purpose of the seminar is to help local vocational schools have a better of the current situation regarding vocational education in Southeast Asia, Chen said.
The ministry also hopes that by sponsoring such an event, Taiwan's vocational education experience and expertise could be recognized on the world stage.
Touching on the ministry's plans, he said that integrating regional educational organizations is key to further develop international cooperation.

The ministry is also planning to speed up its assistance to Southeast Asian nations in the areas of vocational training. The ministry also hopes to recruit students to attend local vocational schools from mainland China and Southeast Asian nations since local vocational schools will be affected by Taiwan's World Trade Organization admission, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE GROUP IN US WARNS CLINTON OF SELLING OUT TAIWAN IN SYDNEY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 20 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwanese in the United States urged former President Bill Clinton Wednesday not to lend a hand to Beijing's campaign for reunification with Taiwan when he attends a rally of a pro-Chinese unification group in Sydney on Friday.

Wu Ming-chi, president of the Washington-based Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA), which advocates Taiwan independence, said Clinton should not attend the rally and should not make any speeches harmful to the interests of Taiwan at the event should he decide to attend.

U.S. President George W. Bush, who is in mainland China on an official visit, pointed out before departing for Asia that Taiwan is Washington's good friend, and reconfirmed the United States' commitment to Taiwan's safety in a speech in Japan Monday, Wu said. Clinton should not embarrass the incumbent president by speaking otherwise, Wu said.
Reminding Clinton that he himself had said during his time in office that any change in Taiwan's status should be approved by its people, Wu urged the former president to hold his ground in Sydney.
As the pro-unification group is an organization established to cater to Beijing's political agenda, Clinton should not stoop to pave the way for Beijing's designs against Taiwan, Wu added.
"The FAPA firmly opposes any U.S. president who plays into the hands of Beijing by serving as its mouthpiece," Wu said.

Several FAPA members delivered a petition signed by about 300 persons to Clinton's office in New York Tuesday, but none of Clinton's staff would officially accept it. They finally had to ask a janitor in the building to relay the letter to Clinton's office.
An FAPA official said Wednesday that Meggie Williams, director of Clinton's office apologized for this later that day in a message left on FAPA's telephone.
Williams said she was out of the office when the petition was delivered.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTRY WORKS OUT PLANS TO STIMULATE ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Christine Tsung Thursday chaired a meeting of her ministry to work out plans for stimulating the country's economy which registered negative growth last year.
According to Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu, the meeting decided to implement 238 plans with a cost of NT$47 billion (US$1.34 billion).

He said that the plans will cover the following areas -- industry, trade, investment, commerce, small- and medium-sized enterprises, energy, cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade, state-run enterprises, water resources, intellectual property, standards-inspection-quarantine, and mining and geological survey.

Lin noted that the focus will be placed on speeding up economic recovery, improving industrial development, boosting infrastructure construction, laying the basis for global trade and beefing up assistance to industrial development.
Regarding Washington's move to review the 301 sanctions list at the end of March, Tsung asked various units of the ministry to strengthen protection of intellectual property rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: S. TAIWAN UNIV. OF TECHNOLOGY TO CEMENT EXCHANGES WITH JAPANESE UNIV.
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, Southern Taiwan, Feb. 21 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The Southern Taiwan University of Technology will strengthen its academic exchanges with Japan's Lyotsu Keizai University, a spokesman for the Taiwan university said Thursday.
The spokesman said that students of the two universities are organizing exchange visits for September.

Professors Masaichi Kanebashi, Masanobu Yatsuda and Yasuhiro Honma from Japan's Lyotsu Keizai University came to Southern Taiwan University of Technology and exchanged views on topics related to student exchanges, teachers pursuing advanced degrees and the issuance of student visas.
Southern Taiwan University of Technology entered into sisterhood ties with Japan's Lyotsu Keizai University two years ago.
The spokesman said that students from Japan Lyotsu Keizai University who are expected to visit Taiwan will be from Japan, Sri Lanka and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER AGAIN BACKS POLICY TO STIMULATE INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: The ROC government will go forward with its "active opening, effective management" economic policy toward mainland China and implement consensuses reached at the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) last August to meet challenges resulting from Taiwan's World Trade Organization's (WTO) admission, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.

Since both sides of the Taiwan Strait are now full members of the WTO, Yu said that cross-strait trade and exchanges will grow and that the increased contact will require Taiwan and the mainland to respect and have faith in one another.
The premier called on both sides of the Strait to put aside their differences and enter into discussions on issues that are important for future stability.

He said that the two sides resolve issues such as ways to promote cross-strait economic cooperation, strengthen investment protection agreements, foster the "mini three links" and come to a conclusion about the controversial notion of whether agreement was ever reached in 1992 on the definition of "one China."

Yu urged Taiwanese businessmen on the mainland to join hands with the government to strengthen Taiwan. He said that tapping the vast market across the Strait was acceptable business but added: "Only by having a strong Taiwan will you be able to work outside of the country without people casting aspersions on your operations."

Yu also promised that the government will continue to improve the investment climate, undertake construction of needed infrastructure projects, strengthen research and development programs in high-tech industries and upgrade the enterprises' competitiveness.

Yu made the remarks while addressing an annual gathering of Taiwan business leaders who have investments in the mainland jointly sponsored by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affair Council (MAC), the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Strait Exchange Foundation and the Chinese National Federation of Industries.

More than 140 members of the Taiwan Businessmen's Association based throughout mainland China took part in the event which was also attended by Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i, Minister of Economic Affairs Christine Tsung and MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL DRUM FESTIVAL TO OPEN IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung International Flag and Drum Festival will open Friday and run through Feb. 24 at the Taisugar Garden and the Kaohsiung Municipal Art Museum.
In addition to five local groups, performing troupes from Indonesia, Japan, Thailand, Australia and mainland China will give performances to entertain visitors.
Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh hosted a dinner at a five-star hotel Thursday in honor of the foreign troupes.
He welcomed them and said he hoped that visitors from home and abroad will come to Kaohsiung to see the performances and the 2002 Kaohsiung Lantern Festival which will be held from Feb. 26.
Organizers said that the events are expected to attract 5 million visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, THAILAND AGREE TO INCREASE PASSENGER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Aviation representatives from Taiwan and Thailand amended their air traffic agreement Thursday by inking a memorandum of understanding, prompting Taiwan-based airlines to explore new tourist destinations in Thailand.
ROC Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Chang Chia-chu said the new accord will enable the two countries to further their cultural, trade and tourist exchanges.

Under the terms of the newly revised pact, both sides agreed to increase the total number of passenger flights between the two countries from the current 91 per week to 104. With an additional 15 flights confined to destinations outside Bangkok, the number of passenger flights between the two countries will increase by 28 per week.
At the same time, the number of bilateral cargo fights has been maintained at 18 per week.

As Thailand is one of the most popular destinations overseas among Taiwan tourists, four Taiwan-based aviation companies -- Far East Air Transport Corp., TransAsia Airways, UNI Airlines and Mandarin Airlines -- which have so far operated domestic routes in Taiwan -- are showing much interest in flying to new tourist destinations in Thailand, such as Hua Hin near Bangkok and other locations near Phuket and Pattaya.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HARBOR LOOKING FOR WAYS TO REGAIN LOST BUSINESS
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Feb. 21 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau (KHB) is looking for lifting management fees for containers in transshipment in order to regain its ranking as the world's third-largest container harbor after being overtaken by Pusan in South Korea last year, KHB officials said Thursday.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) has turned down a suggestion by the KHB that the ministry stop levying fees for the management of the handling of transshipping containers to make the harbor more attractive to shippers.
KHB officials said that they will collect more detailed information for the ministry in the issue of fees but said that they will also continue to push for the lifting of management fees.

The number of containers loaded and unloaded in South Korea's Pusan Harbor surpassed that of Kaohsiung Harbor in 2001, making Pusan the world's third-largest container harbor, replacing Kaohsiung, the KHB said. Kaohsiung has slipped to fourth.
Kaohsiung Harbor handled 7.54 million TEUs during the whole of last year, less than Pusan harbor's 7.9 million.
Hong Kong and Singapore are the world's largest and second-largest container harbors, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN APPRECIATIVE THAT BUSH HAS NOT MADE HARMFUL REMARKS: ROC FM

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is appreciative that U.S. President George W. Bush has not made any remarks harmful to ROC interests during his ongoing trip to mainland China, ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said Thursday.

Chien noted that although the United States and mainland China appear to have achieved consensus on certain issues, Bush and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin were approaching the issue of Taiwan differently, each putting forward their own interpretations.
Chien said that this corresponded entirely with the information that Taiwan received before the meeting between Bush and Jiang.

He said that the ROC government affirms Bush's comment that the Taiwan issue must be resolved peacefully and that the U.S. government will continue to abide by the Taiwan Relations Act, which requires Washington to provide Taiwan with the means to defend itself.
Chien said that Bush's trip to Asia was significant in promoting stability, prosperity and security across the Taiwan Strait.

He added that the ROC government hopes Washington will elevate the level of its relations with Taipei at the same time that it improves relations with Beijing so that a "win-win" situation can be created on the basis of democracy, human rights, economic prosperity, peace and security for all.

Meanwhile, the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), which regards former ROC President Lee Teng-hui as its "spiritual leader," openly urged Bush to take the occasion of his trip to demand that mainland China respect human rights, put a stop to religious prosecution, let Taiwan gain independence and maintain friendly cross-strait ties.
TSU spokesman Lin Chih-chia also urged mainland China to abandon communism and embrace democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT OFFERS TO RECONVENE ADVISORY GROUP

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that the government is offering to reconvene the presidential advisory group that met previously and which was intended to bridge political parties to make recommendations on cross-Taiwan Strait issues.

Chen said at a seminar of heads of Taiwanese business associations in mainland China that he hopes the parties will agree to participate in the President's Advisory Group on Cross-Taiwan Strait Relations, an ad hoc team that in the first few months of his presidency managed to form a basic consensus that served as reference for his cross-strait policy.
During those earlier meetings, neither of the two major opposition parties agreed to attend the advisory committee or take part in any of its activities.

Headed by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, the group announced its "three acknowledgments and four recommendations" after its seventh meeting on Nov. 26, 2000, including a suggestion that Chen should promote cross-strait relations, resolve bilateral disputes and respond to Beijing's "one China" stance in line with the ROC Constitution.

If the ruling and opposition parties are willing, the president said that he hopes the advisory group will reconvene to formulate further recommendations on cross-strait issues that are consensuses of the various political parties and can be agreed upon by all the people of Taiwan.

Chen said that the Economic Development Advisory Conference held in August last year urged the government to consolidate the consensuses of the ruling and opposition parties as soon as possible, to resolve the differences surrounding the issue of the "1992 consensus," to define cross-strait relations in accordance with the ROC Constitution, to set aside political contentions and to negotiate quickly with mainland China on the "three links" issue as well as other issues that concern the welfare of the people.

The president said that his government has continuously offered gestures of good will and sincerity to the other side of the Taiwan Strait and replaced the previous administration's "no haste, be patient" policy on investments in mainland China with one of "active opening, effective management."
All of this was done with the hopes of maintaining harmony and bilateral exchanges, and in the pursuit of normalized development in cross-strait relations, he added.
Chen said that Taipei and Beijing should engage in proactive dialogue and cooperation instead of passive resistance and confrontation.

Taiwan welcomes any actions or remarks from mainland China that are conducive to maintaining cross-strait stability, he said, adding that as along as the two sides have good will and sincerity, and carry out exchanges and dialogue pragmatically, there will surely be improvements in bilateral relations that will lead to reconciliation and everlasting peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDDHIST DA LIN HOSPITAL ASKING FOR DONATIONS FOR AFGHAN REFUGEES
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, southern Taiwan, Feb. 21 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Tzu Chi Da Lin Hospital in Chiayi County will hold a bazaar in the main hall of the hospital Feb. 26 to raise fund for Afghan refugees.
A spokesman said that thousands of Afghan refugees are suffering severe difficulties getting food and finding shelter this winter.
He said he hoped that the public will donate used articles to the bazaar.

In January, two teams from the Hualien-based Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation visited Afghanistan to dole out relief materials for the refugees together with the Los Angeles-based Knightbridge Association.
They distributed some 65 tons of relief materials, including rice, wheat, soybeans, blankets, sugar, edible oil, kerosene, oil-stoves, shoes and medical packages.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPEAKER RULES OUT PARTICIPATING IN PROPOSED COORDINATION GROUP

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng ruled out the possibility Thursday that he would join a proposed coordination group between the legislature and the office of the president.

As head of the legislature, a position which is essentially supposed to monitor the administration, Wang said it would be inappropriate for him to join a group designed to work out policy acceptable to the Presidential Office while chairing the legislature.

Except for what was reported in the newspapers, Wang said he has no idea of the coordination group which is said to be made up of Cabinet members, heads of counties and cities and heads of major think tanks, to replace the so-called "nine-member panel" which is the supreme policy-making body consisting of DPP leaders in the legislature, Cabinet and presidential office.

Wang said lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) who are charged with steering the Cabinet's agenda through the legislature would not breach the basic principles of democracy by serving in the coordination group, but as head of the legislature -- and a member of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -- this would not be possible for him.
He said he is more than willing to offer his opinions on political issues to the ruling authorities if asked, but would not join the proposed coordination group.

He also denied that President Chen Shui-bian is flirting with the idea of forming a non-partisan panel with Wang as its head to sort out differences among the Legislative Yuan, Executive Yuan and the Presidential Office.
Wang said these reports are absolutely groundless.
Wang made the comments while answering questions from journalists on the sidelines of a KMT New Year's party.

In a related development Thursday, People First Party lawmaker Lee Ching-an criticized the idea of forming such a coordination group as not complying with the law, just as the nine-member panel lacks proper legal foundation.
But DPP lawmaker Wang To said the nine-member panel does not contravene the law as there is nothing on the books specifically referring to it.

He said that the coordination group, which would be formed by expanding the nine-member panel, would broaden the basis of communication between the ruling and opposition parties and thereby help the government to carry out its agenda.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADVISER CONFIRMS PRESIDENT IS CONSIDERING REVIVING TASK FORCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian consulted Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh on ways to revive what was to be a non-partisan panel to advise Chen on policy toward mainland China, a president's national policy adviser said Thursday.

Hsiao Hsin-huang, who was also spokesman for the President's Adivisory Group onCross-Taiwan Stait Relations set up in August, 2000 to offer opinions to the president on mainland Chinese policy, said Chen spoke with Lee before the Chinese New Year in hopes of reactivating the now-defunct panel by bringing in representatives of opposition parties.

Given that the political situation in Taiwan has changed greatly after the December 2001 elections of lawmakers, Hsiao said the president thought that the opposition would no longer reject the idea of joining a multi-party presidential advisory panel.
The main opposition parties refused to attend any of the past meetings.
The president's proposal to reconvene the cross-party task force Thursday left the major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) cold.
KMT spokeswoman Kuo Shu-chung said her party will reserve response "until it is clear whether the president is trying to sell snake oil or if he is in fact offering the real deal."

Meanwhile Su Chi, the former chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council and a researcher at the KMT-run think tank the National Policy Foundation, criticized the president as fighting against an imaginary enemy.

"The problem with the president is the widely divergent opinions toward mainland China within his own party," Su said, adding that this problem must be solved by Chen himself rather than any task force outside the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIANT CRUISE LINER MAKES STOP IN KEELUNG
DOC.DATELINE: Keelung, northern Taiwan, Feb. 21 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A 109,000-ton cruise ship carrying 2,000 passengers glided into Keelung Harbor Thursday before proceeding to Japan -- the first time such a huge liner has docked at the port.
The "Star-Princess," started a 12-day, five-nation voyage of Asia Feb. 13 from the west coast of the United States.
After berthing at Bangkok and Hong Kong, it arrived in Keelung at 7 a.m.
The passengers on board got off the ship and visited downtown Keelung City and Taipei City by taking 21 buses.
The huge cruise ship left Keelung Harbor at 5 p.m. to proceed to Okinawa and Osaka.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 22, or the 11th day of the first month of the Year of the Horse according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1512: Amerigo Vespucci, Italian navigator and "discoverer" of the South American coast, dies at the age of 58. America was named in his honor.
1732: George Washington, the first U.S. president, is born.
1784: The Empress of China, the first trading ship sent to China from the United States, sets sail from New York.
1788: Arthur Schopenhauer, German philosopher who saw the ideal state of man as one of contemplative freedom achieved through art, is born.
1810: Frederick Chopin, Polish-born French composer and pianist of the romantic era, is born. His music was noted chiefly for its expressiveness.
1857: Robert Baden-Powell, British hero of the siege of Mafeking in the Boer War and founder of the Boy Scouts, is born.
1819: Spain cedes the state of Florida to the United States.
1879: U.S. storekeeper Frank W. Woolworth, thinking centralized purchasing will help keep prices down and profits up, opens the new F.W. Woolworth Co. Five-and-Ten Cent Store in Lancaster, Pennsylvania.
1924: Calvin Coolidge becomes the first U.S. president to broadcast from the White House.
1932: Edward Kennedy, U.S. senator and younger brother of John F. Kennedy, is born.
1934: Nicaraguan guerrilla leader General Augusto Sandino is executed by his rival, General Anastasio Somoza, commander of the National Guard.
1940: The 14th Dalai Lama is enthroned in Lhasa, Tibet.
1946: Dr. Selman Abrahams announces he has discovered streptomycin, an antibiotic which can be used to treat tuberculosis and bacterial infections.
1948: More than 20,000 students demonstrate against the Yalta Secret Agreement and call for the Soviet Union to withdraw its forces from China.
1967: Indonesian President Sukarno announces the end of his rule and transfers political power to Gen. Suharto.
1967: U.S. forces and South Vietnamese troops launch Operation Junction City, attacking communist forces in Tayninh Province north of Saigon.
1973: Gordon T. Wallis, chairman of the Irving Trust Company of New York, arrives to open a Taipei branch.
1974: Minister of Finance K.T. Li, Minister of Economic Affairs Y.S. Sun and Sheik Mohammed Aba Al-Khail, Saudi Arabian minister of finance and national economy, issue a joint communique on financial and economic cooperation.
1979: The Caribbean island of St. Lucia announces independence from Britain.
1990: The last statue of Joseph Stalin topples in Ulan Bator, capital of Mongolia.
1991: U.S. President George Bush gives Saddam Hussein 24 hours to quit Kuwait or face an all-out ground war against allied forces.
1993: The Taiwanese film "The Wedding Banquet" wins a Golden Bear Award for Best Picture at the 43rd Berlin International Film Festival.
1996: Russia and the International Monetary Fund reach a deal on a loan of more than US$10 billion.
1996: The French government announces the abolition of conscription and the adoption of a voluntary system for military service.
2000: Chien Wen-hui successfully receives a piece of his wife's liver in an operation performed at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Kaohsiung, marking the first wife-to-husband live-donor liver transplant ever conducted in Taiwan.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian is accused of taking bribes from a Malaysian business tycoon.
2001: Two missile patrol boats of the Republic of China Navy runs aground near a seaside resort in northern Taiwan on their way from Suao to Tamsui.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In education, study always as if you have not yet reached your goal and as though apprehensive of losing it."

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 2,400 LOCAL WORKERS HAVE BENEFITED FROM INCENTIVE PROGRAM: CLA

TEXT.P: More than 2,400 domestic laborers have benefited so far from an incentive program implemented last September by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to promote the employment of local laborers in traditional industries, according to CLA statistics.
CLA officials said that the program was put in place in order to encourage traditional industries to hire more local laborers as well as to help solve the labor shortage problem in these industries.

Under the terms of the program, the CLA gives employers in traditional industries NT$60,000 (US$1,709.4) for each domestic laborer they employ continuously for six months, providing an additional NT$10,000 for each month that they retain the employee thereafter.

Meanwhile, the CLA has stiffened the punishment for employers who hire foreign laborers illegally. The employers are subject to fines of between NT$150,000 and NT$750,000 (US$4,273.5 and US21,367.5) for hiring foreign laborers without getting prior approval, and they are subject to imprisonment of up to three years if they violate the regulations again within five years.
The CLA said it made the move to prevent the illegal hiring of foreign laborers in order to protect the rights and interests of local workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LANDERS SUSPECTED OF TRYING TO SNEAK INTO TAIWAN NABBED OFF PENGHU

TEXT.P: A boatload of mainland Chinese men were nabbed off an isle near Penghu Island Thursday before allegedly trying to sneak into Taiwan territory, coast guard forces in the southern county of Chiayi reported Friday.

Acting on a tip, members of the Chiayi coast guard searched the offshore areas around Penghu in the Taiwan Strait on Thursday night and discovered a mainland Chinese fishing boat, the Minjinyu 5782, which was about to anchor at a makeshift pier on the isle of Chimei.

After boarding the small fishing craft, the Chiayi maritime police discovered 43 mainland Chinese on board the vessel which is designed to carry between eight and 10 people along with fishing gear and catch.

Some of the mainland Chinese men, ranging in age from 17 to over 50, were wearing business suits and did not have the darkened skin characteristic of fishermen, although they claimed that they were fishermen, according to maritime police.
Finding neither fishing gear nor catch on the boat, the Chiayi police took all of the mainlanders back to the headquarters of the Chiayi coast guard for questioning overnight.

Of the total, four men could not produce any identification papers to prove their status. When the police asked one of them whether he knew how to fish and also why he was wearing a business suit, the man gave no reply and only smiled timidly.
The police discovered that most of the mainlanders are from Fujian Province or Guizhou Province.

The maritime police handed the 43 mainlanders to the Chiayi intelligence authorities for further questioning out of concerns that they might be spies who had tried to sneak into Taiwan to collect intelligence information.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND GROUP DONATES SET OF RARE BOOKS TO NATIONAL CENTRAL LIBRARY

TEXT.P: The National Central Library received a donation of 123 rare books from a mainland Chinese group Friday, helping to enrich library collections and enhance reading services for Taiwan readers.

The set of 123 rare books, touted as one of the greatest compilations of Chinese classics in 200 years since the compilation of the Si-Ku-Quan-Shu, was donated by the Cheng Cheng Cultural Investment Group as a token of friendship toward Taiwan readers.

Si-Ku-Quan-Shu, or the titles of the complete collection of Chinese books consisting of four major categories, were compiled during the Ching Dynasty -- the last imperial dynasty in China before the Republic of China (ROC) was founded in 1911.

The 123 volumes of Chinese classics -- divided into four major categories, namely Jing, Shih, Zi and Ji -- include important books from each of the dynasties from the feudal state of Chin (879-221 B.C.) through to the Ching rule (1644-1911).

The set of books, reportedly valued at over 16 million renminbi (US$1.93 million), was donated by Zheng Yingliang, a Cheng Cheng representative from Singapore, to the National Central Library in a ceremony held at the display ground of the ongoing Taipei International Book Exhibition.
Chuang Fang-jung, director of the National Central Library, who received the donation on behalf of the library, presented the Cheng Cheng Group with a certificate of gratitude in return.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKER ORGANIZES NEW CROSS-STRAIT FORUM

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator John Chang said Friday he is pushing for the establishment of a new cross-party forum on issues related to the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Speaking at a seminar on the problems faced by Taiwan investors in mainland China, Chang said he intends to invite lawmakers from both the ruling and opposition parties to join the proposed forum which he said would serve as a conduit for dialogue and communication between government officials and Taiwan business people with interests in mainland China.

Chang, a former minister of foreign affairs and secretary-general to the president during the era of KMT rule, said the government's current "active opening, effective management" policy on cross-strait trade and economic relations is self-contradictory.

"My opinion is that the government should replace `effective management' with `pragmatic management' in order to offer local entrepreneurs even greater freedom in tapping into the vast mainland Chinese market," Chang said.

In addition, Chang said, the government should scrap its obsolete practice of meeting with senior executives of Taiwanese trade associations in mainland China only during the three major Chinese festivals -- the Spring Festival, the Dragon Boat Festival and the Mid-Autumn Festival.
"The government should exercise more flexibility in arranging meetings with mainland China-based Taiwan business and industry executives," Chang said.

"Relevant government agencies should maintain regular and frequent contacts with our business people with interests on the mainland in order to better understand their needs and tailor cross-strait policies to meet their reasonable demands in time," he added.

Against this backdrop, Chang said, he is organizing a new forum in the Legislative Yuan to serve as a bridge for increased communications between the government and mainalnd China-based Taiwan entrepreneurs.
"I hope legislators from the various political parties will join the forum to help smooth dialogue between the government and the business community," he said.

A number of legislators from the KMT, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition People First Party attended Friday's seminar to exchange views with Taiwan investors in mainland China on feasible measures to improve cross-strait economic relations.

Many businesspeople present on the occasion said that their operations on the mainland have become increasingly difficult since mainland China joined the World Trade Organization (WTO) late last year.

Chang Han-wen, president of the Dongguan Taiwanese Business Association in southern China, said mainland China has been actively assisting its small- and medium-sized enterprises to expand operations since its WTO accession.

"Such moves have threatened the survival of Taiwan-funded businesses there. Some mainland firms have even hired management personnel from Taiwan-financed companies to enhance their competitive edge," Chang complained, adding that the government should play a more active role in helping integrate the resources of Taiwan-financed firms to maintain their niches in the critical mainland market.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER SUPPORTS TAINAN ORCHID CULTURING ZONE PROJECT

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Christine T.Y. Tsung and Fan Cheng-chung, chairman of the Council of Agriculture, both support the Tainan orchid culturing zone development project, according to Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-dji.

Su said that Tainan County Government and the Taiwan Sugar Corp. plan to jointly develop a 500-hectare orchid growing plantation in Ho-pi in Tainan County. The Council of Agriculture has agreed to provide financial support for the project.

Orchid plantations have become a profit-making side business of the state-owned Taiwan Sugar Corp. The Taiwan Sugar Corp. Orchid Propagation Center (TSCOPC) has earned handsome amounts of foreign exchange with its phalaenopsis, dendrobium and oncidium plants cultured at its computer-controlled greenhouses.

A pioneer in culturing, mass producing and marketing orchid plants, the TSCOPC first introduced the greenhouse technology from the Netherlands in 1987, and has since succeeded in culturing a great variety of species.

With the popularity of orchid plants from Taiwan in the Japanese, European, Northern American and mainland Chinese markets, the TSCOPC is planning to cooperate with Tainan County Government to develop an orchid culturing zone with research facilities in Ho-pi, where the weather is best suited for horticulture.

Orchid growers in Taiwan will sponsor the eighth Asia-Pacific Orchid Conference in the spring of 2004. Taiwan's orchid plants have won numerous prizes at the international event which has been held every three years since the first conference in Japan in 1984. Japan, Indonesia, Australia and Thailand have each hosted the conference since its inception.
While many orchid nurseries around the island are opened to the public, orchid growers have also presented their precious species at exhibitions around the island.

From March 9-17, the Taiwan Orchid Growers Association, the Council of Agriculture, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Tourism Bureau and Tainan County Government will jointly sponsor the Taiwan International Orchid Show 2002 at the Tainan Beru Exhibition Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET CLOSES LOWER

TEXT.P: Prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) closed 0.8 percent lower Friday amid bearish sentiment following Wall Street losses.
The TAIEX weighted price index, the market's key barometer, lost 46.27 points to close at 5,609.83 amid moderate trading.
Market turnover totaled NT$79.29 billion (US$2.27 billion) during the four-and-half-hour trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRAFFIC CONTROLS TO BE IMPOSED OVER ARRIVAL OF BUDDHIST RELIC

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government announced Friday that traffic controls will be imposed on several major thoroughfares Saturday afternoon due to the arrival of a treasured Buddhist relic -- a finger purported to have come from Sakamuni Buddha some 2,500 years ago.

The relic, which is kept at the Famen Temple in Xian, in the northern mainland Chinese province of Shaanxi, will arrive in Taiwan Saturday under the escort of a large number of Buddhist faithful from both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

As the relic will be sent directly from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to National Taiwan University's domed stadium for a three-day exhibition, the Taipei City Police Headquarters (TCPH) said traffic controls will be imposed on major streets along its route, including Hsinsheng S. Road, Jenai Road and Hsinhai Road.

The controls will remain in place from 3 p.m. through 5 p.m., a TCPH official said, adding that drivers are advised to detour during the period to avoid possible traffic jams as throngs of local Buddhist followers are expected to turn out to greet the relic.

Buddhist Master Hsin Yun, founder of the Fokuangshan Monastery in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung, led a 300-member delegation to mainland China Thursday to escort the relic to Taiwan for exhibition in Taipei and other places around the island for 40 days.

Prior to his departure, Hsin Yun said he is convinced that the exhibition of the Buddhist treasure in Taiwan will help "purify human hearts, cleanse social morals and bring peace to the Taiwan Strait."
Noting that the relic is an invaluable symbol of Buddhism and a spiritual asset, Hsin Yun said its arrival will mark a new milestone in cross-strait religious exchanges.

Hsin Yun further said he hopes local people will welcome the arrival of the relic with calm and reason. The Buddhist master, who recently expressed his distaste for the island's prevailing lottery mania, said he would not like to see local people become "wild" over the relic.
According to religious documents, Sakamuni Buddha died in 485 B.C. and the finger was brought to China some 200 years later. It is reputed to be the only real Buddha finger relic ever found.

The finger was sealed in a basement of the Famen Temple's pagoda in 874 by order of an emperor from the ancient Tang Dynasty. Since then it was not seen in public until 1986, when the Shaanxi provincial government cleared the rubble of the temple's pagoda, which collapsed in 1981 amid torrential rains.

In 1998 the Fokuanshan Monastery brought back from Thailand a tooth believed to be one of only three Buddha teeth preserved in the world. The tooth had been held in India since being smuggled out of Tibet during China's 1966-76 Cultural Revolution.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK MARKET CONTINUES LOSING GROUND

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued losing ground Friday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, falling 46.27 points to close at 5,609.83.

The market opened weak amid bearish sentiment following Wall Street losses. The weighted index dropped about 100 points in the first hour of trading, but rebounded a bit after hitting a low of 5,532.17 points around mid-session.

Market turnover totaled NT$79.29 billion (US$2.27 billion) in moderate trading, with more than 2.79 billion shares changing hands during the four-and-half-hour trading session. The trade volume shrank further from Thursday's level as many small-time players kept on the sidelines over market uncertainty.

Of the eight major stock categories, only fianncial issues posted a marginal 0.2 percent gain, while the remaining seven categories all lost ground. Construction and paper stocks both incurred a 2.9 percent losses; textile, plastics and electronics categories all lost 1.2 percent; cement issues slid 0.7 percent; and foodstuff shares fell 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 480 to 140, with 66 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market closed lower Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for March lost 36 points to close at 5,620, with 11,287 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for April went down 19 points to finish at 5,698, with 25 contracts traded, while September futures fell seven points to close at 5,674, with three contracts changing hands. December futures lost 46 points to end at 5,630, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,656 for March, 5,617 for April, 5,661 for June, 5,681 for September and 5,676 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results for March.
TE futures for March lost 1.8 points to close at 295.2, with 2,667 contract transactions, while TE futures for April fell 4.2 points to finish at 291.8, with two contracts traded.

TF futures for March gained 2.8 points to finish at 688, with 669 contracts changing hands.
