DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN APPRECIATIVE OF BUSH'S REAFFIRMATION OF TRA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reiterated its appreciation Friday of U.S. President George W. Bush for his repeated reaffirmation that the U.S. government will continue to abide by the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).

Bush said again Friday at the prestigious Tsinghua University in Beijing that the U.S. government will continue to abide by the TRA, making him the first U.S. president to publicly underline the TRA twice in a single state visit to mainland China.

In his responses to questions raised by Tsinghua students after a 20-minute speech, Bush reiterated the U.S. policy that the Taiwan issue should be resolved peacefully and that cross-Taiwan Strait differences should be settled via peaceful dialogue.

Bush said the United States has for long supported the "one China" policy, but the U.S. government will also continue to abide by the TRA, which requires Washington to provide Taiwan with the means to defend itself.
Foreign Affairs Minister Eugene Chien said the ROC government hopes Washington will elevate the level of its bilateral relations with Taipei at the same time that it improves ties with Beijing.

Chien said the Bush Administration has on several occasions over the past month expressed important and prominent messages that the Taiwan Strait dispute should be resolved peacefully and that Bush has mentioned during his current Asian trip that Taiwan is "one of the good friends" of the United States.
Bush's explicit goodwill toward Taiwan, including the repeated mentioning of the TRA, makes him "very different" from his predecessors, according to Chien.

In a joint news conference with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin held in Beijing Thursday, Bush said that the position of the U.S. government on the issue of Taiwan "has not changed over the years."
"We believe in the peaceful settlement of this issue." Bush said. He went on to say that the United States will continue to support the TRA, adding that "we will urge that there be no provocation."

Chien noted that MOFA has been closely monitoring all developments related to Taiwan and the development of cross-strait relations during Bush's current three-nation Asian trip, which brought him to Beijing, the last leg of the trip, Thursday for a two-day visit.
According to MOFA officials, Washington will brief Taiwan on the development of situations related to Bush's current Asian trip after Bush and his entourage return to the United States.

Meanwhile, commenting on Bush's Friday remarks pertaining to Taiwan, Huang Chih-fang, director-general of the Department of Public Affairs under the Presidential Office, said the ROC Presidential Office thinks the U.S. government's stance toward Taiwan has remained unchanged and is fully confident in Taipei-Washington relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP TOUTS INVESTMENT IN ALLIES TO HELP MITIGATE WTO IMPACT
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Feb. 22 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Friday that Taiwan's agricultural sector "could consider relocating" part of their operations to Republic of China diplomatic allies to help mitigate the impact of World Trade Organization (WTO) accession.

According to Lu, Taiwan's farmers should consider leaving their homes and moving to allied countries if they find it difficult to keep their heads above water amidst the increased competition that comes as a result of WTO membership.

To enable these farmers to restart their businesses abroad smoothly, Lu said the ROC government and the allied countries' governments could provide "joint financing" by allocating budgets for "special programs." She did not elaborate and gave no indication as to how this could be achieved, but she expressed hope that her "plan" will be proposed, drafted, legislated and made available to Taiwan farmers in six months.

She also said she does not think mainland China is an ideal place for Taiwan businesses to invest, claiming that "if the WTO's adverse effects has an impact of 1 on a scale of 100 to Taiwan, investment on the Chinese mainland has an impact of 10."

Lu made special reference to the heated discussion on whether to allow Taiwan's semiconductor manufacturers to relocate their 8-inch silicon wafer fabrication plants to the mainland, saying that the government of Hsinchu -- home to most of Taiwan's high-technology industries -- should have in-depth brainstorming sessions with its people over the issue.

Lu was accompanied by Hsinchu Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin during her whirlwind tour of Hsinchu County, an important agricultural county with prominent high-technology industries and a mainly Hakka agricultural sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLOUD GATE DANCE THEATER HAS INTENSIVE OVERSEAS PROGRAM FOR 2002

TEXT.P: Choreographer Lin Hwai-ming and his Cloud Gate Dance Theater will have a busy year, with 41 performances in Hong Kong, Germany, the United States, Brazil, Mexico and Shanghai in the coming months, a spokesman for the dance group said Friday.
The Cloud Gate dancers will present Lin's "Songs of the Wanderers" -- which premiered in 1994 -- and the 1998 creation "Moon Water", which received critical international acclaim, the spokesman said.

With the performances abroad scheduled until the end of 2004, the Cloud Gate will have fewer opportunities to perform at home, although it will give a series of performances at the National Theater in Taipei, and the cultural centers in Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung in March and April, Lin said.
The local performances will feature "Songs of the Wanderers" and "Burning the Jupiter Branches."

Lin said that since 1994, the Cloud Gate dancers have given 120 performances of the "Songs of the Wanderers" in 25 cities around the globe. Considering it a long-running production, Lin said that "Songs of the Wanderers" is like a gift from Buddha for mankind, and that as the choreographer, he is only the "media" used to convey the heavenly message.

Lin said that he was enlightened by the progress of Prince Siddhartha in summer of 1994 after a trip to Bodhgaya where the Buddha attained his enlightenment under a bodhi tree. The process of creating the 90-minute "Songs of the Wanderers" was like a "spiritual journey," he added.
As one of the most renowned choreographers in Asia, Lin is talented in blending traditional Chinese theater elements with Western dance techniques.

The Cloud Gate founder and artistic director has also won international acclaim because he is able to incorporate Chinese philosophy with dancers' movements in his productions such as "Moon Water," a poetic rendition of the Taoist philosophy of real vs. unreal, "Nine Songs," a production inspired by ancient ritual verses, and the epic dance saga "Portrait of the Families," telling the Taiwanese experience in the past century.

Lin said that the Cloud Gate took an unconventional road when it was founded in 1973. Without any support from the government at the beginning, the group still managed to present new repertoires every year. The group almost succumbed to financial crisis in the late 1980s when it was unable to tour. It was only able to resume performing in the 1990s when the government decided to provide subsidies.

The 55-year-old choreographer said that the audience will find the group becoming ever more mature in its performances and added that he has a deeper appreciation every time he watches his dancers performing "Songs of the Wanderers."

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS CALL FOR GOVERNMENT ACTIONS TO COOL LOTTO FEVER

TEXT.P: A group of scholars and consumer rights activists urged relevant government agencies Friday to take actions to cool down the prevailing lottery mania on the island.
They made the appeal at a seminar sponsored by the ROC Consumers Foundation to discuss the impact on local society of the recently launched public welfare computerized lottery.

Yu Ming-kuo, chairman of the Consumers Foundation, said he himself doesn't oppose the issue of public interest lottery. "But we should improve relevant rules of the game to prevent it from letting the poor become even more impoverished while creating only a few "nauveau riches."

Hsu Wen-ching, chief executive of the Media Watch Foundation, said since the lottery bears the words "public welfare," all of the income from the ticket sales should be contributed to social welfare programs. "No profit-making actions should be allowed in the deal," she asserted.

Hsu went on to say that local media truly have given too much coverage to lottery-related events, with some newspapers and magazines even having opened special columns to provide information on the lottery.

"I hope the Government Information Office (GIO) can immediately demand news organizations that have given improper reports on lottery events to make corrections," Hsu said, adding that the government should also review whether the lottery should be continued or scrapped.
Wu Chung-chi, honorary chairman of the Consumers Foundation, said he is convinced that the deterioration of uneven wealth distribution has helped fuel the current lottery fever.

"My observation is that lottery ticket sales will continue to increase in the future and would eventually affect domestic production and consumer spending," Wu said. "I personally doesn't support suspension of the lottery, but I think that the frequency of lottery draw should be reduced."

Yu Ying-feu, convener of the Consumers Foundation's media commission, said current law bans advertisements (ads) of any gambling games. He expressed doubts about the legality of news media carrying lottery-related ads.

In his view, Yu said although the so-called "public welfare" lottery has allowed both the government and ticket dealers to make quick bucks, it has also created many social problems. He said all proceeds from ticket sales should be used to finance public interest programs and that the general public should closely supervise the flow of lottery profits.

In response, Cha Tai-ming, a GIO section chief, said news media are obligated to report on lottery-related news events. "Nevertheless, they should refrain from reporting relevant stories in a sensational style or manner."

Cha said since the new lottery is designed for collecting funds for social welfare programs, local news media are eligible to carry relevant ads. "As for the lottery future development, it needs extensive discussion by various social quarters."

Huang Tien-mu, a division chief with the Bureau of Monetary Affairs, said the present version of lottery was launched after more than 10 years of research and with the approval of the Legislative Yuan. "Its legality and legitimacy are unquestionable," he stressed.

Huang added that the bureau has ordered Taipeibank, which is authorized to operate the new lottery, to strengthen publicity of the "welfare" purposes of the lottery and make all necessary improvements based on public opinion to minimize adverse impact on society and economy.

Yang Jui-tung, a Taipeibank manager, said it's still premature to judge the impact of the lottery since only nine issues have so far been drawn. "We need more time to evaluate its various effects before making a final decision on its fate."
Since the lottery was launched on Jan. 17, lotto fever has taken the island by storm. Total ticket sales have exceeded NT$15 billion so far.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS OPPOSE HEALTH INSURANCE PREMIUM HIKE

TEXT.P: A group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers voiced opposition Friday to a Department of Health (DOH) plan to raise the premium rate for the National Health Insurance Program (NHIP).

The DPP legislators, including Chang Ching-fang, Lin Chin-hsing, Chen Chung-hsin and You Ching, said the DOH should first resolve the so-called "pharmaceutical prices black hole" issue before considering raising the insurance premium rate.

The lawmakers claimed that large domestic hospitals have usually made big profits from differences in pharmaceutical prices set by the DOH's National Health Insurance Bureau and pharmaceutical makers.

Chang said local hospitals usually apply for the bureau's payments for pharmaceuticals given to the patients based on the officially set prices. In reality, he said, those hospitals usually need not pay that much to drug makers.

In his estimate, Chang said, the gap can reach NT$20 billion annually. "Due to the bureau's poor management, the phenomenon has become rampant. It like a 'black hole' in the bureau's operations," he claimed.

Chang said the DOH should first ask the insurance bureau to improve the situation before considering any premium rate hike. He said the DPP legislative caucus has asked DOH Administrator Lee Ming-liang to report on the issue next Monday.

The DOH said earlier this month it plans to raise the health insurance premium rate from current 4.25 percent to 4.91 percent from July 1 this year to help make its ends meet. The DOH said the insurance bureau has incurred heavy deficits due in part to low fees and local governments' failure to pay premiums in accordance with official regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLARS RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose on the Taipei Foreign Exchange market Friday, gaining NT$0.005 to close at NT$35.102.
A total of US$318 million changed hands.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$35.126 and was traded between NT$35.092 and NT$35.126.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PRAISES EXAMPLES OF MENTALLY AND PHYSICALLY CHALLENGED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed admiration Friday to the winners of the "Golden Eagles Prize," which honors the mentally and physically challenged who have distinguished themselves.
Receiving the winners at his office, Chen praised them for rising beyond the limitations of their bodies and achieving marvelous accomplishments.

Chen also said the prize, organized by the Ministry of the Interior for the fifth time this year, is aimed to hold the winners up as examples for other mentally and physically challenged individuals, to inspire them to be self-reliant.

Although the welfare of the mentally and physically challenged is high on the government's agenda, Chen said, the government is "limited in its means of protecting the county's mentally and physically challenged" and he called the private sector to do its part in improving the living standards of the mentally and physically challenged.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH REITERATES WISH FOR PEACEFUL RESOLUTION OF CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Feb. 22 (CNA) (By Liu Cheng-ching and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush told mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji Friday that the United States maintains its "one China" policy and hopes that Taipei and Beijing will resolve their differences peacefully.
Bush added that the U.S. position will remain unchanged.

At a breakfast meeting with Bush, Zhu said that the Taiwan issue is the most sensitive aspect of Beijing-Washington relations. He said that Beijing follows the principles of "peaceful unification" and "one country, two systems."

Later, at a question-and-answer session with students at mainland China's prestigious Tsinghua University, Bush said that the U.S. government hopes for a peaceful settlement to the Taiwan issue, as well as peaceful dialogue between Taipei and Beijing.
He added that the word "peaceful" is intended for both parties and that Taipei and Beijing should not provoke each other.

In answer to a question on whether a theater missile defense system being developed by the United States will cover Taiwan, Bush did not respond directly but said that his nation will "develop defenses to help our friends, our allies and others around the world to protect ourselves from rogue nations that are trying to develop weapons of mass destruction."

In response to another question on whether he remembers Washington's "commitment" to the people of mainland China to abide by the three joint communiques and the "three noes" just as he remembers Washington's commitment to the people of Taiwan, Bush said only that he is anxious that there be a peaceful resolution that requires both parties to come to a solution.
He added that he honors the Taiwan Relations Act, which says that the United States will help Taiwan defend itself if provoked.
Bush departed Beijing later in the day, wrapping up his week-long visit to Japan, South Korea and mainland China. He spent two days in Beijing.
