DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO IMPROVE HELP FOR TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The government will improve communication channels with Taiwan businessmen investing in mainland China to help them keep abreast of the latest developments in Taiwan, an official in charge of mainland policy said Friday.

Fu Don-cheng, director of the Department of Economic Affairs of the cabient-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks after a seminar during which MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen met with the heads of Taiwan businessmen's associations in Beijing, Shanghai, Shenzhen, Tunguan, Kunshan and Fuzhou.

Fu noted that it is estimated that there are at least 50,000 Taiwan businessmen in the mainland and that a communication mechanism will help Taiwan businessmen keep abreast of the new information and new regulations in Taiwan, especially since both sides of Taiwan Strait are now members of the World Trade Organization.

In view of this, Fu said, the government has decided to step up communication with mainland-based Taiwan businessmen via regular meetings with the heads of Taiwan businessmen's associations, as well as establishing a communication mechanism through the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

The seminar was also attended by Minister of Economic Affairs Christine Tsung, Minister of Finance Lee Yung-shan, Central Bank of China Perng Fai-nan, Vice Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development Ho Mei-yueh and SEF Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TRADE WITH TAIWAN DOWN LAST YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 22 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Two-way trade between the United States and Taiwan last year decreased compared with that of the preceding year, according to statistics released by the U.S. Department of Commerce Thursday.
The statistics listed U.S. imports from Taiwan in 2001 at US$33.39 billion, down from 2000's US$40.53 billion, with exports to Taiwan down from US$24.40 billion to US$18.15 billion.
The U.S. trade deficit with Taiwan declined from US$16.10 billion in 2000 to US$15.24 billion last year.

Meanwhile, U.S. imports from mainland China last year totaled US$102.28 billion, up from the previous year's US$100.01 billion, while exports to mainland China rose from US$16.18 billion to US$19.23 billion.
The U.S. suffered a deficit of US$83.04 billion in its trade with mainland China last year, compared with a deficit of US$83.83 billion for 2000.

The statistics show that total imports by the United States last year amounted to US$1,350 billion, down 6.3 percent from 2000, with exports down 5.81 percent to US$1,003.7 billion, resulting a deficit of US$346.3 billion, the first decline since 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE TAIWAN RUNNERS TO PARTICIPATE IN HONG KONG MARATHON

TEXT.P: Five runners from Taiwan will participate in the Eighth Asian Hong Kong International Marathon Sunday, sources with the Chinese Taipei Track and Field Association said Friday.
Chang Chia-tse and Wu Wan-ling of the Taipei Physical Education College and three others -- Tseng Yi-tsai, Hsu Yi-fang and Weng Chu-yi -- will represent Taiwan, the sources said.
Hsu is Taiwan's 10,000-meter record-holder. His best time in the marathon is three hours, two minutes and eight seconds.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BRACES FOR MAINLAND BAN ON EXPORTS OF FISHERMEN (I)

TEXT.P: As Taiwan rapidly returns to its usual hustle and bustle after the Chinese New Year holiday last week, perhaps only in one area -- the fishing industry -- has the hope for a better year yet to be made certain.

Recently at the port of Patoutzu, located in northern Taiwan's Keelung Harbor, Captain Chiu Jung, who had just returned from fishing off Tainan County for two months, was caught off-guard when he learned that mainland China has apparently decided to impose a ban on allowing mainland fishermen to work aboard Taiwanese vessels.
On his 180-ton ship, only Chiu and the chief engineer are from Taiwan, while there are eight mainland fishermen, including first mate Lin Xuezai from Pingtan County in Fujian Province.
The 58-year-old captain knitted his brows when he heard the news, asking: "What are we going to do without the mainland fishermen? All we'll be able to do is moor the boat."

Taiwan fishing boats rely heavily on mainland fishermen, mainly because they share the same language and culture and have similar living habits, in addition to the fact they are cheaper to employ and are more willing to endure hardship than their Taiwan counterparts.

Chiu, who began fishing at a young age, knows best. "Young people from Taiwan couldn't take the hardship. Just not being able to shower for one or two weeks while working at sea would scare them away," he claimed.

For mainland fisherman Lin, who was promoted to first mate a decade ago because of his hard work and diligence, the experience of working with Taiwan fishermen for more than 10 years has been a worthwhile one.

Lin spent 80,000 renminbi (around US$9,732.36) to build a new two-story home two years ago in Pingtang for his wife and three children. He now has savings of more than 20,000 renminbi (around US$2,433.09). It is stories like Lin's that have attracted more fishermen from the mainland to follow suit.

Taiwan shipowners began to hire foreign fishermen to relieve a shortage of local fishermen about two decades ago. But they gradually shifted to mainland fishermen because of the convenience of similar language and culture in the early 1990s after the Republic of China government gave the green light to employing mainland fishermen under special regulations, as the ROC still bans mainland laborers from working in Taiwan.

But the almost decade-long practice, which is deemed beneficial to both sides of the Taiwan Strait, is now in jeopardy, as Beijing's Xinhua News Agency reported recently that six mainland official agencies had annonced the ban on the export of mainland fisherman to Taiwan from Feb. 1, saying that the measure was taken because the "legal rights" of mainland fishermen have been abused and that no effective solutions are in sight.

The measure calls for the suspension of employment of all mainland fishermen working on Taiwanese vessels, their registration with related mainland authorities and their return to the mainland as soon as their contracts with Taiwan ship owners expire.

The ban is expected to have the greatest effect on Taiwan's coastal fishing operations, as contracts for mainland fishermen in this area are usually one year in duration, while contracts for mainland fishermen engaged in deep-sea operations are usually between two and three years in length.

Mainland China allegedly implemented the ban because of unfair treatment received by mainland fishermen here. Mainland fishermen are not allowed to come ashore in Taiwan and have to stay in floating hostels anchored near the island. The hostels are often converted from disused or dilapidated fishing vessels. When Taiwan ships go out fishing, they come alongside these hostels to take on crew. When the ships return, they first drop off the mainland fishermen at the hostels before discharging their catches and anchoring at port.

The practice has long been criticized because the mainlanders are forced to stay in cramped quarters, unable to come ashore like their counterparts from Southeast Asian nations, except during typhoons or other emergencies. (By Lilian Wu) (to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BRACES FOR MAINLAND CHINA BAN ON EXPORTS OF FISHERMEN (II)

TEXT.P: To improve the living conditions of the mainland fishermen, the Department of Fisheries Administration under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) has started the construction of fishermen's hostels in Suao, Keelung, Taichung and Hsinchu since last year, with the one in Suao, northeastern Taiwan, expected to be completed in a few months.

The mainland clamped the ban ostensibly to protect the "legal rights" of the mainland fishermen, citing the cases of clashes, scuffles and even the murder of mainland fishermen by a Taiwan captain in 1999 while working in Taiwan ships, saying that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have yet to establish an effective communication channel, so that problems cannot be resolved in a timely and appropriate manner.

Statistics compiled by the Department of Fisheries Administration under the COA show that Taiwan fishing boat operators employ between 25,000 and 30,000 mainland fishermen each year, while also employing between 5,000 and 10,000 fishermen of other nationalities on average.

Fishery officials estimate that mainland China earns more than US$144 million in foreign exchange annually from this source, based on the calculation that each mainland fisherman gets paid about US$300 a month.

The officials said that currently, the ratio of mainland or foreign fishermen to local fisherman is about three to one, meaning that for every four crew members aboard a Taiwan fishing vessel, only one is from Taiwan.

This ratio demonstrates that Taiwan relies heavily on mainland fishermen to relieve its serious shortage of hands and also helps improve the economy of mainland fishermen, which the officials said is mutually beneficial to both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

What, then, is Beijing really grinding at by imposing a ban in a situation that seems to be mutually beneficial? Some have speculated that the ban is actually a double-dealing strategy to try to win salary raises and fringe benefits for the mainland fishermen.

This speculation seems to be borne out by the visit of a mainland delegation of brokers for mainland fishermen in December to sound out the possibility of raising salaries. The delegation reportedly called on local brokerages and heads of deep-sea fishing companies and told them that if monthly salary could be increased by US$100, then everything would be fine.
However, the request was flatly refused, with local owners saying that they would not budge because they already raised the pay for deep-sea fishermen just last year.

Commenting on the ban, an editorial in the mass-circulation United Daily News said that Fujian Province is geographically near Taiwan and shares the same religious beliefs, while intermarriages between Taiwan fishermen and mainland brides are fairly common and friends and relatives of the mainland brides are often hired to work on Taiwan ships.

The editorial said that it may not be easy for the mainland to implement the ban, saying that the mainland labor force has assimilated into Taiwan's fishing sector "naturally," taking over the fishing and other chores such as gear maintenance.

They also pointed out that as mainland officials cannot even ban its people from sneaking into Taiwan and Japan illegally, they are unlikely to be able to stop its fishermen from working in Taiwan ships.

If the ban is implemented, they said unemployment in Fujian Province will increase, while its foreign exchange revenues will suffer. The ban will not stop the busy traffic of mainland fishermen coming to Taiwan ships, but will only aggravate the working conditions of illegal mainland fishermen, they continued.

They said that the cheap labor available in the mainland, together with the advantages of Taiwan's technology, capital and marketing, is complementary to the fisheries on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, adding that the cross-strait fishery industry has developed to the point where nothing can stop the merging process and that any attempt to drive a wedge between the two sides will only prove futile. (By Lilian Wu) (to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BRACES FOR MAINLAND BAN ON EXPORTS OF FISHERMEN (III)

TEXT.P: Faced with the impact of the ban, fishery officials said that they will diversify the source of fisherman on Taiwan boats by speeding up the process of introducing more foreign fishermen from Southeast Asian countries, such as Vietnam, Indonesia and the Philippines on the one hand, while the Department of Fisheries said it will try to lure local people to go to sea on the other.

Department officials said they will soon unveil a plan to subsidize local fishermen NT$10,000 (US$284.9) a month for six months to work on Taiwan fishing boats. Initially, the incentive project hopes to train 200 local people to work on Taiwan fishing ships.

A local fishermen's group responded by saying that this may only prove to be a short-term solution. Kuo Sheng-wen, president of a Pingtung association to promote fishermen's rights, said that the difficulty in recruiting local fishermen is that they cannot endure the hardships at sea, while the subsidy measure will be prone to fraud and not feasible.

Meanwhile, reports said that there are new cooperation models being set up since the ban, with brokers on both sides of the Taiwan Strait arranging for mainland fishing boats to ferry mainland fishermen to the high seas where they can be hired by Taiwan ships for short-term fishing operations.
Coast Guard Administration officials have reported that a score of mainland fishermen were arrested off the coast of Taitung County earlier this week in just such an operation.

Urging local Shipowners not to act rashly, fishery associations said that this model of "cooperation at sea" is unprecedented and they expressed worry that the mainland fishermen employed in this way will have no protection at all, while resolution of disputes will become even more complex.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA TO SHORTEN SCREENING TIME FOR FOREIGN FISHERMEN APPLICATIONS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) has decided to shorten the screening time for foreign fishermen to work on Taiwan fishing boats by one day following mainland China's recent decision to ban its fisherman from working on Taiwan vessels.

As Taiwan ships rely heavily on mainland fishermen, Beijing's move has caught many ship owners in Taiwan off guard. The ROC government is now trying to assist local companies by encouraging them to find workers from other countries to fill in for those that would have come from mainland China.

The CLA said that according to foreign labor regulations, the introduction of foreign laborers must not come at the expense of local laborers. The regulations further state that before applying for foreign laborers, ship owners should first place ads for three days to recruit people, and after a 14-day recruiting period, they can begin the application process with the relevant government agencies to hire the workers that they have selected.
The screening time for the applications is usually five day, but the CLA has decided to reduce this to four days.
The CLA is also suggesting that the shipping industry could introduce foreign fishermen in groups through the Council of Agriculture or fishery associations to save time.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2.29 PERCENT ECONOMIC GROWTH PREDICTED FOR TAIWAN IN 2002

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy is predicted to grow 2.29 percent this year, the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) announced Friday.
A previous DGBAS economic forecast made in November last year estimated that the gross domestic product would reach 2.23 percent in 2002 after suffering its first-ever decline in 2001.
According to government statistics, the economy contracted by 1.91 percent last year, better than the negative 2.68 percent originally predicted.
DGBAS head Lin Chuan said that private sector investment remains the key to economic growth.

He noted that although the government spent an additional NT$60 billion (US$1.7 billion) in public infrastructure development last year, private sector investments underwent a NT$420 billion (US$12 billion) year-on-year plunge.

For Taiwan's economy to recover, the investment environment would need to be improved so that private investments can return to their previous level and work together with the government's extra public spending to good effect, he added.

According to the DGBAS, because Taiwan's unemployment problems are expected to remain difficult to overcome in the short term, private sector spending will remain restricted, with annual growth in private sector spending likely to rebound slightly this year to 2.58 percent, from last year's 1.37 percent.

The DGBAS noted that major countries have already lowered their interest rates, adopted tax cuts or increased public spending to stimulate the economy, but recovery has been weak despite being stable.
Domestically, the DGBAS continued, the stock market has bottomed out, and the decline in industrial production has been arrested.

Together with a more relaxed currency policy and better-than-expected private sector spending, the economic growth rate for the fourth quarter of 2001 was able to reach negative 1.87 percent, 0.81 percentage points higher than the original prediction of negative 2.68 percent, DGBAS added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROTESTS PLANNED WHEN CLINTON SPEAKS TO PRO-UNIFICATIONISTS IN SYDNEY
DOC.DATELINE: Sydney, Feb. 22 (CNA) (By Chen Wen-he and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwanese in Australia will demonstrate outside the venue of a gathering of international Chinese pro-unification groups when former U.S. President Bill Clinton delivers a speech to the participants, according to an organizer of the protest.

Chen Shou-shung, president of the Australian Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce said Clinton should respect the choice of the people of Taiwan as demonstrated in the elections in the country in December when the party associated with pro-unification won only 3 percent of the vote for legislators.
The results of the election also show that the people of Taiwan do not accept the "one country, two systems" formula prescribed by Beijing for unification with Taiwan, Chen said.

He questioned the relevance of the two Taiwanese representatives at the gathering -- former Legislative Yuan President Liang Su-yung and former Legislative Yuan Secretary-General Kuo Chun-tzu could reflect.
Liang is the chairman of a Taiwan group which promotes the peaceful unification of Mainland China and Taiwan. Kuo is its vice chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF MEETS WITH RETIRED MILITARY GENERALS

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan met with some 30 retired military generals over a lunch Friday during which he expressed the hope that the country will improve in all aspects this year.
He also said that the KMT, which lost its rule of the island to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the March 18, 2000 presidential election, is determined to speed up party reform.
Lien affirmed the contributions of the retired generals to the country's survival and development since the central government retreated to Taiwan from the mainland in 1949.

The generals present at the lunch party are KMT members. They included former Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen, incumbent Veterans Affairs Commission Chairman Yang Te-chih, presidential strategy advisor Hsia Ying-chou and former Chief of the General Staff Chen Shen-ling.
Lien said that the KMT will do its best to win local elections slated for this year, including the mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung.

The KMT plans to have Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, a KMT member, seek re-election, and cooperate with the People First Party to field a candidate to face Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, who is concurrently DPP chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: 9.2 PERCENT OF TAIWANESE SUPPORT `ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS': POLL

TEXT.P: Only 9.2 percent of the respondents to a recent poll conducted by Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said that they support Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula, 69.2 percent opposed and the remaining were indifferent to the idea.

According to the MAC, which routinely polls the population on the issue, this figure was the lowest ever recorded since the Democratic Progressive Party administration took over the reins of government in May 2000.
MAC Vice Chairman John C.C. Deng said that this means there is "no market" for the formula in Taiwan.

Deng said that a resumption of cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue and the peaceful resolution of differences are Taiwan's long-standing positions. He added that Taiwan hopes Beijing will respond to the island's various suggestions positively even as it improves relations with Washington.
According to the MAC, the percentage of respondents who supported "one country, two systems" was 12.2 percent in May 2000, 16.1 percent in March 2001 and 13.3 percent in July 2001.

Meanwhile, according to the latest poll, 82.5 percent of the respondents advocated maintaining the status quo in Taiwan's relations with mainland China at this time, with only 17.9 percent inclined toward immediately declaring independence and 16.8 percent advocating immediate unification with the mainland.

Furthermore, 60.2 percent of the respondents said that they believe Beijing is unfriendly toward the Republic of China government, and 37.9 percent said that they believe Beijing is unfriendly toward the people of Taiwan. The figures were 5.5 percentage points and 10.2 percentage points lower, respectively, than the results from last July's poll.

The telephone poll on Taiwanese adults aged 20 or older took place between Jan. 31 and Feb. 3, with 1,081 effective samples taken and a reliability of 95 percent. The sampling error was plus or minus 2.98 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMER CONFIDENCE INDEX RISES FOR THIRD CONSECUTIVE MONTH

TEXT.P: Taiwan consumer confidence index in February reached 75.95 points, a level equaling that of July, 2000, the Taiwan Research Institute (TRI) announced Friday.

A TRI official said that Taiwan's political situation has gradually stabilized since the new Legislative Yuan was inaugurated Feb. 1, while relations between the Executive Yuan and the Legislative Yuan and the mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung will be two key factors affecting Taiwan's political situation in the future.

He said that the international economic situation has also improved. According to a survey conducted by MasterCard International Group in December, 2001, the Asian consumer confidence index in general was also on rise, especially in mainland China, with an index of 84.8 compared with 46.2 in Taiwan.
All these signs, he went on, indicate that consumer confidence in Taiwan is increasing.

The TRI recommended that the government concentrate its efforts on economic construction and development in the coming ten months in the lead-up to the year-end Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections.
The statistics also show that the stock investors' confidence index has reached a level similar to that prior to the presidential election of March 18, 2000.
The index soared to 97.40 points, or an increase of 0.7 points over the previous month, representing an increase of 23.1 points over the previous year's level, the TRI said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI QUALIFIES FOR FOUR-MAN BOBSLED EVENT AT OLYMPICS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Feb. 21 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: A Chinese Taipei team will take part in the four-man bobsled event Feb. 23 at the Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City after completing a successful qualification run.
According to Olympic regulations, every team must make three trial runs and at least one of them should be complete -- without the bobsled overturning.

The Chinese Taipei team of Chen Chin-shan, Chen Chien-sheng, Chen Chien-li and Lin Jui-ming, overturned in its first and second attempts. On the last day, however, the team completed the 1,300 meter run with an unremarkable time of 49.77 seconds, but it was enough to qualify.

The novelty of Chinese from Taiwan -- where snow is rare -- participating in the event has caught the attention of reporters. The U.S. television network NBC interviewed the team after their successful run.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPANISH PARLIAMENTARIANS TO VISIT TAIWAN FEB. 24

TEXT.P: A five-member Spanish parliamentary mission is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Sunday for a five-day visit, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced Friday.

They are Tomas Burgos Gallego, a member of the Consuming and Sanitary Committee, Lower House; Ramon Moreno Bustos, a member of National Defense Committee; Alejandro Francisco Ballestero de Diego, a member of the Budget Committee; Susana Camarero Benitez, a member of the National Defense Committee, and Agueda Montelongo Gonzalez, a member of the Education, Cultural and Sports Committee.

During their stay in Taipei, they will call on the Legislative Yuan, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, the Government Information Office of the Executive Yuan, the Department of Health, the Council of Cultural Affairs and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
They will also visit the National Palace Museum, the Taipei World Trade Center, the China Youth Corps and Taiwan's opera college before leaving for home Feb. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN STRESSES IMPORTANCE OF STRONG NAVY TO SAILORS

TEXT.P: A powerful navy is a guarantee of the country's security and thereby a solid base for Taiwan's democracy and economic development, President Chen Shui-bian told a group of ROC Navy soldiers Friday in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

Inspecting a navy base in Kaohsiung, the president said sea lanes which link the island of Taiwan to the outside world are a lifeline for the country, and this is all the more relevant as Taiwan is rapidly integrated into the world economy through business globalization and the island's efforts to build itself into an Asia-Pacific business hub.
Calling it the country's "Great Wall of the sea," the president urged the navy to live up to its role as the ultimate foundation of the island's democracy and economy.
Chen gave the speech on the base during a lunch with seamen and their families.
Before the lunch, Chen boarded a warship and a submarine for inspection, and monitored a drill by sailors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO VISIT AUSTRALIA FEB. 28 TO ACCEPT AWARD FOR CITY

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou is scheduled to leave for Australia Thursday to accept the "global information technology outstanding government award" to be conferred by the World Congress of Information Technology on behalf of Taipei City.
The trip will also bring Ma to Melbourne and Perth where he will observe transport facilities, urban renewal programs and sports facilities, including domed stadiums in these cities.
The conferring ceremony will be held in Adelaide where the closing ceremony of the world c congress will be held.

During his stay in Australia, Ma will call on Minister of Commerce and Tourism of the Western Australian State Government Clive Brown, Adelaide Mayor Alfred Huang, Melbourne Mayor John So and Perth Mayor Peter Nattarass.
Ma is expected to return to Taipei March 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DEFENSE MINISTERS INVITED TO U.S.-TAIWAN DEFENSE SUMMIT

TEXT.P: ROC Minister of National Defense Tang Yao-ming said Friday that he had received an invitation to attend a U.S.-Taiwan defense industry summit to be held in Florida March 10-12.
He did not indicate whether he will attend the summit or not.

The summit is being organized by the U.S.-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council. Wire reports said that the discussions will focus on arms sales procedures and Taiwan's defense needs in the years ahead, particularly in the so-called C4I -- command, control, communication, computers and intelligence.
Senior U.S. officials and representatives from the U.S. defense industry, such as Boeing, Lockheed Martin and Raytheon, will be invited to the summit to be held in St. Petersburg, Florida.

Earlier this week, a spokesman for the ROC Ministry of National Defense said that all kinds of meetings or gatherings conducive to peace, security and stability across the Taiwan Strait are appreciated.

The meeting will be of special significance as it is to be held about three weeks after U.S. President George W. Bush reiterated Washington's commitment to the security across the Taiwan Strait during his Asian trip that took him to Japan, South Korea and mainland China.
Tang, who was chief of the general staff before assuming his current post Feb. 1, spoke while accompanying President Chen Shui-bian on an inspection tour of the Tsoying Naval Base.

DOC.HEADLINE: PALAU PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN FEB. 26

TEXT.P: President Tommy E. Remengesau, Jr. of the Republic of Palau, at the head of a 25-member delegation, will arrive in Taipei Feb. 26 for a five-day visit, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said in a news release Friday.
While in Taiwan, Remengesau will meet with ROC President Chen Shui-bian, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien and attend a luncheon hosted by Chien.
Accompanied by President Chen, Remengesau and his entourage will visit the Taipei Municipal Ching Mei Girls' Senior High School on Feb. 27 to attend celebrations of the school's 40th anniversary.
They will watch a performance of the school's honor guard and will plant a tree to commemorate Remengesau's visit.
The group will also tour several ROC economic and cultural establishments before departing on March 2.
Remengesau studied in the United States where he first majored in criminal law and then obtained a master's degree in public administration.
He was elected senator at the age of 28 in 1984, becoming the youngest senator ever in Palau. He was re-elected four years later.
In 1993, Remengesau was elected vice president of Palau, serving concurrently as minister of administration. He won a second term in 1996 and was elected president in 2000.

Remengesau visited the ROC in December 2000 in his capacity as president-elect of Palau and has toured the ROC many times privately. This will be his first state visit to the country since he was elected president.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MINI THREE LINKS' TARGET OF CRITICISM AT SEMINAR (1)

TEXT.P: Kinmen public opinion leaders and local government officials and business executives were critical of the "mini three links" at a symposium Friday, blaming the government's conservative policy which they said has failed to help improve the island's economy.

Speaking at the gathering held by a Control Yuan assessment task force to assess the "mini three links," which have been in effect for just over a year, New Party lawmaker Wu Cheng-tian said that the program has been superficial and was well below high public expectations for economic prosperity because of the conservative mindset of the government.

According to Wu, Kinmen's economy has been hard hit by rising unemployment as a result of the military's streamlining reform. But he added that the limiting measures made by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) have reduced the program so that it is mostly symbolic. The "mini three links" have not substantially benefit the island's economy, which he said used to depend on the large number of troops station there.

Should the government allow people and cargo from Taiwan to freely proceed to mainland China via Kinmen, Wu said, the frontline island would replace Hong Kong as a major transshipment hub of the indirect trade between Taiwan proper and mainland China.

That would also improve Kinmen's economy and help Taiwan businessmen operating in the mainland save money and travel time, because in Xiamen alone, a port city in mainland China's Fujian province opposite Kinmen, there are about 6,600 Taiwan-funded companies, he added.
Now that the central government is strapped with serious financial burdens, Wu said the government should adopt an open-door policy to help Kinmen improve its economy.

On Jan. 1, 2001, the MAC unilaterally announced the establishment of the direct trade and transport links between Taiwan-controlled Kinmen and Matsu islands with Xiamen and Fuzhou ports in Fujian province as a goodwill gesture toward mainland China and as a means of helping revive the economies on the two frontline islands.
But the effect of the so-called "mini three links" has been limited due to the lack of cooperation from the mainland.

Hsu Yu-chao, deputy speaker of the Kinmen County Council, bluntly called the "mini three links" a failure, accusing executive government agencies of not consulting with local public opinion leaders in advance.

Hsu said nearly 10,000 passengers have headed from Kinmen for mainland China over the past year and have spent at least NT$100 million (US$2.85 million) in the process. But only 900 mainland Chinese citizens, mostly elderly people born in Kinmen, have travel to Kinmen with the county government footing the bill, Hsu noted, warning that Kinmen's economy may be dragged down in the long term.

In addition, Hsu claimed that the MAC's rule that Taiwan residents must have their households registered on Kinmen for at least six months before they can directly travel to mainland China is superfluous. The measure has only created a large "ghost population" on Kinmen, while criminal elements and gangsters may sail freely between the two sides. (By Flor Wang) (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MINI THREE LINKS' TARGET OF CRITICISM AT SEMINAR (II)

TEXT.P: Chu Chao-liang, public prosecutor-general of the Kinmen District Prosecutors' Office, said the public is confused and that language used by the government has led them to believe that petty trade on the beaches is legal. He said easing the current rules is the solution to the problem. This, he said, will help introduce legal trading practices.

C. M. Hsu, chairman of the Kinmen Chamber of Commerce, complained that the "mini three links" are like a balloon only for display to foreigners, which has not helped the island a bit. He proposed leaving the door open for imports from mainland China and imposing no customs duties to regulate the trade between the two sides.

Echoing Hsu's view, Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng favored zero customs tariff for mainland Chinese products and advocated developing Kinmen into a cross-Taiwan Strait postal exchange center. He urged the government to adopt an open-door policy to meet public demand.

MAC Vice Chairman John Teng said the council will submit a comprehensive assessment report on the "mini three links" to the Control Yuan by the end of this month after compiling suggestions from all parties. Despite widespread criticism from the public, he praised the program and pointed out that Kinmen and Matsu residents now can travel safely and legally to mainland China under the framework of the links.

C. L. Lin, head of the Control Yuan task force, said that the differing views showed that there is a huge gap between policy and practice. He said his ad hoc group will work out a report based on all the suggestions aired in the meeting to serve as references for the government and seek solutions to the exiting problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S VP OPPOSES TRANSFER OF 8-INCH WAFER PLANTS TO MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Feb. 22 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: ROC Vice President Annette Lu said in Hsinchu Friday that she is opposed to the transfer of eight-inch wafer plants to mainland China.
She made the remarks while inspecting Hsinchu county and city.

Describing the eight-inch wafer plants as the "lifeline of Taiwan's industry," Lu said that she fears transfer of the wafer plants to the mainland might prompt other high-technology sectors to follow.
She suggested that related enterprises ask the Hsinchu county and city governments to oppose allowing operators of eight-inch wafer plants to invest in mainland China.
Earlier this week, Minister of Economic Affairs Christine Tsung said that her ministry will make a decision on the matter by the end of March.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ASKS COUNTRYMEN TO WORK TOGETHER FOR ANOTHER ECONOMIC BOOM

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun urged his countrymen Friday to work together to create another economic boom in Taiwan.

At a New Year's party hosted by people from his hometown in Ilan County, the premier said economic prosperity is high on his agenda, and called on all the people of the nation to work together to strive to make Taiwan's economy peak now that the causes for political restless have been removed after the December elections for lawmakers.
Vowing to do his best to revive the ailing economy, Yu said he wants to leave the island to the next premier in better shape then when he took office.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 23, or the 12th day of the first month of the Year of the Horse according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1743: Meyer Rothschild, a German banker who founded a bank at Frankfurt am Main, is born. His sons, most notably Salomon and Nathan Meyer, established branches of the bank throughout Europe.
1792: Sir Joshua Reynold, British painter and first president of the Royal Academy, dies at the age of 69. He is considered one of the most important figures in the history of English painting.
1836: The siege of the Alamo begins in San Antonio, Texas. The siege ended March 6 with all the Texans killed by Mexican troops.
1848: John Quincy Adams, the sixth president of the United States, who helped formulate the Monroe Doctrine, dies at the age of 81.
1863: British explorers John Speke and J.A. Grant announce that they have "discovered" Lake Victoria to be the source of the Nile.
1898: Emile Zola, the French writer and critic who was a leading proponent of naturalism in fiction, is imprisoned for the publication of his letter "J'accuse," which accused the French government of anti-Semistism and of wrongly imprisoning Captain Alfred Dreyfus.
1905: Paul P. Harris, a lawyer in Chicago, establishes Rotary International. There are now about 24,500 Rotary clubs in 167 countries, with about 1.1 million members.
1906: Johann Hoch is imprisoned in Chicago for murdering six of his 13 wives.
1924: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and the winner of the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize, dies at the age of 68. His administration was marked by World War I and the introduction of prohibition.
1933: Japanese forces occupy Chinese territory north of the Great Wall of China.
1942: Australia, Britain, New Zealand and the United States sign the Master Mutual Aid Agreement.
1942: A Japanese submarine shells an oil refinery near Santa Barbara, California.
1944: Joseph Stalin dissolves the Chechen republic and forces 1 million Chechens into exile, accusing them of collaboration with Nazi Germany.
1945: U.S. Marines plant the Stars and Stripes on Mount Suribachi of Iwo Jima, a strategic island 750 miles from Tokyo, after 74 days of bombardment and four days of a bitter ground battle.
1955: The first meeting of the Southeast Asian Treaty Organization (SEATO) is held in Bangkok, Thailand.
1957: Republic of China Major-General Chiang Wei-kuo weds Helene B. Chiu in Tokyo, Japan.
1958: Taiwan's first Cobalt 60 medical instrument for treating cancer arrives in Keelung from the United States.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with Cameroon.
1969: Chang Chun-li, chairman of the China Democratic Socialist Party, dies in San Francisco at the age of 83.
1970: British Guinea ends its association with Britain and sets up the Republic of Guyana.
1976: The Association of East Asian Relations and Japan's Interchange Association open a two-day economic and trade conference.
1990: Prince Sihanouk returns to Cambodia after 11 years in exile.
1991: The National Unification Council holds its fifth meeting and passes the Guidelines for National Unification, which are now the highest directives governing the ROC's mainland policy. Its long-term goal is to establish a democratic, free and equitably prosperous China.
1991: Thailand's Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhaven is arrested after the armed forces seize power in a bloodless coup.
1995: U.S. President Bill Clinton voices support for a united Canada in a speech to Canada's parliament.
1997: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes an amendment to Article 4 of the February 28 Incident Disposition and Compensation Act, stipulating that February 28, named "Peace Memorial Day," be deemed a national holiday.
2000: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang adopts a proposal that Adolfo Sun should succeed Kuo Kang to become the ROC's ambassador to the Dominican Republic.
2001: The Council of Agriculture (COA) announces that it has designated the United Kingdom as a foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) area in response to the outbreak of the virus there.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "How toweringly high and surpassingly great in moral grandeur was the way by which the ancient Emperors Shun and Yu came to the government of the Empire, and yet they themselves were unconscious of it."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY (Feb. 24)
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 24, or the 13th day of the first month of the Year of the Horse according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1500: Charles V, the Holy Roman emperor and King of Spain as Charles I, who summoned the Diet of Worms and the Council of Trent, is born.
1815: Robert Fulton, the American engineer who developed the first useful submarine and torpedo and invented the steamboat, dies at the age of 50.
1868: Andrew Johnson, the 17th president of the United States, becomes the first president to have impeachment proceedings brought against him by the House of Representatives. He was acquitted by one vote.
1885: Chester Nimitz, American admiral of the Pacific Fleet during World War II, is born. He halted Japanese expansion and ultimately destroyed the Japanese fleet with a strategy based largely on the use of aircraft carriers.
1891: The Ching court pays an indemnity to Russia for the return of Ili Valley in northwest China.
1909: The world's first color movie is shown in England.
1920: The Nazi Party, or the National Socialist German Workers Party, announces its program to set up the Third Reich.
1920: American-born Nancy Astor becomes the first woman to speak in Britain's House of Commons.
1933: The League of Nations votes 40 to one to pass a resolution refusing to recognize "Manchukuo," a puppet regime installed by the Japanese in China. Japan walks out of the international organization after the vote.
1945: U.S. forces liberate Manila from Japanese occupation.
1945: Ahmed Maher Pasha, premier of Egypt, is shot dead in parliament just after declaring war on the Axis powers.
1946: Juan Peron is elected president of Argentina.
1948: The Labor Union of Taiwan Province is established.
1950: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China holds its first meeting in Taipei.
1962: Dr. Hu Shih, the president of Taiwan's Academia Sinica, who proposed that literature be written in the vernacular rather than in the classical style, dies in Taipei at the age of 72.
1966: Ghana's President Kwame Nkrumah is overthrown in an army coup while he is visiting communist China. He was forced into exile in the Republic of Guinea.
1968: U.S. and South Vietnamese troops recapture the old Vietnamese imperial city of Hue after a fierce battle.
1969: A passenger plane of Taiwan's Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes in Kuijen village, Tainan County, killing all 36 people on board.
1972: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with Malta.
1974: Pakistan officially recognizes Bangladesh as an independent nation.
1976: A nine-member economic mission of Japan's Sankei Shimbun newspaper led by Nobutaka Shikanai, president of the newspaper, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1977: U.S. President Jimmy Carter cuts off U.S. aid to Argentina, Uruguay and Ethiopia because of human rights violations.
1978: Construction of the first-phase of the Taiwan Railway Administration's railway electrification project is completed and opened to traffic.
1989: Funeral rites for Japanese Emperor Hirohito, who had reigned since 1926, are held in Tokyo. His son, Akihito, becomes the new emperor.
1990: Malcolm Forbes, American tycoon, escort of Elizabeth Taylor and owner of "Forbes Magazine," dies.
1997: A fire at a Hindu pilgrim encampment in eastern India claims more than 200 lives and injures over 500 people.
2000: Chung Jung-chi, a minister without portfolio and a key member of the Kuomintang's election machine, announces his resignation from public office and also from the party in a "consciousness-raising" move.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I do not now see a man who can love moral worth in man as he loves beauty in woman."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
U.S. OFFICIALS REFUSE TO COMMENT ON VISA FOR ROC DEFENSE MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 22 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department refused to comment Friday on whether it will issue a visa to the Republic of China's defense minister to enable him to attend a bilateral defense industry summit scheduled for March 10-12 in Florida.

A State Department official, who asked not to be named, said that if ROC Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-ming submits a visa application, the department will make a decision on granting him one based on U.S. laws and policy considerations.
The official would not elaborate.
Meanwhile, Tang said in Taipei that he has received an invitation to attend the summit, which is being organized by the U.S.-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council.
Speculation in local reports is that discussions might focus on arms sales procedures and Taiwan's defense needs in the years ahead.
Senior U.S. officials and representatives from such U.S. defense industry leaders as Boeing, Lockheed Martin and Raytheon are also expected to participate in the summit.

The meeting, scheduled to be held in St. Petersburg, Florida, will be especially significant as it will take place barely a month after U.S. President George W. Bush reiterated Washington's security commitments in the Taiwan Strait during his weeklong trip to Japan, South Korea and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET URGED TO IMPROVE COMMUNICATIONS WITH DPP CAUCUS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet should strengthen contacts and communications with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) legislative caucus to prevent rifts within the current governing team, a DPP heavyweight said Saturday.
DPP legislative whip Wang Tuoh made the suggestion after several DPP lawmakers publicly on Friday criticized the Bureau of National Health Insurance's plan to hike premiums from July.

Wang said the Cabinet should learn a lesson from the event. In the future, he said, the Cabinet should consult with the DPP legislative caucus before it makes any major policy adjustments to avoid giving the impression that the ruling team is divided over major policy issues.

The veteran lawmaker said the current communication mechanism between the Cabinet and the DPP legislative caucus should be expanded to include members of the DPP's Central Policy Coordination Commission. "And the team should meet regularly and frequently to facilitate policy consultations and forge intraparty consensus," he added.

At present, Wang himself and Executive Yuan Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan are responsible for communications between the DPP caucus and the Cabinet. The DPP is now the largest party in the Legislative Yuan, controlling 87 seats in the 225-member chamber.

A group of DPP lawmakers, including Lin Chin-hsing, Chang Ching-fang, You Ching, Chen Sheng-hung and Chen Chung-hsin, voiced their strong opposition to the health insurance bureau's plan to raise premium rates for full-time workers from the current level of 4.25 percent of their monthly salary to 4.91 percent by July. If the plan is approved by the Legislature, workers will have to pay between NT$20 and NT$67 more in health fees each month.

The lawmakers said the bureau should do more to root out inefficiency in the nation's healthcare system before coming up with any proposals to hike insurance premiums. They said many factors have contributed to inefficiency in the healthcare system, including unnecessary medical examinations and prescriptions as well as billing fraud.

Lin claimed that it has become a common practice for local hospitals and clinics, including state-run facilities, to report medical expenses that are far higher than the actual amount spent. "The insurance bureau should take immediate steps to stop such practices in order to save medical resources," he added.
Lee Ming-liang, administrator of the Department of Health, which administers the health insurance bureau, will meet with DPP legislative caucus members Monday to discuss the proposed rate hike issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH HAS ABANDONED THREE JOINT COMMUNIQUES WITH BEIJING: ROC VP

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that U.S. President George W. Bush has abandoned the three U.S. joint communiques with mainland China through his actions.

Lu said at a seminar on the future of Taiwan in the wake of the upcoming 30th anniversary of the Shanghai Communique that Bush's "prudent, precise and consistent" statements on the Taiwan issue as well as his refusal to reiterate the three communiques during his just-concluded visit to Beijing and his vocal support of Washington's support for the Taiwan Relations Act on mainland soil are all worthy of respect.
She said she is "glad" that Bush expended effort trying to maintain Taiwan's dignity and security without harming Taiwan's interests.

Lu pointed out that to Beijing's disappointment, Bush stressed during his visit in mainland China his hope for a "peaceful resolution" to the Taiwan issue instead of advocating "peaceful reunification" between Taiwan and mainland China.

The vice president added that if Bush can use his actions to abandon the three communiques, maybe Taiwan can also abandon its domestic disputes on the independence-versus-unification issue and let go of the "burden" of Beijing's "one China" principle.

At the same seminar, an official of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said that the three communiques between Beijing and Washington have already become relatively "empty" words over the years.
SEF Deputy Secretary-General Andes Yen said that Taiwan should consider whether it should next work toward the goal of abolishing the three communiques.
However, he warned that a risk that should be assessed is whether a replacement to the three communiques might be even more damaging to Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Joanne J.L. Chang, a research fellow at Academia Sinica's Institute of European and American Studies, said that the three communiques are a product of the Cold War era.

She said that the United States had previously assumed that making concessions on its Taiwan policy could lead to progress in Taipei-Beijing relations, but events after former U.S. President Bill Clinton announced his "three noes" policy have demonstrated that Beijing's policies toward Taiwan have not changed because of those concessions.
Chang added that Bush's unambiguous statements in support of Taiwan can be expected to lead other nations in a similar change in attitude in favor of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TO PROBE IMPACT ON ITS ECONOMY OF A FREE TRADE PACT WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 22 (CNA) (By James Kuo and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. International Trade Commission (ITC) will launch an investigation into the possible impacts of signing a free trade agreement with Taiwan on the U.S. economy, ITC sources said Friday.
The ITC has begun soliciting views from the U.S. trade and industrial sectors on the signing of such a free trade agreement, the sources said.

The ITC said that it has decided to launch the probe into the impact of a U.S.-Taiwan free trade agreement on the U.S. economy at the request of the Senate's Finance Committee and that a report on the matter will be sent to the committee before Oct. 17 this year.

In a letter to the ITC, the Senate's Finance Committee said that the United States is excluded from some trade agreements signed among the world's major trade nations that are beneficial only to the development of the signatories' economies.
The letter continued that this does harm to U.S. efforts in expanding trade and goes against U.S. interests.
The Finance Committee said that it is aware that Taiwan's successful admission into the World Trade Organization (WTO) will strengthen Taiwan's role in the multilateral trade system.

In its probe, the ITC said it will also make an evaluation on the removal of trade obstacles between the two countries according to trade figures, tariff and non-tariff trade obstacles, as well as bilateral economic interdependency.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO COOPERATE WITH PFP IN KAOHSIUNG ELECTION: KMT LEADER

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng said Saturday that his party will cooperate with the People First Party (PFP) to field a candidate for the mayoral election in Kaohsiung this year.
Lin told reporters that among the most important tasks for his party this year will be the year-end mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung.

Since Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou of the KMT has indicated his intention of seeking re-election, Lin said that the party plans to cooperate with the PFP to find a qualified candidate for the Kaohsiung mayorship.
He said that if the PFP has any good possible candidates for the Kaohsiung mayoral race, the party can discuss this with the KMT.
The two parties were successful last month in cooperating to have the KMT's Wang Jin-pyng and P.K. Chiang elected as president and vice president of the Legislative Yuan, respectively.
This successful instance of cooperation forms a good formula for the two "pan-blue" parties to work together in future elections as well as in the Legislature, Lin said.

In the previous mayoral elections in Taiwan's two largest cities in 1998, the KMT's Ma defeated then Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, while the Democratic Progressive Party's Frank Hsieh ousted then Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Dun-yi of the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEMICONDUCTOR INDUSTRY REPS ATTEND WORLD SEMICONDUCTOR MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Feb. 22 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Representatives of the Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association (TSIA) attended a two-day meeting of the World Semiconductor Council's (WSC) Environment, Safety and Health Task Force in Rome Feb. 21-22.

To promote worldwide cooperation in the semiconductor industry, the WSC was set up in 1997 under the initiative of the Japan Electronics and Information Technology Industries Association, the U.S. Semiconductor Industry Association, the European Electronic Component Manufacturers Association and the Korea Semiconductor Industry Association.
The TSIA was admitted as the fifth member of the international organization at the council's 1998 annual meeting in Fiuggi, Italy.

The agenda at the Rome meeting included improvements to the business environment for the semiconductor industry, environmental protection, international cooperation, as well as the admission of new members, according to Dr. Quincy Lin, senior vice president and chief information officer of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp.

Lin said that participants at the two-day meeting suggested that Taiwan's semiconductor sector continue to be represented by the TSIA and that representatives of mainland China's semiconductor sector should attend the council under the name of China Semiconductor Industry Association, if the semiconductor manufacturers submit a membership application at the annual conference in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLINE SHOPPING MARKET IN TAIWAN CONTINUES TO EXPAND

TEXT.P: Taiwan's online shopping market continued to expand over the past few years, experiencing an average annual growth rate of 124 percent between 1997 and 2001, according to a report earlier this year by the Marketing Information Center (MIC) of the Institute of Information Industry (III).

The survey indicated that Taiwan's online shopping market totaled NT$8.98 billion in value in 2001, up from only NT$360 million in 1997. The market increased to NT$631 million for 1998, and to NT$1.63 billion for 1999.

Although the dot.com business sector as a whole experienced a great setback during the past two years, e-business continued to grow in Taiwan. In 2000, the online shopping market value amounted to NT$3.95 billion, growing 142 percent over the previous year's level, before increasing by 127 percent for a total value of NT$8.98 billion for 2001, according to the survey.

An analysis by MIC showed that in the past year, travel and ticketing agents as well as websites selling computers, communications products, consumer electronic products, cosmetics and books enjoyed good business.

While the average amount spent per person engaged in online shopping was NT$4,242 for the whole year last year, a heavy buyer with an annual income averaging NT$385,000 could spend over NT$17,000 through online shopping.
The MIC estimates that the local e-business market will continue to grow this year, increasing by 76 percent over last year's level.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG TOURISM SECTOR HAS HIGH HOPE UPON LANTERN FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Tourism establishments in Kaohsiung, including hotels, travel agents, and recreational theme parks are offering their best support to the Kaohsiung City Government to sponsor this year's lantern festival, hoping the lively activities will attract more visitors to this port city in southern Taiwan.
An official of the city government said Saturday that hotels, restaurants, vacationing centers, theme parks as well as temples are presenting a great variety of lanterns for exhibition.
He said that the service sector expects that the colorful lantern festival will be able to help pull Kaohsiung's tourism industry out of sluggishness.

Although festivities marking the occasion will be held around the island on and around the 15th day of the first month in lunar calendar, the Tourism Bureau is co-sponsoring the programs in Kaohsiung, which will be inaugurated on Feb. 26 and last until March 3, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED NOT TO OVERLY SIMPLIFY BUSH'S MESSAGE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator John Chang, also a former minister of foreign affairs, said Saturday that the government should not overly simplify the message given by U.S. President George W. Bush during his just-concluded Asia tour.

Speaking at a seminar on the possible impact of Bush's Asia tour, which took him to Japan, South Korea and mainland China, Chang said Bush's clear statement of support for Taiwan during his three-nation visit does not mean any changes in fundamental U.S. policy on the Taiwan Strait issue.

Noting that Bush's Feb. 21-22 mainland China visit was primarily aimed at mending rifts and improving relations with Beijing, Chang said the basic U.S. policy of "one China, cross-strait dialogue, and maintaining the status quo" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait has remained intact.
"Bush's expression might be more straightforward than his predecessors, such as Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton, the basic tone of U.S. policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged," Chang stressed.

During his Asia tour, Bush had on many occasions reaffirmed U.S. commitments to Taiwan, including affirming explicit support for the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) which says America should help Taiwan defend herself if provoked.

On Friday, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien issued a statement praising Bush for his clear support for Taiwan. "This is the first time over the past 20 years or so that an American president has publicly mentioned while visiting mainland China that the United States should abide by the TRA," Chien said after Bush's speech at Tsinghua University in Beijing earlier in the day.

However, Chang reminded senior officials of the current Democratic Progressive Party government that as the United States has not changed its basic principles for handling Taiwan Strait issues, Taiwan should always maintain independence and self-reliance in its engagements with America.

Speaking on the same occasion, National Taiwan University professor Ming Chu-cheng said Taiwan issue was not a main focus of Bush's Asia trip. "Bush mainly intended to seek Asian support for his anti-terrorism and anti-'axis of evil' campaign," he noted.

In his view, Ming said although Bush managed to reach consensus with mainland China on anti-terrorism issue, he failed to come to terms with Beijing learders on many other topics, including the so-called Taiwan issue.
"The future development of Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations needs further observation and scrutiny," Ming added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENT CHIEF DEFENDS DECISION IN INCINERATOR BIDDING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top environmental protection official said Saturday that the entire bidding process for the construction of an incinerator in Ilan County was transparent and legal despite doubts of impropriety raised by an opposition lawmaker.

Hau Lung-bin, head of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA), said that he had to invoke a special clause in the public procurement law to allow the blacklisted Mitsubishi Heavy Industries to submit a tender because failure to do so would have forced the government to negotiate with a single local company over the already-delayed project.

The Japan-based company, which eventually won the bid for the NT$2.2 billion (US$62.7 million) incinerator project, was banned last Dec. 7 for a year by the Public Construction Commission from taking part in any bidding for public projects in Taiwan after refusing to examine and repair a leak in a natural gas storage tank it built for the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp.
Mitsubishi Heavy Industries has since agreed to repair the leak.

Hau said that he made the decision to include Mitsubishi in the bidding in the interest of promoting competition, maintaining the principle of fairness in public procurement and resolving the garbage issue in Ilan.
EPA officials said that Hau's decision saved the country approximately NT$300 million (US$8.5 million) because the local company bidding for the same project insisted on a higher price.

According to the EPA, bidding for the project failed three times prior to Mitsubishi's participation because only one company tendered a bid in each instance. After the third bidding, the EPA tried without success to negotiate with a local company for an acceptable price.

Earlier, opposition People First Party legislator Hsieh Chang-chieh said the special clause of the public procurement law invoked by Hau can only be used by a senior Cabinet official under special circumstances such as those involving patented technology, but other incinerator projects in Taiwan have proven that several local companies are capable of doing the construction work as well.

Hsieh said that Hau's explanation for allowing Mitsubishi Heavy Industries to participate in the bidding without the approval of the Public Construction Commission was "difficult to accept" and appeared to be merely an excuse to open a "backdoor" for the company.
According to the EPA, it had first sought the counsel of the commission but received a response suggesting that the decision should be made by the EPA chief.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDDHA'S PHALANX SARIRA BROUGHT TO TAIPEI FOR EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: The Buddha's phalanx sarira, the only phalanx relic of Sakyamuni Buddha found in the world, was brought to Taipei from Xian, Shaanxi Province, Saturday aboard a chartered Dragonair plane via Hong Kong.

Shortly after its arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, it was escorted to the domed stadium of National Taiwan University in downtown Taipei under tight security for display through Feb. 26.
Tens of thousands of Buddhist followers greeted the phalanx sarira along the streets when the decorated car taking it reached downtown Taipei.
The phalanx sarira had been kept at Xian's Famen Temple for more than 1,000 years without outside knowledge until the collapsed temple was unearthed in 1987.
It was the second time that the Famen Temple has allowed the foreign exhibition of the phalanx sarira. In 1996, it was exhibited in Thailand.

Some 400 Buddhist followers, led by Foguangshan Monastery founder Master Hsing Yun, escorted the phalanx sarira to Taiwan from Xian by two chartered planes. They included Kuomintang Vice Chairman Wu Po-hsiung and former Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao.

Several mainland Chinese religious leaders and officials in charge of religious affairs also came to Taiwan together with the relic which will also be displayed in Sanhsia, Taipei County, Taichung, Nantou County and Kaohsiung before being sent back to the Famen Temple March 31.

Master Hsing Yun said that he believes the exhibition of the phalanx sarira in Taiwan will help purify human hearts, cleanse social morals and bring peace to the Taiwan Strait. He described it as a milestone in cross-strait cultural exchange.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER'S U.S. VISIT HINGES ON VISA ISSUE

TEXT.P: A visit by Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-ming to the United States to attend a U.S.-Taiwan defense industry summit hinges on whether the U.S. government will grant Tang a visa, a Ministry of National Defense (MND) official said Saturday.
The Republic of China's defense head confirmed Friday that he has received an invitation to attend the summit meeting scheduled for March 10-12 in St. Petersburg, Florida.
"Tang would like to attend the meeting, but it remains unclear whether the U.S. government will issue Tang a visa," said the MND official who preferred to remain anonymous.

Since the United States switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979, only one ROC defense minister has managed to set foot on U.S. soil during his term in office, namely Tang's predecessor Wu Shih-wen, who made a transit stop in New York late last year on his way home after a visit to Central America.

Basically, the MND official said, Tang looks forward to attending any international meeting that enables him to explain the ROC's defense policy, promote international defense technology exchanges, and contribute to peace, stability and security in the Taiwan Strait.
According to the official, both the organizers of the meeting and relevant ROC government agencies are talking with U.S. authorities about issues regarding a visa for Tang.

The U.S. State Department has so far declined to comment on whether it will issue Tang a visa. A State Department official said Friday that if Tang files a visa application, the department will handle the issue based on U.S. laws and policy considerations.
If Tang can secure a visa to attend the meeting, political observers said, it would mark a substantial breakthrough in Taiwan-U.S. relations.

Foreign wire service reports said the upcoming defense meeting is being organized by the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council. Major U.S. defense contractors, including Boeing, Lockheed Martin and Raytheon, reportedly will co-sponsored the conference. U.S. State Department and Pentagon officials in charge of Asia-Pacific and Taiwan-related affairs have been invited to address various panel sessions.
Along with Tang, the ROC's Chief of the General Staff Adm. Li Chieh has also been invited to attend the meeting.

Political analysts said the meeting is of great significance as it will take place barely a month after U.S. President George W. Bush reaffirmed Washington's security commitments to Taiwan during his just-concluded Asia tour that took him to Japan, South Korea and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EXPATRIATES IN AUSTRALIA DEMONSTRATE OVER CLINTON'S SPEECH
DOC.DATELINE: Sydney, Australia, Feb. 23 (CNA) (By Chen Wen-he and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: More than 100 Taiwanese expatriates in Australia demonstrated in Sydney Saturday over former U.S. President Bill Clinton giving a speech at a conference promoting the unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The demonstrators converged at the venue of the conference on the promotion of peaceful reunification of Taiwan and mainland China when Clinton was speaking.
The protesters waved banners and posters while chanting slogans -- "Taiwan is not a province of the People's Republic of China" and "Taiwan is an independent sovereign state."
The protesters said Clinton should not have addressed the conference, organized by the Australian Council for the Promotion of Peaceful Reunification of China, a pro-Beijing organization.

Chen Shou-shung, president of the Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce in Australia, which organized the demonstration, said Clinton should respect the choice of the people of Taiwan as demonstrated in last December's legislative elections when a political party known for its pro-unification stance won only 3 percent of the vote.
The results of the elections also showed that the people of Taiwan do not accept the "one country, two systems" formula prescribed by Beijing for cross-strait unification, Chen said.
Clinton was reportedly paid 300,000 Australian dollars (US$153,000) for his 40-minute speech.

A scuffle broke out when conference delegates attempted to speak to the demonstrators, but it was quickly contained. No arrests and no injuries were reported. The demonstration ended peacefully at 1 p.m.
Australia's Channel 9 TV station broadcast footage showing Clinton's speech and Taiwanese protests in its evening news program.

More than 500 Taiwanese expatriates in the Sydney area will attend a dinner Sunday to signify their resolute support for the Republic of China government and strong opposition to Beijing's unification formula.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VP HAILS BUSH'S REFUSAL TO REITERATE '3 COMMUNIQUES'

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that U.S. President George W. Bush has abandoned the three U.S. joint communiques with mainland China through his actions.

Lu said at a seminar on the future of Taiwan in the wake of the upcoming 30th anniversary of the Shanghai Communique that Bush's "prudent, precise and consistent" statements on the Taiwan issue as well as his refusal to reiterate the three communiques during his just-concluded visit to Beijing and his vocal support of Washington's support for the Taiwan Relations Act on mainland soil are all worthy of respect.
She said she is "glad" that Bush expended effort trying to maintain Taiwan's dignity and security without harming Taiwan's interests.

Lu pointed out that to Beijing's disappointment, Bush stressed during his visit in mainland China his hope for a "peaceful resolution" to the Taiwan issue instead of advocating "peaceful reunification" between Taiwan and mainland China.

The vice president added that if Bush can use his actions to abandon the three communiques, maybe Taiwan can also abandon its domestic disputes on the independence-versus-unification issue and let go of the "burden" of Beijing's "one China" principle.

At the same seminar, an official of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said that the three communiques between Beijing and Washington have already become relatively "empty" words over the years.
SEF Deputy Secretary-General Andes Yen said that Taiwan should consider whether it should next work toward the goal of abolishing the three communiques.
However, he warned that a risk that should be assessed is whether a replacement to the three communiques might be even more damaging to Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Joanne J.L. Chang, a research fellow at Academia Sinica's Institute of European and American Studies, said that the three communiques are a product of the Cold War era.

She said that the United States had previously assumed that making concessions on its Taiwan policy could lead to progress in Taipei-Beijing relations, but events after former U.S. President Bill Clinton announced his "three noes" policy have demonstrated that Beijing's policies toward Taiwan have not changed because of those concessions.
Chang added that Bush's unambiguous statements in support of Taiwan can be expected to lead other nations in a similar change in attitude in favor of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SHOULD STRENGTHEN TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT: ROC VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said in Taipei Saturday that the ROC government should urge the United States to strengthen the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).

She made the remarks while speaking at a seminar organized by the National Development Foundation on Taiwan's past and future 30 years after the signing of the Shanghai joint communique between the United States and mainland China.
Lu said that U.S. President George Bush did not hurt Taiwan's interests during his recent visit to mainland China and added that he even moved to protect Taiwan.
She expressed her heartfelt thanks and respects to Bush for his friendly moves, and went on to say that Bush's statements opened a "window of hope" for Taiwan.

Bush openly described Taiwan as a "good friend" before his departure for Beijing and stressed that the U.S. would not only defend the security of itself, but also that of friendly countries, including Taiwan, Lu said.
Regarding cross-Taiwan Strait disputes, she continued to say that Bush wanted to see a "peaceful resolution" rather than a "peaceful reunification."
Lu said that Bush also expressed his hope that nation-wide elections will be held in mainland China some day and stressed that mainland Chinese people have rights to decide their own future.
She asserted that Bush was the first U.S. president who had ever raised the Taiwan Relations Act during an official visit to Beijing.
Lu noted that Bush's remarks regarding the Taiwan issue were "prudent, precise and consistent," fully displaying his respects for Taiwan.
The vice president said that an important mission of Bush's Beijing trip was to promote "peaceful evolution of China."
She said that the ROC government should take positive action to urge the U.S. to beef up and renovate the TRA so as to cope with the new global situation.

Lu said that Taiwan, located on a vital strategic point in the Asia-Pacific area, should continue pursuing the universal value of freedom and democracy while promoting the formation of an "Asia-Pacific democratic alliance" to counter mainland China's conspiracy to isolate Taiwan.

As the Bush administration was reluctant to talk about the three joint communiques signed by the U.S. and mainland China, Lu said that the people in Taiwan should also stop their contention regarding independence and unification.

Lu said that the people should stand firm on Taiwan while extending their views to mainland China and the world fairly, and should strive to develop Taiwan into an "island of the world." She also called on the U.S. government to make equal and parallel treatment toward Beijing and Taipei.
