ITRI TO UNVEIL STANDARDS FOR INFORMATION APPLIANCES
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) is helping to create a set of standards for information appliance design and production to promote Taiwan's leadership in the fast-growing industry, ITRI sources said Monday.

According to the ITRI Computer and Communications Research Laboratories (CCL), these standards will be finalized after a industry-wide meeting in March to be held under the guidance of the National Information Infrastructure Committee, an ad hoc inter-ministerial steering committee that meets monthly to monitor the development of Taiwan's national information infrastructure.

Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih serves as the convener of a standard-formulating committee involving the CCL and various local high-tech companies. The committee has met 12 times in the past three months, determined that smart handheld devices will be the flagship IA products for Taiwan and drafted standards for them.
CCL Director Lin Pao-shu said these standards are urgently needed in the post-PC era because a lack of them will hamper IA's long-term development.

Wang Fu-ching, deputy director of the CCL, said that his lab aims to help Taiwan become the global leader in IA design and manufacturing before 2006. To reach that objective, standards that are in line with international technological trends and an environment favorable to the IA industry are necessary, he added.
The ITRI is a national-level non-profit research organization that develops industrial technologies and transfers them to domestic private enterprises to boost their global competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL FIRM TO MASS PRODUCE TB TEST KITS

TEXT.P: A local pharmaceutical company is planning to produce test kits for tuberculosis this July, with a target of selling 600,000 test kits this year.

At an inauguration party in the Tainan-based Science Industrial Park Monday, a spokesman for Asia GEN Corp. said the firm will "use technology" to develop a series of kits for testing contagious disease and cancer in the future.
The TB test kit is now at the stage of mass production, and the company will target Pacific ring countries such as mainland China, the Philippines, India, and Taiwan, the spokesman said.

He noted that the World Health Organization has estimated that there are about 8 million new TB cases annually and that the company is working toward the goal of selling 2.6 million test kits annually, accounting for 3 percent of the world market and representing annual revenue of NT$500 million (US$14.24 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange market Monday, losing NT$0.012 to close at NT$35.090.
A total of US$239 million changed hands during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$35.105, and was traded between NT$35.080 and US$35.105.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS BACKS DOH HEALTH-INSURANCE PAYMENT SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) legislative caucus said Monday it supports a Department of Health (DOH) plan to revise the National Health Insurance Act to correct flaws in the current insurance premium payment system.

DPP legislative whip Wang Tuoh made the remarks after DOH Director-General Lee Ming-liang delivered a report to the DPP caucus on the agency's plan to improve the financial status of Taiwan's cash-strapped National Health Insurance (NHI) program.
In his report, Lee said the DOH's Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) has drafted a bill revising the health insurance act to make the premium payment system "more reasonable and fair."

Noting that the spirit of the national health insurance program lies in the rich helping the poor, Lee said the current payment system unfairly allows people with high incomes to pay a lower premium rate than those with low incomes in certain cases.

"Worse yet, under the current system, premiums for civil servants are calculated based on only 55 percent of their full-time monthly salary, while premiums for employees in the private sector are a ratio of their full-time salary," Lee noted.
Meanwhile, he said, unemployed people sometimes find themselves paying more in premiums than those with steady jobs under the present payment system.
"It is our primary concern to mend these unfair flaws in the current health-insurance payment system," Lee told members of the DPP legislative caucus.
He further said the DOH has referred the amendment bill to the Cabinet for further review. The bill will then be sent to the Legislative Yuan for deliberation and approval.

"We hope that both DPP and opposition lawmakers will support the revision bill to remove the unfairness in our current payment system," Lee said, adding that the move would enable the BNHI to increase its annual revenues by NT$20 billion (US$571.43 million) to NT$30 billion.
In response, DPP whip Wang said his party caucus will do its utmost to help the amendment bill clear the legislative floor as soon as possible.

Aside from drawing up the amendment bill, the BNHI also proposed a hike in the premium rate from the current 4.25 percent of the monthly salary to 4.91 percent. According to this plan, the rate hike should be implemented from July this year. The plan had drawn strong opposition from some DPP lawmakers, so the DPP caucus thus invited Lee to give a detailed report on the agency's plan.

After listening to Lee's report, Wang said the plan might be shelved, at least for the time being. In addition to removing the three flaws in the current payment system, Wang said, the BNHI should also work out ways to minimize wasteful use of medical resources before proposing any rate hikes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PALAU MISSION SEEKS COOPERATION WITH KAOHSIUNG COUNTY

TEXT.P: An eight-member delegation from the Republic of Palau visited Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing Monday to exchange views on cooperation in agriculture.
The mission was by headed Sabino Anastacio, a member of the Palau House of Representatives.

He said that the mission would also visit Taitung County, which maintains sisterhood relations with Palau, and added that it visited Tainan County because it had heard of the county's outstanding developments in agriculture.
Anastacio noted that Palau's economy is primarily based on fishing and tourism, but went on to say that his country will place more emphasis on agriculture in the future.
He expressed the hope that his country will be able to learn from Tainan County's experience in agricultural development.
Later, members of the delegation attended a seminar hosted by Tainan County Vice Magistrate Kuo Tai-lin.
The visitors exchanged souvenirs with Yang and invited Tainan County to send a mission to visit Palau.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST ASIAN CUP ENDURANCE RACE TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Five nations and regions will send athletes to compete in the first Asian Cup 24-hour endurance race scheduled for this weekend in Taipei.

Kuo Feng-chou, Soochow University professor and vice president of the Chinese Taipei Road Running Association, said the grueling race will be held at the university's main campus with the participation of teams from Japan, South Korea, India, Hong Kong and Taiwan. There will be 20 Taiwan athletes and 16 foreign runners taking part.

Kuo noted that the school held the first 24-hour endurance race on its campus in 2000, which also marked the school's 100th founding anniversary. He said the race has been expanded and renamed as the Asia Cup championship for the first time this year.
Chen Chun-yen, who is the Taiwan record-holder, said that although the first prize is only US$400, the race is a punishing challenge to the limits of human endurance.
The race will start at 10 a.m. March 2 and finish at 9 p.m. March 3, with the award ceremony held immediately after the competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING DISRUPTING OVERSEAS CHINESE LIVES: ROC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Sydney, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By Chen Wen-ho and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Beijing's continued backing of overseas movements promoting the unification of Taiwan and mainland China will only disrupt the tranquility of overseas Chinese communities, which are well aware of how the two political systems compare with each other, a senior Republic of China official said Sunday.

Wu Hsin-shing, vice minister of the ROC Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, said in Sydney, while in transit to New Zealand, that Beijing should not try to introduce the political differences that exist between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait into overseas Chinese communities, which he said "forces them to choose sides."
He said that Beijing's pro-unification work abroad only raises antagonism and does nothing to promote liberalization and democratization in the mainland.

The people of Taiwan hope that the mainland can speed up a "peaceful transformation" to a free and democratic country, Wu said, adding that existing political differences between Taiwan and the mainland will "naturally resolve themselves" once the mainland embraces freedom and democracy.
He also said that the issue of Taiwan seeking independence does not exist, because the Republic of China has in fact been an independent and sovereign nation for 91 years.
The only issue is the race to see whose political system is better and which one respects the rule of law and the people, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY IS ON THE ROAD TO RECOVER: MINISTER HU

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy is on the mend and recovery looks imminent, Minister without Portfolio Hu Sheng-cheng said Monday.
Taiwan still faces many uncertainties, Hu said, including the emergence of mainland China as a rival economic force and Taiwan's heavy reliance on export of high-tech products to the United States.

Hu made the remarks while delivering the keynote speech on Taiwan's economy at a monthly luncheon gathering of the European Council of Commerce and Trade (ECCT), the largest European Trade Organization in Taipei.
"Now the ROC government should make monetary reform and improving the investment climate its priorities," Hu said.

Hu said that he is optimistic because of the positive outlook for domestic and international trade organizations. These include the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, Taiwan Institute of Research, the Academia Sinica and the Cabinet-level Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.
These organizations have revised their original economic growth rate forecast for first quarter of the year, indicating that Taiwan's economy is on the road to recovery, Hu said.

Touching on the financial and monetary reforms being carried out by the government, Hu said that the ratio of overdue loans has been reduced from 7.79 percent in September, last year to 7.48 percent in December, 2001.

Although Taiwan's competitiveness ranked seventh in the world, Taiwan should continue its financial and monetary reforms, diversify its overseas markets and implement the consensuses reached at the Economic Development Advisory Conference held last August, Hu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND PHASE OF CKS AIRPORT CARGO TERMINAL TO BE INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: The second phase of an air cargo terminal at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan will be inaugurated Tuesday, a CKS airport official said Monday.
Airport Director Wang Teh-ho said the terminal is the result of joint investment by the private sector, including Eva Airways Corp., Singapore Airlines and Eva Air Cargo and Warehouse Co., Ltd.
Construction began in September, 2000 and the terminal will be fully operational in June this year, he said.
The Eva Air Cargo and Warehouse Co. Ltd. is a modernized air cargo handling center with capital investment totaling NT$3 billion.

The new terminal will have a handling capacity of 500,000 metric tons of cargo per year when it becomes fully operational. It is expected to handle 138,000 metric tons of cargo this year. Federal Express, Eva Airways and Singapore Airlines will operate in the terminal in the initial stages.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S OUTPUT OF INFORMATION APPLICATION PRODUCTS ON THE RISE
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is becoming a leading manufacturer of information application products based on system-on-a-chip (SOC) technology, a task force under the National Information Infrastructure (NII) Committee said Monday.
The NII is funded by the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) to monitor the development of the country's information infrastructure.
The task force's target is to develop Taiwan into the world's top maker of SOC-based information application products by 2005.
According to NII statistics, Taiwan produced 1.65 million personal digital assistants (PDAs) last year, a 14 percent global market share.
The figure for this year is expected to increase to 3.53 million, accounting for 22 percent of the global market.
In order to cope with the increasing demand, the task force said that a national SOC design center should be established in addition to the present SOC design center operated by the NSC.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIREWORKS FACTORY EXPLOSION KILLS ONE, LEAVES SIX MISSING
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan County, southern Taiwan, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: An illegal firecracker factory in southern Taiwan exploded Monday, killing a child and leaving six adults missing, according to police reports.
The explosion took place in Yenshui, a township in Tainan County that is well-known for its annual Lantern Festival fireworks extravaganza.
The body of a 12-year-old child -- the son of a missing factory worker -- was found at the scene.
Police said that although they could not find the missing workers and owners, body parts were littered throughout the burnt-down factory and in the surrounding fields.
However, according to a conflicting report from Tainan County Deputy Magistrate Tseng Hsu-cheng, five bodies had been found but were awaiting identification.
Within half an hour of receiving calls about the explosion and the ensuing fire, firefighters had brought the flames under control.

This year's "hive cannon" fireworks display -- so called because fireworks shoot out erratically like swarms of bees in all direction from wire cages carried through the streets of the town on palanquins -- will continue as scheduled Tuesday despite the accident, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO `DEVELOP AN ECONOMY WITH LOCAL CHARACTERISTICS'

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun vowed Monday to "develop an economy with local characteristics" to sustain the country's growth in the face of the relentless tide of globalization.

In his first annual report to the legislature on his administration's agenda, the premier said globalization and localization are the two leading factors dictating the country's economic competitiveness.

He said Taiwan cannot maintain its economic development by simply keeping its economic edge of the past, but must find a new dynamic that will help keep its head above water amidst the tide of globalization. This, he said, can be done by "building an economy with local characteristics."
Yu promised to turn the island's cultural diversity and wide geographic differences into valuable economic resources and engines for uninterrupted development.

As to the debt-saddled National Health Insurance program, the premier stopped short of asking for a hike in premiums as demanded by the National Health Insurance Bureau, which manages the program, but he promised to come up with a second-generation insurance program to replace the current one.
He reiterated President Chen Shui-bian's "active opening, effective management" statement as the supreme guidance in the government's economic policy toward mainland China.

Direct trade and transportation links with mainland China will be launched in line with the country's market-opening program according to World Trade Organization rules, Yu said in his report, which he will deliver to the legislature Tuesday.
The report also offers a glimpse into his agenda for other areas, including:

-- strengthening the election and recall systems, pushing for a mechanism for referendum and initiatives to give citizens the power to veto or propose legislative measures and doing away with the election of township heads;
-- contributing to the international crackdown on terrorism, helping to improve the security and peace in the Asia-Pacific region;
-- balancing the government's budget within five to ten years, fairly dividing revenues among governments at various levels; and
-- winning the public's trust in the government by vigorously bearing down on corruption.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSASIA AIRWAYS INAUGURATES ALL-CARGO FLIGHTS TO MACAU

TEXT.P: A Taiwan airliner announced Monday that it is inaugurating all-cargo flights to Macau Tuesday.

A spokesman for TransAsia Airways said that with the rapid growth of cross-Taiwan Strait trade, revenue from its Taiwan-Macau route accounted for 46 percent of the airline's revenue last year, which prompted the decision to inaugurate the all-cargo flights.

The spokesman said the airline estimates that with the inauguration of the new flights, the company's cargo revenue could surge to NT$400 million (US$11.38 million) this year from the NT$250 million (US$7.12 million) generated last year.

TransAsia Airways signed an agreement with a Macau forwarder Monday and said that it is converting its ATR 74-seat passenger planes to 6.5-ton cargo planes that will ply the route with 12 flights per week.

TransAsia Airways Chairman Tony Fan said that the company previously used the bellies of its Airbus A320 and its A321 passenger planes to carry cargo to Macau. The volume of cargo was 5,175 tons in 1999, which had increased 49 percent to 7,687 tons as of 2000, he added.
Although economy was sluggish in 2001, there was still a 13 percent growth on the Taiwan-Macau route, suggesting great potential, he noted.

Fan said that although the ATR cargo plane has limited cargo capability, it is economically efficient and will allow flowers from Kunming, in southwestern mainland China's Yunnan Province, to be sold in Taipei's flower market the morning after shipping, while key parts and components produced in Taiwan's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park can be delivered to Kunshan, Shanghai, and on display in retail outlets the next day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY MISSION LEAVES FOR PRETORIA

TEXT.P: A five-member delegation headed by Taipei City Council Vice Chairman Fei Hung-tai left Monday for Pretoria, the administrative capital of South Africa, to strengthen sisterhood relations between the two cities.

Other members of the delegation are councilwoman Chen Hsiu-hui, Taipei City Government Deputy Secretary-General Liu Pao-kuei, Taipei City Council Deputy Secretary-General Su Cheng-mao and Chen Wen-pin, director of the city council's public affairs department.
Taipei and Pretoria signed their sisterhood pact in October 1983. The delegation will return to Taipei March 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TRAVEL AGENTS' GATHERING HELD IN MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Dalian, China, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By Liu Te-tsang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: It is the fifth such gathering and the first since Taiwan opened its tourism market to mainland Chinese people residing overseas at the beginning of this year.
Participants at the three-day gathering will exchange views on the promotion of cross-strait tourism.

Speaking at the gathering, He Guangwei, director of mainland China's National Tourism Administration, said that since the Republic of China government lifted the restrictions on its citizens visiting the mainland in 1988, the number of tourist arrivals in the mainland from Taiwan had increased to 3.44 million in 2001 from 440,000 in 1988.

As of the end of last year, the total number of tourist arrivals in the mainland from Taiwan had exceeded 23.8 million, He said, adding that the permissible reasons for Taiwan people's trips to the mainland have also been expanded from visiting relatives to travel, business and exchanges in various fields.
Li Qingsong, president of mainland China's Association for the Protection of Travel Quality, said that the two sides began travel agency exchanges five years ago.

He said that the average annual number of Taiwan people traveling abroad is 7 million, half of whom have gone to the mainland, which he said is a sign of the potential for cross-strait travel exchanges.
He expressed hope that travel agency exchanges can strengthen mutual understanding and cooperation on both two sides to provide better travel services.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO CALL FOR PEACEFUL CROSS-STRAIT CO-EXISTENCE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Yu Shyi-kun will call for cooperation and peaceful co-existence between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait when he presents his first administrative report to the Legislative Yuan Tuesday.
Officials from the Executive Yuan said Yu will propose that Taipei and Beijing dispatch personnel on exchange visits to discuss a broad range of matters of mutual concern.

Yu, who was appointed premier by President Chen Shui-bian last month, will stress that Taiwan now stands at a historic turning point, which he will also describe as the starting point of cooperation in an age of challenge.

The new premier will say that Taiwan has over the past year taken concrete steps to promote constructive relations with mainland China, and will add that Taiwan is happy to see Beijing's willingness to take a pragmatic attitude toward the fact that the Democratic Progressive Party has become the ruling party in Taiwan.

Yu will note that Taiwan insists that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should respect and understand each other while seeking ways to resolve political differences, including the interpretation of the process and results of the so-called "1992 consensus."
In his report, the premier will express the hope that both Taipei and Beijing will "cooperate hand in hand" to strive for "peaceful co-existence and co-prosperity."

Regarding U.S. President George Bush's recent trip to Asia, Yu will indicate Taiwan's welcome and thanks for Bush's statement that "the United States will remember its commitment to the people of Taiwan."
He will also point out that Taiwan will be happy to see the upgrading of triangular relations between the U.S., Taiwan and the mainland, the Executive Yuan officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ASKS FOR CLOSER CONSULTATION BETWEEN DPP CAUCUS AND CABINET

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun asked the vice ministers of all the government ministries Monday to meet weekly with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPPs) caucus at the legislature.

The premier was quoted as saying that the weekly meeting will be part of his Cabinet's efforts to take more closer counsel with DPP lawmakers, which will enable his administration to accommodate their concerns in laying down policy.
Yu made the announcement at a DPP caucus meeting, according to DPP party whip Wang Tu.

Wang quoted Yu as encouraging DPP lawmakers to serve as "political ballast" to the legislature by helping to steer the government's legislative measures through the Legislative Yuan, especially the 200-odd pieces of legislation rejected or not adopted by the previous legislature.
Wang said Yu hopes the legislature will substitute negotiations for confrontation, and rational debate for partisan bickering.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 26, or the 15th day of the first month of the Year of the Horse according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1531: An earthquake rocks Portugal, killing more than 20,000 people.
1791: The Bank of England issues the first-ever pound note.
1802: Victor Marie Hugo, the French writer who wrote such novels as "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" and "Les Miserables" and went into exile after Napoleon III seized power in 1851, is born.
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte escapes from exile on the island of Elba.
1901: Chi Hsui and Hsu Cheng-yu, leaders of the "Righteous Harmony Fist" uprising, or the Boxer Rebellion, are publicly beheaded by a court executioner in Peking (Beijing), ending two years of unrest over the presence of foreigners in China.
1906: Angered by an incident in which a French missionary stabbed and injured the magistrate of Nanchang County in Kiangsi Province, Nanchang citizens kill a total of nine English and French missionaries in the county.
1935: Sir Robert Alexander Watson-Watt, a Scottish electronics engineer and inventor, demonstrates for the first time, at Daventry in England, the radar he helped develop.
1936: An army revolt to establish a more nationalistic government fails, but three leading members of the civilian government are killed during the uprising, and Japan's military leaders gain a firm control of the government.
1936: German Chancellor Adolf Hitler opens the first factory for the production of the Volkswagen, literally the "People's Car," in Saxony.
1946: U.S. Secretary of State James Byrnes denies knowledge of a Big Three Agreement authorizing the USSR to remove machinery from Manchuria.
1951: The 22nd Amendment to the United States Constitution is passed, limiting presidents to two four-year terms in office.
1952: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill announces that Britain has developed an atomic bomb and will test it in the Australian desert.
1964: The ROC Air Force receives a number of F-104G jet fighters from the United States under a military aid program.
1970: The Executive Yuan decides to go ahead with construction on the North-South Freeway.
1974: Members of the International Academy of Trial Lawyers arrive for their 1974 conference in Taipei.
1975: The Republic of China and South Africa sign a trade agreement in Taipei.
1976: Spain gives up control of the Spanish Sahara, and the region comes to be called the Western Sahara, which is divided into two parts under the separate control of Morocco and Mauritania, respectively.
1979: Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan is formally opened.
1980: The Ministry of Finance approves the opening of Taipei branches by five European banks: Grindlays Bank (Great Britain), the European Asia Bank (West Germany), the Societe Generale (France), the Banque de Paris et des Pays-Bas (France), and Hollandsche Bank-Unie, N.V. (the Netherlands).
1981: A French super-high-speed train connecting Paris with several cities in France travels at a top speed of 380 kph, a new world record.
1982: An ancient tomb dating back to the Han dynasty (206 B.C.-8 A.D.) is unearthed in Mawangtui, in suburban Changsha City, Hunan Province.
1990: President Lee Teng-hui and El Salvadoran President Alfredo Felix Cristiani Burkard sign a joint communique for closer bilateral cooperation.
1990: Vaclav Havel, Czechoslovakia's new president, announces in Moscow that all Soviet troops will leave his country by July, ending 21 years of armed occupation.
1991: Saddam Hussein orders Iraqi troops to retreat from Kuwait and declares a great victory.
1993: Two mainland Chinese basketball teams arrive in Taiwan to play exhibition matches against local teams, marking the first time in four decades that athletes from Taiwan and the mainland will compete in Taiwan.
1995: Communist China and the United States sign an agreement mandating Chinese respect for copyrights, trademarks and patents.
1995: Barings, the London finance house, collapses after suffering losses run up in Singapore by trader Nick Leeson.
2000: ROC Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho holds a ribbon-cutting ceremony to mark the completion of 49 newly-built brick houses in a village in northern Thailand for Nationalist veterans.
2001: The first kiosk that allows flight passengers to automatically check themselves in is formally inaugurated.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Youth should be respected. How do we know that their future will not be as good as we are now?

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The China Times:
Blast at illegal firecracker factory in Tainan County kills six.
The United Daily News:
Explosion at illegal fireworks factory in Yehshui, Tainan County claims lives of six.
The Liberty Times:

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTRY MULLS OVER REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE NAME CHANGE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Tuesday that it was "too early to say" if the names of its representative offices in countries without diplomatic ties with the ROC will be changed to uniformly replace the word "Taipei" with "Taiwan."

In response to local media reports, MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said that the ministry has no predetermined stance and will continue to evaluate all propositions while taking such factors as current international events, cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the opinions of foreign governments into consideration.
Chang said that the MOFA has not yet approached any foreign governments to consult them on the issue.
Late Monday, she said that if any changes are implemented in the future, the move should not be seen as a form of provocation regarding cross-strait relations.

Chang said that in the event of such an across-the-board name change, the government will "naturally" first seek to use the official name of the Republic of China. If the official name cannot be used, the government will not rule out considering other appropriate names including "Taiwan," she added.
Meanwhile, she clarified that the ministry has not instructed the ROC representative offices in the United States to change their names to include the word "Taiwan."

According to a public opinion poll conducted by the MOFA in August 2000, approximately 50 percent of the respondents said that they prefer the name "Taiwan Representative Office" over "Taipei Representative Office" if "the Republic of China" cannot be used in the name.
In two subsequent polls carried out in July and November 2001, the percentage of respondents in favor of using the name "Taiwan Representative Office" increased to approximately 70 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT GIVES PEP TALK TO POLICE COLLEGE CADETS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that the nation's police forces are responsible for providing a stable social order even as the rest of the country works hard on the economy.
Chen said during an inspection visit to Taiwan Police College that the police have the widest, most frequent and most direct contact with the public.

As such visible representatives of the government, the police should fully cooperate with the administration's new policies to become an effective and diligent law enforcement team free from corruption, he added.

Chen stressed that the police must know and follow the law as well as embrace administrative neutrality. They should stand their ground in the government's fight against organized crime and moneyed influence in politics, he said.
Professional education for the future police force and continued promotion of neighborhood watch programs are both necessary in the face of a new era of challenges, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENTAGON TO SEND STAFF TO TAIWAN IN MARCH TO DISCUSS SUB DEAL DETAILS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) declined to make any comment Tuesday on a report that the United States will present options to Taiwan in the spring for their conventional submarine deal.

The magazine U.S. Defense News reported in its latest issue that U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Peter T.R. Brookes told the weekly in an interview that the Pentagon had received offers from various weaponry manufacturers regarding its plan to sell eight diesel-powered submarines to the Republic of China.

Brookes further said that the Pentagon was studying all the offers presented by prospective defense contractors and that U.S. naval authorities will refer all available options to Taiwan this spring for the island to make a final choice.
The MND would not confirm the report on the grounds that it is the ministry's established policy to refrain from making any comments on its military procurement plans.

Nevertheless, Chief of the General Staff Adm. Li Chieh said earlier this month in an interview with the local news media that U.S. authorities would send staff to Taiwan in March to discuss issues related to Taiwan's submarine procurement plan.
Li said the U.S. government would take full charge of seeking prospective contractors as well as handle submarine construction matters.

"The U.S. government has invited prospective suppliers to present their design and manufacturing blueprints through its official Web site," Li said, adding that Taiwan's state-owned China Shipbuilding Corp. has also expressed its intention of joining in the bidding.

Earlier this month, Li said, U.S. authorities informed the ROC Navy that they had completed an extensive evaluation of options put forth by interested contractors and would send representatives to Taiwan next month to discuss further details with ROC naval authorities.

The Bush administration agreed to sell Taiwan eight conventional submarines last year to help beef up the island's naval defense capabilities in the face of mainland China's mounting military threat. Although the United States has not produced diesel submarines for a long time, it has vowed to make every possible effort to assist Taiwan in acquiring the advanced vessels.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. GOV'T URGED TO KEEP PRESSURE ON BEIJING ON RELIGIOUS FREEDOM

TEXT.P: The U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom on Monday welcomed the U.S. president's speech in Beijing last Friday emphasizing religious freedom and human rights, but strongly urged Washington to keep the pressure on Beijing to stop its crackdown on spiritual and religious groups.

"President George W. Bush told the Chinese people the truth: Religious believers are not a threat to China's public order -- they build civic society," Felice Gaer of the commission's executive committee said.

"It was important that the president's talk was carried live on Chinese television. The Chinese people need to know that America's interest in religious freedom and other human rights is part of who we are as a people, and it's a worldwide concern that China has pledged to respect," Gaer noted.

"We sincerely hope," she added, "that Chinese officials at all levels will take President Bush's words to heart and end their deepening campaign of repression against the Falun Gong, unregistered Protestant and Catholic Christians, Tibetan Buddhists, and Uighur Muslims -- a campaign that has resulted in tens of thousands being sent to detention camps and scores being brutally murdered in official custody."
"As the United States deepens its relationship with Beijing, we strongly urge the U.S. government to keep the pressure on China to stop these atrocious violations," she added.

In a January 31 letter to President Bush, the commission recommended that he "obtain assurances from the Chinese government that you will be given an opportunity to address the Chinese people directly by live, uncensored broadcast in a major speech on fundamental human rights and freedoms, particularly freedom of religion and belief."

The commission also issued recommendations regarding mainland China on Feb. 13 urging the U.S. government to press Beijing to end its crackdown on religious and spiritual groups, to reform its repressive legal framework, to affirm the universality of religious freedom and mainland China's international obligations, and to foster a culture of respect for human rights.

Among its specific recommendations, the commission wrote that the U.S. government "should seek expanded opportunities to speak frankly and directly to the Chinese people to express why the U.S. government, on behalf of the American people, is concerned with violations of internationally recognized human rights, including freedom of religion or belief."

The U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom was created by the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 to give independent recommendations to the executive branch and to Congress on policies to promote international religious freedom.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTRY TO SPONSOR SEMINARS ON TAIWAN'S INDUSTRIAL OUTLOOK

TEXT.P: The Industrial Technology Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will sponsor a series of seminars on Taiwan's industrial potential and opportunities at the Taipei International Convention Center March 18-29, an MOEA official said Tuesday.

The official said that the MOEA formed a think tank and network of industrial information sources in Taiwan, namely Industrial Technology Intelligence Services (ITIS), in 1989 to help domestic industries boost their competitiveness.
ITIS specialists will give analysis on the impact on Taiwan's industries of the island's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) as well as the opportunities and threats that lie ahead.

Topics to be discussed at the 20 seminars will cover macroeconomics, as well as Taiwan's industrial sectors, including the aerospace, automation, biochemistry, chemical, consumer electronics, communications, electrical appliances, food, industrial materials, industrial safety, information technology, measurement instruments, mechanical, metal, optical electronics, semiconductors, shipbuilding, and textiles sectors.
The official said that the MOEA expects to provide prompt and accurate information to the industry. The information will cover new technologies and marketing strategies.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market closed higher Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for March gained seven points to close at 5,529, with 13,586 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April went up 87 points to finish at 5,600, with 58 contracts traded, while June futures gained six points to close at 5,461, with six contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,522 for March, 5,513 for April, 5,455 for June, 5,576 for September and 5,532 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results for March.
TE futures for March gained 0.15 points to finish at 289.65, with 2,554 contract transactions, while TE futures for April lost three points to close at 291, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
TF futures for March went down 5.6 points to finish at 670, with 517 contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER SAYS CONSENSUS NECESSARY TO USE `TAIWAN' TO JOIN U.N.

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday that if the Republic of China is to apply to re-join the United Nations under the name "Taiwan," a national consensus will be necessary.
Yu said at a legislative interpellation session that applying to enter international organizations is a continued goal of the administration.
However, he said that because ROC diplomatic allies in the United Nations are few in number, any attempt to join the United Nations using the official name the Republic of China would be "difficult."
If using the official name proves to be unfeasible, then the government will consider using another name such as "Taiwan" if there is a widespread consensus, he added.

Meanwhile, in response to an opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union lawmaker's proposal to introduce a bill allowing only ROC citizens born in Taiwan to run for president or vice president, Yu said the government does not have this kind of policy and must respect the opinions of the various political parties as well as those of the Legislative Yuan.

Implementing such a measure would have to take into account the domestic situation because of the presence of varying opinions on the issue in society, he said, adding that the government needs half a year to evaluate the proposal.

In regard to reports that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) might give up its controversial party assets, Yu said that he is "glad" to see the KMT display such a constructive attitude. However, he stressed that such party assets should be handled according to the law.
Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan said that related draft bills on the management of party assets have yet to be completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. VISIT NOT TO TOUCH ON ARMS PROCUREMENT: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-ming said Tuesday the focus of his planned visit to the United States in March is to explain the ROC's defense structure and policies.

"During my visit, I have no plans to touch on any issues related to specific arms procurement projects or the possibility of Taiwan joining the U.S. Theater Missile Defense (TMD) system," Tang stressed.

The ROC's first Taiwan-born defense minister made the remarks in response to an inquiry by opposition Taiwan Solidarity Unity (TSU) Legislator Ho Min-hau about the main purposes of Tang's planned visit to the United States in March to attend a Taiwan-U.S. defense industry summit meeting.

Noting that national security is key to social stability, Tang said that as the minister of national defense, he is obligated to help the U.S. government and its private sector understand Taiwan's defense policies and strategies.
Asked whether the upcoming Taiwan-U.S. defense summit would discuss the TMD or any Taiwan arms procurement issues, Tang said none of those issues are on his agenda.
Tang instead said that since Taiwan is always under threat of missile attack from mainland China, the ROC military must be prepared to protect the 23 million people of Taiwan.

He also said that it is a general practice in democratic countries to refrain from publicly discussing any unfinished military development plans. The ROC follows these guidelines, Tang said, adding: "The Ministry of National Defense needs room to protect the interests of our people."
As the U.S.-proposed TMD is still in the experimental stage, Tang said it would be premature to estimate any possible cost for Taiwan should it be asked to join the program.

The U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, the chief organizer of the March 10-12 defense industry summit in St. Petersburg, Florida, has sent an invitation to Tang to attend the conference, but it remains unclear whether the U.S. Department of State will grant Tang a visa.

If Tang manages to secure a U.S. visa, he will be the first ROC defense minister to visit America during his term of office since the two countries terminated diplomatic ties in 1979. The only exception was Tang's predecessor, Wu Shih-wen, who made a transit stop in New York late last year on his way home after a visit to Central America.

Meanwhile, an earlier news report said Tang is also scheduled to visit the United States in August. At Tuesday's legislative session, opposition Kuomintang Legislator John Chang, who once served as the ROC's minister of foreign affairs, said he is almost certain that if Tang had planned to go to the United States in August, the intense media scrutiny ahead of the trip had already scuttled the plan.
Due to Beijing's persistent diplomatic embargo of Taiwan, Chang said, the ROC government must handle all issues relating to foreign affairs with prudence and pragmatism.

"'Do more and speak less should be our government's top working guideline in handling external affairs," Chang said, adding that the premature leaking of Tang's possible August U.S. visit betrayed the current Democratic Progressive Party government's inexperience in dealing with diplomatic affairs.
In Chang's view, he said, even if Tang manages to visit the United States in August, U.S. authorities would very likely downgrade its reception of Tang under pressure from Beijing.
The defense ministry, however, nor any other government agency has ever confirmed the media reports regarding Tang's possible visit to the United States this August.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES CLOSE SLIGHTLY LOWER

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange ended a touch lower Tuesday as wary investors found few buying incentives ahead of the onset of the second quarter, traditionally a slack season for the global information-technology industry, market analysts said.
The weighted price index, the market's key barometer, edged down 10.92 points, or 0.19 percent, to close at 5,499.79 amid volatile trading.

Encouraged by a Wall Street gain, the market opened higher and the weighted index advanced more than 100 points in the first hour of trading. The rally, however, slackened after mid-session as wary investors were reluctant to make new purchases and kept on the sidelines over uncertain market prospects.

The stock index fluctuated between 5,629.68 points and 5,492.94 points during the four-and-half-hour trading session. Market turnover expanded to NT$93.01 billion (US$2.66 billion), with more than 2.83 billion shares changing hands.

Of the eight major stock categories, textile stocks posted a 1.3 percent gain and plastics issues went up 0.3 percent. Electric and electronics remained unchanged. And the other five categories all suffered losses, with cement stocks falling 1.6 percent; foodstuff stocks dropping 1.4 percent; construction issues sliding 1.8 percent, paper stocks declining 0.7 percent and financial issues posting a 0.9 percent loss.
Losers outnumbered gainers 385 to 210, with 94 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXXON-MOBIL NEGOTIATING WITH CPC ON COOPERATION PROJECT

TEXT.P: The international oil giant Exxon-Mobil is negotiating with the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) to use Taiwan's refineries to process its oil, according to CPC Chairman Regis C.W. Chen.

Chen said that the Exxon-Mobil has submitted an application to the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) for a license to import oil products, as the domestic oil products market has been opened to imports starting this year.
The CPC chairman said that international oil companies operating in Taiwan may become competitors as well as partners.

Taking the Exxon-Mobil as an example, Chen said the international oil giant is negotiating with the CPC, hoping the state enterprise's oil refineries can process its products. In the meantime, Exxon-Mobil is also discussing a joint venture project with the Pan Overseas Corp.

After the MOEA's announcement in late December that it would liberalize Taiwan's oil products market, a Pan Overseas spokesman said that the company's newly built oil tanks at Taichung Harbor would be in use early this year and the company will try to win supply contracts from gas stations around the island.

Currently, the CPC is the biggest oil products supplier to domestic gas stations. With around 1,600 gas stations around the island being supplied with CPC oil products, it has a 40 percent market share.

Formosa Petroleum Corp., which grossed NT$130 billion from oil products last year, has contracts with more than 500 domestic gas stations, making it the second-largest supplier in the country. A company spokesman said recently that the company intends to win 50 percent of the market share before the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER GAINING SIGNATURES FOR BILL ON TAIWAN REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The future of Taiwan could one day be in the hands of the people of the island through a referendum on the issue and one lawmaker is trying to lay the foundation for such a vote to take place.

Lawmaker Tsai Trong-rong of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday that he has gained the endorsement of 114 of his colleagues at the 225-seat Legislative Yuan advocating the passage of the "public referendum bill" in the current session of the legislature, which opened Feb. 1.

Tsai said the right to determine the future of a nation by the people through a fair and open vote is the mandate of a democratic nation and the widespread support from lawmakers with different political affiliations is a reflection of public opinion. He said that he will continue seeking non-partisan backing from all lawmakers and hopes the bill can be passed into law this session after being put into the legislature's agenda.
According to Tsai, the 114 lawmakers included members from the DPP, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, the Kuomintang, the People First Party and independent legislators.

Tsai said that this is the right direction for the country to follow in its further democratization, adding that it was unlikely that the issue would spark disagreements between the pro-unification "pan-blue alliance" and the pro-independence "pan-green" forces.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO CHAIR INAUGURATION OF RESTRUCTURED DEFENSE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will preside over the inaugural ceremony for the restructured Ministry of National Defense (MND) Friday, a senior official said Tuesday.

MND Administrative Deputy Minister Vice Adm. Kao Yang told a news conference that the MND has completed planning and preparatory work for the restructuring in line with the Ministry of National Defense Organization Law and the Statute on Organization of the General Staff Headquarters (GSH), both of which will take effect Friday.

According to the two new acts, the GSH will come under the MND jurisdiction to materialize the government's goal of integrating military command and administration. In the past, no clear laws regulate the MND and GSH structures and their relations and respective functions.

"The ultimate goals of implementing the two new laws include 'nationalizing' the armed forces, having the military led by civilians and integrating military command and administration," Kao explained.
Under the two new laws, the GSH will serve as the defense minister's staff agency regarding military command as well as the command unit of combined services operations.

The new laws also authorize the MND to set up a bureau to take charge of procurement or acquisition of all weaponry systems and military equipment. But the Legislative Yuan has yet to complete legislation of a law regulating the bureau's organization. "The new bureau is not expected to become fully operational until Feb. 1, 2003," Kao said.

Speaking on the same occasion, military spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said the MND restructuring is the ROC's yet another major military reform step following the first-phase troops reduction plan.
"The restructuring would facilitate upgrading of professionalism, efficiency, transparency and accountability in our national defense system," Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDDHA'S FINGER RELIC MOVED TO SANHSIA TEMPLE FOR EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: The Buddha's finger relic, which was brought to Taipei for exhibition from Xian, mainland China Feb. 23, was moved to the Chinguangming Temple in Sanhsia, Taipei County, Tuesday for exhibition until March 3.
The four-day exhibition at the domed stadium at National Taiwan University (NTU) in downtown Taipei attracted some 300,000 visitors, according to organizers.
The finger relic, apparently the only one left by the Buddha some 2,600 years ago, was unearthed in 1987 when researchers excavated a cell under the half-collapsed Famen Temple of Xian City.
The cell had been sealed for more than 1,110 years since Emperor Hsi Tsung of the Tang dynasty.
The relic was brought to Taipei with the consent of the mainland Chinese authorities. Some 400 Buddhist followers escorted it to Taipei via Hong Kong aboard two chartered Dragonair planes.
Master Hsing Yun of the Kaohsiung-based Foguangshan Monastery, expressed the hope that the exhibition of the Buddha's relic in Taiwan will bring peace and prosperity across the Taiwan Strait.
Before the finger relic was moved to the Chinguangming Temple, a solemn Buddhist ceremony was held at the NTU domed stadium with Master Hsing Yun presiding.

The finger relic will also be exhibited at the Foguangshan Monastery in Kaohsiung March 3-14, in Taichung March 15-17, in Nantou County March 17-26 and again at the Foguangshan Monastery March 26-31. It will be returned to Xian March 31.

A group of mainland Chinese monks and officials in charge of religious affairs came to Taiwan along with the relic. They visited the Dharma Drum Monastery in suburban Taipei Monday and the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Association in Hualien Tuesday.
They will continue visiting other leading Buddhist establishments in Taiwan, including Foguangshan in Kaohsiung and Chungtai Temple in Nantou, before leaving Taiwan March 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DECLINES SLIGHTLY IN TAIPEI FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) (By Victor Lai) (By Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA): The U.S. dollar declined slightly against New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange market Tuesday, losing NT$0.02 to close at NT$35.088.
A total of US$303 million changed hands during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$35.061, and was traded between NT$35.061 and NT$35.105.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF FOREIGN LABORERS DOWN IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: There were 303,567 foreign workers in Taiwan as of the end of January, down 1,038 from December of last year, according to the latest statistics released by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).

The CLA said the government has adopted measures to reduce the number of foreign workers in Taiwan and those working in the construction and manufacturing sectors have dropped noticeably; however, the number of foreign maids and caregivers has continued to grow.

In the construction sector, 28,521 alien workers were employed in government public works projects last month, down 1,098 from December, while the number in private-sector construction projects fell by 1,044 to 2,358, according to the tallies.

In the manufacturing sector, there were 50,250 foreign laborers employed in major investment projects in January, down 269 from the previous month. But the number of foreign caregivers and maids increased by 955 at the same time.

The CLA forecast that the number of foreign fishermen working for Taiwan fishing vessels may slightly increase in the near future after mainland China recently banned its seamen from working on Taiwan ships. Currently, there are more than 1,000 foreign fishermen working for Taiwan-based fishing boats.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SPEAKS OF EXPECTATIONS FOR TAIWAN IN FIRST OFFICIAL REPORT

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun outlined the direction of his government Tuesday as he spoke of his ideals on a new political environment, a new economy, a new society and the cultural identify that is Taiwan.
Yu made the remarks when he gave his first administrative report in the legislature after taking office as premier this month.

Yu also expressed the hope that the executive and legislative branches could communicate and work out their differences in a rational way, quoting the words by the late U.S. President John F. Kennedy: "Our problems are man-made; therefore, they may be solved by man."

The premier said that he hopes to "replace luxury with thrift, extravagance with modesty" in his Cabinet, and government reforms will be his top priority. He said that several such key programs will include a revised draft law on the organization of the Executive Yuan, the adjustment of the timing of various elections to reduce their numbers, and the privatization of state-owned enterprises.

On the economy, Yu also said that bills related to the consensus reached in a national economic conference last August will be sent to the legislature as soon as possible. After the bills clear the legislature, he said, the nation should be better tuned for future challenges.

He also mentioned four core industries: semi-conductor related, LCD manufacture, biotechnology and digital related, saying that the government is confident that the production value of the semi-conductor and LCD-related industries will hit NT$1 trillion (US$28.49 billion) in a few years, while the production value of the biotechnology and digital industries will reach NT$250 billion (US$7.12 billion) and NT$300 billion (US$8.54 billion) within six years, respectively.

Yu also envision a society based on cooperation between men and women, rich and poor, various parties and ethic groups, saying that the government will build a "nuclear-free" land and a sound social security system, including pensions for the old, welfare for the jobless as well as a system of support for women and children in need..

On the culture that makes Taiwan special, he promoted the ideals of humanistic values and life-long learning, stressing that a high-quality living environment is crucial to meet the challenges of being a member of the global neighborhood.
On cross-strait relations, Yu said he was happy to see that mainland China is more willing to deal pragmatically with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

He said that to promote positive exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the government has continued to extend olive branches over the past months, and it is happy to see a recent softened tone by Beijing, showing that it is facing the fact that the DPP is the ruling party instead of shunning it because of its past advocacy of independence for the island.

The premier again urged both sides to work for the mutually beneficial aims of peace and cooperation. He suggested that both sides send officials to exchange views on matters of mutual concern, which should give some impetus for the renewal of stalled cross-strait talks.

The premier stressed that with both sides joining the World Trade Organization and facing global competition, Taiwan has consistently advocated cross-strait understanding and respect. In this way, he said, there is a chance to solve bilateral disputes using the process and interpretation of the result of the 1992 talks, which paved the way for the first high-level discussions the following year after more than five decades of deadlock across the Strait.

On Beijing's successful bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games and its determination to upgrade its national image through the Games, Yu said that Taiwan will undertake a six-year national construction project, hoping that the world will see the economic prosperity of the nation that enjoys a pluralistic society that live in tolerance of others as the world will gradually turn its attention to Asia in the run-up to the 2008 summer Games, Yu said.

On United States' President George W. Bush's just-concluded Asian trip, and his remarks that the United States will remember its commitment to the people of Taiwan, Yu expressed his appreciation, adding that Taiwan will make positive contributions to peace in the Taiwan Strait and add to regional prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRIME UP IN 2001 AS PERCENTAGE OF CASES SOLVED BY POLICE DROPS

TEXT.P: Rising unemployment and a flagging economy may be reasons for the increase in crime in 2001 over the year before and the news gets worse: police are solving fewer cases, according to information released recently by government sources.
Criminal cases reported to police last year hit 491,245, a 12 percent rise over 2000, statistics released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics show.

According to the tallies, an average of 2,199 criminal cases were committed for every 100,000 people last year, an increase of 222 from 2000. Of the total criminal cases reported to the police, 55.3 percent were solved last year, down 3.9 percent from 2000. The 2001 ratio of violent criminal cases solved dropped 5.9 percent from a year ago, while the number of solved burglaries fell 4.4 percent.
In terms of crimes, there were 338,423 burglaries last year, accounting for the most cases at 68.9 percent. The ratio was up 10.7 percent from 2000, the second year in a row that the rate had risen.

Meanwhile, there were 14,402 violent criminal acts in 2001, up 39.7 percent from 2000. However, only 60.4 percent of these crimes were solved, down 5.9 percent year-on-year. The number of robberies also increased significantly -- 65.6 percent -- to 7,830, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO REVISE LAW TO ALLOW IMPORTS OF MAINLAND BOOKS

TEXT.P: A group of opposition People First Party (PFP) legislators urged the government Tuesday to revise current laws to allow for the import of mainland Chinese publications, particularly academic books.

The lawmakers, including Pang Chien-kuo, Chin Hui-chu and Lee Ching-hua, made the call at a news conference after a number of mainland publications imported by Taipei-based Ask Ford Book Store for exhibition at the just-concluded Taipei international book fair were withheld by Taiwan customs.
Under the existing regulations governing relations between the people on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, mainland publications cannot enter Taiwan without prior government approval.
Chin said the restriction has become outdated in the wake of Taiwan's and mainland China's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

"The government should amend the law to pave the way for the legal import of mainland Chinese publications, especially academic books, to boost cross-strait cultural and academic exchanges," Chin urged. "The government need only make some exceptions under the principle of free imports."
Pang claimed that the current mainland book import ban no longer meets actual demands and has become an obstacle to the development of knowledge-based economy.
Despite the ban, Pang added, many mainland academic books have long found their way into Taiwan.
"The government should not continue turning a blind eye to the phenomenon and should instead take steps to formally legalize imports of mainland Chinese publications," he said.
Pang said the Government Information Office should be authorized to draft a package of regulations to govern imports of mainland publications, films, radio and television programs.
Pang said he and his PFP colleagues have drafted a revision to the current statute governing cross-strait civilian exchanges to allow for the free import of mainland publications.
"The bill has received the endorsement of 16 lawmakers from different political parties and we'll continue seeking support from as many other legislators as possible," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXCHANGE FIREWORKS NOT GUNFIRE SAYS KINMEN MAGISTRATE

TEXT.P: "Let's exchange fireworks, not gunfire across the Taiwan Strait," Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng proclaimed Tuesday as he officiated at a ceremony featuring simultaneous displays of fireworks on Kinmen and in the mainland Chinese port city of Xiamen.

People from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait for the first time jointly observed the annual Lantern Festival by setting off fireworks simultaneously on either side of the narrow stretch of water separating the island of Kinmen from Xiamen.
The idea for the displays was initiated by the Xiamen city government and received enthusiastically by Lee.

The Xiamen officials originally proposed that the two places set off fireworks simultaneously on the eve of the Lunar New Year, which fell on Feb. 11, but their Kinmen counterparts suggested instead that the event be postponed until the Lantern Festival in order to allow plenty of time for the requisite arrangements to be made.
Some 1,500 fireworks were set off on Kinmen in the two-hour display, while about 4,000 fireworks were sent up in Xiamen.

In addition to the fireworks displays, the Kinmen county government also sponsored a lantern exhibition in Kinmen and a traditional Chinese puppet show performed by the troupe of mainland classic puppet master Huang Yi-chueh, according to Kinmen officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KEELUNG MAYOR ANNOUNCES BID FOR DPP CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: Former Keelung Mayor Lee Chin-yung announced Tuesday his plan to run for the chairmanship of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Praising the contribution made by incumbent DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh, Lee said he is willing to promote the traditional values treasured by the DPP -- justice, morality and vision -- in his participation in the race for the party's top post.
The former Keelung mayor lost his re-election bid to the Kuomintang's Hsu Tsai-li last December.

Lee also called on members of the ruling party to vote for a service-oriented new leader and to step up their efforts to cultivate a political elite in order to maintain the party's competitiveness in Taiwan's political arena.
In response to a reporter's question as to whether President Chen Shui-bian is aware of his bid to run, Lee said he has written to the president to inform him of his decision.

Lee said he does not expect a "blessing" from the president and added that he strongly believes that the president will remain neutral on matters related to party affairs and personnel. Chen and Lee belong to the same faction within the DPP.

Lee added that any new head of the DPP, as long as he is elected through democratic process by party members, will enjoy full backing from the party. He said he will continue to seek support from all the DPP's factions.
Meanwhile, Yao Chia-wen, a senior advisor to the president, also declared his bid to take part in the race for the DPP's chairmanship.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN THANKS BELIZE FOR LONG-TERM SUPPORT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian offered his appreciation to Belize Tuesday for the Central American nation's long-term support for the Republic of China in the international community.

Belize has demonstrated firm and steady support for the ROC's bid to rejoin the United Nations and take part in activities of other international organizations, Chen said when he met with visiting Belize Prime Minister Said W. Musa, who arrived in Taipei late Monday for a four-day state visit.

Chen lauded Belize for its continuous development and progress over the past decade. Bilateral exchanges between Taiwan and Belize have become even more solid and frequent since Musa assumed office, Chen added.

Under Musa's capable leadership, the People's United Party (PUP), of which Musa is the chairman, won a landslide victory in 1998 parliamentary elections, Chen noted, adding that the party will be given a new overwhelming mandate by the Belize people in elections slated for next year.
Chen also expressed his willingness to visit Belize. In return, Musa extended a personal invitation, saying that he hopes Chen will visit Belize this year, and the earlier the better.

Musa said he called on Chen in his capacity not only as the Belizean prime minister, but also as chairman of the Organization of Eastern Caribbean States, which met for a leadership summit last month.

During the summit, according to Musa, subjects concerning economics and environmental protection, as well as anti-terrorism, were mooted and the Eastern Caribbean political leaders resolved that small countries like those the group comprises should cooperate among themselves to overcome the economic difficulties they face.

Musa expressed gratitude to Chen for the aid that Taiwan has provided Belize over the years and said that Belize will continue to support Taiwan in its efforts to join the UN and other international organizations.
Earlier in the day, Musa met with Vice President Annette Lu, also at the Presidential Office, for a brief meeting.

During the meeting, Lu told Musa that she has been encouraging Taiwan businesses to relocate some of their manufacturing operations to Taiwan's allies in Central and South America in an attempt to mitigate the adverse impact that Taiwan is sustaining in the wake of the island's entry to the World Trade Organization at the beginning of this year.

In response to Lu's ideas, Musa said the Belizean government has long adopted a hands-off policy toward foreign investment and is particularly welcoming to Taiwan businesses wishing to transfer their capital and production know-how to Belize.
Musa said Lu's proposal is not only feasible, but also a "win-win" approach for both Taiwan and Belize.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: The party caucus of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) was inaugurated Tuesday with its party whip claiming that the fourth-largest party in Taiwan will not be a "subordinate party" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, Legislative Vice President P.K. Chiang, Premier Yu Shyi-kun and Vice Premier Lin Hsin-yi, as well as officials from the ruling and opposition parties, attended the inauguration tea party held in the legislature.
TSU whip Hsu Teng-kung said that although the TSU is "not subordinate" to the ruling party , it will rally behind the party if its proposals are beneficial to the nation.

DPP whip Ke Chien-ming noted that the DPP and the TSU fought hand-in-hand in the legislative presidential and vice presidential battle, as well as in the review of the allocation law regarding government revenues and expenditure, and said there could be more cooperation on bills and policies.
The TSU, founded last August by former Minister of the Interior Huang Tsu-wen, took 13 seats in the 225-seat legislature in last December's election.

Former President Lee Teng-hui, the "spiritual leader" of the TSU, said last year that he would form a party to help the then-minority government form a majority for political stability, which is why critics have questioned if the TSU party line is merged with that of the DPP.

TSU Chairman Huang said that in order to implement its goals to stabilize politics, stimulate the economy, cement democracy and strengthen Taiwan, the TSU had proposed a motion to halve the number of legislative seats and hoped that it would get cross-party support.
Premier Yu said that although the TSU is not a large party, interpellations by TSU legislators Liao Ben-yen and He Min-hao that day were like "shock training" for him.
He expressed the hope that the TSU will show "mercy" in dealing with Executive Yuan officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-AIR FORCE COMMANDER-IN-CHIEF TO BECOME VICE DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has approved the appointment of Gen. Chen Chao-min as one of two vice ministers of national defense, effective March 1, the day two new defense laws are put into force, Kao Yang, the deputy chief of staff for administration under the Ministry of National Defense, said Tuesday.
Chen will serve as a vice defense minister on active duty, Kao said, adding that the choice of the other vice defense minister, who will be a civilian, has not yet been finalized.
Chen has served as vice commander-in-chief and commander-in-chief of the Republic of China Air Force. He is now a military adviser to the president.

The appointment of two vice defense ministers is based on the National Defense Law and the Organization Law of the Ministry of National Defense, which were promulgated by the president in January 2000 and will be formally put into force in March, Kao said.

The implementation of the new laws will see the consolidation of the military command system and the military administrative system, which are presently chaired by the chief of the general staff and the defense minister, respectively.
The new laws also provide that the president can give orders directly to the defense minister, who in turn can instruct the chief of the general staff to execute orders.

At present, the chief of the general staff acts as the chief of staff to the president for operational matters in the military command system and serves as the chief of staff to the minister of national defense in the military administrative system.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RENEWS CALLS FOR NORMALIZATION OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that normalization of relations is the road the two sides of the Taiwan Strait must take and that the process could start with normalization of economic ties.

In a teleconference address to Asian studies professors and graduate students at Harvard University and several other U.S. institutes of higher learning, Chen said his administration is willing to send representatives to mainland China to exchange views on a range of issues that concern both sides.

Those issues can include normalization of cross-strait economic and trade ties, investment protection agreements, the "three mini-links" and the controversies surrounding the interpretations of the process and results of the 1992 talks between the two sides, Chen said.
"If China wishes to send representatives here first," Chen went on, "we will warmly welcome them and make all necessary arrangements."
Chen said he believes that only through dialogue and contact can the two sides avoid suspicion and misjudgments and resolve differences.
"Therefore, I urge that there should be `more economics, less politics; more contact, less misunderstanding; and more trust, less suppression' between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait," Chen said.
He further said the accession of Taiwan and mainland China to the World Trade Organization (WTO) has opened up an ideal platform for cross-strait dialogue.

Nevertheless, he went on, the WTO is not the only stage upon which the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can talk. He said that as long as the top leaders of the two sides have willingness, sincerity and creativity, they can talk on any topics of mutual interest under the principles of "democracy, parity, peace and no preconditions."

The teleconference was organized by the Fairbank Center for East Asian Research, Harvard University. In addition to delivering a speech on the Republic of China's political situation, ROC-U.S. relations and cross-strait ties, Chen also took questions from the 20-plus American scholars and graduate students present.

Responding to a question about his possible response if U.S. President George W. Bush were to offer military and financial aid to assist Taiwan in seeking independence, Chen said the ROC government is fully aware that U.S. policy toward Taiwan has long been steadfast and consistent and will not be subject to any fundamental changes simply because of the change of ruling party.

Chen further said the ROC government also understands that there are critical differences between America's "one China" policy -- which calls for peaceful resolution of cross-strait issues -- and Beijing's "one China" policy -- which stresses peaceful unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

As the ROC's popularly elected president, Chen said he is obligated to safeguard national sovereignty, dignity and security in accordance with the nation's Constitution and to pursue the common well-being of all ROC citizens.

Noting that respecting people's free choice is a norm of democratic countries, Chen said he is convinced that the U.S. government and people would certainly respect the final decision of the people of Taiwan on the island's future.

Asked whether Taiwan's recent decision to add the words "Issued in Taiwan" to the cover of the ROC passport is a gradual move toward independence, Chen said the measure has nothing to do with promoting Taiwan independence.
The addition is mainly designed to make the ROC passport more distinguishable from the passports issued by the People's Republic of China (PRC), mainland China's official title, Chen explained.
While traveling abroad, Chen said, many ROC nationals have suffered inconveniences and humiliation at the hands of foreign immigration officials because they were mistaken for PRC citizens.

"As a responsible democratic government, we can't overlook complaints from our people," Chen said, adding the addition of the words "Issued in Taiwan" on the passport cover just depicts the facts and has nothing to do with independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER RENEWS CALL FOR CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGE OF OFFICIAL VISITS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun called Tuesday for Taiwan and mainland China to exchange officials to discuss matters of mutual concern, which should give some impetus to the renewal of stalled cross-Taiwan Strait talks.

In order to implement the exchanges, Yu said, the two sides should first talk about the issues of who, where, when and how and make certain that the visits are conducted according to the principles of equality and goodwill.
Yu said during a legislative interpellation session that he has no opinion about the level of the officials who should be allowed to visit the other side.

Meanwhile, the premier defended the Executive Yuan's recent approval of an amendment to the Statutes Governing Relations Across the Taiwan Strait that formally excludes Outer Mongolia from the Republic of China's maps of the "Mainland China Area."

The Executive Yuan approved the amendment, proposed by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Jan. 31, agreeing that the revised ROC-defined "Mainland China Area" indicates "the area under the control of the mainland Chinese authorities," instead of "the area under the control of the mainland Chinese authorities and Outer Mongolia."

However, some legislators said the amendment is tantamount to Taiwan's recognition of Outer Mongolia as an independent nation and a move that runs counter to the ROC Constitution, which claims Outer Mongolia as ROC territory.
Yu said removing Outer Mongolia from the map and definition of the "Mainland China Area" does not involve the issue of whether Taiwan recognizes Outer Mongolia or not.
The initiative was only designed for the convenience of Taiwan exchanges with Outer Mongolia, Yu noted.

Answering questions on the issue, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen stressed that related stipulations in the ROC Constitution remain unchanged and will not be altered as a result of the approval of the amendment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO SWEEPING REFORMS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that consolidating Taiwan's democracy will be his administration's next goal.

"In an effort to advance Taiwan's politics, economy and society, my administration's primary work is to actively promote government re-structuring," Chen said in a teleconference speech to 20-plus professors and graduate students from several noted U.S. universities, including Harvard University.

Chen said his administration will do its utmost to "streamline government's structure, improve administrative efficiency and enhance its ability to handle international political and economic crises in order to establish a small, beautiful and highly capable government."

Noting that last December's legislative election was by nature a vote of confidence by the people of Taiwan for the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government and himself, /chen said the increased number of votes and seats has made the DPP the largest party in the Legislature.
"It represents the public endorsement and willingness to give the DPP a chance to govern the country," Chen said.

To live up to the public's expectations, Chen said, his administration will actively promote political reforms through legislation on the Political Contribution Law, the Conflict of Interest Law, the Political Party Law, the Lobbying Law, and electoral reform laws.
"We'll faithfully implement these laws so that the goal of an honest government and clean elections can be achieved," Chen pledged.
