Turning to the economic front, Chen said, Taiwan's economy has live through the bitter winter of recession and a ray of sunlight has gradually dawned.

"However, we are not content with these achievements," Chen said, adding that his administration has come up with a plan to "deeply cultivate Taiwan with a global perspective" as the vision for Taiwan's national economic development in the new century.
On Jan. 1, Chen said, Taiwan became the 144th member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) -- the "economic United Nations."

"In fact, Taiwan's accession to the WTO is an important step in returning to the international community," Chen noted. "Like any democratic country, Taiwan expects to receive equal treatment and respect from the world."

Chen said the people of Taiwan hope that the United States and other countries around the world can understand their common aspirations to fulfill their international obligations and extend greater support to Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization and other international bodies.

Stressing that normalizing relations across the Taiwan Strait has been one of his most important tasks since he took office, Chen said Taiwan is willing to resume dialogue with mainland China, provided there are no preconditions.

"Now that both sides are members of the WTO, we should be able to utilize its international mechanism to establish dialogue on economic and trade issues, which would not only facilitate normalization of bilateral trade and economic relations, but also reduce cross-strait tensions," he added.

The teleconference was organized by the Fairbank Center for East Asian Research, Harvard University. In addition to delivering a 20-minute speech, Chen also took questions from U.S. scholars and graduate students.

DOC.HEADLINE: BROAD DISCUSSION REQUIRED ON TRANSFER OF WAFER KNOW-HOW: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A Taipei official said Tuesday that the government will take various aspects into consideration before deciding whether to allow local wafer manufacturers to invest in mainland China.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman John Deng made the remarks while speaking at a public hearing organized by two legislators on the proposed transfer of wafer know-how to mainland China.
Deng said that the government has no intention of postponing its decision but added that the issue must be discussed fully.
He noted that the MAC's basic principles on the issue are that Taiwan's economic growth must be sustained and that enterprises wishing to invest in the mainland must keep their roots in Taiwan.

The MAC official went on to say that the government will also pay attention to the flow of capital and the maintenance of a good environment for up- and down-stream development, as well as the employment situation on the island.
He said that the MAC will try to obtain more information on the issue but admitted that he could not say when the final decision will be made.
Minister of Economic Affairs Christine Tsung said recently that her ministry will submit suggestions to the Executive Yuan for a final decision on the issue by the end of March.
In a related development, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tze said Tuesday that he supports the proposal of allowing local wafer manufacturers to build eight-inch wafer plants in mainland China.
He stated that the know-how is not the monopoly of Taiwan companies and added that even if Taiwan does not invest in the mainland, other countries will.
It was the first time that the Nobel Prize winner had openly voiced his support for the transfer of wafer technology to the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF ALLOWS HONG KONG BANK TO OPEN KAOHSIUNG BRANCH

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) approved an application Tuesday from Hong Kong's Bank of East Asia to open a branch office in Kaohsiung.
The bank, which established a Taipei branch office in May 1997, becomes the 11th foreign bank to open a branch office in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
The opening of the new branch office will increase the number of foreign bank branch offices in Taiwan to 70.

DOC.HEADLINE: LANTERN FESTIVAL CELEBRATED ISLANDWIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lit the key lanterns at a ceremony held Tuesday evening in the southern port city of Kaohsiung to mark the annual Lantern Festival.

Addressing the ceremony, in which a jumping fish and flying dragon were featured as a theme on numerous paper lanterns, Chen said the vibrant theme lantern symbolizes Kaohsiung's fast development and upgrading as one of Taiwan's most important cities.
The festival was celebrated all over the island, with all the major cities lighting up their own theme lanterns amid festive celebrations.
In Taipei, Vice President Annette Lu and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou jointly officiated at a ceremony at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall Park to kick off the six-day Taipei Lantern Festival.
The giant theme lantern -- a horse, which is the Chinese zodiac animal for 2002 -- brightened up the Taipei skies with blinding laser beams and vivid colors.

In addition to the horse theme lantern, the Taipei lantern craftsmen also showed off their skills by presenting a series of giant lanterns featuring Vincent van Gogh's "Irises in the Garden," Marc Chagall's "I and the Village," Gustav Klimt's "Kiss," and Pablo Picasso's "Dream."

In Yenshui, Tainan County, where the township's annual fireworks festival routinely steals the show of Lantern Festivals elsewhere -- at least in terms of noise generated -- the number of spectators decreased by about one-third after six people were reported killed the previous day in an explosion at an illegal fireworks factory.

In the offshore county of Kinmen, residents observed for the first time fireworks being set off simultaneously with fireworks displays being staged on the coast at Xiamen, a mainland Chinese port city located just opposite Kinmen across the Taiwan Strait.
Witnessing the unprecedented cross-strait fireworks displays, Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng proclaimed: "Let's exchange fireworks, not gunfire across the Taiwan Strait."
Kinmen was an outlying Republic of China bastion against the Chinese communists, who showered the island with bombs and bullets on alternate days until less than three decades ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: PALAU PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN TAIPEI FOR STATE VISIT

TEXT.P: President Tommy E. Remengesau, Jr. of the Republic of Palau arrived in Taipei at the head of a 25-member delegation Tuesday for a five-day state visit.
Remengesau and his delegation were warmly greeted upon arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport by Foreign Minister Eugene Chien and other government officials.

President Chen Shui-bian will officiate at a military salute Wednesday in Taipei City to extend an official welcome to his Pacific island nation counterpart, as well as hosting a state banquet in his honor.
Remengesau will also hold talks with Chien and tour several economic and cultural establishments in the country before departing on March 2.
Remengesau was elected senator at the age of 28 in 1984, becoming the youngest senator ever in Palau. He was re-elected four years later.
In 1993, he was elected vice president, serving concurrently as minister of administration. He won a second term in 1996 and was elected president in 2000.
He has visited Taiwan many times and last visited in December 2000 in his capacity as president-elect.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT EXPERTS ATTEND SEMINAR ON AGRICULTURAL BIOTECHNOLOGY
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, southern Taiwan, Feb. 26 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Experts and scholars from Taiwan and mainland China attended a seminar on agricultural biotechnology at National Chiayi University Tuesday.
The seminar was chaired by NCU President Yang Kuo-shih, who welcomed the participation of the 12-member mainland Chinese delegation.
Participants heard reports and exchanged views on the development of biotechnology.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL MEDIA FORUM FORMED IN TOKYO
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 26 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The International Media Forum (IMF) was formed in Tokyo Tuesday with its members comprised of press officials from the Republic of China, Germany, France and Canada, as well as senior journalists from Asahi Television Corp. and the Tokyo Shimbun.
The inauguration ceremony was held at a Tokyo hotel and organized by Hsu Kuo-chen, director of the information section under the ROC Representative Office to Japan.
ROC Deputy Representative to Japan Chen Chin-hsien spoke at the ceremony, expressing his hope that the forum will promote international media exchanges.
The non-profit group will meet once every two months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ATTEND WORLD CUP LATIN AMERICAN DANCE CHAMPIONSHIPS

TEXT.P: Two Taiwan dancers will compete in the 2002 World Cup Latin American Dance Championships that will be held March 2 in Vilnius, Lithuania, Chinese Taipei Sports Dance Association Chairwoman Liu Mei-li said Tuesday.
Liu said that she will accompany Wang Yu-hung and Hsiao Wan-ju to Vilnius Wednesday to attend the dance championships.
It will be the first international dance pageant attended by the Chinese Taipei Dance Association for this year and the first time for Wang and Hsiao to compete in Europe, Liu said.

Because of the high level of most of the competitors, the chances Taipei dancers are unlikely to score well and the main purpose of competing is to give them the opportunity to learn from other international dancers, she said.
The competition will also serve them as a warm-up in advance of the England Standard Dance and Latin American Dance Open slated for May in Blackpool, Liu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 27, or the fifth day of the second month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
285: Constantine I, Emperor of Rome known as "Constantine the Great," is born. He adopted the Christian faith and suspended the persecution of Christians.
1782: The British Parliament votes to abandon the American War of Independence.
1844: The Dominican Republic gains its independence from Haiti.
1861: Rudolf Steiner, the Austrian philosopher, educationalist, and founder of anthroposophy, is born.
1879: Constantin Fahlberg, a chemist at Johns Hopkins University, announces the discovery of saccharine, a synthetic sweetener.
1910: Dr. Sun Yat-sen sets up a U.S. headquarters in San Francisco after organizing the Revolution Alliance in Tokyo in 1905 to sponsor an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1922: Dr. Sun Yat-sen issues a proclamation at a "harangue-the-troops" ceremony in Guilin, Guangxi Province, before a military expedition northward to eradicate various feuding warlords in central and northern China.
1932: British physicist Sir James Chadwick discovers the neutron, a subatomic particle which is used by scientists to render various elements radioactive.
1933: Japanese troops invade Jehol Province in northeastern China.
1933: Chancellor Adolf Hitler calls for a "God-given signal" that the communists should be crushed, as a mysterious fire guts Berlin's Reichstag, or Parliament.
1942: Japanese forces sink three Allied destroyers and a cruiser in the first phase of the Battle of the Java Sea.
1948: The Czechoslovakian Communist Party seizes power in Prague with communists given all the top jobs in the new Cabinet.
1952: The United Nations convenes its first session in its new permanent headquarters in New York.
1962: Two mutinous Republic of Vietnam Air Force planes bomb the presidential office in Saigon. President Ngo Dinh Diem escapes unscathed.
1973: Governor Yu Kuo-hwa of the Central Bank of China leaves for Saigon to sign a US$5 million loan contract with the Vietnamese government.
1973: Ronald H.C. Ho assumes office as president of the Bank of Taiwan.
1974: Osamu Itagaki, chairman of the Sino-Japan Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei for talks on ROC-Japan civil aviation relations.
1975: The ROC and Saudi Arabia sign an air agreement in which Saudi Airlines will offer flight services from Jeddah or Riyadh to Taipei or Kaohsiung and China Airlines will offer flight services from Taipei or Kaohsiung to Jeddah or Riyadh via Hong Kong.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan receives Dennis Theike, commander of Pacific Areas of the U.S. Veterans of Foreign Wars.
1980: Taiwan Power Co. signs a syndicated loan of US$100 million with ten foreign banks to finance development projects.
1981: Beijing strongly protests against the Dutch government's decision to sell two submarines to the ROC, with both sides recalling their respective envoys.
1993: Taiwan Provincial Governor Lien Chan succeeds Hau Pei-tsun as premier of the ROC following his confirmation by the Legislative Yuan.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Shui-bian promises to create 100,000 jobs to benefit 100,000 families and one million people if he is elected president on March 18.
2001: Kuomintang Chairman Lian Chan meets with People First Party Chairman James Soong, with the two agreeing to bolster future cooperation.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you speak to a man in the strict words of the law, he will probably agree with you; but the important point is that he should so profit by what you say to him as to change his conduct. If you speak to a man in parables, he will probably be pleased with your story; but the important point is that he should apply the moral to himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Wednesday are as follows:
The China Times:
Premier Yu unveils new six-year national development plan.
The United Daily News:
The statute governing relations between the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will be revised to exclude Mongolians from its coverage.
The Liberty Times:
Taiwan will no longer treat Mongolia as part of China.
The Taiwan Daily:
Taiwan's semiconductor giant United Microelectronics Corp. will buy into mainland China's wafer plant.
The Central Daily News:
Ruling and opposition parties squabble over Mongolia's status.
The China Post:
Premier Yu targets challenges by 2008.
The Taiwan News:
China warns Taiwan will 'pay for it.'
The Taipei Times:
Name-change idea angers China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 196.32 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 196.32 points to close at 5,696.11.
Market turnover amounted to NT$110.29 billion (US$3.15 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 196.32 points to close at 5,696.11.

The bourse opened at 5,536.81 and continued to go up due to a strong rebound in both electrical shares and plastics and chemical stocks. The index fluctuated between 5,699.67 and 5,536.81 during trading.

A total of 3.2 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$110.29 billion (US$3.15 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 2.83 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$93.01 billion (US$2.66 billion).

All eight of the major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemical stocks and electrical shares moving up the most, both at 4.2 percent, followed by textile issues at 2.5 percent, bank and insurance shares at 2.3 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.6 percent, cement stocks at 1.2 percent, construction stocks at 0.9 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 575 to 65, with 56 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONGOLIAN STATUS ISSUE NEEDS LEGISLATIVE DECISION: LEGISLATURE HEAD

TEXT.P: The Cabinet's decision to alter Mongolia's status may involve changing the boundaries of the Republic of China's territorial claims which would need to be settled by amending the ROC Constitution, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday.

The Executive Yuan on Jan. 31 approved an amendment, proposed by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), to the Statutes Governing Relations between the People on Both Sides of the Taiwan Strait, thereby formally excluding outer Mongolia from the Republic of China's maps of the "Mainland China Area."
The amendment redefined the original regulations that defined mainland China as areas under Communist Chinese control, plus Mongolia, by excluding Mongolia.
Accordingly, citizens of Mongolia are now considered by the ROC government to be foreigners entitled to visas, instead of entry permits, when they visit Taiwan.

Subtly hinting his complaint that the Cabinet adopted the changes without notifying the Legislature, Wang said that related disputes that will crop up due to the adoption of the amendment will be mitigated only if the Executive Yuan shows some respect to the Legislative Yuan in advance.

Defending the Cabinet decision, MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Tuesday that the amendment is meant to bring the law into line with the actual current reality, pointing out that it will now be easier for Taiwan to deal with its increasing trade and cultural exchanges with Mongolia.

Chien Shih-ying, chief secretary of the Cabinet-level Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission, said excluding Mongolia from the "Mainland China Area" is a pragmatic policy since more than 140 nations around the world recognize the sovereignty of Mongolia, which has been independent since 1921.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for March moved up 171 points to close at 5,700, with 15,385 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April surged 192 points to finish at 5,714, with 26 contract transactions, while June futures gained 188 points to close at 5,650, with four contracts traded.
December futures rose 121 points to close at 5,660, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,529`for March, 5,522 for April, 5,462 for June, 5,583 for September and 5,539 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
March TE futures moved up 11.3 points to close at 300.95, with 3,241 contract transactions, while next April TE futures increased 11 points to finish at 298, with one contract traded.
June TE futures rose 3.35 points to close at 291, with three contract transactions, while September TE futures surged 19.7 points to finish at 301.5, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
March TF futures rose 13 points to finish at 683, with 473 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS, PRODUCTION ENJOY REBOUND

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export orders and industrial production rebounded in January after nearly one year's downturn, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Wednesday.

Export orders received by Taiwan exporters and manufacturers during the month reached US$11.32 billion, up 9.16 percent from the year-earlier level, while domestic industrial production increased 11.98 percent, both figures marking the first rebound since February, 2001, MOEA officials said.
The officials attributed the rebounds mainly to a lower comparison basis laid in January 2001, date of last year's Chinese New Year holidays.
Chang Yao-tsung, director-general of the MOEA's Statistics Department, noted that export orders in February are expected to be lower as a result of this year's February Chinese New Year holidays.

Chang said the export orders are expected to rebound again, although slightly, in March and gradually expand in the months to come. He added that "noticeable growth" in this area will not be seen until the second half of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU PUSHES FOR PRESIDENTIAL STATE SPEECH AT LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) is planning to push for a resolution calling for President Chen Shui-bian to make a state of the nation speech at the Legislative Yuan.
Chen has yet to be invited by the legislature to make a state of the nation speech since his inauguration nearly two years ago, said Cheng Chen-lung, a TSU party whip at the Legislative Yuan.
Cheng said it is "natural and justifiable" that Chen be invited to address the legislature, which represents what he described as the "new people's wills," two years after he assumed office.
Cheng added that he is confident that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, now the largest party in the legislature, will throw its full support behind the TSU proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BE STRICTER ON GUARANTORS WHO SIGN FOR MAINLAND CHINESE

TEXT.P: The government will impose stricter responsibilities on guarantors who sign for mainland Chinese people wishing to enter Taiwan, the head of the Bureau of Immigration said Wednesday.
Bureau of Immigration Commissioner Tseng Wen-chang made the remarks when he briefed Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien.
Tseng said that the bureau is mulling whether to revise related regulations to increase the responsibilities of guarantors who vouch for mainland people applying to come to Taiwan.

Under the conditions being considered, the main guarantor would have to be the spouse of the applicant, who would have to shoulder the responsibility for all expenses incurred in any problems that arise. Only if the original guarantor is deceased or cannot be located can the list of possible guarantors be expanded to the original guarantor's relatives.

Tseng said that the stricter regulations are designed to prevent the common practice of mainland people coming to Taiwan to work or engage in illegal activities under marriages of convenience to Taiwan people.

Yu also said that as mainland China is stalling over the repatriation of illegal mainland immigrants detained in Taiwan, which he said has added to the government expenses and resources, he will submit the issue to the Mainland Affairs Council and related agencies for more consultation.

Tseng noted that the repatriation of illegal mainland immigrants is conducted through the Red Cross Society of the Republic and China and its mainland counterpart under the Kinmen Agreement, and that while the ROC has no problem accommodating male illegal mainland immigrants, the main problem lies with the detention of female illegal immigrants.

He added that during recent raids, police have cracked down on many mainland Chinese women who have entered Taiwan on a bogus marriage. The Hsinchu shelter, he went on, is currently overwhelmed with female illegal immigrants.

However, National Police Administration Director General Wang Chin-Wang said that there are only 722 illegal immigrants in detention at present, compared with more than 2,000 in December 2000, when mainland China was refusing to take back illegal immigrants.
Wang said that the police administration will continue to communicate with its mainland counterpart on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEARCH FOR MISSING U.S. CITIZEN CONTINUES: POLICE

TEXT.P: The search for an American citizen who was reported missing Feb. 9 is still going on, Hualien police authorities said Wednesday.
Christopher Dale Deiwert, an English teacher in the eastern Taiwan county of Hualien, has been missing since visiting the beach near Chihsing Lake Feb. 9, police said.
"We combed the area after receiving information about his disappearance, but have not found him so far," said Chu Ai-hua, chief of the Hualien Police Bureau's foreign affairs section.
Nevertheless, Chu said, they have discovered some of Deiwert's personal belongings, including his passport, backpack, a notebook and bicycle, on the Chihsing beach.

"We have interviewed residents in the area, but none of them have seen him," Chu said. "We have also contacted Deiwert's friends based on telephone numbers we found in his notebook, but have made no breakthroughs and have found no clues," he added.

Chu recalled that the wind was strong and the seas high at the beach on the day of Deiwert's disappearance. "We have asked the Hualien Coast Guard Corps to assist in searching for Deiwert at sea, but the maritime search has so far not scored any results."
Meanwhile, Chu said, his section has posted information about Deiwert's disappearance on a Web site to seek online assistance in the search.
"We'll continue the search through every possible channel or means and will make public any results and information we may glean," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAY CHAO BECOMES 1ST CHINESE-AMERICAN TO SERVE IN N.Y. STATE CABINET

TEXT.P: May M. Chao on Tuesday became the first Chinese-American to gain a Cabinet-level position in the New York State Senate when the governor confirmed her nomination as the chairwoman and executive director of the Consumer Protection Board (CPB).
When Gov. George Pataki nominated her in January, he said Chao shares his commitment to protecting New Yorkers from unscrupulous business practices.
Upon hearing the Senate's vote, Chao said she is honored to officially serve in Pataki's administration and pledged to fulfill her mandate of providing help to millions of consumers in the state.

Chao will be responsible for the management of the CPB's operations, including serving as the state's top consumer protection watchdog, as well as developing consumer education and fraud prevention programs.
Ms. Chao spent 12 years as vice president of an international shipping and trading company with responsibilities that included personnel management, as well as insurance and business development.

She received her bachelor's degree in economics from Wellseley College, graduating with honors, and then later earned her Master of Business Administration degree from Harvard University's Graduate School of Business.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO ATTEND WORLD IT CONGRESS IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will leave for Australia Thursday to attend the World Congress on Information Technology, a bi-annual event sponsored by the World Information Technology and Services Alliance (WITSA) in Adelaide, South Australia from Feb. 27-March 1.

On behalf of the Taipei city government, Ma will receive a public sector excellence award for the city's IT services. The city government's "Easy City -- a new metropolis on the Internet" program won most of the votes of the WITSA members in a competition, with entries from the business as well as the public sector.

A delegation of the local IT industry headed by Vice Economics Minister Richard Yin and James Wong, chairman of the board of the Information Service Industry Association of China, Taipei (CISA), is attending the three-day conference.

Taipei was the host city of the last WITSA conference. The 2000 World Congress on Information Technology held in Taipei from June 11-14 was lauded "the best ever IT World Congress" by the organization, with the participation of the chief executives of top international IT corporations.

To express its appreciation for winning the right to sponsor the 2002 congress, the Australian delegation to the Taipei conference in June 2000 promised to present a pair of glossy black cockatoos to the Taipei Zoo. The rare birds arrived in Taipei recently, according to an CISA official.

Founded in 1978, WITSA is a consortium of 41 IT industry associations from economies around the world. The world congress is held every two years with the participation of government officials in charge of industrial affairs and chief executives of IT corporations.

According to the sponsor, the 2002 conference has attracted many well-known speakers, including former U.S. President Bill Clinton, Al Berkeley, vice chairman of the board of directors of the Nasdaq Stock Market, Doug T. Elix, senior vice president and group executive of IBM Global Service, Michael Capellas, chairman and chief executive officer of Compaq and Naoyuki Akikusa, president and CEO of Fuhitsu Ltd.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER MAINLAND CHINESE TENNIS ACE VOWS TO NURTURE `TAIWAN SEEDS'

TEXT.P: Committing herself to an ambitious 10-year training plan, former mainland Chinese tennis player Hu Na envisions nurturing Taiwan's own version of the Williams sisters.

Believing that Taiwan's aboriginal youths have potential and stamina equal to that of Venus and Serena Williams if properly explored, Hu, the former mainland Chinese Olympian who sought political asylum in the United States some 20 years ago, embarked on her 10-year plan to nurture three aboriginal children who she hopes will become the "seeds" of tomorrow's young Taiwan tennis players.

Hu, who settled permanently in Taiwan six years ago and now runs a tennis club in Taipei, traveled to Hualien, eastern Taiwan, during this year's winter break to interview seven schoolgirls from Hualien's Kuangfu Primary School who are considered to have high tennis potential.
Finding that all seven "could hit the ball the first time they held a racquet," she invited all seven to Taipei for a month-long training session at her tennis club during the winter break.
When the training ended, Hu signed three of them up for long-term training.

Despite the fact that it will cost about NT$1 million a year to nurture the three girls, an "investment" that will not see a return anytime soon, Hu said she considers the three as "blue chip" stocks. "I believe the three of them will turn out to be champions of the 12-year-old class National Youth Tennis Competition in two years," she said.

Hu, in her early 40s, is not only a good tennis coach, but also has a brilliant business mind. Since taking over her tennis club three years ago, she has signed several up-and-coming young players who train at her club.

Hu's training program has won sponsorships from the local business and industrial communities and she regularly receives cash donations from local tycoons, including the owners of the Brother Hotel Chain and the Sampo Corp.
Hu, who lives with her parents, describes tennis as her "better half," despite her name being frequently linked with various local businessmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar climbed on the Taipei Foreign Exchange market Wednesday, rising NT$0.024 to close at NT$35.112.
A total of US$342 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$35.136 and was traded between NT$35.106 and NT$35.141.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGES RULING PARTY TO PRESENT PRAGMATIC MAINLAND CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang, said Wednesday that he hopes the ruling party can build consensus among its various factions that will allow the Cabinet to present a pragmatic mainland China policy.

Lien made the remarks after hearing Su Chi, an official of the National Policy Foundation -- a KMT think tank -- present a report on the cross-strait situation and its prospects at a KMT regular Central Standing Committee meeting.

Lien said that there is a discrepancy between the government and private sectors, as well as between the political and economic sectors, claiming that the government and political sectors are lukewarm toward the other side of the Taiwan Strait, while the private and economic sectors are "rushing feverishly" to the mainland, which he said runs counter to the expectations of the people regarding cross-strait relations. He also expressed worry that the development has even bogged down Taiwan's economic development.

Lien said that United States President George Bush's recent trip to the mainland shows that Washington and Beijing are still testing their relations, while the U.S. commitment to Taiwan's security remains firm.

Lien reiterated that Taipei-Washington relations and cross-strait relations should be two parallel lines and that if the lines are skewed, then national interests will suffer. He added that as the U.S has stressed its commitment to Taiwan, the ROC should have more confidence in reviving the deadlocked cross-strait dialogue and implementing the consensus reached by a national economic conference in August.

He described the KMT's mainland policy as "sound and middle-of-the-road" -- not advocating Taiwan independence or rapid unification, which is in tune with the mainstream of Taiwan people and will create a mutually beneficial situation for both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

He also said that cross-strait talks should be based on an equal footings and that the KMT cannot accept any pre-conditions regarding the "one country, two systems" espoused by the mainland, nor will it agree with he said is "the government's tendency to annihilate the Republic of China."

He was assumed to be referring to the decision to add "issued in Taiwan" to the cover of the ROC passport and a plan to substitute the word "Taiwan" for the existing "Taipei" in the names of ROC overseas missions, although he failed to explain how such wording could be construed as "annihilating the Republic of China."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LAYS OUT RED CARPET TO WELCOME PALAU PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over a ceremony Wednesday to welcome Palau President Tommy E. Remengesau, Jr., who arrived in Taipei a day earlier for a five-day state visit.

Remengesau was accorded full military honors, complete with a 21-gun military salute, in a welcoming ceremony held at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex in downtown Taipei near the Presidential Office.
Speaking on the occasion, Chen said relations between the Republic of China and Palau have been growing steadily since the two countries forged formal diplomatic ties in December 1999.
"We believe that President Remengesau's current visit will further strengthen bilateral cooperation and turn a new page in our relations," Chen said.

Noting that both the ROC and Palau will face new opportunities and challenges in the new century, Chen said he hopes the two countries can cooperate closely to overcome difficulties and enhance their people's well-being.
For his part, Remengesau expressed his gratitude for all the hospitality the ROC government and people have shown to him and his entourage.
Remengesau also echoed Chen's call for increased bilateral cooperation, saying that his present visit is aimed at seeking new cooperative programs between the two countries.
Vice President Annette Lu and many other senior ROC officials, as well as members of the diplomatic corps, attended the welcoming ceremony.
Later in the day, Remengesau paid a visit to Chen and the two leaders had wide-ranging talks.
Chen said during the meeting that as a member of the "global village," the ROC has the right and obligation to take part in international activities and organizations to fulfill its duties.

"We appreciate Palau's resolute support for our bids to join the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other major international bodies," Chen said, adding that he was impressed by Remengesau's speech in support of the ROC's U.N. bid at the General Assembly's general debate session last November.

Chen said that although the ROC and Palau have enjoyed diplomatic ties for only two years, bilateral technological and sports exchanges and cooperation have made significant progress. Palau has recently opened an embassy in Taipei, the Pacific nation's third after the United States and Japan.

Quoting official tallies, Chen said more than 12,000 ROC citizens visited Palau last year, making Taiwan the nation's second-largest source of tourist revenue, behind only Japan. "I believe that more Taiwan people will make pleasure trips to Palau in the future," he added.

In addition to reaffirming Palau's strong support for the ROC's U.N. bid, Remengesau said he has come to understand the importance of partnership between the two countries over the past two years. "The ROC is one of our best friends. We should further beef up economic cooperation and cultural exchanges," he stressed.

Remengesau is accompanied by his wife and 20-plus Palau officials and congressional leaders on his current Taiwan visit. Aside from meeting with senior ROC officials, the Palau president will also tour major Taiwan economic and cultural development projects during his stay.
Remengesau will also hold talks with Chien and tour several economic and cultural establishments in the country before departing on March 2.
Remengesau was elected senator at the age of 28 in 1984, becoming the youngest senator ever in Palau. He was re-elected four years later.
In 1993, he was elected vice president, serving concurrently as minister of administration. He won a second term in 1996 and was elected president in 2000.
He has visited Taiwan many times and last visited in December 2000 in his capacity as president-elect.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA APPROVES 15 INDIRECT INVESTMENT PROJECTS IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Wednesday approved 15 local indirect investment projects in mainland China worth a total of US$126 million, according to sources from the MOEA's Investment Commission.

Among the approved cases, Compal Electronics Inc. will buy shares in two mainland Chinese electronic companies for US$12.15 million to become the major shareholder of the companies, which produce notebooks and palmtops, as well as GSM and CDMA cellular phones.
Pacific Construction Co. will pour US$6.6 million into mainland Chinese department stores, retail sales, food, trading and consulting services.
HannStar will invest US$15 million in the mainland to produce and sell printed circuit boards.
Electronic companies form the bulk of the approved investment cases, followed by plastics, textile and service firms, according to the Investment Commission officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO VISIT PERTH, MELBOURNE

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will visit the Colonial Stadium in Melbourne, the Obahn transportation system in Adelaide and the East Perth project during a five-day visit to Australia from Feb. 28 to March 5.
Ma will also be attending the World Congress on Information Technology, which is being held in Adelaide, South Australia.

After attending the conference, Mayor Ma will meet with Adelaide Mayor Alfred Huang, Clive Brown, minister for state development, tourism and small business of the Western Australian Government, Melbourne Mayor John So and Perth Mayor Peter Mattarass, to exchange views on urban development.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSC SEEKING ALLIANCE WITH PRIVATE SECTOR

TEXT.P: The state-owned China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSC) is seeking alliances with local private shipbuilding companies, a CSC spokesman said Wednesday.

The spokesman said that the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has signed an agreement for the state enterprise to take care of the maintenance of all military vessels. The MOEA has instructed that the CSC should cooperate with local private shipbuilding companies to share the market resources.
The CSC has suffered heavy losses in recent years as a result of fierce competition from mainland China, Japan and South Korea.

The company went through a painful "rebirth program" late last year, laying off 2,300 workers at its Kaohsiung and Keelung shipyards and cutting the salaries of the survivors by as much as 35 percent. A MOEA report indicates that the company managed to operate with a pre-tax surplus of NT$35 million in January, while the operational cost for the month was cut by NT$340 million.

Under the MOEA's plans, the CSC will be the sole window to negotiate with the navy on shipbuilding and maintenance contracts, while the company will be at liberty to find private shipbuilders to be its sub-contractors, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT ASSURES HI-TECH FIRMS OF WATER SUPPLIES

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan decided Wednesday to allow 18,000 hectares of rice paddy in northern Taiwan to lie fallow in an attempt to alleviate a drought that has affected the operations of a nearby industrial complex.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun gave the order at a Cabinet meeting after demanding that Vice Premier Lin Hsin-yi work out contingency measures in conjunction with the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Council of Agriculture, the National Science Council and the Hsinchu and Taoyuan county governments, Executive Yuan spokesman Chuang Suo-hang told a news conference following the meeting.

Stressing that it is the government's responsibility to provide the public and industry with sufficient water, Lin said following a "tea party" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party that construction of the second-phase Paoshan Reservoir is slated to be completed by the end of 2004, which will secure a daily water supply of 590,000 tons for the greater Hsinchu area until 2021. According to Chuang, the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration was to inform the companies based at the northern industrial park later that day of the government's decision.

Administration Director Lee Chieh-mu said 600,000 tons of water per day will be supplied to factories, schools and residential communities near the industrial park and he promised that the decision not to irrigate the rice paddies means there will be no water shortage.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said he has submitted a report to the Executive Yuan expressing Taipei's willingness to help supply water indirectly to the Hsinchu Science based-industrial Park by providing 100,000 tons of water per day from Taipei via Shihmen Reservoir in Taoyuan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC TO EASE RESTRICTIONS ON MAINLAND TOUR GROUPS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Wednesday it is consulting with relevant government agencies on easing restrictions on mainland tour groups' nightime activities during their stay in Taiwan.
The council issued the statement amid reports that a second mainland Chinese tour group is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Friday from the United States.
According to the reports, prospective mainland Chinese tourists are worrying about Taiwan's strict restrictions on their activities on the island.

"We are discussing the issue with security authorities," said an MAC official. "We are confident that the rule requiring all members of mainland tour groups to end their daily activities and return to hotels by 11 p.m. during their staye will be eased soon."
Many members of the first mainland Chinese tour group, composed of mainland passport holders in Japan, complained about that restrictions at the end of their visit earlier this month.

MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen clarified during a meeting with a group of Taiwanese businessmen with interests in mainland China that the MAC has not banned mainland tourists from leaving hotels after 11 p.m.
Tsai was also quoted as having said that the "curfew" might have been imposed by other agencies on the ground that tour guides need a rest at night.
Meanwhile, the Tourism Bureau reiterated Wednesday that mainland Chinese tourists must still abide by the "group tour" and "group activity" rules.
Reports from San Francisco said a tour group composed of mainland Chinese nationals with permanent residency in the United States will arrive in Taipei Friday for a sightseeing trip.

It will be the second mainland tour group to visit Taiwan since the Republic of China government opened its doors to overseas mainland Chinese citizens traveling in groups at the beginning of this year. The first group, composed of elderly mainland Chinese residents of Japan, visited Taiwan Feb. 5-9.
The San Francisco-based Phoenix Travel Agency has cooperated with Taipei's Richmond Travel Agency in organizing a six-day, five-night tour package for the 12-member group.

A Phoenix spokesman said members of the group include people working in the high-tech industries and banks as well as social group volunteers and housewives. "All of them have permanent residency in the United States and have passed qualification screening by Taiwan's representative office here," he said. "And our Taipei partner has asked the Taipei Association of Travel Agents to apply for travel permits for our customers with the Taiwan authorities."

In addition to touring Taiwan's major tourist attractions and historic relics in northern and central Taiwan, the spokesman said, the mainland visitors also hope to see for themselves Taiwan's general lifestyle, social customs and cultural development.

"We have arranged for them to visit noted sightseeing spots in northern and central Taiwan, including the National Palace Museum in suburban Taipei and scenic Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County," he added.

As part of its efforts to boost exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan began Jan. 1 to allow mainland citizens with permanent foreign residency or mainland students studying abroad to make pleasure trips to the island, as long as they travel in a group at all times. (Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ASKS GOVERNMENT TO MAP OUT NATIONAL CONSTRUCTION PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun instructed the Council for Economic Planning and Development Wednesday to map out projects for implementing the six-year national construction program he proposed in his first administrative report to the legislature the previous day.

At a weekly Cabinet meeting, Yu asked the CEPD to combine opinions offered by various relevant Cabinet departments and to submit a draft of the project to the Cabinet for approval by the end of April.
Yu also asked the Ministry of Finance to develop a financial program to support the program that will see a variety of public construction projects implemented over the next six years.

Setting 2008 as the target for the completion of the six-year national construction program, Yu said he hopes the Cabinet will map out a "general national construction project" that can promote the nation's developments in various fields.
Yu set 2008 as the target in response to Beijing's successful bid to host the Olympic Games in that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: THINK TANK ASKS BUSH TO ABANDON SHANGHAI COMMUNIQUE

TEXT.P: A pro-Taiwan independence group issued an open letter in Taipei Wednesday, urging U.S. President George W. Bush to abandon the Shanghai Communique and fully implement the Taiwan Relations Act.

The "Taiwan Heart," an action-oriented think tank composed of about 300 university professors, lawyers and entrepreneurs, asked the United States to re-examine the effectiveness of what it said was "the inadequate Shanghai Communique" inked by Washington and Beijing in 1972, because both Taiwan and mainland China were ruled by "authoritarian regimes" at that time and the voice of the people in Taiwan could not be heard.

Calling the communique a "historical mistake," the group said the so-called "one China" principle advocated by Beijing is only the recognition of a minority of political leaders which lacks a popular representation.

The letter said, "Bush's clear commitment and unyielding stance to protect a free and democratic Taiwan is a real godsend. We feel deeply that your strong gesture is like 'sending us coal during a severe winter.' We will remember you as the best friend Taiwan has ever had.

The letter also highly praised Bush's leadership, indicating that "Since Sept. 11, you have shown leadership rarely seen in modern times. Your vision for mankind, courage to defend freedom and democracy and decisiveness in the war against terrorism will surely be written into history books."
The Taiwan Heart issued the letter prior to the 30th anniversary of the Shanghai Communique to thank Bush's efforts in fighting terrorism and making the world a more peaceful place.

The Shanghai Communique was signed by then-U.S. President Richard Nixon and mainland Chinese Premier Zhou Enlai to serve as a foundation for the establishment of formal diplomatic links between the United States and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLY 10 PERCENT OF TAIWAN INTERNET USERS SHOP ONLINE

TEXT.P: Only 10 percent of Taiwan's 8 million cyber population are frequent shoppers on the Internet, according to statistics compiled by the Institute for Information Industry.

According to industry sources, business transactions made by shoppers on the Internet totaled NT$8.9 billion (US$250 million) last year and the figure is expected to hit NT$37 billion within three years.

At the same time, the United States-based online trading leader eBay forecast that the number of Taiwan online shoppers will increase and that the e-commerce market in Taiwan may amount to NT$476 billion (about US$14 billion) in 2005.

Statistics compiled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs show that Taiwan's private consumption totaled NT$30 trillion in 2001, 0.03 percent of which was made through the Internet, far lower than 1.6 percent in the United States.

The sources attributed the gap between the two countries to a lack of confidence for online businesses among Taiwan consumers and reports of frauds in cyberspace. They also said the e-commerce market forecast made by eBay remains a remote goal.

Of the domestic e-commerce business, Taiwan-based auction Web site Coolbid.com said 50 percent was for ticket bookings, while 12 percent was made for purchases of 3C products -- cars, computers and consumer electronics.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS AUDIT OF TAIWAN MUSEUM COLLECTION

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun ordered an audit of the state-run Taiwan Museum Wednesday after several important objects were reported missing from its storehouse.

Yu asked the Council for Cultural Affairs to form an ad hoc team to take a thorough inventory of the museum's collection before the end of the year, address any mismanagement and find out those responsible for any wrongdoing.

Cabinet spokesman Chung Suo-hang said the premier gave the order one day after a Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator accused museum staff of selling off valuable objects and replacing them with reproductions.
Legislator Chen Ching-chun filed a complaint with the Control Yuan that day, accusing senior museum staff of failing in their duties by not reporting the disappearance of many valuable objects.
The lawmaker said the museum's inventory listed 50,000-odd objects, but he claimed that no one has ever checked them since the museum was taken over from its Japanese founder in 1945.
He singled out in particular the staff of the anthropological department, accusing them dragging their feet as regards inventory-taking.
Chen said the three staff members had recorded only some 4,000 objects, or just 16 percent of the entire anthropological collection, in more than ten years.
Chen said he suspected that fear of being found out might be behind the staff's reluctance to hand over parts of the museum's collection to two other state-supported museums.
Hsieh Ching-hui, the member of the Control Yuan who accepted Chen's complaint, said the government's supreme watchdog has assigned six members to look into the complaints.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR HEALING OF WOUNDS CAUSED BY 2-28 INCIDENT

TEXT.P: On the eve of the anniversary of the 2-28 Incident in 1947 in which thousands of Taiwanese civilians were killed by government forces in Taiwan, ROC President Chen Shui-bian called for tolerance and a healing of old wounds.
"The 2-28 Incident represents a shared experience of pain and suffering for all on Taiwan, regardless of their ethnicity or party affiliation," the president said.
Chen said, "All people in Taiwan must work together to heal the wounds and eliminate the pain."
The president made the remarks while speaking at the opening of an exhibition at the art gallery in the Presidential Office marking the 55th anniversary of the 2-28 Incident.
As Taiwan has now become a democratic country, Chen said, there is no reason for anybody to continue living under the "shadow of hatred."
He said, "We should not forget history, but we must forgive ignorance and misunderstanding of the past and face the present with compassion, love and tolerance."

Through joint efforts, Chen said that he believes human rights will be further respected and protected in Taiwan and expressed his hope that no tragedies like the 2-28 Incident will ever happen again.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY BOUND FOR RECOVERY IN SECOND QUARTER: CEPD OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy may show signs of recovery in the second quarter and could well be on the way to getting back on its feet in the third quarter, a government official said Wednesday.

Hu Chung-ying, director of the Economic Research Department under the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said Taiwan's relations with mainland China and political stability are the two prime factors which will have an impact on the expected economic recovery.
Meanwhile, the CEPD issued major economic indicators for the local economy in January, which indicate that an economy recovery is underway.

The January leading indicator index, which gauges economic activities for the next three to six months, increased by 1.5 percent from December to 98.3 points, the fourth-consecutive monthly rise and the highest level since Jan. 2001. The January coincident index rose by 3.2 percent month-on-month to 100.9 points, the same level posted in March 2001.

At the same time, the January composite indicator, which reflects current economic conditions, flashed a "blue light" in a five-color rating system on the performance of the domestic economy for the 14th consecutive month at 15 points. It is an indication that Taiwan's economy has not yet fully regained its momentum.

DOC.HEADLINE: DGBAS PREDICTS UNEMPLOYMENT RATE TO IMPROVE IN THIRD QUARTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment situation was better in January, but an official from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Wednesday that Taiwan may not be out of the woods until the third quarter.
Chen Chin-cheng, a DGBAS official, attributed the drop in January's unemployment rate mainly to higher demand for workers in the manufacturing and construction sectors.
The unemployment rate is expected to further decline in February thanks to the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday and the need for temporary workers during that time, he said.
However, he warned that the unemployment rate could surge in March after the temporary workers have been laid off.
The unemployment rate fell in January for the third consecutive month and could fall further in the third quarter, the official said.

He maintained that the unemployment situation as a whole has not improved yet, but after the third quarter things may improve. The DGBAS estimated that the unemployment rate for this year will be 5 percent.
Vice Premier Lin Hsin-yi has said he hopes this year's unemployment rate can be held at 4.5 percent.

According to statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level DGBAS, the island's unemployment rate stood at 5.14 percent in January, with the number of unemployed reaching 1.14 million, a drop of 34,000 over the previous month.

The number of those who lost their jobs in January because of factory shutdowns or downsizing was 277,000, nearly the same as December of last year. The figure stopped rising for the second month after rising for 16 consecutive months.
Meanwhile, the DGBAS statistics also show that among those unemployed in January, their average unemployed period was 30.4 weeks, reflecting the difficulty of finding a job.

Keelung City, in northern Taiwan, registered the highest unemployment rate of 5.55 percent. The rates in some counties, including Chiayi and Tainan, were under 4 percent because of the winter harvest.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAD OF LAFAYETTE WARSHIP PROBE MAY CONSIDER DEFENSE POSTING

TEXT.P: Kang Ning-hsiang, a senior member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and a member of the Control Yuan said Wednesday that he would consider accepting the post of vice minister of national defense after the investigation report into allegations of irregularities surrounding the purchase of six French Lafayette-class frigates is published.
Kang is currently chairman of the National Defense Committee of the Control Yuan.
Kang presides over a five-member ad hoc task force of the Control Yuan who are investigating allegations of payoffs and possible murder involving the purchase of warships from the French in 1992.
The task force is expected to make public an investigation report on the matter in mid-March, officials said.

Kang and other officials visited Fredrick Chien, president of the Control Yuan -- the body that oversees the government -- before Chinese Lunar New Year's day -- Feb. 12 this year -- where Kang told Chien that he could change jobs within the government, according to officials at the Control Yuan.

Kang told Chien that he did not rule out the possibility of taking the post of vice minister of national defense, the sources said, adding that Chien said he would support whatever decision Kang made.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF HEAD EXTENDS CONDOLENCE TO ARATS CHIEF OVER HIS WIFE'S ILLNESS

TEXT.P: Koo Chen-fu, the head of Taiwan's quasi-official body in charge of cross-strait negotiations, sent a letter of condolence Wednesday to his mainland counterpart after learning that his wife has fallen seriously ill.
Koo, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), faxed the message to Wang Daohan, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).
Besides extending his concern over Wang's wife, Koo also expressed his hope that Wang and he will meet again to talk about the old days. Koo last met Wang in Shanghai in 1998 on a private visit.
The two held the first "Koo-Wang talks" in April 1993 in Singapore.

In June 1995, Beijing indefinitely postponed the second Koo-Wang talks originally scheduled for July 1995 to protest then-President Lee Teng-hui's visit to his alma mater, Cornell University of the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTRY TO HELP KEY FOREIGNERS GET PERMANENT RESIDENCY

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien said Wednesday that he has instructed his ministry to come up with amendments to the immigration laws to enable foreign experts in high technology or those have made significant contributions to Taiwan to obtain permanent residency.

During a visit to the Bureau of Immigration, Yu said he is aiming to produce amendments by the end of March to allow prominent foreign individuals to become permanent residents of Taiwan on a case-by-case basis.
Yu visited Bjarne Gislefoss, co-founder of the Puli Christian Hospital, and his wife in Nantou, central Taiwan last week to better understand their residency problems.

He said the Norwegian couple, who have dedicated most of their life to serving people in Taiwan, have lived on and off in Taiwan for nearly 50 years, but have not received permanent residency because of the stringent restrictions stipulated in immigration laws.

Under current Taiwan law, foreigners who have legally and continuously lived in Taiwan for seven years and have spent over 270 days per year on the island are eligible to apply for permanent residency.

"Now times have changed and Taiwan has become a part of the global village," Yu said, adding that he has instructed the Population Administration and National Police Administration (NPA) to complete the revisions to the immigration laws as soon as possible.

Last month, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Apollo Chen said he would propose an amendment to allow foreigners who have stayed in Taiwan legally for over 20 years and who have spent over 183 days per year during 10 of those years on the island to be eligible to apply for permanent residency.

Chang Chi, a section chief of the NPA, said foreign experts in high technology are not as likely to work in Taiwan if they cannot obtain permanent residency. Chang said that the NPA has considered allowing some prominent foreign individuals to be exempt from certain restrictions in the immigration laws.
Chang added that the NPA will also form a special commission to screen applications.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND SHIP LEGALLY DELIVERS CARGO DIRECTLY TO KINMEN

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese cargo ship reached Kinmen from Xiamen with a cargo of river sand Wednesday, becoming the first legal mainland freighter to reach the offshore island since the "mini three links" of trade, postal and transport links between the two sides opened in January last year.
The 2,000-ton "Zhong Zhou" was carrying 1,940 metric tons of river sand ordered by Kinmen Tungfu Enterprise. It left Xiamen Port at 10:55 a.m. and reached Kinmen at 1:50 p.m.

Over the past year, cargo ships belonging to mainland China or other countries had carried cargoes to Kinmen from Xiamen 21 times, but all voyages were illegal and were undertaken without official permission from government authorities.
Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng said that the "Zhong Zhou" was the first freighter to reach Kinmen from Xiamen with official permits from both sides.
He expected that the voyage would pave the way for future legal transactions of commodities between Kinmen and Xiamen.
Lee also hoped that the ROC government will allow mainland Chinese cargo vessels to carry commodities to the mainland during its return trip.
An additional 2,000 metric tons of river sand ordered by the Kinmen company will be shipped to Kinmen from Xiamen in the coming days by the 3,700-ton "Ding Jiang."

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC COMMUNITY LEADERS SUPPORT EFFORTS TO STIMULATE ECONOMY

TEXT.P: The leaders of the six local leading economic organizations, including the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, put their heads together Wednesday to pledge their full support for the government's efforts to stimulate the economy.

They expressed the hope that the island will achieve a 3.5 percent real economic growth rate this year, higher than the 2.7 percent growth rate set by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, and will recover to the 6 percent level next year.

The leaders also decided to appoint four legislators with different political affiliations to serve as deputy secretaries-general of the Council of Industry and Commerce which was formed by the leaders.

The four legislators are Lin Chung-cheng of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, Lee Chia-chin of the Kuomintang, Chiu Yi of the People First Party and Wu Tung-sheng of the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

Meanwhile, the economic community leaders approved a set of recommendations to be submitted to the government for reference. The recommendations consist of three parts: government organizational reform, financial and monetary reforms, and utilization of land.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDE SAYS PRESIDENT WOULD BE GLAD TO ADDRESS LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian would be happy to give a state of the nation address to the Legislative Yuan -- defusing a possible political showdown, a staff member at the Presidential Office said Wednesday.
Huang Chih-fang, director for public affairs at the Presidential Office, said Chen welcomes and appreciates any opportunity to outline his visions for the country to the people.
The exact details of how Chen's address could be delivered is up to the legislature and the president will respect its decision if it is in accordance with the ROC Constitution, Huang said.

Chen's office made the statement after lawmakers of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) proposed Wednesday to ask Chen to make a report on the state of the nation and explain his ideas about revising the Constitution.

The proposal by the TSU, which is a group sympathetic to Chen's administration, drew a cautious reaction from Chen's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) earlier the same day, although such an address to the legislature is provided for in the Constitution.

Before Chen announce through his aide that he would be willing to address the legislature, DPP whip at the lawmaking body Wang Tu said that the TSU should think carefully about what it is asking since the party may be inadvertently painting the president into a corner by the request.

Should Chen decide to turn down the offer to speak to the legislature, Wang said, it could be seen by opposition parties as a snub of the legislature and could result in political fallout -- even though the Constitution does not require the president to accept an offer to speak before the legislature.
Chen's announcement later, however, seems to have avoided any possible political finger-pointing.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTRY WILL REVIEW LOTTERY AFTER SIX MONTHS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance will wait six months to see whether it is necessary to reduce the current lottery drawings from two times a week to one, Minster of Finance Lee Yung-san said Wednesday.
Lee said his ministry has asked the Taipei Bank, which operates the lotto, to withdraw its television commercials for the lotto to try to cool down the public's zeal for the lottery.
He made the comments after lawmakers suggested earlier in the day to reducing the frequency of the drawings.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE DETAIN 25 ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS FROM MAINLAND CHINA OFF KEELUNG

TEXT.P: Twenty-five illegal immigrants from mainland China were detained Wednesday night by police aboard a Taiwanese fishing ship off the northern coast near Keelung.

The police said that the operation was jointly conducted by the Keelung Office of the Coast Guard Administration and the Police Department of the city government following tips that the mainlanders would use the cover of night to try to land in the area.
The detainees include 19 men and six women, the police said, adding that most of them came from Pingtan and Fuzhou of Fujian province.
According to preliminary investigations, all the women are in their 20s. The police suspect that they were trying to sneak into Taiwan to be prostitutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEADS OF 12 COMMITTEES IN LEGISLATIVE YUAN CHOSEN

TEXT.P: Thirty-six lawmakers were chosen Wednesday to head the 12 committees in the Legislative Yuan, with three conveners for each committee.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which is the biggest party controlling 89 seats in the 225-seat legislature, got the lion's share, or 14 seats, after all four parties in the legislature agreed to share the seats for conveners in proportion to the numbers of their lawmakers.
The major opposition Kuomintang got 12 seats, the People First Party (PFP) won seven seats and the Taiwan Solidarity Union three seats.

DPP whip at the legislature Ke Chien-ming said the multiparty agreement on sharing the seats for conveners bodes well for friendly relations between the ruling and opposition parties in the Legislative Yuan.
Notable among the new conveners is Sisy Chen, an independent who has been supported by the PFP. She was chosen as a convener for the committee on diplomacy.
A PFP official said the party backed Chen's bid for the seat after she agreed to join the PFP caucus at the legislature but not a member of the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 28, or the 17th day of the first month of the Year of the Horse according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: John Wesley, the British religious leader who founded Methodism in 1738, signs the "deed of declaration" formalizing the establishment of the Wesleyan faith.
1825: Russia and Britain sign a treaty settling the border between Canada and Alaska, then a Russian possession.
1854: U.S. opponents of slavery, meeting at Ripon, Wisconsin, agree to form a new political party. The Republican Party was born later in 1854.
1900: The British Labour Representation Committee, which later would become the Labour Party, is founded with Ramsay MacDonald as its secretary.
1909: Linus Pauling, the American chemist and physicist who won the Nobel Prize for chemistry in 1934 and the Noble Peace Prize in 1962, is born.
1921: Russian sailors of the Baltic Fleet and workers at Kronstadt naval base rise up against the communist government.
1922: Britain declares Egypt's independence, while it retains control of the Suez Canal.
1942: Japanese troops land in Java, Indonesia after the Japanese sink two more Allied ships on the second day of the Battle of Java Sea.
1946: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Shih-chieh and French Ambassador to China Jacques Meyrier sign the "Sino-French Treaty Regarding the Revocation of French Extraterritorial Jurisdiction and Related Privileges in China" in Chungking.
1947: Rioting breaks out in Taipei, following an incident in which an old woman was brutally beaten by police for violating the tobacco monopoly by selling untaxed cigarettes.
1951: The Republic of China Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Dr. Chien Shih-liang as president of National Taiwan University.
1956: Indonesia and India sign a mutual aid treaty.
1967: American editor and publisher Henry Robinson Luce dies at the age of 69. He co-founded Time in 1923 and later founded Fortune in 1930 and Sports Illustrated in 1954.
1973: Forty-four additional members of the ROC Legislative Yuan are sworn in.
1976: Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines and Thailand sign a treaty of friendship and cooperation.
1987: President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines announces full and complete amnesty to communist rebels who lay down their weapons.
1992: The ROC and the Philippines sign an official investment guarantee agreement to protect Taiwan businesspeople investing in the Philippines.
1992: The United Nations Security Council approves a peacekeeping force for Cambodia.
1995: ROC President Lee Teng-hui gives an apology to the families of the victims of the Feb. 28 Incident in 1947 during a ceremony at Taipei's New Park, where a monument commemorating the tragedy was built with government sponsorship.
1996: Russia becomes the 39th member of the Council of Europe.
1996: Britain's Princess Diana agrees to divorce her estranged husband Prince Charles.
1997: An earthquake hits western Pakistan, claiming more than 35 lives, while another earthquake in Iran destroys over 20 villages and kills nearly 1,000 people.
2000: The Philippine government urges Taipei to return to the negotiating table to resolve the fresh aviation dispute between the two sides and proposes that the talks be reopened in Manila between March 1-2.
2000: Chen Li-an, former president of the Control Yuan, formally makes known his intention to support Vice President Lien Chan, the presidential candidate of the ruling Kuomintang.
2001: Taipei and Shanghai authorities agree to further bolster sisterhood exchanges between the two mucipalities, beginning with a student exchange program.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When I find a man agrees with me in what I say without being able to profit by it by changing his conduct, or one who is pleased with my parable without being able to apply the moral to himself -- I can do nothing for such a man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The China Times:
In a policy about-face, supplementary teaching materials and selective courses will not be included in academic proficiency tests for junior high school students.
The United Daily News:
Junior high school proficiency tests will not include supplementary teaching materials.
The Liberty Times:
President Chen calls for love and forgiveness in commemorating the 2-28 Incident.
The Taiwan Daily:
President Chen is willing to deliver state-of-the-nation report to the Legislature.
The Central Daily News:
The opposition KMT urges the government to take steps to break the cross-strait impasse.
The China Post:
President Chen has consoling sentiments for tragic anniversary.
The Taiwan News:
Arts can heal 2-28 wounds, says President Chen.
The Taipei Times:
Cabinet says it's tackling water crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER YU PRESIDES OVER CEREMONY MARKING FEB. 28 TRAGEDY
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, southern Taiwan, Feb. 28 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun presided over a ceremony at a memorial park in downtown Chiayi Thursday marking the 55th anniversary of the 228 Incident that led to a bloody crackdown by authorities and the infamous "white terror" era in Taiwan.

Unrest broke out in Taipei and then spread around Taiwan following a free-for-all scuffle Feb. 28, 1947 triggered by a conflict between a police officer and a peddler who violated the tobacco monopoly imposed by authorities.

Yu offered incense and a white lily plant to a monument erected at the Chiayi 228 Memorial Park to commemorate citizens who were killed during the 228 Incident and during the ensuing "white terror" that lasted for years islandwide.
In his address at the ceremony, Yu called for forgiveness while at the same time a remembrance of the lessons that history has taught.

In Chiayi City, like Taipei, a great number of citizens -- many of them among the social elite -- were victimized during the "white terror" years. It was the first city in Taiwan where a 228 monument was erected and a memorial park developed to commemorate the sad incident.

Yu, meanwhile, announced that 228 Memorial Day will become a national holiday, with no work or classes, as of 2003 to clear away the confusion surrounding this year's 228 Memorial Day when local governments in many cities remained undecided as to whether the day should be a holiday or simply a day of observance while schools and businesses remain open.
In Taipei City, Mayor Ma presided over a commemoration ceremony held at the Taipei 228 Memorial Park.

Addressing the occasion, Ma said the 228 Incident was not an "ethnic conflict" between the "Taiwanese and the people from the mainland" as he said has long been misperceived. He said the incident was a conflict resulting from the authorities' suppression of ordinary people.

Noting that many historical accounts show that many Taiwanese helped the "mainlanders" and vice versa during the challenging times, Ma called for empathy and brotherhood among all people in Taiwan, regardless of where they are from.

In a similar function held in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, Mayor Frank Hsieh also called for the people of Taiwan to be mindful of the historical lessons of the 228 Incident, which left some 20,000 people, mostly members of the social elite, dead or missing, and resulted in a long standoff afterward between the authorities and the private sector.
In the central city of Taichung, Mayor Jason Hu called for love and peace during his address at a memorial ceremony as a means for the people of Taiwan to face history and the future.
"All of us should show respect for life and learn to love and forgive," Hu noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR MA TO RECEIVE WCIT AWARD FOR TAIPEI'S CYBER SERVICES

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou left for Australia Thursday to receive an award from the World Conference of Information Technology (WCIT) in recognition of the cyber services that the Taipei city government offers its residents.
Ma will receive the Outstanding Governmental Sci-Tech Award from the WCIT on behalf of the Taipei city government, which since late 2000 has championed building Taipei into a cyber city.

The Taipei city government has computerized its services for the city's residents by opening 418 windows on the Internet from where Taipei citizens can download information or get access to information in 109 service categories.

Meanwhile, the city government is also aiming to build 800 public Internet service stations citywide by the end of this year to allow Taipei citizens to surf the Web more conveniently. As of today, 380 stations have already been established.

With the implementation of these services, the city government is now preparing to premiere the Taipei Portal in March to provide instant and comprehensive information regarding weather, traffic conditions, travel affairs, consumer news and government policies.

Representatives from the information technology industry in 41 nations and areas around the world are gathering in Australia's southern city of Adelaide for the annual meeting of the WCIT -- widely renowned as the "Olympics of the world information technology industry."
Ma is expected to give a speech during a WCIT award-presentation ceremony slated for March 1.

In addition to taking part in the WCIT gathering, Ma will take time to visit Taipei's sister city of Perth on the west coast of Australia and discuss city affairs and urban development with Perth Mayor Peter Nattarass.
He will also meet personally with Melbourne Mayor John So and Adelaide Mayor Alfred Huang, both of whom are Chinese-Australians, to exchange views on matters of mutual concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUNDATION FORMS WATCH GROUP TO COUNTER EHTNIC DIVISIONS

TEXT.P: A foundation that advocates peace across the Taiwan Strait announced Thursday the establishment of a group to promote ethnic reconciliation as Taiwan marked the 55th anniversary of the 2-28 Incident.

Chien Hsi-chieh, executive director of the Peacetime Foundation of Taiwan, which started a "reconciliation day" last year, said that initially the team will observe political figures and will passively appeal to people to stop using words or acting to incite ethnic rivalry.
The team will present reports on its findings and will publish the names of candidates for public office who have used racial epithets to incite voters, he said.

In the future, the team will be more active in promoting ethnic harmony with the goal of eliminating the use of ethnic divisions as a campaign strategy in the year-end mayoral elections and the 2004 presidential election.

The foundation will also monitor the use of racial slurs and words of hatred that are posted on online forums used by university students, as well as radio and TV call-in programs. These terms fall under the heading of "words of ethnic violence," according to the foundation.
Chien noted that some people used "dehumanizing" words, such as mainlander pigs, Taiwan dogs, aboriginal children, and PRC dogs to defile other ethnic groups.

Cultural commentator Ping Lu, who was also at the event Thursday, said that establishing an watch group on the anniversary of the 2-28 Incident is significant. He said that Taiwan easily falls prey to ethnic divisions, adding that the most likely crisis in Taiwan will be the schism along the lines of ethnicity.
Ping said that the foundation is hoping that the "ethnic reconciliation" campaign will restrain people and help awaken them to the potent problem.

The tragic incident in Taipei on Feb. 28, 1947 was triggered by a dispute between a police officer and a peddler selling cigarette which violated the tobacco monopoly. Chaos quickly spread around Taiwan and led to the infamous "white terror" that lasted for years islandwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: HARD TIMES FOR CHINA AIRLINES AS IT SELLS AGING PLANE FOR SCRAP

TEXT.P: Analysts say that the aviation industry has seen the worst of the economic slowdown, but things got so bad for China Airlines (CAL) after the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in the United States that the Taiwan carrier had to sell one of its aging planes for scrap.

Wishing to upgrade its fleet, CAL planned to sell a 21-year-old Boeing 747-200 cargo plane for US$28 million last year. But CAL was forced to cut the price in half immediately after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
