But even at that price there were no buyers so the former national carrier dismantled the plane and sold the pieces for US$100,000 as scrap. CAL said that this was preferable to paying to maintain the plane.

CAL officials said that fortunately, the aviation industry has begun to bottom out since the beginning of the year, adding that CAL's revenues in January were NT$280 million (US$7.97 million), better than its targeted NT$110 million (US$3.13 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TRADE WITH MAINLAND CHINA IN 2001 DOWN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade with mainland China in 2001 was estimated at US$29.963 billion, down 7.4 percent from the previous year, according to statistics released by the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT).
The number accounted for 13 percent of the island's total foreign trade in that year that was up 1.8 percentage points from the previous year, the statistics showed.

Taiwan's exports to mainland China in 2001 stood at about US$24.061 billion, a decrease of 8 percent from 2000. The decreasing scale accounted for 19.6 percent of Taiwan's total exports in that year that was 2 percentage points higher than that in 2000, the figures reveal.

Taiwan's imports from mainland China in 2001 were approximately US$5.902 billion, a year-on-year decrease of 5.2 percent. The number accounted for 5.5 percent of Taiwan's total imports in that year that was up 1.1 percentage points from the previous year.
The BOFT attributed the decrease in both the exports to and imports from the mainland mainly to the recession of the global economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD MEDICAL STUDENT CONFERENCE SLATED FOR LATE JULY IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: In a bid to solicit global support for Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization (WHO), domestic medical student groups have managed to arrange for the international annual conference to be held in Taipei from July 26 to Aug. 2.

According to a local student representative, Cheng Ming-lung, the "World Medical Student Alliance" is a non-governmental umbrella grouping of the WHO and this year's annual conference of the alliance is expected to attract over 800 medical students from around the world.
Participants will release their reports and give keynote speeches to boost mutual understanding and exchange opinions during the eight-day conference.
Meanwhile, a 38-member delegation composed of Taiwanese medical students will head for Yugoslavia next week to take part in a meeting ahead of the world yearly conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: WATER SHORTAGE MAY FORCE HIGH-TECH FIRMS OUT OF TAIWAN (I)

TEXT.P: The lingering water shortage problem may force companies in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park -- the heartland of Taiwan's high-technology industry -- out of the island, a group of corporate executives warned Thursday.

The high-tech CEOs made the warning at a colloquium with Minister of Economic Affairs Christine Tsung, National Science Council (NSC) Chairman Wei Che-ho, Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin, and other officials as well as legislators elected from the Hsinchu constituency.

A drought in northern Taiwan in recent months has hit microchips companies in the Hsinchu park, whose daily water demand reaches 130,000 tons. The unusual scarcity of rainfall this month has resulted in a daily water shortfall of 8,000 tons in the region.

Although relevant government agencies have tried to increase the water supply to the island's high-tech bastion through a pipeline linked to the Feitsui Reservoir in Taipei, some 100 kilometers to the north, the water shortage has continued to trouble corporate executives inside the park.

In an effort to allay their worries, Minister Tsung said at Thursday's seminar that a fallow project covering 18,000 hectares of farmland in Hsinchu and neighboring Taoyuan County will begin Friday and will last until the end of May to address the park's water problem.
Tsung said the fallow program was worked out after consultations among the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), the Council of Agriculture (COA), the NSC and other relevant government agencies.

"The fallow program will save an average of 600,000 to 650,000 tons of water daily used to irrigate rice paddies in the Hsinchu-Taoyuan areas," Tsung said. "The saved water will be able to satisfy the demands of information technology (IT) companies and ordinary households in the drought-hit region until May when Taiwan will enter its annual monsoon or 'plum rain' season."
Tsung's announcement, however, failed to calm corporate executives present at the seminar.

Huang Yen-chu, vice president of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. and managing director of an association of IT makers in the Hsinchu park, took the lead in complaining about the water-supply problem.

"We have long been troubled by frequent water shortages, particularly before and after the Chinese New Year holiday. I simply can't understand why the government has failed to resolve the problem once and for all," Huang said.
With the park's production increasing steadily, Huang said, its water consumption has also been skyrocketing. "Why can't the government improve its overall water supply system after all these years?"

Noting that the water shortage is not just a regional issue, but rather a nationwide headache, Huang said the MOEA should conduct a thorough review of the island's water resources distribution system.

"We shouldn't have to rely on fallow projects to satisfy the industrial sector's water demand," Huang said. "Worse yet, the upcoming fallow project can only help the Hsinchu park's operations until the end of May. It remains uncertain whether the 'plum rain' season will provide enough rainfall to help us out."

Speaking on the same occasion, Lee Ching-chao, president of Taisil Electronics Materials Corp., said many companies in the park have to hire water trucks to transport water from neighboring counties to meet their own demand, increasing production costs.

"Moreover, the price has continued rising amid the current dry spell, surging from NT$3,000 (US$85.71) per 30 tons to NT$7,000 Wednesday," Lee said, adding that he is worried that if the water-shortage problem cannot be resolved, IT firms in the park may be unable to keep their businesses in Taiwan. (By sofia Wu) To Be Continued

DOC.HEADLINE: WATER SHORTAGE IN HSINCHU (II)

TEXT.P: In response, Tsung said that as a provisional pipeline linking the park to a reservoir in Pingchen, Taoyuan County was inaugurated Thursday, companies in the park will no longer have to hire water trucks from now on. She added that a permanent pipeline linking the park to the Pingchen Reservoir will come on line two months later to increase the park's water supply.

As for Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng's demand that government compensation to farmland to be affected by the fallow project be increased to NT$80,000 per hectare, Tsung said the COA will discuss the issue with the county government and other relevant agencies before making a final decision in line with current laws and budget rules.

According to an earlier COA announcement, cash reimbursements for farmland to be left fallow in the Hsinchu and Taoyuan areas will be NT$46,000 per hectare and an addition NT$7,000 per hectare will be given for farmland which has already been planted with rice.

DOC.HEADLINE: BORLAND CHAIRMAN SPEAKS ON HIGH-TECH DEVELOPMENTS IN TAIPEI FORUM

TEXT.P: Future high-tech developments will revolve around the integration of biotech and information technology, but success will depend on their commercialization and their ability to meet market demands, Borland Software Chairman William F. Miller said in Taipei Thursday.

Miller said at a roundtable forum on the industrial outlook of the Asia-Pacific region that Silicon Valley has been a high-tech breeding ground for the past several decades, but future opportunities lie not in the development of newer technologies but rather in how these technologies are commercialized and introduced into business enterprises.

He said that combining biotech with IT will open new realms of discovery like biochips, while progress in nanotechnology will help lower the manufacturing costs of microchips and information products.

Miller, a professor and former provost of Stanford University, was invited to speak at the roundtable by Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute to provide local officials, experts and scholars with a more global view of future high-tech developments.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUTH COMMISSION URGES LOCAL YOUNG PEOPLE TO BE VOLUNTEERS

TEXT.P: The National Youth Commission (NYC) of the Republic of China Thursday urged young people in Taiwan to join the activities of Global Youth Service Day to make contributions to improving the world.

Officials of the NYC said Global Youth Service Day will be celebrated April 26-28, and the NYC welcomes the participation of local young people to build their communities and their world through voluntary service.

Global Youth Service Day is an annual global event organized by Youth Service America and the Global Youth Action Network in April 2000. The event has the participation of 31 international organizations and people from more than 100 countries.
Last year, more than three million young volunteers from 117 countries joined in the social service.
The NYC called on young people between the ages of 15 and 30 to participate in the Global Youth Service Day, and those interested in the activities can visit its Web site: www.gysd.nyc.gov.tw.
The Cabinet-level NYC said young volunteers can present their suggestions for improving their communities in various aspects including economy, education, social welfare, culture and nature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO INTRODUCE `.GAME.TW' SECOND-LEVEL DOMAIN IN JULY

TEXT.P: A new ".game.tw" second-level domain will be open for registration beginning July, Taiwan Network Information Center decided Wednesday.

The move will help promote the development of the local game industry and is primarily aimed at game companies, Internet cafe owners and online game consumers, the center's executive director, Chen Wen-sheng, said.
According to center, Taiwan currently has 93,423 registered domains for ".com.tw," 1,325 for ".net.tw," 3,750 for ".org.tw" and 18,138 for ".idv.tw."

The local game industry has seen an annual composite growth of 69 percent over the past two years, according to SEEDnet, a local Internet service provider established by the state-run Institute for Information Industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAY BECOME HUB FOR BIOTECHNOLOGY INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan stands a good chance of becoming an investment conduit and manufacturing hub for the biotechnology industry, a local industrial technology expert said Thursday.

Lee Chung-hsi, deputy director of Taiwan's state-funded Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI), made the remarks at the opening of BioBusiness Asia 2002, co-sponsored by the ITRI's Biomedicine Center and the Biotechnology Industry Development Association.

Lee said the biotechnology industry has gradually grown in major Asian countries, including Taiwan, Singapore and India. In the past, Asian countries have organized many international biotech symposiums.

"But those seminars tended to focus on technological developments," Lee said. "Moreover, due to the lack of a transparent mechanism and a viable conduit to mediate international cooperation, Asian biotech firms have difficulties acquiring international capital to help finance their development projects."
In contrast, Lee said, the ongoing two-day seminar will focus on biotech investment issues and potential genetic technology development opportunities.
Noting that the current seminar is the first of its kind ever held in Taiwan, Lee said he hopes that similar forums will be held annually in the future.
"We also look forward to seeing the forum become Asia's largest and most famous intermediary platform for biotech investment," he added.
Given Taiwan's exuberant venture capital investment environment, Lee went on, the island should be able to emerge as one of Asia's most important biotech investment and development hubs.

Speaking on the same occasion, Shih Yen-hsiang, director of the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said despite Taiwan's economic recession last year, the island's overall investment in biotech industry still reached NT$22 billion in 2001 under the government's encouragement and promotion.
"The investment amount will exceed NT$30 billion this year," Shih said, adding that he hopes the current forum will attract even more foreign investors in Taiwan's burgeoning biotech industry.

The current forum brings together more than 200 senior executives and researchers from 24 biotech firms in eight countries -- the United States, Israel, India, Australia, South Korea, Japan, Singapore and Taiwan -- to discuss relevant topics. Among the participating companies are several world-renowned biotech venture companies, including MPM Capital, MDS Capital and Becton.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU PLANS TO PUT FORTH BILL ON ADMINISTRATIVE DISTRICTS RESTRUCTURING

TEXT.P: A legislator of the tiny opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Thursday that his party plans to come up with a bill on restructuring Taiwan's administrative districts for legislative deliberation in the near future.
Liao Pen-yen, a TSU lawmaker from the Taipei County constituency, said the existing administrative districts were demarcated decades ago under Kuomintang rule.

"The demarcation has become obsolete with the island's economic and urban development over the past five decades," Liao noted, adding that many city and county governments should be merged or integrated to improve operational efficiency and make the best use of the country's resources.

Moreover, Liao said, since the Taiwan Provincial Government has been "marginalized," it has become meaningless to define Taipei and Kaohsiung -- the island's two largest cities -- as "special municipalities" under direct jurisdiction of the Cabinet.

"The reality is that all cities and counties on the island are now under the jurisdiction of the Cabinet. None of them are under the jurisdiction of the provincial government," he stressed. "Therefore, Taipei and Kaohsiung should be deprived of their 'special municipalities' status."
The TSU controls only 13 seats in the 225-member Legislative Yuan. Its bills must receive the support of major political parties before they can become laws.

Wang Tuoh, legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said he himself supports the TSU's proposal. "Nevertheless, restructuring involves many complicated problems, it needs further discussion," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHECK DEFAULT RATE DROPS IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: The check default rate in January in Taiwan reached 0.66 percent, the lowest level since 1996, according to statistics compiled by the Central Bank of China (CBC).

There were 109,983 bounced checks in January, according to CBC statistics. This is a drop of 0.14 percent over that of December of last year. The value of the bad checks also declined to NT$18.5 billion from NT$20.2 billion registered the previous month.

Tsai Chun-hsiung, vice director-general of the CBC's banking department, attributed the drop in the check default rate to the flourishing local stock market that has enabled corporations or individuals to transfer and raise money easier.

Among different industries with check default rates, that of the business and construction sectors increased by 1.4 and 0.04 percent, respectively. Manufacturing and financial industries declined by 0.63 and 0.49 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOVERNMENT DONATES POLICE CARS TO PARAGUAY
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Feb. 28 (CNA) (By Wang Ching-mei and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government donated 25 police cars to Paraguay's police Thursday, according to sources with the ROC Embassy in Paraguay.
ROC Ambassador to Paraguay Yen Ping-fan presented the cars to Sixto Mauro, Paraguay's police chief, in a ceremony attended by Paraguayan President Luis Angel Gonzalez Macchi, the sources said.
The donation is part of a batch of 35 police cars donated by the ROC government, the remaining 10 of which will be donated at a later date, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL FRANCHISE EXHIBITION OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: An international exhibition of franchises opened at the Taipei World Trade Center Thursday for four days.

The third Taipei International Chain and Franchise Exhibition has brought together 120 franchise companies from around the world and provides a good chances for the island's surging unemployed population to begin a new business on their own, according to its organizer, the Association of Franchise Promotions.
Lin Yi-chun, president of the association, said the show is designed especially to give jobless, middle-aged people a second chance at a career.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER DEMANDS SOLUTION TO HSINCHU WATER PROBLEM

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Christine Tsung instructed Thursday the Hsinchu County government to resolve a land acquisition problem in order to help pipe water from Taipei to the region, which has been hard hit by a severe drought.

Tsung said she expects the problem to be resolved within two months, as the Hsinchu county government will seek to acquire the land where a 300 meter-long pipe must be laid in order to allow the Taipei Water Department to pipe water from the Feitsui Reservoir to Hsinchu, home to a large number of Taiwan's leading hi-tech companies.

According to the Water Resources Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the normal daily water supply of 370,000 tons can be maintained until late May in the Hsinchu area after a large-scale water rationing was imposed Wednesday. But it pointed out that the water shortage may worsen if the rainfall continues to be scarce, as has been forecast by the Central Weather Bureau.

To help alleviate the situation, which has threatened the operations of many hi-tech firms in the region, the Executive Yuan made a decision a day earlier to leave 18,000 hectares of rice paddy in Hsinchu and Taoyuan fallow, a move will help save about 650,000 tons of water per day for the public and factories.

In addition, the Water Resources Bureau said the second-phase construction of the Paoshan Reservoir is slated to be completed in December 2004, which will increase the water supply by 590,000 tons per day for the greater Hsinchu area.

DOC.HEADLINE: JET TRANSFER FROM TAIWAN UP TO PHILIPPINES: U.S. PACIFIC COMMANDER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 27 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The U.S. commander of Pacific forces said Wednesday that it is up to the cash-strapped Philippines to decide if it is willing to accept the transfer of a batch of surplus F-5E jet fighters from Taiwan to boost its air defenses.

Adm. Dennis Blair made the comment at a House subcommittee meeting in response to an inquiry by U.S. Representative Dana Rohrabacher on his stance on the transfer proposal, which has been brought up in the past with no definite conclusion.
An aide to the California Republican said that Rohrabacher supports the proposal but has no intention of taking part in discussions between Taiwan and the Philippines on the issue.
The aircraft were assembled in Taiwan with U.S. parts and technology and require U.S. agreement before they can be transferred to a third country.
Rohrabacher is a senior member of the House International Relations Committee and serves as vice chairman of the East Asia and Pacific subcommittee.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR "DEEPENING" HISTORICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF 228

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called Thursday for deepening the historical significance of the February 28 Incident as the best way to heal the wounds caused by the outrage.

In a ceremony marking the 55th anniversary of the incident, Chen said the government's apology to and compensation for the families of the victims is not enough and the government should put the tragedy to good account by pressing home its historical significance.
Without the home-grown campaign for democracy, Chen said, the families of the victims would never have seen justice done.
As part of the commemoration, Chen also presided over a wedding ceremony.

The February 28 incident took place in 1947, when a government crackdown on untaxed cigarettes triggered islandwide riots. The government quashed the disturbances with an iron fist and thousands people were arrested or executed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO PRESENT BILL CALLING FOR HALVING OF NUMBER OF LEGISLATORS

TEXT.P: A leader of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Thursday that the party will present a bill to cut the number of Legislative Yuan members from 225 to 113.
Chen Chien-ming, deputy secretary-general of the TSU legislative caucus, told reporters that the TSU has collected over 80 signatories from legislators in support of the bill to be presented Friday.
Bills for this kind of constitutional amendment require the signatures of at least 25 percent of the legislature, or 56 legislators.
Chen admitted that the prospects for the bill are uncertain because it will have to be forwarded to the constitutional amendment committee of the Legislative Yuan for review.

Even if the bill is approved by the committee, it will still require the approval of more than 75 percent of the legislators present at a plenary session of the Legislative Yuan, which itself would require the participation of over 75 percent of the legislature.
Once it is approved by the Legislative Yuan, the bill will then need to be sent to the National Assembly for final decision.

As the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) are reluctant to cooperate with the TSU, Chen said he was not optimistic about the bill's prospects in the immediate future. The KMT and the PFP control half of the 225 seats in the Legislative Yuan.
The TSU, which has only 13 seats in the legislature, was formed last year by supporters of former President Lee Teng-hui, with halving the number of Legislative Yuan members among its main platforms.

In another development, Chen also said that his party has decided to postpone making a request that President Chen Shui-bian deliver a state of the nation report before the legislature, mainly because of opposition from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

As Premier Yu Shyi-kun has already delivered his administrative report to the Legislative Yuan and as the legislature has just completed the formation of various committees, Chen explained that the timing for the request is inappropriate.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPANISH CHAMBER ORCHESTRA TO PERFORM IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Orquestra de Cambra de L'Emporda -- hailed as the most representative interpreters of Spain's classical chamber music -- will kick off a series of Taiwan performances Friday.
The group will start its tour at Kaohsiung City's Chung Cheng Cultural Center and will perform in Taipei Sunday, playing pieces by Manuel de Falla, Turina and Toldra.
Chiang Hui, a Taiwan-born, Austria-trained violinist who will play solo, said she hopes to be able to present "the best music for the Taiwan audience."
The chamber orchestra was set up in 1988 and has toured Europe, the United States and Russia, winning many awards along the way.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROWTH SLOWS IN TAIPEI CONSUMER PRICE INDEX

TEXT.P: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) in Taipei City stood at 106.07 for last year, an increase of 0.43 percent over the 2000 figure and the second-lowest growth rate in five years, according to statistics compiled by the Taipei city government.

Officials of the city government's Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said that the slow growth in 2001 reflected relatively stable prices. The CPI is calculated based on prices of goods and services.
The statistics show that the prices of goods fell 0.66 percent in Taipei last year, while those of services increased by 1.46 percent.

The house-rental index -- included in the service sector -- registered a decline of 0.7 percent last year, while the price index of food increased by 0.48 percent, due mainly to the typhoons that made fruit and vegetables more expensive in the city, according to the statistics.
The officials noted that the slow CPI growth in Taipei was at odds with the overall CPI drop for Taiwan as a whole, indicating the increasing consumption by Taipei citizens.
Although Taipei's CPI has grown every year since 1997, growth rates have not exceeded 2 percent, which means prices have remained stable, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: RYDER MAY SET UP AIR MAINTENANCE COMPLEX IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Representatives of Ryder System, Inc., a U.S.-based provider of logistics, supply chain and transportation management solutions, and the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) of the Republic of China's Ministry of Economic Affairs signed a memorandum of understanding in Singapore Wednesday, pledging to cooperate in the establishment of an Asian Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul (MRO) Center and Aerospace Logistics Support Center complex in Taiwan.

The proposed project is intended to provide a receiving, storage and shipment complex for aerospace-related parts and components used in Taiwan's MRO Center and distributed to aerospace-related customers through the Asia-Pacific region.

Dr. David R.C. Chu, director of the IDB's Committee for Aviation & Space Industry Development (CASID), and Willy Lai, Ryder's Vice President & Managing Director for the Asia-Pacific region, inked the paper at a signing ceremony witnessed by ROC Representative to Singapore Ou Yang Jui Hsiung.
"This will be the first logistics center specialized in the aerospace field within the Asia-Pacific region," said Chu at the ceremony.

"Based on Taiwan's solid manufacturing base, our strategy is to combine local manufacturing industry with a high value-added aerospace service industry and turn Taiwan into a maintenance repair and overhaul and logistics center, echoing the Global Logistics Center policy of our government. " he added.
Ryder has nearly 30,000 employees worldwide and business operations on four continents, with annual sales of more than US$5 billion, Lai said.
Ryder currently serves customers all over the world including Northrop-Grumman, United Technologies, British Airways, and Lockheed Martin, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BIOTECH INDUSTRY SHOULD PLAY TO STRENGTHS: U.S. EXPERT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's biotech industry should not blindly pursue what is fashionable but should instead play to its own unique strengths and establish alliances with appropriate partners, Isis Pharmaceuticals CEO Stanley T. Crooke said in Taipei Thursday.

Crooke said at BioBusiness Asia 2002, a newly established forum for biotech companies in the region, that although the most popular direction for biotech companies at the moment is to create new drugs with new technologies, agricultural biotechnology might be an area in which Asian companies can excel.

He said that Taiwan's biotech industry has good opportunities for future development because the island's workers are innovative, professional and hardworking. Meanwhile, he continued, the government has wisely invested in the local biotech industry, while U.S.-educated specialists have been returning to Taiwan.

Crooke said that a company entering the biotech industry should seek the help of experienced talent, but he added that Taiwan's lack of large research-focused pharmaceutical companies might hamper its search for alliance partners around the globe.

Asked if Isis will look for partners or invest in Taiwan, Crooke said that this was only his first visit to the island and that no investment plans are in the works. However, he added that he will not rule out looking for alliance partners in Asia or Taiwan in the future.
Isis was recently given the prestigious industry Helix Award by the U.S. Biotechnology Industry Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. PACIFIC COMMANDER `CONCERNED' OVER TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The military situation in the Taiwan Strait is currently stable, but this and other flashpoints in Asia are still sources of concern, according to Adm. Dennis Blair, commander-in-chief of the U.S. Pacific Command.

The military balance across the Taiwan Strait, North Korea's missile proliferation and continued tension between nuclear neighbors India and Pakistan "still keep me awake at night and they keep my forces extremely busy," Blair told a congressional panel Wednesday.
He later added, however, that the current military situation in the Taiwan Strait is "quite stable."
"The fundamental situation is that the Chinese can cause a great deal of damage to Taiwan in ways that the Taiwanese armed forces and even the U.S. armed forces cannot stop," Blair said.
The possible methods of mainland attack on Taiwan include missiles, long-range aviation and sabotage, he said.
On the other hand, mainland China "cannot attain its stated goal of reunifying Taiwan by military force," he said. "They do not have the military capability to take and hold Taiwan."

"And that military reality," he said, "as long as the United States follows the Taiwan Relations Act and ensures that Taiwan has sufficient defense, and as long as my forces have the orders -- which they do have -- to be ready to support Taiwan if ordered, that situation is not going to change."
Blair said that he believes the increasing economic interaction and other contacts between Taiwan and the mainland will eventually lead to a mutually satisfactory agreement.
"In the meantime," he said, "I think we can ... make it very unattractive for China to conduct military aggression."
"Nothing I see in military developments over the year ... changes that view," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENEGAL PRESIDENT PRAISES ROC FOR PROVIDING TECHNICAL AID
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Feb. 27 (CNA) (By M.J. Tzou & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Senegal President Abdoulaye Wade Tuesday praised the Republic of China government for providing agricultural and technical assistance to his country, according to a report in Senegal's Le Quotidien de la Republique newspaper.

The daily said that Wade voiced his appreciation while chairing a meeting to hear a report by ROC Ambassador Tou Choou-seng on the results of Taiwan's agricultural and technical assistance to the African country.
The country's premier and several Cabinet ministers, as well as officials in charge of agricultural and industrial developments, were also present at the meeting.
Tou explained how ROC technicians in Senegal use the latest reprocessing techniques to help local people increase the value of their agricultural products.
The reprocessed products, which can be stored for long periods and exported, include dried fruit, popcorn, rice noodles, rice powder, peanut candy and peanut milk.
Tou said that reprocessing of agricultural products was an important factor in Taiwan's economic success and added that he believes Senegal's agriculture has a rosy future.
Wade reportedly expressed his thanks for Taiwan's technical assistance, which he said not only helps promote Senegal's agricultural development but also increases job opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC CONSTRUCTION OFFICE HEAD INSPECTS TUNNEL SITES

TEXT.P: The chairwoman of the Public Construction Commission inspected construction sites of the Shuashan Tunnel of the Taipei-Ilan Freeway Thursday.

Describing her visits to various construction sites along the tunnel route as a "trip of learning," Kuo Yao-chi praised the endeavor and diligence of the construction team and added that the visits have allowed her to gain "a full understanding" of the difficulties the team has to overcome.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun has placed the completion and inauguration of the 31-kilometer Taipei-Ilan Freeway high on the Cabinet's agenda.

National Public Works Bureau head Cheng Wen-lung said the completion of the 12.9-kilometer tunnel is slated for the end of 2005 after the construction project of the Taipei-Ilan Freeway commenced nearly 10 years ago. Completion of the freeway will allow the journey to be made in just 40 minutes, he added.
According to Cheng, the Shuashan Tunnel will be the world's third-longest tunnel after a tunnel linking Switzerland and Italy and another that links Switzerland and France.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP TO LAUNCH CAMPAIGN TO HELP POOR STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu will launch a charity bazaar March 8 -- Women's Day -- to raise funds to help poor students to complete their education, according to sources from the Vice President's Office.
Lu plans to integrate the efforts of 15 enterprises and organizations to help children who cannot afford to attend school, mainly because their parents are unemployed.
Students who have never received government or private sector subsidies and whose parents are unemployed or are unable to work because of disability will be eligible for subsidies from the funds.

Eligible senior high school students will be able to receive between NT$6,000 and NT$8,000 per semester, while elementary and junior high school students will be able to receive NT$4,000 per semester.
Lu's campaign has already borne fruit, with the Taiwanese Association of American donating US$50,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SEX DISCRIMINATION LAW TO TAKE EFFECT MARCH 8

TEXT.P: Discrimination against women will be illegal from March 8 -- Women's Day -- when a new law forbidding sex discrimination take effect.
The law, aimed at wiping out the "gender gap," outlaws discriminatory practices against women in recruiting, employment and payment.

Touting the law as a milestone in the country's human rights record, Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu said her council has already come up with seven complementary measures to ensure the full implementation of the law.
In the preliminary stages, however, the government will honor employers who fully comply with the law and complementary measures rather than punish those who fail to abide by them.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT GIVES KNEE SPEECH TO ASIAN ORTHOPEDISTS

TEXT.P: Asian people who often kneel to practice their religion are susceptible to knee injuries and need special medical care, President Chen Shui-bian told a group of medical experts Thursday.

Speaking at a dinner given to a group of orthopedists attending an Asia-Pacific conference on the knee, the president described the knee as "one of the most important joints in the human body." He noted that "it bears the whole weight of the body and is subject to tremendous force during vigorous activity."

Owing to the efforts of the orthopedists and the advancements in medical technology, the president said, it is now possible to replace the knee with an artificial one, which greatly improves the mobility of patients with damaged knees.

In addition to welcoming the knee specialists to Taiwan, the president urged his audience to buy Taiwan's cheap information products and to deepen their understanding of the country's culture by touring the National Palace Museum.
The conference, to open Friday, will end on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE BUDDHIST MISSION VISITS NANHUA UNIVERSITY
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, southern Taiwan, Feb. 28 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A 60-member mainland Chinese Buddhist mission visited Nanhua University in Dalin Township, Chiayi County Thursday, accompanied by Foguangshan Monastery founder Master Hsing Yun.
The delegation came to Taiwan Feb. 23 along with the Buddha's finger relic currently being exhibited at the Chinguangming Temple in Taipei County.
Shortly after their arrival at the university, the visitors were given a briefing on the founding and operations of the university by its president, Chen Miao-sheng.
Chen noted that the university was founded six years ago with contributions from some 1 million donors in a campaign initiated by Master Hsing Yun.

Hsing Yun expressed the hope that the university, located at the foot of Mt. Ali, will engage in more cultural exchanges with its namesake located at the foot of Mt. Heng in mainland China's Henan Province.

In the previous few days, members of the mainland Buddhist mission had visited the complex of the Dharma Drum Mountain in suburban Taipei, as well as the Tzu Chi Compassionate Relief Foundation in Hualien and the Foguangshan Monastery in Kaohsiung.

The Buddha's finger relic has already been exhibited at the National Taiwan University stadium. It will also be exhibited in Kaohsiung, Taichung and Nantou before being returned March 31 to its home, the Famen Temple outside the mainland city of Xian.
The relic was unearthed in 1987, some 1,110 years after being hidden in a sealed underground cell by a Tang Dynasty emperor.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHILDREN UNDER 3 TO GET FREE MEDICAL TREATMENT

TEXT.P: Children under the age of three will receive free medical treatment from Friday at Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) hospitals, Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien announced Thursday.

Speaking at a news conference, Yu said the move is in line with the Ministry of the Interior's medical subsidy program for children under the age of three that has already been adopted by the Legislative Yuan.

Under the current national health insurance system, which covers everyone except servicemen, those who receive medical treatment at BNHI hospitals must pay a registration fee and a portion of the total medical expenses, with the remaining expenses paid by the government.

It is estimated that the implementation of the new program, under which parents need pay only the registration fee for their offspring, will benefit 833,600 children and save some NT$1.3 billion (US$37.1 million) for their parents annually, Yu said.
